601 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Santos


Court of Appeals of New York


304 N.Y. 483; 109 N.E.2d 71; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 727


Argued October 7, 1952.  
November 20, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Appeal dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant synagogue child adoption committee sought review of a resettled order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which, in a dependency proceeding, reversed the domestic relations court in all respects upon questions of law and fact, and remanded the matter to the domestic relations court in accordance with N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law. § 86(3) and N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 88(1), (5).


OVERVIEW: When the mother's demand for the return of the children was refused she petitioned the domestic relations court to vacate its prior ex parte order that found that the children were neglected. At the hearing evidence was offered to show that the children were baptized Roman Catholic, but the mother boarded the children with a lady who caused them to be instructed in the Jewish religion. The domestic relations court ordered the children to be committed to the custody of the synagogue. The appellate division held that the domestic relations court should have committed the children to the care of a duly authorized agency under the control of the children's religious faith. The issue on appeal was whether the appellate division's order was a final determination in respect to the synagogue. On review the court held that the appellate division did not dismiss any party to the proceeding, nor did it make any conclusive ruling in respect of the rights of any party. The order did not finally determine the proceeding within the meaning of N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 7(1), (7) and the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the appeal.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the appeal with costs.


HEADNOTES

Parent and child - commitment of neglected children - religion of custodians - appeal to Court of Appeals - nonfinal order - (1) New York City Domestic Relations Court adjudged that children of respondent mother were neglected and committed them to care of Jewish adoption agency; evidence that they had [***2] been baptized as Roman Catholics but had been boarded with, and reared as, Jews; Appellate Division reversed order and remanded matter for further hearing and consideration in accordance with its opinion which said that custodial agency must be of same faith as children; under such order and after such hearing, Domestic Relations Court may award custody to mother or State agency or may make new determination of children's religious affiliation and award custody to private agency of that affiliation - (2) such order of Appellate Division is nonfinal; accordingly, appeal taken to Court of Appeals as of right is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

1. An order of the New York City Domestic Relations Court, Children's Court Division (1) adjudged that the two children of respondent mother were neglected and that she was not a fit and proper person to have their custody, and (2) committed them to the care of a Jewish adoption agency. There was evidence at the hearing that the mother was of Roman Catholic faith and that the children had been baptized in that faith, but that she had boarded them with a person who had instructed them in the Jewish faith. The Appellate Division reversed [***3] the order on questions of law and fact and remanded the matter for further hearing and consideration in accordance with its opinion. It said in such opinion that the children should have been committed to the care of an agency under the control of the children's faith (N.Y. Const., art. VI, § 18; N.Y. City Dom. Rel. Ct. Act, § 86, subd. 3; § 88, subds. 1, 5). Under that order, the Domestic Relations Court, upon rehearing and reconsideration, may (1) award custody of the children to their mother or to a State agency, or (2) make a new judicial determination in respect of the religious affiliation of the children and then award custody of them to a private agency managed by members of their religion.

2. The order of the Appellate Division did not dismiss any party to the proceeding or make a conclusive ruling as to the rights of any party. It was not an adjudication of a controversy between adversary parties, but was an exercise by the State through its courts of its power as parens patriae to protect infants qua infants. The order of the Appellate Division did not finally determine the proceeding within the meaning of the State Constitution (art. VI, § 7, subds. [1],  [***4] [7] ) and hence, an appeal to the Court of Appeals, taken as of right, must be dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

 

602 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mid-States Freight Lines, Inc. v. Bates


Court of Appeals of New York


304 N.Y. 700; 107 N.E.2d 603; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 909


Argued June 5, 1952  
July 15, 1952, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - highways - validity of statute imposing highway use tax - action for judgment declaring highway use tax (L. 1951, ch. 74; Tax Law, art. 21) unconstitutional - statute levying tax for use of highway measured by weight-mile formula on vehicles over 18,000 pounds exempts omnibuses, farmers' vehicles, vehicles used or owned by Federal, State, county, city or town governments and vehicles used within limits of zones established by Public Service Commission - contention by plaintiffs that statute was unconstitutional in that it constituted burden on interstate commerce, delegated legislative authority to Public Service Commission, and by reference, unconstitutionally incorporated zones established by Public Service Commission - judgment upholding constitutionality of statute properly affirmed.

 

603 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Danziger v. Hearst Corp.


Court of Appeals of New York


304 N.Y. 244; 107 N.E.2d 62; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 736


Argued April 7, 1952.  
July 15, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Ordered accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant publishers appealed a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed an order striking their complete affirmative defense of privilege and partial defense of mitigating circumstances to plaintiff husband's libel action.


OVERVIEW: The publishers of a newspaper and its magazine section printed an article, which repeated charges that were made by a wife against a husband in a separation action. The publishers obtained, from the files of the divorce court, and published a copy of the wife's affidavit in support of her motion for alimony. The publishers' first and complete defense in the husband's libel action alleged that the publication was privileged as a fair and true report of official and judicial proceedings. The partial defense alleged that the publication clearly indicated the reliable source on which it was based. The lower court granted the husband's motion to strike the defenses. The appellate court affirmed. The publishers appealed. The court held that the first defense was rightly stricken because the publishers' inspection of the court papers was barred by N.Y. C.P.L.R. 278, which did not violate the freedom of the press to obtain the details of a matrimonial action from another source. The court modified the order according to its opinion that the facts pleaded in the answer could have, on proof of mitigating circumstances, been sufficient as a partial defense.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed, with costs to the husband, the order striking the privilege defense. The court modified the order to allow the publishers' partial defense to the libel action.


HEADNOTES

Libel and slander - privilege - (1) rule 278 of Rules of Civil Practice, directing officers of court not to allow strangers to action to examine papers in matrimonial actions without court order, does not violate freedom of press; clerk's minutes available; publication from other sources available, too, subject to liability for indefensible defamation - (2) rule 278 is derived from court rules of 1847 and is authorized by Judiciary Law ( § 83) - (3) section [***2] 337 of Civil Practice Act, allowing fair and true report of judicial or other public proceedings, does not include proceedings that are not public - (4) where newspapers, by violating rule 278, obtained copy of affidavit of plaintiff's wife filed with motion in separation action, and published defamatory charges made therein, defense of fair and true report properly stricken - (5) but order modified so as to reinstate partial defense that judicial proceedings were sources of information, as "mitigating circumstances" (Civ. Prac. Act, § 338).

1. Rule 278 of the Rules of Civil Practice, which directs officers of the court, in a matrimonial action, not to permit persons other than parties or their counsel to examine the papers except by order of the court, does not violate constitutional guarantees of freedom of the press. The minutes of the clerk of the court are open and will show the pendency or result of the action. Nor does the rule prohibit publication of details of a matrimonial action that are obtained from a source other than the court files. Of course, such a publication is actionable if defamatory but this liability for indefensible defamation is not an unconstitutional [***3] restriction of the freedom of the press.

2. Rule 278 (which has been repeatedly re-enacted since 1847 by the New York Supreme Court) is within the court's rule-making power. (Judiciary Law, § 83.)

3. Section 337 of the Civil Practice Act, which provides that: "A civil action cannot be maintained against any person, firm or corporation, for the publication of a fair and true report of any judicial, legislative or other public and official proceedings", does not include judicial proceedings that are not public. A contrary construction would do violence to the public policy behind the statute and would in effect nullify other statutes enacted to preserve secrecy of certain judicial records (Judiciary Law, § 90, subd. 10; N.Y. City Dom. Rel. Ct. Act, § 52; Mental Hygiene Law, § 74, subd. 6; Code Crim. Pro., §§ 913-f, 952-t; L. 1951, ch. 716, § 23).

4. Accordingly, where newspapers, by violating rule 278, obtained a copy of an affidavit of plaintiff's wife, which had been filed with motion papers in a separation action, and published defamatory charges therein contained against plaintiff, their defense to his libel action that they had published a fair and true report [***4] of judicial proceedings was properly stricken as insufficient.

5. However, the order is modified so as to reinstate, as a partial defense, the plea of judicial proceedings as defendants' source of information, under section 338 of the Civil Practice Act, which says: "In an action for libel or slander, the defendant may prove mitigating circumstances, including the sources of his information and the grounds for his belief, notwithstanding that he has pleaded or attempted to prove a justification."

 

604 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Blair v. Du Mond


Court of Appeals of New York


304 N.Y. 607; 107 N.E.2d 91; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 853


Argued May 19, 1952  
June 5, 1952, decided


HEADNOTES

Appeal - Court of Appeals - constitutional questions - appeal, on alleged constitutional grounds, from judgment of Supreme Court declaring constitutional section 115 of Agriculture and Markets Law which permits Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets to require dogs to be confined at night - appeal dismissed on ground questions other than validity of statutory provision under State or Federal Constitutions were involved (Civ. Prac. Act, § 588, subd. 4).

 

605 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Holmes Electric Protective Co. v. New York


Court of Appeals of New York


304 N.Y. 202; 106 N.E.2d 607; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 760


Argued March 5, 1952.  
June 5, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Judgments reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer filed an action against respondents, the City of New York and its officers, for a refund of certain taxes and for a judgment declaring that said taxes were illegal and null and void. The taxpayer challenged an order of the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the dismissal of its action.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer conducted a business in which it safeguarded buildings throughout the city against burglaries. Essentially, it installed and operated alarms. The City and its officials determined that the taxpayer was providing a telegraphic service and imposed a tax on the taxpayer pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 22(8) (1938), New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § Q41-1.0. Essentially, the City had determined that the taxpayer was providing a utility service. The taxpayer filed an action against the City and its officers for a refund and for a declaratory judgment that said taxes were illegal and null and void. The trial court dismissed the action and the appellate court affirmed. The court reversed. The court found that the City's authority to tax utilities was limited by N.Y. Tax Law § 186-a. The court held that § 186-a was not broad enough to include the taxpayer's activities. Further, the court noted that the legislature had declined to adopt the definition of "telegraphic service" as provided for in New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 22(8) (1938).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's order that affirmed the dismissal of the taxpayer's action and remitted the cause to the trial court for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - municipal tax on utilities - telegraph services - statutory history - (1) burglar alarm service corporation not subject to New York City tax on utilities - (2) not claimed here that service supplied has changed since 1942 when Court of Appeals held that company's business was not that of selling electric or telegraph service; municipal power to tax electric, telephone and telegraph utilities (Tax Law, § 186-a; General City Law, § 20-b) not enlarged by city's own definition of telegraph service as including "alarms" (Administrative Code of City of New York, § Q41-1.0) - (3) Legislature refused to adopt such definition.

 [***2] 1. A corporation which installs in buildings electric devices whereby, in event of a wrongful breaking or entry, an alarm is mechanically transmitted by wire to one of the corporation's offices from which its guards or the city police are notified to go to the place of disturbance, is not subject to a tax imposed by the City of New York on utilities engaged in furnishing or selling electric, telephone or telegraph service. (Administrative Code of City of New York, § Q41-1.0.)

2. In the instant case it is not claimed that the service supplied by the company's has changed since 1942 when the Court of Appeals decided that the company's business was not the selling of electric, telephone or telegraph service (Matter of Holmes Elec. Protective Co. v. McGoldrick, 288 N.Y. 635). But in 1938, after the litigation which resulted in the 1942 decision had been instituted, the city amended its local law so as to define telegraph service as including "alarms * * * or information of any kind". However, the power of a city to tax utilities is limited by State statutes (Tax Law, § 186-a; General City Law, § 20-b), and no definition of telegraph service is found in those statutes. 

 [***3] 3. It is a significant item of legislative history that in 1942 the Legislature refused to amend its statutes so as to adopt the city's definition. The city's power to tax utilities has not in this case been enlarged by its own definition.

 

606 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Brous v. Smith


Court of Appeals of New York


304 N.Y. 164; 106 N.E.2d 503; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 766


Argued April 15, 1952.  
May 29, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a real estate developer and builder (the builder), appealed an order from the Supreme Court at Special Term, Suffolk County (New York) that dismissed the builder's petition for an order directing respondent, as Building and Zoning Inspector of the Town of Islip (the inspector), to issue building permits for the construction of six homes within the Town of Islip. The builder claimed that N.Y. Town Law § 280-a was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The builder proposed to build several homes within the town on lots that lacked roads for ingress and egress. The inspector refused to grant any building permits to the builder unless the builder, pursuant to § 280-a, constructed roads giving access to the proposed structures, or, in the alternative, posted a performance bond to insure the installation of such roads after erection of the buildings. The trial court dismissed the builder's N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding to compel the inspector to issue the permits and rejected the builder's claim that § 280-a was unconstitutional. On appeal, the court ruled that: (1) the statute was a proper exercise of police power to ensure the public health, safety, welfare; (2) the state had a legitimate interest in requiring that the means of access provided for homes was sufficient for such a purpose; (3) the town was not condemning the builder's land, but merely required the builder to comply with reasonable conditions that worked to the benefit of the public, and thus there was no taking of his land without compensation in violation of N.Y. Const. art. I, § 7.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed an order that dismissed the builder's petition for an order to compel the inspector to issue building permits to allow the builder to construct several homes within the Town of Islip.


HEADNOTES

Towns - streets - planning - proper street access to buildings as condition for building permits - constitutional law - (1) builder's application for permit to build houses in town on lots along streets not physically in existence refused unless, under section 280-a of Town Law, streets are constructed to give access thereto or bond is procured to insure same; in proceeding to compel issuance of permits statute held constitutional and petition properly dismissed - (2) section 280-a which provides that no permit for building shall be issued unless street giving access thereto shall be "suitably improved", deemed [***2] proper exercise of police power - (3) State has legitimate interest in requiring that means of access provided for homes be properly improved and sufficient for purpose - (4) contention that compelling construction of streets on petitioner's land without compensation violates section 7 of article I of State Constitution rejected; town merely conditions approval of construction by petitioner on compliance with reasonable conditions for benefit of both ultimate purchasers and public - (5) section provides for relaxation of requirement in case of unnecessary hardship.

1. Many of a group of 850 lots, as shown on a map filed in the Suffolk County Clerk's office in 1872, were located back from existing highways and along streets on the map which were not physically in existence. On some of the lots, petitioner desired to build houses in accordance with the planning regulations of the town, and he applied to respondent Building and Zoning Inspector for permits which were refused unless petitioner, in accordance with section 280-a of the Town Law, should construct streets giving access to the structures or post a performance bond to insure such streets after erection of the buildings.  [***3] In a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act to compel issuance of such building permits, Special Term properly held that the statute was constitutional and dismissed the petition.

2. Section 280-a provides that no permit for erection of a building shall be issued unless a street giving access to such building has been placed on an official map or plan, and also that such street shall have been suitably improved to the satisfaction of the town board or planning board as adequate in respect to the public health, safety and general welfare. The requirement that the road shall be "suitably improved" before a permit may be issued, became a part of the Town Law in 1938, and petitioner is the first to complain that such provision or any similar provision in other statutes interferes with the proper enjoyment of his property. However, decisions from other jurisdictions furnish persuasive support for sustaining the validity of the section as a proper exercise of the police power.

3. There can be no doubt, in light of the importance of proper means of access, that the regulation is reasonable and valid. Not only is it essential to have a road over which fire apparatus [***4] and the like can travel safely, but modern living is impossible without improved highways. Unimproved or defective roads can cause complete breakdown of services in a community, and the State has a legitimate interest in requiring that the means of access provided for homes be properly improved and sufficient for the purpose.

4. While petitioner contends that, granting the necessity of such roads, it is a violation of section 7 of article I of the State Constitution to compel him to construct them on his land at his expense without compensation, the town does not seek to condemn this land. It is petitioner who wishes to construct dwellings on his property, and the town merely conditions its approval of such construction upon his compliance with reasonable conditions designed for the protection both of the ultimate purchasers of the homes and of the public. That the State may empower the town to do this, is clear. The regulation here involved is not essentially different from other regulations of property in the interest of public health, safety or welfare.

5. While situations may arise where compliance with such requirement would occasion unnecessary hardship, the section [***5] itself provides the means for relaxing such requirement, and the board of appeals is empowered to make a reasonable exception in favor of an owner in such case. There is no violation of the State Constitution where the statute does not unreasonably deprive an owner of his property, if the statute is properly administered in accordance with its terms.

 

607 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Arnold v. Twomey


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 937; 105 N.E.2d 628; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 1384


Argued March 6, 1952  
April 17, 1952, decided


HEADNOTES

False imprisonment - constitutional law - statutory definition of vagrancy - action to recover damages for false arrest and imprisonment following plaintiff's acquittal on charge of vagrancy under Code of Criminal Procedure (§ 887, subd. 1) defining vagrant as "person who, not having visible means to support himself, lives without employment" - contentions by plaintiff that defendant police officer and city had no defense to action since statute was violative of Thirteenth and Fourteenth Amendments to United States Constitution, and that, in any event, defense failed to show justifiable grounds for arrest - order denying motion to strike answer as sham or to strike out denials and defenses properly affirmed.

 

608 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Brown v. Board of Trustees


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 484; 104 N.E.2d 866; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 790; 34 A.L.R.2d 720


Argued January 7, 1952.  
March 13, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant minor sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court at a Trial Term in Orange County (New York), which denied the minor's motion for leave to serve notice of claim upon defendant, school district board of trustees (board), after the expiration of the statutory period for such service as provided in N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e.


OVERVIEW: The minor was injured while on property owned and controlled by the board. Sixteen months later the minor's guardian ad litem sought leave to serve notice of claim. The trial court denied the guardian's request as untimely pursuant to § 50-e. The guardian sought review arguing that § 50-e was unconstitutional because it denied the minor equal protection of the laws. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's findings and upheld the constitutionality of § 50-e. The court held that the right to file a cause of action against a municipality was granted upon such conditions as the legislature, in its wisdom, saw fit to impose. The court held that a statutory or charter provision requiring the service of a notice of claim, as a condition precedent to an action against a municipality, was constitutional. The court held that municipalities were afforded a measure of protection against stale claims, or the possible connivance of corrupt officials. The court held that the goals sought by such enactments were not dependent upon the age of the claimant nor did they vary with the claimant's age.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the findings of the trial court. The court held that the limitation period for filing a negligence claim against a municipal corporation was constitutional, even as it applied to minors.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - notice of claim - constitutional law - (1) claimant, six years of age, was injured by fall from slide on public school grounds; claimant's father appointed guardian ad litem sixteen months later; subsequent application for leave to file notice of claim against board of education under section 50-e of General Municipal Law properly denied - (2) section 50-e, which requires ninety days' notice of tort claim against public corporation, provides for leave to serve notice after expiration thereof where claimant is infant but application must be made within one year, so statute prevents present claimant from instituting action - (3) claimant, where under [***2] fourteen years of age and so unable to sue directly, not deprived by statute of rights and privileges given other citizens by State Constitution (art. I, § 1) and of equal protection of laws (U.S. Const., 14th Amendt.) - (4) since liability in negligence of municipalities is statutory, any liability imposed may be made subject to limitation - (5) limitations of section 50-e not dependent on age of claimant nor do they vary with such age.

1. Claimant, an infant six years of age, was injured by a fall from a children's slide located on school grounds controlled by defendant board of education. Sixteen months later claimant's father was appointed guardian ad litem, and subsequently such infant, by his guardian ad litem, and the father, as parent, moved for leave to serve on said board of trustees a notice of claim for personal injuries after the expiration of the statutory period for such service as provided in section 50-e of the General Municipal Law. The motion was properly denied.

2. Subdivision 1 of section 50-e requires that, where a notice of claim in a tort action is required as a condition precedent to an action against a public corporation, it must be given within [***3] ninety days after the claim arises, and subdivision 5 provides that, where the claimant is an infant and notice is not timely filed, the court, in its discretion, may grant leave to serve the notice within a reasonable time after the expiration of the time specified, but application for such leave "must be made within the period of one year" after the event. Consequently, in this case, the statute prevents claimant from instituting an action against the board.

3. There is no merit in claimant's contention that since an infant under fourteen years of age may not sue directly nor initiate proceedings by application to the court for appointment of a guardian ad litem, compliance with the section is impossible, and his remedy is withdrawn before he is able to exercise it, with the result that the statute deprives him of the rights and privileges secured to other citizens by section 1 of article I of the State Constitution, and of equal protection of the laws guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment to the Federal Constitution.

4. The right of citizens to bring suit against boards of education for alleged negligence in performance of the governmental function of maintaining school [***4] playgrounds did not exist at common law, nor has it ever been guaranteed by constitutional provision. The present rule, that the State and its municipal adjuncts are liable in negligence in the same manner as individuals or corporations, is statutory in origin, and any such right so given is one which might have been withheld by the Legislature. Consequently, such right may be granted upon such conditions as the Legislature sees fit to impose: In this case, a limitation on the established liability.

5. Statutes such as section 50-e are enacted to enable municipalities to make early investigations of claims and to marshal evidence when it is possible to do so, and they afford a measure of protection against stale claims and needless litigation. These objects are not dependent upon, nor do they vary with, claimant's age.

 

609 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Garzo v. Maid of The Mist S.B. Co.


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 516; 104 N.E.2d 882; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 795


Argued January 7, 1952.  
March 13, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff minority shareholders appealed Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) judgment that affirmed the dismissal of their complaint which alleged that inadvertent expiration of defendant corporation's charter entitled them to a distribution of assets.


OVERVIEW: Defendant corporation, a sightseeing company, was chartered in 1892 and did not realize its 50-year charter had expired until 1947, when it revived its charter under N.Y. Gen. Corp. Law § 49 with the approval of three-fourths of the shares. Section 49 was not enacted until 1943 and plaintiff minority shareholders, who wanted a distribution of assets, contended that retroactive application of the statute unconstitutionally interfered with their vested right. The trial court dismissed plaintiffs' complaint and the court affirmed. While statutes generally were applied only prospectively, the extension of corporate charters did not involve such an organic or fundamental change as to bar retroactive application. As a de facto corporation at the expiration of its charter, no one but the state could question its existence in any event.


OUTCOME: The dismissal of plaintiff minority shareholders' complaint was affirmed, with costs, because the statute allowing revival of corporate charters was to be applied retroactively.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - corporations - revival of corporate existence after expiration of term of charter - statutory construction - (1) language and legislative history of General Corporation Law (§ 49), enacted in 1944, show that it applies retrospectively to going corporation whose fifty-year charter had expired, and validly authorized filing thereafter of certificate of revival of corporate existence - (2) under section 45, which was part of corporate charter by operation of law, such certificate could have been filed before expiration of term; revival and extension thereafter under section 49 not fundamental alteration (N.Y. Const., art.  [***2] X, § 1; General Corporation Law, § 5) - (3) hence, immaterial that section 49 does not give objecting minority stockholders right to be paid appraised cash value of stock - (4) minority stockholders have shown no equitable right to such appraisal and payment for their stock.

1. The General Corporation Law (§ 45) provides that a corporation, the term of whose existence under its certificate of incorporation is about to expire, may file a certificate extending its corporate existence for a term of years or in perpetuity, by authority of a majority of its members or the holders of a majority of its stock. Under section 49 (eff. April 6, 1944) a like certificate may be filed after the stated term of existence of a corporation has expired (except where liquidation has been initiated and except in certain other circumstances listed in subdivision 11). The language of section 49 and its legislative history show that it validly applies retrospectively to a going corporation such as the one in this case, which inadvertently permitted its fifty-year term of duration to expire in 1942 and which filed a certificate of revival of existence in 1947 under section 49.

2. When the present [***3] corporation was organized in 1892, the predecessor of section 45 was already in existence, and became part of the corporation's charter by operation of law. Section 49, enacted in 1944, in effect permits a going corporation, which has inadvertently omitted to file a certificate under section 45, to file one after the expiration of the term set forth in its certificate of incorporation. The new section makes no organic change and violates no constitutional prohibition against the enactment of retroactive laws. The predecessor of section 45 required the consent of the holders of two thirds of the stock, and the revival in this case has been consented to by the holders of approximately three fourths of the stock. The State has reserved the power to alter corporation laws and charters. (N.Y. Const., art. X, § 1; General Corporation Law, § 5.) A corporation whose charter has expired continues to have a de jure existence for the purpose of winding up its affairs (General Corporation Law, § 29). Further, where, as here, a corporation continues to carry on its business, it is a de facto corporation as well, and no one but the State may question its existence.

3. Section [***4] 49 does not afford objecting minority stockholders (such as plaintiffs in this action to dissolve the corporation and distribute its assets) a right to be paid the appraised cash value of their stock. It is not necessary to determine whether such a right must be provided in order to validate an organic or fundamental change. The extension after inadvertent expiration in this case was not such a fundamental change.

4. Nor is it necessary to determine whether such a minority right may exist as a matter of equity apart from statute. There is no basis in the record for disturbing the conclusions of the courts below that the circumstances of this case do not warrant equitable relief.

 

610 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Ahern v. South Buffalo R. Co.


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 545; 104 N.E.2d 898; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 799


Argued December 4, 1951.  
March 13, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, DESMOND, DYE and FROESSEL, JJ., concur with CONWAY, J.; FULD, J., dissents in opinion.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which unanimously affirmed a decision and award of respondent, the Workmen's Compensation Board (board), denying to the employer a review and rehearing of an award made to respondent claimant, a widow, under New York's Workmen's Compensation Law.


OVERVIEW: The claimant's deceased husband was employed as a switchman by the employer. Before death he filed a claim for disability compensation. The claim was based upon a coronary occlusion which the decedent suffered as an alleged result of extra exertion during the course of employment. The board issued three awards to the decedent, all of which were paid up until his death. The employer filed an application for review, contending that the decedent's claim was preempted by the Federal Employers' Liability Act (FELA). The board denied the application. The lower court affirmed the board's decision and the employer sought review. On appeal the court affirmed, holding that FELA did not preempt the settled claims in question. It was clear that the conduct of the parties subsequent to the board's ruling on the questions of accident and causal relation and its decree that compensation be paid, established that it was the mutual desire of the parties that the board, acting as an impartial third person, should determine the amount to be paid in discharge of the claim by the decedent. Thus, the claims fell within the ambit of N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law §113, which was found to be constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the widow.


HEADNOTES

Master and servant - workmen's compensation - Federal Employers' Liability Act - waiver - jurisdiction of Workmen's Compensation Board - (1) application by employer for rehearing of award, after having paid disability compensation for over four years, upon ground that claim was covered by Federal Employers' Liability Act and that board accordingly was without jurisdiction,  [***2] properly denied - (2) Congress did not intend to prohibit injured employee from compromising claim - (3) Workmen's Compensation Law ( § 113) provides for awards by board where claimant, employer and carrier waive interstate commerce rights and remedies - (4) section 113 not intended to codify prior rule that only final award which had been paid precluded assertion of Federal rights; section 113 not in conflict with Federal law - (5) employer's agreement of waiver made by conduct, not by declared intention - (6) payments not rendered involuntary by employer's denial of accident and causal relation at initial hearings - (7) employer's silence and continued payments until Statute of Limitations had run on claim under Federal act, construed as acceptance of employee's offer to compromise - (8) employee's actions also amounted to waiver.

1. In 1945, an employee of appellant railway filed a claim with the Workmen's Compensation Board based on an asserted coronary occlusion suffered during his employment upon which an award was made for temporary total disability from the date of injury to June 5, 1945. A second award was thereafter made for the period from June 5, 1945, to January 8,  [***3] 1946, and a third award was made for the period from January 8, 1946, to February 4, 1947. The employer, self-insured, paid all of these awards and continued to pay compensation up to December 20, 1948, pursuant to the order of the board, and, on January 3, 1949, the injured employee died. At a subsequent hearing the employer, for the first time, challenged the jurisdiction of the board, but an award of disability compensation was made for the final two-week period preceding the employee's death. An application by the employer for a review or rehearing of such award on the ground that at the time of the accident decedent had been employed in interstate commerce, that the case came within the provisions of the Federal Employers' Liability Act, and that the Workmen's Compensation Board was without jurisdiction, was properly denied.

2. Congress, by enacting the Federal Employers' Liability Act, has preempted the entire field of liability with respect to personal injuries of railroad employees whose duties "further", or "directly", or "closely affect" interstate commerce. The act makes void any "contract, rule, regulation, or device whatsoever" to exempt a carrier from liability.Nevertheless,  [***4] Congress did not intend to prevent an employee from disposing of a claim against his employer by entering into a compromise. Only contracts before injury exempting the employer from liability are forbidden.

3. Section 113 of the Workmen's Compensation Law provides that awards may be made by the Workmen's Compensation Board in respect of injuries subject to the admiralty or other Federal laws in case the claimant, the employer and the insurance carrier waive their admiralty or interstate commerce rights and remedies. In the present case the facts evidence an intention having the force of an agreement to forego rights under the Federal law and to accept rights under the Workmen's Compensation Law, and such intention has been announced by all who must participate in such an agreement.

4. This provision in section 113 was not intended simply to codify the rule which existed previously that only a final award of the board which had been paid - in other words, not merely an accord but a satisfaction - precluded an individual from asserting his Federal rights. It is a permissive statute intended to empower the board to make awards of compensation if all the parties elect to settle [***5] their dispute in that manner and forego their Federal rights and remedies. As so construed section 113 does not conflict with the fundamental law of the land.

5. In the present action the employer made his agreement of waiver by conduct rather than by a declared intention. Neither party's actions at the initial hearings constituted such waiver. But their conduct subsequent to the board's ruling on the questions of accident and causal relation and its decree that compensation be paid establish that it was the mutual desire of the parties that the board should determine the amount to be paid in discharge of the employee's claim.

6. The employer's conduct in denying accident and causal relation on the initial hearings does not establish that the payments thereafter made were involuntary. It took no appeal from any of the awards except the present appeal, which deals only with the award covering the last two weeks of the employee's life. The employer is chargeable with knowledge that the board was without power to require it to pay compensation unless it waived its Federal rights and remedies. Moreover, despite the fact that it appears that counsel for the employer over the [***6] last forty years have been cognizant of the nature of its liability to its employees, the employer made payments for four and one-half years without asserting that the board lacked jurisdiction.

7. Furthermore, the employer made payments beyond the time when the Statute of Limitations had run on the employee's claim under the Federal act and the statute has also run on the death claim. The employer cannot lead the employee to believe that it is agreeable that the board shall act without having its silence construed as an acceptance of the employee's offer to compromise the claim.

8. By his actions before the board, the employee also evidenced his willingness to submit the dispute to the board for determination.

 

611 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Buffalo v. Roadway Transit Co.


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 453; 104 N.E.2d 96; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 808


Argued December 3, 1951.  
January 24, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city brought an action against defendant company to restrain the company from violating the city's residential zoning laws. The trial court found for the city. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) reversed and dismissed the complaint. The city appealed.


OVERVIEW: The company leased premises within the city for use as a private garage for the storage and repair of trucks and as a terminal for freight shipping. The property was located in a residential area and was nonconforming to the city's zoning ordinances. The premises had earlier been used for a public garage in an area zoned for business use. The area was then rezoned residential. The court found that the use of the public garage was a lawful nonconforming use. The company's subsequent use of the structure as freight terminal was not a continuation of that prior use. The ordinance restricted freight terminals to industrial zones. The ordinance only allowed a change in a nonconforming use only to a more restrictive use. The transformation of the public garage to the freight terminal was not a change to a more restrictive nonconforming use. Also, the nonconforming use altered the essential character of the residential area.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the ruling of the appellate court and affirmed the trial court's ruling.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - Buffalo, City of - zoning - (1) after permit had been obtained for use of building for "Garage & Truck Terminal", motor carrier leased building and remodeled it for use as truck terminal for delivery and loading of freight;  [***2] activities carried on twenty-four hours a day; premises were in residence district under amended zoning ordinance of city and use by carrier was nonconforming; at time zoning was adopted premises were placed in business district and used as public garage, and owners legally continued operation of garage as lawful prior use; in action by city to restrain use of premises in alleged violation of ordinance, judgment in favor of city affirmed - (2) present use of premises not continuation of former nonconforming use, nor equivalent thereof; activities of carrier fall within term "freight terminal" as used in ordinance and permitted in industrial district - (3) words "freight terminal", as used in ordinance in 1925, deemed to include motor truck freight terminals, although none such then existed; means of transporting freight to terminal of no moment - (4) defendants may not change nonconforming use to one of equal industrial classification since ordinance prohibits change except to more restricted use; since present use not more restricted than former nonconforming use, it is illegal and may be enjoined - (5) use to which defendants now put property cannot fail to alter residential character [***3] of neighborhood - (6) issuance of permit cannot confer rights in contravention of zoning laws which provide that such permit shall be void - (7) claim of unconstitutionality of ordinances overruled.

1. Under a lease permitting lessee motor carrier to use premises for a truck terminal and other activities in connection therewith, and after a revocable permit had been obtained from the director of buildings of the city of Buffalo to use the building for a "Garage & Truck Terminal" subject to the zoning ordinance, defendant interstate motor carrier used the premises as a terminal for freight shipped into, or out of, said city. Some remodeling of the premises was done when defendant went into possession, including the installation of a loading dock, and operations are presently carried on twentyfour hours a day by about 71 employees. Each day about 12 of the carrier's trailers arrive at and depart from the premises, and about twice that many tractors, and freight is delivered for shipment by other carriers in their own trucks. Under the provisions of the present zoning ordinances of the city of Buffalo, the premises are in a second residence district, and the use above outlined [***4] is clearly nonconforming. At the time the original ordinances were adopted, the premises were placed in a business district and were then being used as a public garage. A public garage was a permitted use only in a first industrial district. As a matter of right, the owners of the property thereafter continued to operate the garage as a continuation of a use lawful prior to the adoption of the zoning ordinances. In this action by the city of Buffalo to restrain the carrier and lessor from using the premises in alleged violation of the zoning ordinances, judgment in favor of the city should be affirmed.

2. The present use is not a continuation of the former use, nor the equivalent thereof, but is that of a freight terminal rather than a "public garage" within the definition thereof in the ordinance. The activities of the carrier resemble neither the ordinance definition nor the common concept of a public garage but fall within the term "freight terminal" as used in the ordinance for a use permitted in the first industrial district.

3. A contention that the words "freight terminal", as used in the ordinance, cannot be applied to motor truck freight terminals since such were [***5] not within the contemplation of the framers of the ordinance in 1925, is without merit. Such a terminal is not essentially different from any other freight terminal. What was originally confined to an industrial district was the operation of handling freight at a terminal point, and it can make no difference what the means of transporting the freight to that point may be.

4. Originally the ordinance provided that a nonconforming use should not be changed "except" to a more restrictive use, but this was later amended to read that premises devoted to a nonconforming use "may be changed in use, when changed to a more restricted use". While zoning statutes are to be strictly construed in favor of the landowner, courts may not disregard the intention of the legislative body when it is clearly to be found in the language used. Here, in view of the language, no distinction can be made between the original, and the present, wording of the ordinance. Since the present use is not more restrictive than the former nonconforming use, it is illegal and may be enjoined.

5. The neighborhood has an established residential character, as was recognized by the 1946 amendment rezoning the [***6] area from business to second residential, but the use to which defendants have now put that property cannot fail to alter the essential character of an otherwise residential neighborhood and to render it not merely commercial but industrial in nature.

6. The issuance of a permit by the director of buildings cannot help defendant, for such a permit cannot confer rights in contravention of the zoning laws. Moreover, the ordinance provides that any permit for the use of premises contrary to the provisions thereof shall be void. In addition, the permit was issued for a "Garage & Truck Terminal", not for a freight terminal.

7. The asserted unconstitutionality of the ordinance rests upon a claim that the city means to limit use of the property to second residential purposes, despite the prior use and the impossibility of adapting the building to residential use, but the record discloses no such intent or threat on the part of the city.

 

612 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. County Transp. Co.


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 391; 103 N.E.2d 421; 1952 N.Y. LEXIS 810


Argued November 30, 1951.  
January 17, 1952, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant bus company challenged an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the third judicial department (New York) that found that plaintiff state was entitled to recover a penalty under N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 63-c after the bus company failed to obtain authorization from the state public service commission to enter into a conditional sales contract for the purchase of buses.


OVERVIEW: The bus line, which operated a service in New York, entered into a conditional sales contract for the purchase of buses without obtaining authorization from the state public service commission pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 62. The lower court found that the state was entitled to recover a penalty from the bus line, and on appeal, the court affirmed, holding first that the bus company was required to obtain authorization under § 62 because the statute covered conditional sales contracts. The court also held that Congress had not occupied the field so as to exclude the state legislation and that it was clear that Congress had purposely excluded from the field of its legislative competency small interstate omnibus companies such as the bus company and conditional sales contracts of all omnibus companies of any size. The court found that in the absence of conflicting federal legislation, a state could make laws for the common good that affected or regulated interstate commerce. Section 62 was a reasonable exercise by the state of its police power to protect customers and creditors of the bus company from loss of service from uncontrolled financing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's order that found that the state was entitled to recover a penalty from the bus company after the bus company failed to obtain authorization from the state public service commission to enter into a conditional sales contract for the purchase of buses.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - interstate commerce - public utilities - omnibus corporations - statutory construction - (1) omnibus corporation "may issue stocks, bonds, notes or other evidences of indebtedness" provided it obtains authorization of Public Service Commission (Public Service Law, § 62, subd. 1); bus corporation which executed conditional sales contract for balance of purchase price of ten buses, without obtaining authorization from commission, must pay penalty to People (§ 63-c) - (2) inclusive phrase, "notes or other evidences of indebtedness", was enacted instead of proposed phrase "or other form of security issue"; legislative history of statute shows intention to regulate financial obligations so as to protect bus-using and ratepaying [***2] public, and it has been so administered - (3) Federal Motor Carrier Act has not pre-empted field, since it regulates only security issues and only carriers with securities of over half million dollars; therefore State Public Service Commission may continue to regulate smaller bus corporations and their conditional sales contracts, even though bus line is interstate - (4) State act does not obstruct interstate commerce - (5) State act is reasonable exercise of police power.

1. The Public Service Law ( § 62, subd. 1) provides that "An omnibus corporation organized or existing * * * under or by virtue of the laws of the state of New York, may issue stocks, bonds, notes or other evidences of indebtedness payable on demand or at periods of more than twelve months after the date thereof * * * provided and not otherwise that there shall have been secured from the commission an order authorizing such issue". A New York corporation, which operates a bus line between a city in New York State and a city in the State of Connecticut and over connecting routes within New York State, purchased ten buses for approximately $160,000 and entered into a conditional sales contract for part of the [***3] purchase price. For its failure to obtain authorization of the Public Service Commission to enter into such contract, the corporation must pay a penalty to the People of the State of New York (pursuant to Public Service Law, § 63-c).

2. The legislative history of section 62 shows that it was enacted to protect the bus-using and rate-paying public against improper issues of obligations by a public utility, and not merely to regulate the marketability of securities for investors. Furthermore, when the precursor to the present statute was first proposed and enacted in 1907, the proposed words "stocks, bonds, evidence of indebtedness or other form of security issue" were stricken from the bill and the words above quoted enacted. Those words, within the legislative intention and within the administrative practice of the commission, include a conditional bill of sale to finance a purchase.

3. The Federal Motor Carrier Act of 1935 (U.S. Code, tit. 49, § 301 et seq.) was not intended to supersede section 62 of our Public Service Law. The Federal act regulates only motor carriers which have issued securities exceeding $500,000 - which this carrier had not. Moreover, the Federal [***4] act regulates "securities" and has been construed by the Interstate Commerce Commission not to include a conditional sales contract. Thus the Federal and State acts can logically and practically coexist. Congress has not evinced an intention to pre-empt the field as to motor carriers or as to their conditional bills of sale. As long as the Federal Government does not choose to regulate the execution of conditional sales contracts by omnibus corporations, there is no reason why our Public Service Commission should not continue such regulation through the provisions of section 62 of our Public Service Law.

4. The Congressional power to regulate interstate commerce (U.S. Const., art. I, § 8) does not exclude powers "reserved to the States" (10th Amendt.). In a field where national uniformity is not demanded, and where Congressional legislation has not covered the subject matter of the State statute, and where application of the latter will not obstruct interstate commerce, the State statute will be upheld. State highways are, of course, subject to regulation by the State in the public interest.

5.Section 62 of our Public Service Law helps to ensure the general financial responsibility [***5] of a public utility operating under a franchise granted by this State, and thereby to protect the public against interruptions or deprivations of bus service. The statute is not drastic or discriminatory, but is a reasonable exercise by the State of its police power to protect customers and creditors of a small bus corporation from the danger of high rates or loss of service resulting from uncontrolled financing.

 

613 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Russo


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 673; 102 N.E.2d 834; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 1099


Argued October 10, 1951  
December 6, 1951, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - crimes - unlawful possession of firearms - validity of statute creating presumption of possession of pistol (Penal Law, § 1898-a) - defendant convicted of unlawful possession of firearm upon evidence that revolver was found in automobile in which he had been seated and that he knew such weapon was there - defendant offered no evidence to rebut presumption of his illegal possession - contention by defendant in Court of Appeals that evidence was insufficient to support conviction, and that section 1898-a of Penal Law was unconstitutional - Court of Appeals, in determining that judgment of conviction had been properly affirmed, stated that section 1898-a of Penal Law had been declared constitutional, citing People v. Gerschinsky (281 N.Y. 581) and People v. Terra (303 N.Y. 332).

 

614 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Giaccio


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 709; 103 N.E.2d 62; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 1118


Argued October 18, 1951  
December 6, 1951, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional [**3] law - infants - youthful offenders - infants, indicted for crimes of robbery, grand larceny and assault, examined as, and adjudged to be, youthful offenders - following explanation by Trial Judge of procedure under Youthful Offender Act (Code Crim. Pro., §§ 913-e-913-r), infants signed statement consenting to consideration of themselves as youthful offenders and consenting to use by court of records concerning them - contentions by infants that Trial Judge was biased, that statute was unconstitutional, and that they had been compelled to testify against themselves - judgments properly affirmed.

 

615 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Terra


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 332; 102 N.E.2d 576; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 669


Argued October 5, 1951.  
December 6, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the fourth judicial department (New York), which affirmed the judgment of the county court that convicted defendants of the wrongful possession of a machine gun in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 1897(1-a).


OVERVIEW: Defendants, two brothers, operated a business that distributed and serviced pinball machines. A machine gun and ammunition was found in defendants' store. Defendants were convicted of the wrongful possession of a machine gun. The court affirmed. The statute created a presumption that the possession of such a gun was in the illegal possession of all persons that occupied the place where the gun was found. The court found that it was neither unreasonable nor unfair to presume that defendants were aware of the gun in the store. The statute did not oppressively burden the accused. Defendants had the opportunity to rebut the presumption, which they failed to do. The prosecutor still had the burden of proving defendants guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. Thus, defendants were not denied a fair trial.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - crimes - unlawful possession of machine gun - statutory presumption that machine gun found in occupied room is illegally possessed by occupants - (1) Penal Law (§ 1897, subd. 1-a) constitutionally provides that unauthorized possession of machine gun is felony and that "presence of such machine-gun in any room * * * shall be presumptive evidence of its illegal possession by all the persons occupying the place"; on evidence that machine gun had been found in one-room store used by defendants for pinball machine distributing business, judgments of conviction affirmed - (2) statutory presumption reasonably based [***2] on life's experiences; defendants may rebut presumption; jury may refuse to convict despite lack of explanation by defendants; burden of proving guilt beyond reasonable doubt still rests on People - (3) unnecessary, on these facts, to consider whether statutory presumption applies equally to "room, dwelling, structure or vehicle".

1. The Penal Law (§ 1897, subd. 1-a) constitutionally provides that possession of a machine gun (except by police and other designated classes of persons in the discharge of their official duties) is a felony, and that "The presence of such machine-gun in any room, dwelling, structure or vehicle shall be presumptive evidence of its illegal possession by all the persons occupying the place where such machine-gun is found." Judgments of conviction under this statute should be affirmed, where a machine gun and ammunition for it were found in a one-room store occupied - or so the jury could have concluded from the evidence - by defendants and used by them in connection with their business of distributing and servicing pinball machines.

2. The statutory presumption has a reasonable basis in life's experiences which teach that the presence of a machine [***3] gun in a room occupied either as a residence or for a business has a sinister and inculpatory significance, that normally the persons who occupy a room in which there is found such a large and uncommon object are conscious and knowing of it, and that their possession of such a death-dealing weapon is not law-abiding. In this case, the accused have had every opportunity to rebut the presumption and to explain the proof that the machine gun was found in a room occupied by them. Even if they offer no explanation, the jury may still refuse to convict. The burden of proving guilt beyond a reasonable doubt remains with the prosecution and defendants' right to a fair trial continues undiminished. No constitutional right or safeguard has here been shown to have been impaired by the statute.

3. On the facts of this case, it is not necessary to consider whether the statutory presumption validly applies, not only to a "room," but also to a "dwelling, structure or vehicle".

 

616 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Joseph Burstyn, Inc. v. Wilson


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 242; 101 N.E.2d 665; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 677


Argued June 1, 1951.  
October 18, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS and CONWAY, JJ., concur with FROESSEL, J.; DESMOND, J., concurs in separate opinion; FULD, J., dissents in opinion in which DYE, J., concurs.

Order affirmed. [See 304 N.Y. 718.] 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner former licensee sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which confirmed a determination by respondent licensor to cancel licenses for the film "The Miracle" because it was deemed sacrilegious in violation of N.Y. Educ. Law § 122.


OVERVIEW: Respondent licensor canceled licenses for petitioner former licensee's film "The Miracle" because it was deemed sacrilegious. The lower court confirmed respondent's determination, and the court affirmed the order. The court held that a public showing of an obscene, indecent, immoral, or sacrilegious film could do incalculable harm and that, under N.Y. Educ. Law § 122, the state could afford protection as broad as the danger presented. The court held that the action of the motion picture division of the state education department was reviewable by respondent in any case where the license was refused or granted. The court held that the word "sacrilegious" provided a sufficiently definite standard and that the film encroached upon the sacred relationship between Jesus Christ, Mary, and Joseph, and the biblical presentation of the birth of Christ, associating it with drunkenness, seduction, mockery, and lewdness. The statute was clearly directed to the promotion of the public welfare, morals, public peace, and order, objects of police power, and any incidental benefit conferred upon religion was not sufficient to render the statute unconstitutional under U.S. Const. amend. I.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's order that confirmed a determination against petitioner former licensee by respondent licensor to cancel licenses for the film "The Miracle" because it was deemed sacrilegious. The court found that there was nothing more than a denial of the claimed right to hurl insults at the deepest and sincerest religious beliefs of others through the medium of a commercial entertainment spectacle.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - statutory construction - police power - motion picture licenses - freedom of religion - (1) Board of Regents had power to cancel, upon ground that motion picture was sacrilegious, licenses previously issued by motion picture division of State Education Department - (2) power to cancel [***2] license in such circumstances is implicit in constitutional and statutory provisions for licensing of motion pictures; express grant of power unnecessary - (3) Legislature did not intend to prohibit review of determinations of said motion picture division - (4) rights acquired under licenses not contractual - (5) Education Law ( § 122) prohibiting license for film deemed sacrilegious provides sufficiently definite standard - (6) Board of Regents did not act arbitrarily or capriciously - (7) Education Law ( § 122) does not violate First Amendment to Federal Constitution, dealing with religious freedom - (8) licensee, seeking benefits under statute, may not argue that motion pictures must be granted constitutional protection of press - (9) in any event, United States Supreme Court has decided to contrary - (10) at time decisions rendered by Supreme Court technical developments increasing impact of motion pictures were foreseen.

1. The Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York had the power and rightfully exercised its jurisdiction to cancel licenses issued by the motion picture division of the State Department of Education for the exhibition of a motion picture [***3] entitled "The Miracle" (part of a trilogy called "Ways of Love") upon the ground that said picture was sacrilegious.

2. The history of the statutory provisions for the licensing of motion pictures, the constitutional grant of power to the Board of Regents to appoint and remove a Commissioner of Education, the naming of the Regents as head of the Education Department in the same paragraph of the Constitution as the Governor, Comptroller, and Attorney-General (N.Y. Const., art. V, § 4), the placing of the former independent motion picture commission in the Department of Education, the statutory grant of power to the board to appoint the director, officers and employees of the motion picture division, to prescribe their powers and duties and to fix their compensation, to establish local offices of the division, and to enforce the provisions and purposes of the statute governing the said division, indicate that the division is subordinate to the Education Department and the Board of Regents, and not independent thereof, and that the Regents had the power, implicit in their broad powers, to review and to cancel licenses previously granted. An express grant of power was unnecessary [***4] since such power is essential to the exercise of the powers expressly granted.

3. The Legislature did not intend that the protection of the public from films intended to be denied a license under the Education Law ( § 122) should rest entirely on the judgment of one or two persons in the motion picture division, without review of such action.

4. Rights acquired under licenses issued in an exercise of police power are not contractual in the constitutional sense, notwithstanding the expenditure of money by the licensee in reliance thereon.

5. Section 122 of the Education Law, insofar as it provides that a license shall not be issued for the exhibition of a film which is "sacrilegious", does not delegate legislative power without an adequate standard. The dictionary definition of "sacrilegious" as "the act of violating or profaning anything sacred" is clear, and it has been determined by the courts that the word "sacrilegious" and its synonym, "profane", provide a sufficiently definite standard.

6. The picture itself, depicting a demented peasant girl who is caused to become intoxicated and then seduced by a stranger whom she addresses as "St. Joseph", the personalities [***5] involved, the use of scriptural passages, other portions of the script, and the title of the film support the conclusion that, in reaching its determination, the Board of Regents did not act arbitrarily or capriciously.

7. The statute does not violate the provisions of the First Amendment to the Federal Constitution relating to religious freedom since (a) religious presentations, as well as educational and scientific films, are exempt (Education Law, § 123) and no one is prevented by the statute from propagating his own religious view by means of motion pictures; (b) the Regents are not required to form religious judgments in order to determine whether a film is sacrilegious. The standard applied is that no religion shall be treated with contempt, mockery, scorn and ridicule by those engaged in selling entertainment by way of motion pictures; (c) the statute is directed to the promotion of the public welfare, morals, peace and order and the fact that some benefit may incidentally accrue to religion is not sufficient to render the statute unconstitutional; (d) denial of the right of the government to interfere to protect religious beliefs from private or commercial attacks or [***6] persecution is a denial of its power to keep the peace and of the right of the free exercise of religion.

8. Since the licensee sought and obtained benefits under the statute and seeks to retain the licenses granted, such licensee may not argue that the statute is unconstitutional in toto as a prior restraint on the right of free speech.

9. But, in any event, it has been decided that motion pictures are primarily a form of entertainment and not in the same category as the press as vehicles of thought ( Mutual Film Corp. v. Industrial Comm. of Ohio, 236 U.S. 230; Mutual Film Co. v. Industrial Comm. of Ohio, 236 U.S. 247; Mutual Film Corp. v. Hodges, 236 U.S. 248). The Court of Appeals will not predict that the United States Supreme Court will overrule these cases.

10. Technical developments since the foregoing cases were decided, which have allegedly changed the nature of motion pictures, were foreseen in those cases and were realized at the time of the decision in RD-DR Corp. v. Smith (183 F. 2d 562 [1950], certiorari denied 340 U.S. 853). Technical developments which have increased the impact of motion pictures actually render the problem [***7] more acute.

 

617 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Wilson


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 107; 100 N.E.2d 159; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 693


Argued May 15, 1951.  
July 11, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner board of education of a school district (district) sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the district's petition on the merits. The district sought, in a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act, to set aside or modify a determination of school districts by the New York State Commissioner of Education (commissioner) pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 1801.


OVERVIEW: The voters of nine common school districts, among them District No. 2, petitioned their trustees to take action to consolidate the districts into a union free school district. The voters of the school districts voted for the formation of a union free school district, which was the petitioner. Prior to the vote on the consolidation, however, the district superintendent made an order dissolving District No. 2, and annexing its territory to an adjoining school district. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the district's petition on the merits. Because the district superintendent's order of dissolution and annexation of District No. 2 was upheld on appeal and the matter was one affecting the administration of the educational system, the determination was final as to the district. Also, the district had no standing to question the act of the commissioner in incorporating that territory into the new central school district.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the district's petition on the merits.


HEADNOTES

Schools - central school districts - union free school districts - common school districts - district superintendents - constitutional powers of Commissioner of Education - (1) determination of Commissioner of Education, affirming decision of appellate committee appointed by county judge which affirmed order of supervisory district superintendent dissolving common school district and [***2] annexing its territory to adjoining union free school district, not reviewable as far as it concerns school districts (Education Law, §§ 310, 1505) - (2) supervisory district superintendent had discretionary power to make such order, although voters of that and other common school districts had petitioned their trustees for voluntary consolidation into different union free school district; after their vote, his statutorily required order designating their consolidated district (Education Law, §§ 1513, 1523) rightly excepted common school district which he had dissolved - (3) thus, since such common school district never became part of consolidated district, latter cannot question power of Commissioner of Education to make order incorporating such common school district with other districts into one central school district - (4) in laying out central school districts, Commissioner of Education may include all or part of any existing school districts (N.Y. Const., art. V, §§ 2, 4; art. XI, § 1; Education Law, §§ 1801, 1802, 1803-a); order here rightly included such common school district regardless of whether it was part of voluntarily consolidated union free school district or part [***3] of district to which district superintendent had annexed it - (5) territory of school districts may be altered by administrative acts of officers of State Education Department - (6) district may not complain that its loss of assessed valuation of transferred territory reduces security of its bonds - (7) determination of commissioner not arbitrary; approved by voters of central school district by ratio of three to one.

1. A determination of the Commissioner of Education, affirming a decision of an appellate committee appointed by a county judge, which decision affirmed an order of a supervisory district superintendent dissolving a common school district and annexing its territory to an adjoining union free school district (Education Law, §§ 310, 1505), is a matter of administration of the State educational system and therefore is not reviewable by the courts, so far as it concerns a member of that system - the board of education of a union free school district, which is the petitioner in this proceeding to review and to set aside or modify said determination.

2. The supervisory district superintendent acted within his discretionary power, even though his order of dissolution [***4] and annexation was made after voters of the common school district and other common school districts had petitioned their trustees to take action for voluntary consolidation into a different union free school district. When, thereafter, the voters did vote for such different union free school district, the district superintendent had, as a ministerial act, to designate it as such a district under the statute [Education Law, §§ 1513, 1523], but his order of designation refused to include the common school district as to which he had already exercised his discretionary power, and his decision was upheld on appeal to the Commissioner of Education. Thus, the excepted common school district never became part of the voluntarily consolidated union free school district. ( City of New York v. Porter, 299 N.Y. 587, distinguished.)

3. Therefore, the voluntarily consolidated union free school district has no standing to question (as it attempts to do in this proceeding), the power of the Commissioner of Education to make an order incorporating the excepted common school district, together with other common school districts and union free school districts, into one central school [***5] district.

4. The Commissioner of Education had power to order, as he did, that the new central school district should include the excepted common school district "whether the same is now part of" the union free school district to which the district superintendent annexed it "or part of" the voluntarily consolidated union free school district. The commissioner, in laying out a central school district, has constitutionally been given power to include all or part of an existing school district. (N.Y. Const., art. V, §§ 2, 4; art. XI, § 1; Education Law, §§ 1801, 1802, 1803-a; Gardner v. Ginther, 232 App. Div. 296, affd. 257 N.Y. 578, followed.)

5. A school district is a municipal corporation within the General Corporation Law (§ 3) but not within the General Municipal Law ( § 51). Its territory is subject to change through acts of the administrative officers of the State Education Department.

6. That the loss of territory having substantial assessed valuation reduces the security of bonds of the district is not sufficient ground for objection by the district. ( Board of Educ. of Union Free School Dist. No. 6 v. Board of Educ. of Union Free School Dist. No.  [***6] 7, 76 App. Div. 355, affd. 179 N.Y. 556, followed.)

7. The laying out of the central school district by the Commissioner of Education was not arbitrary. It carried out the recommendation of the Joint Legislative Committee on the State Education System, the determinations of the district superintendent and the committee on appeal therefrom, and the results of the commissioner's own investigation.
