The dissolved common school district had, for nineteen years, maintained no district school but had sent its pupils to the adjoining union free district school. The new central school district will result in improved buildings and transportation and kindergarten and high school opportunities and has been approved by a three-to-one vote of the inhabitants of such central school district.

 

618 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Murray v. McNamara


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 140; 100 N.E.2d 377; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 697


Argued April 10, 1951.  
July 11, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY and DYE, JJ., concur with FROESSEL, J.; FULD, J., dissents in opinion in which LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., and DESMOND, J., concur.

Ordered accordingly. [See 303 N.Y. 804.] 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant pavers sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the first judicial department (New York), which affirmed the denial of the pavers' application to remove names from a pavers list, and reversed an order nullifying a promotion examination held for the position of rammer and directing that only persons on a specified list be certified as eligible for the rammer position.


OVERVIEW: The pavers sought on order directing respondent, the Municipal Civil Service Commission, to remove persons from the paver list on the ground that such persons did not have five years' satisfactory experience as paver or a satisfactory equivalent; to nullify all proceedings had with reference to a promotion examination for rammer; and to certify as eligible for the position of rammer the list of eligibles for the position of paver. On appeal, the court affirmed the nonremoval of certain persons from the pavers list. The requirement of a satisfactory equivalent in lieu of five years' satisfactory experience as a paver was not so vague and indefinite as to be unconstitutional. The court reversed regarding the rammer examination and eligibility. The court found that the commission acted contrary to law, in giving the rammer examination as a promotion examination open to laborer employees. The position of rammer was classified in a skilled part of the competitive class, whereas the position of laborer was in a wholly different class and ungraded. The court found that the paver list was the existing eligible list most nearly appropriate from which to make appointments to rammer.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order refusing to remove any eligibles from the paver list. The court reversed the order denying the nullification of all proceedings had with reference to the promotion examination for rammer, and in not directing that the commission certify as eligible for the position of rammer only persons appearing on the paver list, until a proper rammers' list was promulgated.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - New York City - civil service - appointment and promotion - (1) in open competitive municipal civil service examination,  [***2] requirement of five years' experience or "satisfactory equivalent" is valid - (2) but promotion examination to position of rammer in skilled craftsman service of competitive class may not be given to laborers in ungraded labor class who never took open competitive examination for "lower grade" of rammer type of work (Civil Service Law, § 16); words "lower but corresponding character" in rule of municipal civil service commission may not be read to contrary - (3) since such promotion list to rammer is illegal, and since open competitive paver list is most nearly appropriate (Civil Service Law, § 14, subd. 8), appointments as rammer must be made from paver list, until proper rammers' list is promulgated - (4) Statute of Limitations in proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act runs from time when first appointment is made from illegal list.

1. In an open competitive civil service examination for the position of paver in the city of New York, a requirement of five years' satisfactory experience as a paver or a "satisfactory equivalent" is not so vague as to be unconstitutional, or so clearly irrelevant and unreasonable as to authorize the courts to set aside an eligible list [***3] established as a result of the examination.

2. However, the municipal civil service commission had no power to give to "laborers" in the ungraded labor class, a promotion examination to the position of rammer in the "skilled craftsman and operative service" of the competitive class. Under section 16 of the Civil Service Law, promotion examinations may be given only to persons who have passed an open competitive examination for a "lower grade" in the type of work involved in the position to which it is sought to promote them. A rule of the municipal civil service commission which was apparently designed to implement the statute, but used the words "lower but corresponding character", may not be read to the contrary. These laborers never took an open competitive examination which tested their skill as rammers.

3. Since the only promotion list for rammer was not legally created, and since this record shows that the paver list is the existing eligible list most nearly appropriate (Civil Service Law, § 14, subd. 8) from which to make appointments to rammer, appointments to that position should be made from it, at least until a proper rammers' list is promulgated.

4. The [***4] present proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act was timely brought and the petitioners (pavers) were not guilty of laches.Petitioners were harmed, not when the promotion examination for rammer was held or the list promulgated, but when the first appointment was made from the list; and they brought this proceeding a month later.

 

619 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Zorach v. Clauson


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 161; 100 N.E.2d 463; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 699


Argued May 31, 1951.  
July 11, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY and DYE, JJ., concur with FROESSEL, J.; LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., concurs for affirmance upon the authority of People ex rel. Lewis v. Graves (245 N.Y. 195); DESMOND, J., concurs for affirmance in a separate opinion; FULD, J., dissents in opinion.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, parents of children attending public schools in New York City who did not avail themselves of the "released time" program, sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), affirming a trial court judgment that upheld the constitutionality of the program. The program permitted parents to withdraw their children from the public schools for one hour a week to receive religious instruction.


OVERVIEW: In their suit against respondent Board of Education of the City of New York, the parents claimed that the program violated the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment of the Federal Constitution, as applied to the states by the Fourteenth Amendment, and prohibited the free exercise of religion in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution and the New York Constitution art. I, § 3. The court disagreed and affirmed the judgments of the two lower courts. The court distinguished the case from a United States Supreme Court case, which had struck down an Illinois "released time" program. The court noted that, in Illinois, the instruction took place on school grounds, school officials supervised and approved the religious teachers, and pupils were solicited in school buildings for religious instruction. To the contrary, in the New York program, there was neither supervision nor approval of religious teachers and no solicitation of pupils, and the religious instruction was held outside the school building and grounds. The court noted that the Supreme Court had never held that "released time" programs per se violated the First Amendment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court judgment, which affirmed the trial court order upholding the constitutionality of the program.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - schools - released time from public schools for religious instruction - (1) constitutional prohibitions against [***2] laws respecting establishment of religion and against denial of free exercise of religion (U.S. Const., 1st and 14th Amendts.; N.Y. Const., art. I, § 3) not violated by release of New York City public school pupils whose parents request it, for one hour at close of one weekday session to attend courses given outside school grounds by religious organizations which file attendance reports with public school authorities who make no announcements or comment (Education Law, § 3210, subd. 1, par. b; Regulations of Commissioner of Education; Regulations of New York City Board of Education) - (2) petition in proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act properly dismissed without trial; allegations of disobedience of regulations by some teachers and principals do not amount to unconstitutional pattern of discrimination.

1. The constitutional prohibitions against laws "respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof" (U.S. Const., 1st Amendt., as applied to the States by the 14th Amendt.; see, also, N.Y. Const., art. I, § 3) are not violated by the provision of the Education Law ( § 3210, subd. 1, par. b) which, in regard to the attendance of minors [***3] in public schools, states that "Absence for religious observance and education shall be permitted under rules that the commissioner shall establish" and by the rules established thereunder by the State Commissioner of Education and by the New York City Board of Education. The rules of the commissioner provide for such absence for not more than one hour each week at the close of a day's session, to attend courses given outside the school grounds by duly constituted religious bodies, upon written request of parent or guardian, and that registration and attendance reports must be filed by the religious organizations with the public school authorities. The Regulations of the New York City Board of Education provide that the released hour in the schools in the borough of Brooklyn shall be on Wednesday, and that "There will be no announcement of any kind in the public schools relative to the program. * * * There shall be no comment by any principal or teacher on the attendance or non-attendance of any pupil upon religious instruction." The New York City board provides more days a year for secular instruction than are required by law (Education Law, § 3204, subd. 4). Such a released [***4] time program is constitutional.

2. The petition in this proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act was rightly dismissed on the merits without a trial. The allegations of fact, as well as the many merely conclusory allegations merely suggest disobedience of regulations by some teachers or principals which might warrant disciplinary proceedings but not the total discontinuance of the released time program. Such allegations do not show a pattern of discrimination consciously practiced.

 

620 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Di Brizzi


Court of Appeals of New York


303 N.Y. 206; 101 N.E.2d 464; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 701


Argued June 21, 1951.  
July 11, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS and DESMOND, JJ., concur with CONWAY, J.; FULD, J., concurs in separate opinion; DYE, J., dissents in opinion in which FROESSEL, J., concurs.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the first judicial department (New York), which denied petitioner's request to quash certain subpoenas as being unconstitutional. Petitioner alleged that the creation by executive order of the New York State Crime Commission was not authorized under N.Y. Exec. Law § 62(8).


OVERVIEW: Petitioner sought an order quashing subpoenas issued by the New York State Crime Commission. Petitioner alleged that there was no statutory authority for the creation of the New York State Crime Commission. The lower court denied petitioner's application. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment. According to the court, N.Y. Exec. Law § 62(8) did not expressly authorize by statute the creation of the New York State Crime Commission. However, the court determined that the appointment of the individual mention in the governor's executive order by the state attorney general was proper. The court further held that the topic or areas that were to be investigated by the "commission" were within the purview of § 62(8). The court stated that organized crime and its relationship to units of government in the state were matters concerning the public peace, public safety and public justice. Moreover, the court held that the mere fact that the appointed individuals called themselves the New York State Crime Commission was of no consequence. Lastly, the court found that the legislature properly conferred the authority upon the executive department to exercise subpoena power.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment denying petitioner's request to quash subpoenas directed to him because the investigation of organized crime was a matter directed related to the public health of the state. The court held that although there was no statutory authority for the creation of the New York State Crime Commission, the individuals appointed were properly appointed and were free to label themselves as they wished.


HEADNOTES

Governor - State Crime Commission - validity of subpoena issued by commission - (1) subpoena issued over names of members of "New York State Crime Commission" directed petitioner to appear before such commission and give evidence in inquiry directed by Executive Order concerning "public peace, public safety and public justice"; commission created to investigate relationship between [***2] organized crime and government; pursuant to said Executive Order Attorney-General directed, under subdivision 8 of section 62 of Executive Law, to make inquiry and "requested" to appoint members of commission with power to subpoena witnesses or records; five men named by said Executive Order appointed as law officers and members of commission; order denying petitioner's application to quash subpoena affirmed - (2) subdivision 8 of section 62 provides for such inquiry by Attorney General and permits him, in his discretion, to employ necessary officers with power to subpoena witnesses; action of Attorney-General in appointing persons named in order was in accordance with statute and he was not deprived by such statute of his discretion in making such appointments - (3) inquiry as to "public peace, public safety and public justice" broad enough to include investigation in question - (4) use of subpoena power in investigation in aid of executive function long authorized; Constitution charges Governor with duty to report as to "condition of the state" and to "take care" that laws are executed; subdivision 8, as here applied, not unconstitutional since reasonable relation exists between [***3] action taken by Governor and proper discharge of executive function - (5) necessity of inquiry as to existence of individual crimes does not constitute usurpation by investigation of province of grand jury.

1. By a subpoena issued over the names of the members of the "New York State Crime Commission" and the Attorney-General and signed by the Chief Counsel to the commission and a Special Assistant Attorney-General, petitioner was commanded to appear before said commission to give evidence in an inquiry into matters concerning "the public peace, public safety and public justice, as directed by the Executive Order of the Governor". The Executive Order named five men as constituting the commission to investigate and take action concerning the relationship between organized crime and government and specified certain duties and powers. By the order the Attorney-General was directed, under the terms of subdivision 8 of section 62 of the Executive Law, to inquire into matters involving the "public peace, public safety and public justice" and was "requested" to do so by appointing the members of the commission for such purpose, and the commission, together with the Attorney-General,  [***4] (a) were directed to exercise all powers under said section 62 which the Governor had the power to delegate, and (b) were authorized to administer oaths and to subpoena any person or records. The Attorney-General thereupon appointed each of the five men mentioned in the order as an officer of the State Department of Law and a member of the "New York State Crime Commission". An order of Special Term denying petitioner's application to vacate and quash the subpoena should be affirmed.

2. Subdivision 8 of section 62 of the Executive Law provides that the Attorney-General may, with the approval of the Governor, inquire into matters concerning "the public peace, public safety and public justice" for which purpose he may, in his discretion, employ such officers as he deems necessary and that he and other officers delegated by him are empowered to subpoena witnesses. The Governor directed the Attorney-General to act under subdivision 8 of section 62 and the action of the Attorney-General in appointing the persons named was in accordance with the terms of the statute. He was not deprived of the discretion granted in making these appointments since he was not directed, but merely "requested"  [***5] to do so. Nor is it of moment that the members of the commission are not all lawyers.

3. In granting authority to inquire into matters concerning the "public peace, public safety and public justice" the statute used language sufficiently broad to include an investigation such as this, where the principal purpose is to determine whether a relationship exists between organized crime and any units of government. It is clear that organized crime and its relationship to units of the State Government are "matters concerning the public peace, public safety and public justice" within the meaning of subdivision 8 of section 62 of the Executive Law. The Legislature, therefore, had the power, under the State Constitution, to authorize the investigation.

4. The Legislature may constitutionally confer authority upon the Executive Department to exercise subpoena power in connection with an investigation in aid of the executive function. Under the Constitution (art. IV, § 3), it is the Governor's duty to communicate to the Legislature the "condition of the state" with recommendations and to "take care" that the laws are faithfully executed. If there be a relationship between organized [***6] crime and units of government in the State, and if there be defects in the existing relationship between the State Government and local law enforcement, these are matters affecting "the condition of the state" which should be communicated to the Legislature with appropriate recommendations for their elimination. If existing laws be adequate, at least the Governor would have additional information so that he might "take care that the laws are faithfully executed." Since there exists a reasonable relation between the action taken by the Governor, through the Attorney-General, and the proper discharge of the executive function, it cannot be said that subdivision 8 of section 62, as here applied, is unconstitutional.

5. The fact that the Attorney-General and the members of the commission in discharging their duty may find it necessary to inquire as to whether individual crimes have been committed does not constitute usurpation by the investigation of the traditional province of the grand jury in each county of the State. ( Ward Baking Co. v. Western Union Tel. Co., 205 App. Div. 723, distinguished.)

 

621 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fara Investors, Inc. v. Lourie


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 880; 100 N.E.2d 55; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 991


Submitted May 21, 1951  
June 1, 1951, decided

 

622 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Denihan Enterprises, Inc. v. O'Dwyer


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 451; 99 N.E.2d 235; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 719


Argued March 8, 1951.  
May 24, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS and FULD, JJ., concur with FROESSEL, J.; DESMOND, J., dissents in opinion in which CONWAY and DYE, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city appealed a decision from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which reversed the dismissal of a taxpayer's complaint, denied the city's motion to dismiss, granted a temporary injunction, and certified to the court the question of whether the trial court properly granted the city's motion to dismiss the complaint, in an action brought under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51.


OVERVIEW: The city entered into a contract with a company under which the city agreed to acquire property by condemnation, pursuant to N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 72-j(3), to offer it at public auction, for a term of 50 years, subject to conditions providing for the construction of a public parking garage, and for commercial facilities. The taxpayer contended that the contract was illegal because inter alia, (1) the use contemplated was not public but private; (2) it was not authorized, (3) even if authorized and found in some respects to be public in nature, it was so subordinated to the private benefit of the company that the end result was a private use. The court found that it could not say as a matter of pleading that no cause of action whatsoever was set forth, and that no triable issues were presented. Sufficient facts were alleged purporting to show that the public use here might be only incidental and in large measure subordinate to the private benefit to be conferred on the company, and not for the purposes authorized by the statute. This was not a case to be decided on the pleadings. The constitutionality of the regulations must be decided after the facts were determined on the trial.


OUTCOME: The court answered the question certified in the negative, and affirmed the order of the lower court with costs.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - eminent [***2] domain - private uses - (1) triable issues presented by complaint in taxpayer's action for injunction (under General Municipal Law, § 51) - (2) in order to condemn and then lease land for construction of "parking garages" for relief of traffic congestion (General Municipal Law, § 72-j), City of New York contracted with corporation that city would condemn area and lease it at public auction, and that corporation, if successful bidder, would construct and operate garage with stores, commercial facilities and landscaping; complaint presents triable issues of fact as to whether contract was drawn so as to discourage competitive bidding, benefit corporation's adjoining apartment house, and create practically no new car spaces for public - (3) condemnation is not for public use where public benefit is merely incidental to private benefit - (4) legality of city's agreement to rezone area for purposes of lease or to lease for more than ten years not passed on.

1. On a motion to dismiss a complaint for legal insufficiency, such pleading must be given the benefit of every favorable inference notwithstanding that the proof may fall short of the allegations. Triable issues are presented [***3] by the complaint in this taxpayer's action for an injunction under section 51 of the General Municipal Law.

2. Section 72-j of the General Municipal Law authorizes a municipality, in order to relieve traffic congestion, to acquire real property by condemnation and to lease it for "parking garages or parking spaces". A contract has been entered into between the City of New York and an insurance corporation whereby the city agrees to acquire by condemnation a parcel of real property and then at public auction to lease it for fifty years. Further provisions are that the corporation will bid; that the successful bidder, as lessee, will remove the tenants, who number over 100, and will build a public parking garage (title to which shall vest in the city) for at least 750 cars; that the building may include stores and other commercial facilities; that the lessee may determine the amount of space to be allotted to comply with a recommendation of the traffic commission that such a garage would fill a need for storage space for cars of nearby residents and will afford limited space for transient parking; that the lessee will pay an initial rent equal to the condemnation awards, expenses [***4] and taxes, and an annual rent of at least $25,200, and may charge garage rates to be approved by the city and which will bring the lessee a 6% annual return on its broadly defined investment. Plaintiff taxpayer alleges facts to show that such contract contemplates primarily a storage garage rather than a public parking garage; that after the corporation has provided storage space for its tenants and made provision for the 308 now existing car spaces in the area to be condemned, the net gain for the general public will be only 17 spaces; that many specifications will benefit the corporation and discourage other bidders and will not benefit the public, such as the limitation to two stories (notwithstanding expensive subcellar construction) which does not help to relieve parking congestion but grants easements of light and air for the corporation's high rent apartment house across the street; the landscaping of the garage roof for an elevated public park on the southerly half and a strictly private park on the northerly half, for its tenants to view, rather than employing same for parking purposes; the construction of a center mall, necessitating the widening of a street, only to create [***5] a bottleneck at each end and to locate entrances and exits opposite the corporation's apartment house; the onerous financial requirements for a probable outlay of $4,000,000, without right to mortgage; all of which, taken together with other allegations of the complaint, present triable issues as to whether the taking is primarily for a private, rather than a public, use.

3. A use is not public where the public benefit is only incidental to a private benefit. Moreover, the validity of a statute upon one set of facts is immaterial if in its application to another situation it results in invalidity.

4. Other questions, such as the legality of the city's agreement to rezone the area for the purposes of the lease, or its power to lease its property for more than ten years (New York City Charter [1938], § 384, subd. b), are not passed upon at this time.

 

623 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Erickson


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 461; 99 N.E.2d 240; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 720


Argued April 11, 1951.  
May 24, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the first judicial department (New York), which unanimously affirmed the trial court's conviction of defendant, upon his guilty plea, of one crime of conspiracy N.Y. Penal Law § 580, and of 59 crimes of book-making in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 986. His total sentence, on all 60 counts, was five years' imprisonment and $ 30,000 in fines.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that N.Y. Penal Law § 986 penalized only the operating of a bookmaking business, and that, accordingly, the nonconspiracy counts in the information (numbers 2 to 60) charged not 59 crimes, but one crime, and could result in one sentence only. His second point was that if these were 60 different crimes, then N.Y. Penal Law § 2190, authorizing separate consecutive sentences on those 60 counts, was unconstitutional under N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 2, and 6, and N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 18. The court disagreed with defendant's arguments and held that N.Y. Penal Law § 986 was a listing of a number of different kinds of acts or conduct, all of them related to "book-making," each of which was a separate misdemeanor. Therefore, defendant was charged with 60 different crimes. The court also held that, under N.Y. Penal Law § 2190, a number of related offenses could be covered by the same indictment or information, and that for each such count on which defendant was found guilty, he could receive a separate and cumulated sentence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment and defendant's conviction and sentence.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - sentence - (1) one who pleaded guilty in court of special sessions to sixty counts of information, first of which charged conspiracy to violate section 986 of Penal Law ("book-making") and remaining fifty-nine charged separate violations of same section, properly sentenced on all sixty counts to five years' imprisonment, last three being suspended, and $30,000 in fines - (2) section 986 which prohibits "book-making" lists number of different acts all relating thereto but each constituting [***2] separate misdemeanor - (3) information here charges one conspiracy to violate said section and fifty-nine separate violations thereof - (4) sentence not violative of State Constitution; statutes (Code Crim. Pro., § 279; Penal Law, § 2190) when read together provide that number of related offenses may be covered by same information and, for each count on which defendant is found guilty, that he may receive separate and cumulated sentence; defendant's rights not invaded and constitutional jurisdiction of special sessions not enlarged by allowing such sentence under one, rather than under sixty, informations.

1. In a court of Special Sessions of the City of New York defendant pleaded guilty to each of sixty counts of an information. The first count charged a conspiracy to violate a statute which prohibited "book-making" (Penal Law, § 986) while each of the following fifty-nine counts alleged a specific violation of said section. Defendant was thereafter properly sentenced on each of the first two counts to imprisonment for one year in a penitentiary and a $500 fine, the total sentence on all sixty counts being five years' imprisonment, with the last three years thereof suspended,  [***3] and $30,000 in fines.

2. Section 986 is a long statute which makes guilty of a misdemeanor a person who is guilty of any one of a number of different kinds of activities and acts. Defendant would construe the section as if it merely prohibited the engaging in book-making and as if all the rest of the statutory language were merely explanatory of what the Legislature meant thereby. The statute, however, is rather a listing of a number of different kinds of acts or conduct, all of them relating to "book-making" but each separately made a misdemeanor.

3. The first count charges that defendant had entered into a conspiracy - continuing from 1930 to 1950 - to engage with others in book-making in violation of section 986, while each of the remaining fifty-nine counts (identical except for dates) accuses defendant with receiving, forwarding and being the custodian of money wagered on specified dates. The reference in each such count to "book-making" is surplusage since the remaining language alleges a complete crime and it follows that the information charges one conspiracy to violate, and fifty-nine separate violations of section 986.

4. Provisions of the State Constitution [***4] (art. I, §§ 2, 6) which require that infamous crimes be charged only by indictment of a grand jury and give a defendant a right to trial by jury do not apply to offenses where the maximum punishment is no more than one year in a penitentiary, plus a maximum $500 fine, and which are triable, according to specific statutes, by a court of special sessions. If the statutes (Code Crim. Pro., § 279; Penal Law, § 2190) purported to authorize a trial on an information in a court of special sessions without a jury, of an offense carrying heavier punishment than that assigned to misdemeanors, to that extent they would be unconstitutional - but neither of said statutes has such result. Read together they provide that a number of related offenses may be covered by the same indictment or information and that for each such count on which a defendant is found guilty, he may receive a separate and cumulated sentence. The acts to which this defendant pleaded guilty could have been charged against him in sixty separate informations and he could have received sixty separate, consecutive sentences. No right of his has been invaded nor is the constitutional jurisdiction of the special sessions court [***5] enlarged by allowing all this to be done under one, rather than by sixty, informations.

 

624 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fara Investors, Inc. v. Lourie


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 730; 98 N.E.2d 704; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 888


Argued March 5, 1951  
April 12, 1951, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - landlord and tenant - rent regulation - plaintiff landlord had obtained title to premises in mortgage foreclosure action which terminated prior leases held by tenants on February 1, 1948, and parties subsequently negotiated new leases for increased rental in 1948 - premises were decontrolled from February 1, 1948,  [**3] until April 1, 1949, when Housing and Rent Act of 1949 became effective - subdivision (b) of section 203 of said statute recontrolled premises where leases had terminated between January 1 and April 1, 1948, and fixed rental as that filed under 1947 act - contention by landlord that section 203 (subd. [b]) was arbitrary and discriminatory in that it denied increased rental to landlords where leases expired before April 1, 1948 - judgment in favor of tenants properly affirmed.

 

625 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Chatlos v. McGoldrick


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 380; 98 N.E.2d 567; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 735


Argued February 27, 1951.  
April 12, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landlord sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order that denied the landlord's application for an order directing respondent state rent administrator to set aside a regulation.


OVERVIEW: After a long period of federal rent regulation, the federal government passed an act that permitted the states to take over rent control within their boundaries. New York responded by enacting a law that stated that where the federal maximum rent differed from the local maximum rent, the latter prevailed. By reason of an unusual set of circumstances, the federal maximum on a particular apartment was lower than the local maximum. The state rent administrator fixed the rent at the lower federal maximum pursuant to a regulation that stated that the lower of the two applied. The landlord filed a protest with the State Rent Commission, which rejected it. The landlord then filed an Article 78 proceeding in the trial court. Both the trial court and the appellate division affirmed. The landlord appealed. The court affirmed. The court agreed that the statute, on its face, made no provision for when the local maximum rent exceeded the federal maximum. However, the court found that the legislature's intent in having enacted the statute was that the lower maximum should have applied. The court held that the legislature's intent prevailed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the denial of the landlord's petition for an order directing the state rent administrator to set aside a regulation.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant - rent regulation - maximum rent - statutory construction - (1) intent of State Emergency Housing Rent Control Law (in L. 1950, ch. 250, § 4, subd. 1, par. [a] ) was correctly expressed by State Housing Rent Commission regulation (§ 21, subd. 1, eff. May 1, 1950) that maximum rent should be Federally prescribed maximum on March 1, 1950, but maximum prescribed by New York City local law, if lower - (2) 1950 statute could have meant that local law maximum was to prevail even when higher than [***2] Federal maximum, but 1951 act (L. 1951, ch. 36) amended earlier act and stated "intent of the legislature by this act to clarify" 1950 act; such construction is entitled to great weight and avoids unexpected result.

1. When Federal control of residential rents in New York State was terminated (pursuant to Federal Housing and Rent Act of 1947, as amd.; U.S. Code, tit. 50, Appendix, §§ 1893, 1894) the State Emergency Housing Rent Control Law (L. 1950, ch. 250, § 4, subd. 1, par. [a] ) stated that the State Housing Rent Commission "shall establish maximum rents * * * which shall be the same as those prescribed on March first, nineteen hundred fifty, pursuant to the federal housing and rent act * * * or local laws specified in chapter one of the laws of nineteen hundred fifty. Where there were different maximum rentals prescribed pursuant to such laws on March first, nineteen hundred fifty, the maximum rental established hereunder shall be the same as that prescribed pursuant to the local laws". One of such local laws ("Sharkey Law", Local Laws, 1949, No. 73 of City of New York; ratified by L. 1950, ch. 1) undertook to forbid the collection of apartment rent increases in New York [***3] City granted by the Federal authorities after March 1, 1949, and to that extent had been held unconstitutional during Federal control (in Teeval Co. v. Stern, 301 N.Y. 346). When the State took over rent control, its legislative act stated ( § 14) that local laws were referred to therein solely for purposes of identification and that any invalidity of such local laws should have no effect on their use as points of reference. The Legislature also stated ( § 13-a, subd. 1) that it was acting to prevent tenants from being subjected to increases ordered by Federal law. The intent of the Legislature was correctly and validly expressed by the State Rent Commission in a regulation (§ 21, subd. 1, eff. May 1, 1950) which provided that maximum rents prescribed by New York City local law should prevail only if lower than the Federally prescribed maximum on March 1, 1950.

2. In 1951 it was called to the Legislature's attention that its 1950 act, taken at its face could mean that the local law maximum was to prevail even in the very unusual cases (such as petitioner's case here) where it was higher than the Federal maximum. The Legislature was reminded that the Governor in signing [***4] the 1950 bill had stated that it fixed rents at the Federal or local level "whichever is lower" and that the Attorney-General had rendered a similar opinion. Thereupon the Legislature amended the 1950 act (by L. 1951, ch. 36) so as to show that locally prescribed maximum rents were not to prevail when higher than the Federal, and that "It is the intent of the legislature by this act to clarify the provisions of" the 1950 act. Such a subsequent clarification and construction by the Legislature is entitled to great weight, and in this case avoids an unexpected result.

 

626 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fink v. Cole


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 216; 97 N.E.2d 873; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 745


Argued January 16, 1951.  
March 8, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Ordered accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated appeals, appellant horse owner sought review of the orders of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the first judicial department (New York), which confirmed the determinations of respondents, the Racing Commission of the State of New York (commission) and a private corporation, that denied the horse owner a license to race horses in the State of New York in 1949 and in 1950.


OVERVIEW: The owner challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Unconsol. Laws §§ 7508, 7512, which purported to delegate to the private corporation certain powers that the owner asserted the legislature could not delegate within the framework of the federal and state constitutions. On appeal, the court reversed the orders confirming the determinations by the commission and the private corporation, which denied the owner's application for a license for two consecutive years. The court held that the delegation by the legislature of its licensing power to the private corporation was such an abdication as to be patently an unconstitutional relinquishment of legislative power in violation of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1, which provided that the legislative power of New York was vested in the senate and assembly. It also was unconstitutional as a delegation of the power to "fix" the rates of taxes on owners, trainers, and jockeys, and therefore also to fix the taxing policy of the state. The court noted that even if the legislature's power to license had been delegated to a governmental agency, the challenged statute would have to have been stricken down for lack of guides and proper standards.


OUTCOME: The appellate court's orders confirming the determinations by the commission and the private corporation, refusing the owner's application for a license in the years 1949 and 1950, were reversed, and the determinations of the commission and the private corporation were annulled.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - horse racing - legislative delegation of licensing power - (1) legislative power unconstitutionally delegated to Jockey Club, private corporation, to license horse owners, trainers and jockeys at races and to make rules and regulations (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 1; L. 1934, ch. 310, §§ 4, 5, as amd.) - (2) even if licensing power were delegated to governmental agency, statute unconstitutional for lack of guides and standards - (3) determinations of State Racing Commission and stewards of Jockey Club, upholding refusal to issue license to petitioner, annulled.

1. For the declared purpose of maintaining proper control over racing meetings within New York State, the Legislature unconstitutionally abdicated its legislative power (contrary to N.Y. Const., art. III, § 1) in delegating to The Jockey Club [***3] (a private corporation) the power to "license owners [of horses], trainers and jockeys at running races" and to make "reasonable rules and regulations", pursuant to which The Jockey Club has empowered its stewards - its officers, who are not public officers chosen by and responsible to the State government - to grant or refuse such licenses "at their discretion". (L. 1934, ch. 310, §§ 4, 5, as amd. [McKinney's Unconsol. Laws, §§ 7508, 7512]; Jockey Club's "Rules of Racing", rule 34.)

2. Even if the Legislature had granted its sovereign power of licensing to a governmental agency, this statute would be unconstitutional for lack of guides and proper standards.

3. Orders of the Appellate Division confirming determinations made pursuant to the statute by a joint board consisting of the three members of the State Racing Commission and two stewards of The Jockey Club, which upheld The Jockey Club's refusal to issue a license to petitioner, should be reversed and such determinations annulled.

 

627 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Guardian Life Ins. Co. v. Chapman


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 226; 97 N.E.2d 877; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 746


Argued November 29, 1950.  
March 8, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Ordered accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial District (New York) which affirmed the order of respondent when additional taxes were assessed under N.Y. Tax Law §187 for direct and reinsurance premiums realized by appellant.


OVERVIEW: Respondent assessed additional franchise taxes under N.Y. Tax Law §187 for direct premiums and reinsurance premiums against appellant. Appellant alleged that § 187 was not applicable for premiums received in states where appellant was not authorized to do business. The court held that appellant deposited the money in accounts in New York, thus, the money was received in New York. The inclusion clause of § 187 (5) included the direct premiums because both the intent of the language of the statute were satisfied. The court held that the reinsurance premiums received from states where appellant was not authorized to do business could not be included under § 187 because the statute was limited to direct premiums. The court reversed the inclusion of reinsurance premiums and affirmed the inclusion of direct premiums in appellant's tax liability.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the inclusion of direct premiums in determining appellant's tax obligation where premiums were received within New York both in the intent and language of the statute but reversed respondent's inclusion of reinsurance premiums because the inclusion clause referred only to direct premiums.


HEADNOTES

Insurance - taxation - franchise tax on domestic life insurance corporations - statutory construction - constitutionality of tax as applied to interstate commerce - (1) under Tax Law ( § 187, subds. 2, 5; L. 1937, ch. 530) domestic life insurance corporation must pay franchise tax based on direct premiums received on risks resident in this State and on "premiums written, procured or received in this state on business which cannot specifically be allocated or apportioned and reported as taxable premiums on business [***2] of any other state"; that includes premiums on lives of residents of States where insurance corporation had no licenses, and collected by its agents in States where it had licenses, and ultimately received by it in this State, and on which it has paid no tax to any State - (2) such premiums are "received in this state" - (3) Tax Law ( § 187) and Insurance Law ( §§ 550, 552) are in pari materia and must be construed harmoniously - (4) domestic corporation may not raise constitutional questions applicable only to foreign corporations - (5) no ad valorem tax (N.Y. Const., art XVI, § 3) - (6) no question of multiple taxation which might burden interstate commerce - (7) Congress allows State regulation and taxation of insurance (U.S. Code, tit. 15, §§ 1011, 1012) - (8) under Tax Law ( § 187, subd. 5) no tax on reinsurance premiums received in this State by domestic insurer from another insurer not authorized to do business here, where person insured by such other insurer is not resident of this State - (9) meaning of Tax Law provisions of 1937 clarified by in pari materia provisions of Insurance Law of 1939.

1. The Tax Law ( § 187, as rewritten by L. 1937, ch. 530) provides that "every [***3] domestic life insurance corporation * * * shall, for the privilege of exercising corporate franchises * * * pay a tax of one and three-fourths per centum on all gross direct premiums * * * received in cash or otherwise on risks resident in this state" (subd. 2). It further provides that "In ascertaining the amount of direct premiums * * * there shall be first determined the amount of total gross premiums * * * on all policies * * * insurance and reinsurance executed, issued or delivered on property or risks located or resident in this state, including premiums for reinsurance assumed, and also including premiums written, procured or received in this state on business which cannot specifically be allocated or apportioned and reported as taxable premiums on business of any other state or states." (Subd. 5.) Under the latter provisions, petitioner (a domestic life insurance corporation authorized by all but fifteen of the States to do business therein, and which pays to such authorizing States franchise taxes based on premiums on the lives of insured residents) must pay a tax on premiums which it received on the lives of residents of the fifteen States where it had not been authorized [***4] to do business and on which it had not paid taxes to any State.

2. It is settled by decisions of the United States Supreme Court that an insurance corporation like petitioner does not, merely by accepting premiums on the lives of residents of fifteen States where it has not been authorized to do business, transact such a business there as is taxable by those States. Policyholders in such States pay their premiums, after the initial payment, either to petitioner's home office in New York or to an agent in a nearby State where petitioner is authorized to do business and said agents there deposit the premiums in bank accounts in petitioner's name, withdrawable only by petitioner. From time to time petitioner draws checks on such out-of-State bank accounts and thereby withdraws the premiums to New York. None of the authorizing States has attempted to tax those premiums and it is not clear whether they can. Those premiums are "received in this state" by petitioner, and are reasonably and peculiarly attributable to its New York franchise, and are taxable to petitioner by New York "for the privilege of exercising corporate franchises".

3. In this State, domestic and foreign insurance [***5] corporations are taxed under provisions of the Tax Law and the Insurance Law.Such taxing statutes are in pari materia and must therefore be read together and applied harmoniously. The corresponding provision of the Insurance Law ( § 550, subd. 2, as recodified and clarified in 1939 without intended change of substance from § 34, which had been rewritten together with Tax Law, § 187, as part of L. 1937, ch. 530) states that "all such premiums * * * shall be deemed written on property or risks located or resident in this state".

4. Petitioner is a domestic, not a foreign, insurance corporation, and is, therefore, without standing to assert that the Tax Law provision as applied to a foreign insurance corporation might violate the due process clause of the Federal Constitution.

5. The tax is not an ad valorem tax on intangible personal property. (N.Y. Const., art. XVI, § 3.)

6. The tax is not on the importation of the money into New York as though it were an article of interstate commerce. [See U.S. Const., art. I, § 8.] Rather the tax is on the privilege of exercising a corporate franchise granted by New York and is measured by the premiums reasonably attributable [***6] to the exercise of that franchise. The tax is exactly the same as to domestic and foreign insurers. No question of multiple taxation, which might be conceived as a potential burden upon interstate commerce, can arise, because the statute by its own terms applies only where such premiums are not otherwise taxed anywhere.

7. In any event, Congress, after investigating the effect of the commerce clause, has declared "that silence on [its] part * * * shall not be construed to impose any barrier to the regulation or taxation of such business [insurance] by the several States." (U.S. Code, tit. 15, § 1011; see, also, § 1012.)

8. However, the Tax Law ( § 187, subd. 5) does not tax reinsurance premiums which are received in this State by a domestic insurance corporation from another insurance corporation which is not authorized to do business here where the person originally insured by such other corporation is not a resident of this State. Reinsurance premiums are taxed only "on property or risks located or resident in this state" (subd. 5) which, as to life insurance companies, can only mean "risks * * * resident in this state". In its context, ordinary meaning, and common [***7] understanding in the insurance world, that means the residence of the insured person, not the place of contract of the reinsuring corporation.

9. This interpretation of the Tax Law ( § 187, subd. 5) as to reinsurance premiums was adopted by the Legislature in 1939, when it recodified corresponding in pari materia tax provisions which it had written in 1937 in the Insurance Law ( § 34). The provision as to premimus "allocated or apportioned and reported as taxable premiums of any other state or states" is now in a separate place and applies only to "direct premiums" (Insurance Law, § 550, subd. 2). Alien insurance corporations are taxed on reinsurance premiums only "to the extent that the same covers property or risks located or resident in this state" ( § 552, subd. 4). It is unlikely that the Legislature intended to discriminate in favor of alien insurers and against domestic insurers; rather the statutory provisions should be read together.

 

628 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Fernandez v. Denno


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 651; 98 N.E.2d 473; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 831


Argued March 7, 1951  
March 7, 1951, decided


HEADNOTES

Crimes - murder in first degree - date of execution - new date of execution fixed by Court of Appeals following denial of certiorari by United States Supreme Court - relators, convicted of crime of murder in first degree, appealed to Court of Appeals where judgment of conviction was affirmed and new date of execution fixed - pending determination of application to United States Supreme Court, execution stayed and, upon subsequent denial of certiorari, new date of execution fixed by Court of Appeals under new section 503 of Code of Criminal Procedure - writs of habeas corpus, issued upon allegations that relators had been deprived of constitutional rights in not being brought personally before court for fixing of new date of execution, dismissed - orders affirmed.

 

629 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rodgers v. Tarrytown


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 115; 96 N.E.2d 731; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 757


Argued October 9, 1950.  
January 18, 1951, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, DYE and FROESSEL, JJ., concur with FULD, J.; CONWAY, J., dissents in opinion in which DESMOND, J., concurs.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owner appealed from a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed the dismissal of his complaint challenging the validity of two amendments to the zoning ordinance of defendant village and seeking to enjoin defendant property owner from constructing multiple dwellings on her property.


OVERVIEW: Some years ago, the village enacted a General Zoning Ordinance dividing the village into seven districts or zones for single family dwellings, two-family dwellings, multiple dwellings and apartment houses, three business districts and an industrial zone. Plaintiff, who owned a residence on a six-acre plot, brought an action to have two subsequent zoning amendments declared invalid and to enjoin defendant property owner from constructing multiple dwellings on her property. The appellate court adjudged the amendments valid and dismissed the complaint. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court. The court found that, viewing the rezoning amendments in the present case in the light of the area involved and the present and reasonably foreseeable needs of the community, the conclusion was inescapable that what was done not only accorded with sound zoning principles, not only complied with every requirement of law, but was accomplished in a proper, careful, and reasonable manner.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court that dismissed plaintiff's complaint challenging the validity of two zoning ordinances and seeking to enjoin defendant property owner from constructing multiple dwellings on her property. The court found that, viewing the rezoning ordinances at issue in light of the area involved and the present and reasonably foreseeable needs of the community, the amendments were reasonable and proper.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - zoning - (1) village board of trustees in 1947 amended zoning ordinance by creating new "Residence B-B" zone for garden apartments and for one- and two-family dwellings, such zone to be limited to ten-acre plots and to be fixed by later amendment of zoning map; defendant with ten and one-half acre plot later applied for creation of new "Residence B-B" zone and, by second amendment of ordinance, property was placed in such zone; in action to have both amendments declared invalid and erection of apartments enjoined, complaint dismissed - (2) village board may amend [***2] zoning ordinance to promote general welfare and its judgment therein is conclusive unless shown to be arbitrary as to which burden of proof rests on objecting party - (3) board had choice of methods of accomplishing zoning aim to promote garden apartments; necessity for separate legislative authorization for each project presents no obstacle - (4) restriction of such zone to plots of ten acres or more not unfair; board's grant or refusal to zone any such plot subject to review by courts - (5) amendments here not illegal as "spot zoning" since they gave each owner of ten acres identical rights and were not for benefit of particular owner alone - (6) amendments not device for creating variance; issue as to property zoned not question of hardship but desirability of location for garden apartments - (7) 1947 amendment not invalid for failure to set boundaries or make proper changes on zoning map - (8) amendments not invalid because board employed two steps to accomplish what it could have covered in one.

1. Years after enacting a general zoning ordinance dividing a village into seven zones including Residence "A", "B" and "C" zones for single family, two-family, and multiple family [***3] dwellings respectively, as well as business and industrial zones, the board of trustees, by ordinance enacted in 1947, created a new class of zone to be called "Residence B-B" in which (besides one- and two-family dwellings) buildings for multiple occupancy of fifteen or fewer families were permitted - the boundaries thereof to be fixed by subsequent appropriate amendment of the building zone map. A minimum of ten acres of land for such zone was required by the ordinance. A year and a half after the 1947 enactment one of defendants sought to have her property, consisting of ten and one-half acres in a Residence A district, placed in the new classification and several months later, after approval by the village planning board, the board of trustees passed another ordinance which provided that such a district should be applied to her property and the official building zone map amended accordingly. In this action brought by a nearby property owner to have the amendments declared invalid and to enjoin said defendant from constructing multiple dwellings on her property, the complaint was properly dismissed.

2. Persons who own property in a particular zone enjoy no eternal vested [***4] right to that classification if the public interest demands otherwise and a village may amend its basic zoning ordinance in such a way as reasonably to promote the general welfare. Decision as to how a community shall be zoned or rezoned and as to how various properties shall be classified or reclassified rests with the local legislative body and its judgment is conclusive unless shown to be arbitrary by one who so asserts it.

3. Considering the zoning aim of the board of trustees of furnishing additional housing facilities, attracting business to the community and lightening the tax load of the small home owner, a choice of methods lay with the board. It could either amend the general zoning ordinance so as to (1) permit garden apartments on any plot of ten acres or more in Residence A and B zones, or (2) invite, as it did here, owners of ten or more acres who might wish to build garden apartments on their properties to apply for a "Residence B-B" classification. The necessity of separate legislative authorization for each project presents no obstacle.

4. A requirement that the applicant own a plot of at least ten acres was not unfair to other owners. Some definite acreage [***5] had to be chosen and, so far as appears, the choice of ten acres as a minimum plot was well within the range of an unassailable legislative judgment. The owner of a ten-acre plot is not entitled ipso facto to the new classification. It still remains for the board, in the exercise of a reasonable discretion, to decide whether a particular application shall be granted or denied and recourse may be had to the courts to correct an arbitrary or capricious determination.

5. "Spot zoning" - defined as the process of singling out a small parcel of land for a use classification totally different from that of the surrounding area for the benefit of the owner of such property and to the detriment of other owners - is the very antithesis of planned zoning. An ordinance enacted in accordance with a comprehensive zoning plan is not illegal "spot zoning" even though it singles out and affects but one small plot, or creates in the center of a large zone small areas devoted to a different use. In this instance the amendment of 1947 applied to the entire territory of the village and gave each owner of ten or more acres identical rights.

6. There is no basis for an argument that what [***6] was done constituted a device for creating a variance. The board of trustees followed approved procedure by changing the general zoning ordinance itself and, when called on to consider the reclassification of defendant's property, it was concerned not with any issue of hardship but only whether the property constituted a desirable location for a garden apartment.

7. There was no need that the 1947 amendment should fix boundaries for the new district or make changes in the building zone map for until both conditions are met no new zone actually comes into being and no property is affected. The amendment was merely the first step and provided for further action which, when taken in 1948, fixed the boundaries of the zone and amended the map accordingly. Read together, the amendments fully complied with the requirements of the Village Law and properly accomplished a rezoning of village property.

8. Had the board simply amended the general zoning ordinance so as to permit property in Residence A and B zones to be used for garden apartments, provided they were built on ten-acre plots, there would be no doubt as to the propriety of the procedure despite the same uncertainty as [***7] to the location of the various types of structures. Therefore to strike down the ordinances in question merely because the board employed two steps to accomplish what usually is done in one would be to exalt form over substance.

 

630 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


County of Broome v. Bates


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 587; 96 N.E.2d 892; 1951 N.Y. LEXIS 790


Argued November 17, 1950  
January 11, 1951, decided


HEADNOTES

Judges - compensation - action for judgment declaring sections 144-a and 144-b of Judiciary Law, which provided for payment of additional compensation to Justices of Supreme Court in third and fourth judicial departments, to be unconstitutional in that said statutes unlawfully delegate legislative powers (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 1); incorporate other laws by reference (art. III, § 16); fail to appropriate necessary moneys (art. VII, § 7); grant extra compensation to public officers (art. IX, § 10), and provide for increase in salary of public officer [**4] during term of office (art. XIII, § 12) - statutes properly declared constitutional and complaint properly dismissed.

 

631 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Friedman


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 75; 96 N.E.2d 184; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 770


Argued October 16, 1950.  
December 1, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants were convicted of the crime of having publicly sold and offered for sale uncooked meats on a Sunday in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 2147. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), affirmed the convictions. Defendants sought review of that judgment.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of violating § 2147 for having publicly sold and offered for sale uncooked meats on a Sunday. The intermediate appellate court affirmed the convictions. On further review, the court also upheld the convictions. In reaching its decision, the court held that § 2147 did not impinge upon religious freedom because it was not a law respecting an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof. Also, the court determined that § 2147 did not deny the equal protection guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment by reason of being discriminatory class legislation. According to the court, the statutory scheme, viewed as a whole, was a valid one and did not constitute discrimination. The court rejected defendants' claim that the statute had been consistently enforced discriminatorily in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11. According to the court, the offer of proof was not an offer to show a pattern of discrimination consciously practiced; it merely indicated some nonenforcement as to certain other business, many of which were allowed to remain open for the sale of permitted commodities.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the intermediate appellate court's judgment upholding defendants' convictions for the crime of having publicly sold and offered for sale uncooked meats on a Sunday.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - sale of food on Sunday - (1) section 2144 of Penal Law exempting from prosecution for Sunday work and labor persons observing another Sabbath not to be read into section 2147 dealing with "public selling" on Sunday; conviction for sale of food on Sunday in violation of section 2147 of Penal Law, affirmed - (2) section 2147 not unconstitutional as infringement on religious freedom; Sunday [***2] laws have long recognized necessity of setting apart day of rest for physical and moral welfare of individual members of community - (3) section 2147, as asserted discriminatory class legislation, does not deny equal protection of laws - (4) claim that statute has been enforced in discriminatory manner in violation of equal protection clause without merit - (5) plea that statute imposes hardship should be addressed to Legislature.

1. Section 2144 of the Penal Law, which exempts from prosecution for work or labor on Sunday persons observing as a Sabbath another day of the week, may not be read into section 2147 dealing with "public selling * * * upon Sunday". For almost three quarters of a century the exemption clause has been interpreted as referring only to laboring or working and as excluding selling. Accordingly, a judgment convicting defendants of the crime of having publicly sold and offered for sale uncooked meats on a Sunday in violation of section 2147 of the Penal Law should be affirmed where the defense is the invalidity of said section or its discriminatory application.

2. Section 2147 is not unconstitutional because of infringement upon religious freedom. It [***3] works no restriction upon the exercise of religion according to the dictates of one's conscience nor does it in any way enforce or prohibit religion. Although the so-called Sunday laws may have had a religious origin, our statute has also recognized that the first day of the week by general consent is set apart "for rest", in accord with the general experience of mankind that it is wise and necessary to set apart such a day for the physical and moral welfare of members of the community.

3. Section 2147 does not deny the equal protection guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment by reason of being discriminatory class legislation. The statutory scheme is that of a general prohibition against specified activities on Sunday with some exceptions, many of which emphasize the day as one for rest, play, relaxation and recreation rather than merely a religious Sabbath.

4. A claim that the statute has been consistently enforced discriminatorily in violation of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and section 11 of article I of the State Constitution is without merit. The proof offered merely indicated some nonenforcement as to certain other businesses many of which [***4] were allowed to remain open for the sale of permitted commodities.

5. A plea that a statute imposes inconvenience or hardship upon a litigant should be addressed to the Legislature.

 

632 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Stevenson v. News Syndicate Co.


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 81; 96 N.E.2d 187; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 771


Argued October 11, 1950.  
December 1, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed, etc. [See 302 N.Y. 690.] 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff husband and defendant newspaper both appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the supreme court's denial of the newspaper's motion for dismissal of the libel action and the denial of the husband's motion for judgment on the pleadings.


OVERVIEW: The husband and his wife were involved in a separation action. The newspaper published in several editions of its papers an article concerning their separation action. Subsequently, the husband filed a libel action against the newspaper, claiming that it was in violation of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 278. The newspaper claimed that the article was privileged under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 337. On review, the court affirmed the denial of both motions. Denial of the husband's motion for judgment on the pleadings was proper because the newspaper had raised an issue of material fact, i.e., whether the husband had lost income as a result of the published article. On the newspaper's motion to dismiss, the court found that the article fell far short of the standard for privilege under Rule 337 because it was neither true nor fair. The article failed to make any mention of the fact that the charges were made as part of a motion, which had been withdrawn. Further, the article made a false assertion as to when the wife made her charges against the husband. Thus, the privilege declared by Rule 337 did not attach to the article.


OUTCOME: In a libel action, the court affirmed the orders that denied both the newspaper's motion for dismissal and the husband's motion for judgment on the pleadings.


HEADNOTES

Libel and slander - privilege - fair and true newspaper report of judicial proceedings - (1) since answer contains denial (that plaintiff lost position because of defendant's newspaper publication) which raises issue of fact, plaintiff's motion for judgment addressed to entire answer must be denied - (2) defense of new matter is deemed controverted (Civ. Prac. Act, § 243) and ordinarily not to be considered on defendant's motion [***2] for judgment on pleadings, but motion here is based also on admissions by plaintiff of genuineness of papers annexed to defense of privilege, consisting of plaintiff's wife's motion papers for temporary alimony in separation action against plaintiff and of order withdrawing her motion - (3) answer pleads defense of "fair and true report of * * * judicial * * * proceedings"; article not full, fair and impartial, and omitted fact that wife had withdrawn her motion; publication not privileged; order denying defendant's motion for judgment on pleadings affirmed.

1. A motion by a plaintiff for judgment on the pleadings, when addressed to the entire answer, will be denied irrespective of the merits of an affirmative defense, if the answer contains a denial which raises an issue of fact. In this libel action defendant's answer denies the allegation that plaintiff lost his employment because of defendant's publication. Hence, the order denying plaintiff's motion should be affirmed.

2. A defense consisting of new matter is deemed controverted (Civ. Prac. Act, § 243) and ordinarily will not be considered on a defendant's motion for judgment on the pleadings. Nevertheless, the question [***3] here presented is whether the defense of privilege pleaded by defendant newspaper is valid, because defendant's motion for judgment is made on the pleadings and on admissions which plaintiff made pursuant to section 322 of the Civil Practice Act. Those admissions establish the genuineness of the papers annexed to and made part of the plea of privilege in the answer - that is, copies of motion papers for temporary alimony filed by plaintiff's wife in her separation action against plaintiff and of an order under which her motion was withdrawn.

3. The answer pleads that defendant's article was a "fair and true report of * * * judicial * * * proceedings" (Civ. Prac. Act, § 337). The article, in part, reads: "That double-dealing husbands are a dime a dozen * * * . But [plaintiff], $27,000-a-year treasurer of * * * Corp., does not fool around on so small a scale, his wife, Grace, charged yesterday in Supreme Court, Manhattan. Bob, said Grace, is a triple-dealer. By this [she] explained in a suit for separation, she means that [he] not only has been double-dealing her with a lady in his employ but also is cheating on the co-respondent." No mention was made that such charges [***4] (which the article falsely said were made "yesterday") were made as part of a motion which had theretofore been withdrawn. The article was neither true nor fair and consequently not privileged under section 337 of the Civil Practice Act. Accordingly, the order denying defendant's motion for judgment on the pleadings should be affirmed.

 

633 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bristol-Myers Co. v. Picker


Court of Appeals of New York


302 N.Y. 61; 96 N.E.2d 177; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 777; 22 A.L.R.2d 1203


Argued October 18, 1950.  
November 30, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND and DYE, JJ., concur with FROESSEL, J.; FULD, J., dissents in opinion in which LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., concurs.

Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant manufacturer challenged an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the first judicial department (New York), which found that appellee seller's actions of providing consumers with a cash discount upon the purchase of manufacturer's products did not constitute a violation of the Fair Trade Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law art. XXIV.


OVERVIEW: Appellant manufacturer brought suit against appellee seller alleging unfair competition. Manufacturer alleged that seller violated the Fair Trade Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law art. XXIV, by giving consumers a cash discount of two and a half percent when a purchase was made. The appeals court entered judgment finding that the transactions did not violate the law. The supreme court reversed the judgment. According to the court, when a consumer was accorded a discount, the consumer in reality paid that much less for the article that he purchased, and this was none the less true because the return was by way of merchandise rather than coin, which might purchase merchandise. The court held that when seller sold manufacturer's products at fair trade prices, and as a part of the same transaction gave their customers cash register receipts having a redemption value of two and a half percent of such fair trade prices, they, in effect, sold manufacturer's products at two and a half percent less than the prices fixed. The court concluded that such behavior was violative of the act and that manufacturer was entitled to an injunction upon proof that its products were willfully sold at a lesser price.


OUTCOME: Judgment finding that appellee seller's actions of providing consumers with a discount upon the purchase of appellant manufacturer's products did not constitute a violation of the Fair Trade Law was reversed because such actions actually reduced the price of manufacturer's products, which in turn was an assault on manufacturer's good will.


HEADNOTES

Trade-marks, trade names and unfair competition - Fair Trade Law - constitutionality of provision prohibiting price cutting - (1) issuance by [***2] retail druggist of cash register receipts on purchases of miscellaneous merchandise, including plaintiff's trade-marked products which defendants knew were price-fixed (under General Business Law, art. XXIV-A), and redemption of $10 worth of such receipts in merchandise worth twenty-five cents, properly enjoined - (2) Fair Trade Law (General Business Law, § 369-a et seq.) constitutional - (3) defendants' plan constitutes price cutting - (4) defendants' plan directly related to price, unlike free parking and free delivery - (5) injunction against unfair competition of such price cutting may be granted without proof of specific money damages - (6) judgment of trial court enjoining defendants from selling plaintiff's products at less than fair trade contracts prices, reinstated.

1. A manufacturer of drug and cosmetic products expended large sums of money in advertising and selling its products under distinctive trade-marks and established a valuable reputation and good will for them. To protect that good will it established minimum retail prices for its products and fulfilled all the requisites to their trading pursuant to the Fair Trade Law (General Business Law, § 369-a through [***3] § 369-e). In this action such manufacturer seeks to restrain defendants, who operate a retail drugstore where plaintiff's products are sold, from selling such products at less than the prices fixed in fair trade contracts made with dealers. Defendants had no fair trade contract with plaintiff but knew that plaintiff's products were fair-traded. Some years prior to passage of the Fair Trade Law, defendants originated a merchandising plan under which their customers could redeem cash register receipts in specified articles of merchandise.Later, such cash register receipts were redeemable in trade from defendants' merchandise, whether fair-traded or not, at the rate of 2 1/2% of cash purchases, when they aggregated $10 or more. Later, defendants and fourteen other merchants (not druggists) formed a "Lynbrook Dividend Club" plan, under which each store redeemed its own receipts as well as those issued by any other member store, and monthly adjustments were made. The customer, upon accumulating $10 worth of the receipts from any of these stores, could redeem them in any of the stores for a great variety of merchandise, whether fair-traded or not, at a value of twenty-five cents for [***4] each $10 of receipts. Such plan, "whether the person so * * * selling is or is not a party to such [fair trade] contract, is unfair competition and is actionable at the suit of any person damaged thereby." (General Business Law, § 369-b.) Special Term properly enjoined defendants from advertising or selling plaintiff's trade-marked products at prices less than those fixed by plaintiff in contracts made under the Fair Trade Law.

2. Congress has removed from the interdict of the Federal anti-trust and unfair competition laws resale price maintenance agreements which are valid in the State of resale. (U.S. Code, tit. 15, § 1.) In any event, the validity of the State statutes as against constitutional objections (U.S. Const., 14th Amendt.; N.Y. Const., art. I, § 6) is founded upon the protection thus afforded the manufacturer as the owner of the brand name and good will of trade-marked merchandise. Our Fair Trade Law constitutes a valid exercise of police power to protect such good will against assault and it is a lawful limitation upon freedom of contract to cut prices.
