3. Defendants' plan constitutes price cutting. The Fair Trade Law makes no exception for, and does [***5] not sanction, such discounts. (Cf. General Business Law, § 369-a, subds. 2, 3; § 369-c; Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, § 101-b, subd. 2, par. [b]. )

4. Considered as a method of advertising, defendants' scheme must be differentiated from types of service such as free parking, self-service, care of infants, entertainment, free delivery and the like, which have no direct relation to the article purchased or the price paid and which are too remote from the pricing element to come within the statute's prohibition. Under defendants' plan, the benefit to the customer is directly, proportionately, inseparably and specifically related to the article purchased and its price.

5. The Fair Trade Law provides that cutting prices of fair trade articles is unfair competition. The base of unfair competition is an assault upon good will. Such injury to good will, actual or threatened, may be enjoined, even though proof of specific money damages is not supplied.

6. The weight of the evidence lies with the finding of Special Term that defendants' practice does constitute price cutting, and the Appellate Division was in error on the law when it held that such practice is not within [***6] the prohibition of our Fair Trade Law. The judgment of the Appellate Division should be reversed and that of Special Term affirmed. [Civ. Prac. Act, § 605.]

 

634 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Thompson v. Wallin


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 476; 95 N.E.2d 806; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 782


Argued October 11, 1950.  
November 30, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the Chairman of the Communist Party, teachers, and the union, brought actions against defendants, board of regents and the board of education, challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Educ. Law § 3022 (1949). The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) reversed the judgment in favor of plaintiffs, declared the statute constitutional, and dismissed the complaint. The plaintiffs appealed.


OVERVIEW: The chairman, public school teachers, and the union brought actions against the boards to have § 3022 declared unconstitutional. They contended that the United States Constitution and the New York Constitution were violated by provisions of § 3022 which declared that membership in any organization, which the board of regents, after notice and a hearing, found to be advocating the overthrow of the government by violence or unlawful means, was prima facie evidence of disqualification for appointment or retention in the service of the public school system. The court upheld the statute as being constitutional, finding that it had none of the characteristics of a bill of attainder. The court also held that the statute was not vague and that it did not infringe upon any constitutional right of free speech, assembly, or association.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments of the intermediate appellate court, finding the statute to be constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - public schools - teachers and other school employees - subversive activities - (1) after enacting section 3021 of Education Law directing removal of public school teachers for seditious acts or utterances, section 12-a was added to Civil Service Law disqualifying from positions in public schools any who taught overthrow of Government by force; later by section 1 of chapter 360 of Laws of 1949, Legislature found that members of subversive groups and particularly of "communist party" had infiltrated into public schools despite statutes to prevent same and had used their positions to teach subversive doctrines; section 3022 (Feinberg Law), added to Education Law by chapter 360, provides for disqualification by Board of Regents of public school employees who violate section 3021 of Education Law or are ineligible under section 12-a of Civil Service Law; subdivision 2 of statute directs Board of Regents to list [***4] subversive organizations and states that membership in any such constitutes "prima facie evidence of disqualification" for such positions; statute constitutional - (2) said law implements section 12-a of Civil Service Law and provides basis of disqualification for employment in public education, constitutional function of State; restrictive provisions of statute bear reasonable relation to purpose of safeguarding public schools - (3) constitutional rights to freedom of speech and press not absolute and do not deprive State of primary right of self-preservation; in view of declaration of findings by Legislature in preamble, statute not unreasonable or arbitrary exercise of police power nor does it unwarrantably infringe constitutional rights of free speech and assembly - (4) statute has no legal characteristics of bill of attainder despite mention of "communist party" as subversive in preamble thereto since preamble enacts nothing - (5) no lack of clarity in subdivision 2 directing listing of subversive organizations as set forth in section 12-a of Civil Service Law - (6) while membership in such organization deemed prima facie evidence of disqualification for employment, presumption [***5] disappears on offer of substantial evidence to contrary; no question of procedural due process - (7) no restriction in statute exceeding Legislature's constitutional power.

1. In 1917 the Legislature added to the Education Law present section 3021 directing the removal of superintendents, teachers and employees in the public schools for treasonable or seditious acts or utterances. In 1939 there was added to the Civil Service Law section 12-a which provided, inter alia, that no one should be appointed to or continued as superintendent or teacher in a public school who advocated or taught that the Government of the United States or of any State or political subdivision should be overthrown by force or who organized or became a member of any society or group teaching such doctrine. One so dismissed or declared ineligible was entitled to a hearing on such charges and the burden of sustaining the order by a fair preponderance of credible evidence was on the person making the order. Ten years later by section 1 of chapter 360 of the Laws of 1949, the Legislature found that members of subversive groups and "particularly of the communist party" had infiltrated into the public schools [***6] despite the statutes designed to prevent such action and that members of such groups advocating violent overthrow of the Government used their position to advocate and teach subversive doctrines and, further, that to avert such infiltration the Board of Regents should be directed to meet the menace by affirmative action. To meet such conditions section 3022 (known as the Feinberg Law) was enacted by said chapter. It provides that the Board of Regents shall adopt and enforce rules and regulations for the disqualification of superintendents, teachers or employees in the public schools who violate the provisions of section 3021 of the Education Law or who are ineligible on any of the grounds set forth in section 12-a of the Civil Service Law. Subdivision 2 directs the Board of Regents to list the organizations which it finds to be subversive for teaching the violent overthrow of Government and provides that it may utilize similar listings promulgated by any Federal agency and that it shall provide that membership in any such organization shall constitute prima facie evidence of disqualification for appointment to or retention in any position in the public schools. Judgments and orders [***7] upholding the constitutionality of said section should be affirmed.

2. The Feinberg Law serves to implement section 12-a of the Civil Service Law in manner found by the Legislature to be expedient in view of the circumstances set forth in its preamble. It provides a basis of disqualification for employment by State or municipal agencies of personnel essential to a constitutional function of the State, the education of its children. The judgment of the Legislature as expressed in the restrictive provisions of the statute bears a reasonable relation to the legislative purpose to safeguard the public school system.

3. The freedoms of speech and press guaranteed by the First Amendment to the Federal Constitution and those guaranteed by section 8 of article I of the State Constitution are not absolute and do not deprive the State of its primary right of self-preservation. Those freedoms do not sanction unbridled license. By enacting the Feinberg Law, the Legislature - acting within its province - has found and has declared that conditions - referred to in the preamble - did exist and required the adoption of statutory measures to protect public school children from subversive [***8] influences. Whether the danger envisaged was "clear and present" is answered by the Legislature's factual finding that an infiltration of members of subversive groups into employment in the public schools has occurred and that the consequence thereof is that subversive propaganda can be disseminated among children of tender years and that members of such groups use their office to teach such doctrines. The Feinberg Law is neither an unreasonable or arbitrary exercise of the police power nor does it unwarrantably infringe upon any constitutional right of free speech, assembly or association.

4. It is contended that the statute is a bill of attainder violative of section 9 of article I of the Federal Constitution, in that its preamble states that members of subversive groups "and particularly of the communist party" have infiltrated into public employment in the public schools. The preamble, however, enacts nothing, contains no directive and, indeed, was not made part of the Education Law. Provision is made for a hearing to be afforded any organization as to which an inquiry shall be instituted and no punishment is inflicted on any organization which, after hearing, the board [***9] shall find advocates the overthrow of Government by force or unlawful means. Any organization aggrieved by the board may, under the statute, bring a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act.

5. There is no lack of clarity in the operative clause of subdivision 2 of said section 3022 which directs the board to list organizations found to be subversive for teaching the overthrow of Government by force.

6. Under subdivision 2 no organization may be listed as subversive until after inquiry and appropriate hearing. While knowingly holding membership in such an organization shall constitute "prima facie evidence of disqualification" fortion disappears and thus the quoted phrase imports a hearing at which one who seeks appointment or retention is afforded an opportunity to present such evidence. Once such contrary evidence has been received, the official who made the order has the burden of sustaining the validity thereof and provisions for review are prescribed by section 12-a of the Civil Service Law. Consequently, there is no question of procedural due process.

7. There is no restriction in the statute which exceeds the Legislature's constitutional power.

 

635 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


St. Nicholas Cathedral of the Russian Orthodox Church in N. Am. v. Kedroff


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


302 N.Y. 1; 96 N.E.2d 56; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 772


Argued June 1, 1950.  
November 30, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, DYE and FROESSEL, JJ., concur in opinion by CONWAY, J.; LEWIS, CONWAY and DYE, JJ., concur in separate opinion by FROESSEL, J.; DESMOND, J., dissents in opinion in which LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., and FULD, J., concur.

Judgments reversed, etc. [See 302 N.Y. 689.] 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff corporation, which owned a Russian Orthodox cathedral, filed suit against defendants, schismatics who occupied the cathedral, and sought to prove they were not the proper parties to administer the religious trust. The trial court dismissed the complaint after trial, and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed. The corporation appealed.


OVERVIEW: Following the 1917 Russian Revolution, the Russian Orthodox Church in North America held a sobor in 1924 at which it was determined that local administration was called for in light of the repression of the church in the Soviet Union. However, the schismatics, who were credentialed with a variant church that had some governmental support in the Soviet Union, had filed actions in New York to establish the validity of their appointments and had obtained an injunction to occupy the cathedral. They claimed that they were properly occupying the cathedral. The corporation claimed that the beneficial use of the cathedral properly belonged to the Russian church in America, which was forced to declare its administrative autonomy at the 1924 sobor. The court held that N.Y. Relig. Corp. Law § 5 provided for denominational control and administration of church properties and temporalities, so that the corporation could not simply evict the schismatics. However, N.Y. Relig. Corp. Law § 107 provided that every New York Russian Orthodox church was to be subject to the jurisdiction of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America. Therefore, the lower courts erred in finding for the schismatics.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower courts' rulings in favor of the schismatics and directed judgment for the corporation, reinvesting the corporation and the autonomous metropolitan district that it represented with the possession and administration of the cathedral.


HEADNOTES

Religious corporations and associations - title to church property - constitutionality of legislative determination of beneficiaries for whom church property is held - (1) in ejectment action for possession of cathedral in New York of North American diocese of Russian Orthodox Church, wherein title was proved by plaintiff corporation which represents autonomous North American district created after Russian Government had subjugated central church authority,  [***2] judgments of trial court and Appellate Division in favor of defendant bishop appointed by subjugated central church authority, reversed and judgment directed for plaintiff - (2) courts below could have found that autonomous North American district is proper trustee of cathedral for benefit of faithful of diocese - (3) article 5-C of Religious Corporations Law is construed as legislative determination that autonomous North American district of church is trustee of purposes for which cathedral was originally dedicated - (4) such legislative determination, as exception to general provision of section 5 of Religious Corporations Law for denominational control of church property, is constitutional; facts of subjugation of central church are deemed found by Legislature.

1. In this ejectment action for possession of a building in New York City which, since 1905, has been the cathedral of the North American diocese of the Russian Orthodox Church, the defendants are the ruling bishop of the diocese appointed by the purported head of the church in Russia and a priest ordained by said bishop. Plaintiff, a New York religious corporation, has proved (1) that the church has been subjugated [***3] by the Russian Government and has not had an independent existence in Russia since at least 1923, (2) that an American convention of the church in 1924 created an autonomous North American district under an archbishop who had been designated to rule the North American church by the last free act of the head of the church in Russia, (3) that most of the parishes adhere to such autonomous North American district, (4) that plaintiff corporation, composed of said archbishop and other members of such Russian Orthodox Church in North America, was created by a special act of the State Legislature (L. 1925, ch. 463, confirmed by L. 1945, ch. 817), (5) that plaintiff corporation has a deed from the religious corporation in whose name the title to the cathedral was originally held, executed in 1925 by the Russian Consul General as one of the two incorporators of the grantor but not executed by the Ambassador as the other incorporator of the grantor, and that such defect was cured by an act of the Legislature (L. 1942, ch. 206). Judgments of the trial court and the Appellate Division, dismissing the complaint, should be reversed and judgment directed for plaintiff.

2. Since 1875, the Legislature [***4] has provided for the denominational control of church properties (Religious Corporations Law, § 5). The corporate owner thus holds the property in a trust dedicated to the religious uses of the church. On the evidence, the courts below would have been warranted in exercising the discretionary power of the Supreme Court over the conduct of trustees and in determining that the leaders of the North American autonomous district are the trustees who may be relied upon to carry out the purposes of this religious trust for the benefit of the faithful for whose use the cathedral was originally dedicated. The courts below failed to exercise that discretion, because they believed that the appointees of the nominal church authorities in Russia were legally entitled to possession of the cathedral. This was error. The determinative issue in this case is whether the central organization of the church in Russia is a free religious body or a mere organ of an antireligious government.

3. By article 5-C of the Religious Corporations Law (added by L. 1945, ch. 693; amd. by L. 1948, ch. 711) the Legislature has conclusively determined, in effect, that the autonomous North American district (the [***5] "Russian Church in America") is the trustee which may be relied upon to carry out more effectively and faithfully the purposes of this religious trust. This is the only construction which gives effect to all the language of sections 105 and 107 of article 5-C.

4. The general rule of section 5 of the Religious Corporations Law is that the trustees of a religious corporation must administer the temporalities in accordance with the discipline of the ecclesiastical body to which the corporation is subject, irrespective of the wishes of the majority of the local congregation. But the Legislature may constitutionally modify this rule in a case where its literal enforcement would be unreasonable. The Legislature, in the exercise of its extensive power to act for the common welfare, may find as a fact that a situation has arisen of such novelty that existing law is incapable of performing its avowed function - preservation of religious temporalities for the use of their original and accustomed beneficiaries. In such case, there can be no constitutional objection to a legislative tracing and identification (as in article 5-C) of the authentic group entitled to the administration of [***6] such properties. The facts as to the subjugation of the church in Russia must be deemed to have been found by and to have been within the knowledge of the Legislature when it decided to act in 1945 and 1948. Even assuming that courts are prevented from recognizing these facts, the Legislature is not under such an unrealistic handicap.

 

636 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Faulds v. Herberich


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 614; 93 N.E.2d 913; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 943


Argued May 25, 1950  
July 11, 1950, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - extradition - habeas corpus - relator, indicted in Ohio for crime of nonsupport, but not fugitive from that State, held for extradition under section 834 of Code of Criminal Procedure - contentions by relator that statute permitting such extradition unconstitutional, that State without power to agree to extradite persons who were not fugitives, that extradition not exercise of police power, that Federal Constitution (art. IV, § 2) prohibited return of persons who were not fugitives, and that statute violated full faith and credit clause of Federal Constitution - order dismissing writ of habeas corpus properly affirmed.

 

637 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re GUARANTY TRUST CO.


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 653; 93 N.E.2d 924; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 965


Argued May 29, 1950  
July 11, 1950, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional [**4] law - taxation - estate taxes - apportionment - corpus of two inter vivos trusts included, for purposes of taxation, in estate of intestate who died resident of Florida in 1948 - Florida taxing statute, enacted in 1949, and applicable by its terms to intestate's estate, provided for apportionment of taxes among persons interested in estate - contentions in Court of Appeals by remaindermen of one of such trusts that retroactive provision rendered statute unconstitutional and that direction in order appealed from as to payment of interest on taxes was improper - order of Appellate Division upholding constitutionality of statute affirmed.

 

638 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re NATIONAL CITY BANK OF NEW YORK


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 656; 93 N.E.2d 925; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 966


Argued May 29, 1950  
July 11, 1950, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional [**4] law - taxation - estate taxes - apportionment - corpus of two inter vivos trusts included, for purposes of taxation, in estate of intestate who died resident of Florida in 1948 - Florida taxing statute, enacted in 1949, and applicable by its terms to intestate's estate, provided for apportionment of taxes among persons interested in estate - contentions in Court of Appeals by remaindermen of one of such trusts that retroactive provision rendered statute unconstitutional and that direction in order appealed from as to payment of interest on taxes was improper - order of Appellate Division upholding constitutionality of statute affirmed.

 

639 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gallewski v. H. Hentz & Co.


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 164; 93 N.E.2d 620; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 793


Argued May 17, 1950.  
July 11, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant brokerage firm appealed the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the trial court's order denying the brokerage firm's motion for summary judgment dismissing the action brought by plaintiff, the administrator of the client's estate, to recover the value of the client's securities that were sold by the brokerage firm without authorization.


OVERVIEW: The client, who was a resident of the Netherlands, entered into an agreement with the brokerage firm whereby the brokerage firm agreed to buy and sell securities for the client. Subsequently, the brokerage firm without the client's knowledge or authorization sold the major portion of the securities held for the client's account. Thereafter, World War II began, and the client was arrested and deported to a concentration camp where he died. After the war, the administrator filed the action on the client's behalf to recover the value of the securities sold without authorization. The brokerage firm alleged that the suit was barred by the statute of limitations. The trial court denied the brokerage firm's motion to dismiss, and the appellate court affirmed. On appeal, the court also affirmed, holding that the administrator's action commenced the period permitted by the statute of limitations. The court concluded that the Civil Practice Act was applicable in favor of the client, who was a citizen of an enemy-occupied country, and that §§ 27 and 28 of the Civil Practice Act applied to the administrator's cause of action and effectively tolled the statute of limitations during the war.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's order affirming the trial court's denial of the brokerage firm's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - limitation of actions - revival of cause of action - (1) under agreement between decedent, resident of Netherlands, and defendant, New York broker, for purchase and sale of securities, latter held securities for former at time of occupation of Netherlands by German Army in May, 1940; decedent [***2] was deported to concentration camp and died in May, 1944; about May 22, 1940, broker, in violation of agreement, sold decedent's securities to reduce his indebtedness; plaintiff, decedent's ancillary administrator, commenced action in 1948 to recover value of securities; action not barred by Statute of Limitations - (2) on April 17, 1950, and after leave to appeal to Court of Appeals had been granted, new section 28-a added to Civil Practice Act tolling Statute of Limitations in action by resident or sojourner in territory occupied by Government of foreign country while at war with United States; statute made new section applicable to causes of action already barred; Court of Appeals will apply law as it exists at time of its decision; new section applies to decedent - (3) Legislature may constitutionally revive personal cause of action where circumstances are exceptional and serious injustice would result to guiltless plaintiffs - (4) revival proper in present case; facts illustrate type of injustice legislation was intended to remedy - (5) statute adding section 28-a constitutional; deducting period of decedent's residence or sojourn in occupied territory, action brought within six [***3] years.

1. On April 30, 1940, pursuant to an agreement made by decedent, a citizen and resident of the Netherlands, and defendant, a New York broker, for the purchase and sale of securities, defendant held for decedent's account securities subject to an indebtedness of about $24,000. On the following May 10th, the Netherlands was invaded by the German Army and during the occupation, decedent was arrested and deported to a concentration camp. It has been established that he died in May, 1944. Between May 14 and May 22, 1940, defendant, contrary to law and in violation of the agreement, sold the major portion of the securities and reduced decedent's indebtedness thereby. In October, 1946, plaintiff was appointed ancillary administrator of decedent's estate and in 1948 brought this action to recover the value of the securities with dividends and interest. Defendant asserts that since the action accrued not later than May 22, 1940, it was barred by the Statute of Limitations. Summary judgment dismissing the complaint was properly denied.

2. After leave to appeal to the Court of Appeals had been granted and on April 17, 1950, the Civil Practice Act was amended by adding a new [***4] section 28-a (L. 1950, ch. 759, § 1) which provided that if one entitled to maintain an action was a resident or sojourner in a foreign country with which this country or its allies were at war between September 1, 1939, and August 14, 1945, or any territory occupied by the Government of such foreign country, the period during which such territory was so occupied should not be part of the time limited for commencing an action provided that the period for commencement should not extend more than one year from the date of the statute. The same chapter further provided that, except in cases of actions involving title to property, the new section should apply to causes of action theretofore accrued and barred. In a case such as this, the Court of Appeals will apply the law as it exists at the time of its decision. The new section applies to decedent who was a resident or sojourner in a territory occupied as described.

3. The Legislature may constitutionally revive a personal cause of action where the circumstances are exceptional and such as to satisfy the court that serious injustice would result to plaintiffs not guilty of any fault if the intention of the Legislature were not [***5] effectuated. The court is free to approach each revival statute on its individual merits in the light of its own peculiar circumstances and setting. ( Robinson v. Robins Dry Dock & Repair Co., 238 N.Y. 271, followed.)

4. In this case a situation is presented in which revival - even if considered an extreme exercise of the legislative power - is entirely proper. World War II resulted in a complete and thorough disruption of communication by those on the mainland of Europe with the outside world. Aside from the question of legal disability to sue, the citizens and residents of occupied territory were, during such occupation, under a practical and total inability to commence actions in the courts of this State to protect and effectuate their rights. To permit the Statute of Limitations to run against their claims during the continuance of such inability would not accord with elementary notions of justice and fairness. The facts of the instant case illustrate the type of injustice this legislation was intended to remedy.

5. Chapter 759 of the Laws of 1950 is constitutional and under the terms thereof the period of decedent's residence or sojourn in territory occupied [***6] by the Germans is not a part of the time limited for commencing the action. Deducting that period from the normal time, the action was brought within six years from the time it accrued.

 

640 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Concordia Collegiate Institute v. Miller


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 189; 93 N.E.2d 632; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 796; 21 A.L.R.2d 544


Argued May 22, 1950.  
July 11, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Orders reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant nonprofit corporation sought review of a judgment from Supreme Court, Westchester County (New York), which affirmed an order denying the nonprofit corporation's application for a mandamus order directing respondent building superintendent to issue a building permit.


OVERVIEW: The nonprofit corporation sought an order in mandamus that would direct the building superintendent to issue a building permit. The lower court affirmed the dismissal of the nonprofit corporation's case and the denial of the building permit. On appeal, the nonprofit corporation challenged the constitutionality of the zoning amendment upon the ground that it was arbitrary, unreasonable, and confiscatory in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. The court reversed the lower court judgment because it found that the amendment to the zoning ordinance was invalid. The provisions of the zoning amendment withdrew the unrestricted permission to use property in the residential district for educational purposes, but authorized permission with the consent of adjoining property owners. The court held that the amendment was invalid because the nonprofit corporation and building superintendent would both be powerless in that adjoining property owners could prevent authorized uses of property. The court concluded that the zoning amendment was invalid because it violated due process.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court order and granted the nonprofit corporation's application for an order directing the issuance of the building permit.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - municipal corporations - zoning - school buildings - (1) amendment to village zoning ordinance which provided for granting of variance in residence district by board of appeals to permit erection of building for educational purpose upon filing of consent of 80% of owners of adjoining property, invalid; no triable issue of fact presented; application for order directing issuance of permit for erection of school buildings granted - (2) effect of ordinance would be that adjoining [***2] property owners could determine petitioner's use of property - (3) no standards or guides for exercise of discretion of board of appeals provided - (4) not necessary to seek relief under invalid amendment or to show hardship under section 179-b of Village Law - (5) provisions of prior ordinance permitting erection of buildings for education purposes restored.

1. A village, in which an educational institution had continuously owned and operated its property as a school and campus site for about forty years, in 1938 enacted a zoning ordinance which placed the school's property in a residence district where educational buildings were expressly permitted (art. 3, § 1, subd. [b] ). In 1941 this provision was repealed and the zoning ordinance amended to provide (art. 12, § 7, subd. [f] ) that a variance might be permitted in a residence district by the board of appeals for the erection or alteration of a building for educational purposes provided consents were filed of 80% of the owners of property fronting on the streets enclosing the block within which lies the property intended for such use. This amendment is invalid. It violates the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment [***3] of the Federal Constitution and section 6 of article I of the State Constitution. Since no triable issue of fact is presented, petitioner's application for an order directing that a building permit for the erection of additional school buildings be issued should be granted.

2. The effect of the amendment would be that school buildings could not be erected as a matter of right in any of the residence districts, comprising 97% of the village territory. The remaining 3% is not only not available for such use but would be impractical for it. A small number of adjoining property owners could thus determine, by dissent or indifference, and with no guides or standards, the kind of use petitioner might make of its property. Consent provisions may be proper when dealing with offensive uses of property, but an educational use furthers the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the community.

3. The ordinance is invalid also in that it provides no standards or guides for the exercise of the discretion of the board of appeals in approving or rejecting educational uses.

4. Petitioner was not required to seek relief under the 1941 amendment, nor was it required to attempt [***4] to show hardship under section 179-b of the Village Law. The restriction of the ordinance is an invasion of petitioner's property rights, and it need not seek as a matter of grace and special privilege what it should have as a matter of right.

5. The provisions of the 1938 ordinance permitting the erection of buildings for educational purposes are restored, insofar as petitioner's use is concerned, upon the determination that the amendment is invalid. There was no intention, in adding the amendment, to bar permits for educational buildings. The permits were merely subjected to limitations, which are here declared to be invalid.

 

641 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Teeval Co. v. Stern


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 346; 93 N.E.2d 884; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 814


Argued February 20, 1950; May 31, 1950.  
July 11, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: In the first, second, third and fourth above-entitled actions: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FROESSEL, JJ., concur; FULD, J., taking no part.

In the fifth and sixth above-entitled actions: LEWIS,  [***4] CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and FROESSEL, JJ., concur.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlord appealed a decision from the Municipal Court of the City of New York (New York), granting defendant tenant's motion for an order dismissing the landlord's complaint for insufficiency in law, on the ground that both the Sharkey Law and the state rent control statute were constitutional and dismissed the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The collection in the City of New York of any rent higher than that payable on March 1, 1949 was prohibited by the validated Sharkey Law for the period ending April 30, 1950, and for that beginning May 1, 1950, by the terms of the state rent control statute. In issue was whether the state rent control statute was invalid because thereby rents payable on and after May 1, 1950, in the city were rolled back to the March 1, 1949, levels. The court concluded that the state rent control statute was valid. Also in issue was whether the landlord was entitled to collect the arrears of rent for the period from October 1, 1949, to April 30, 1950, a period prior to the effective date of the state rent control statute. The Municipal Court of the City of New York had jurisdiction to adjudicate a claim for arrears of rent. Section 13-a of the state rent control statute attempted to abolish or at least to suspend that jurisdiction solely in respect of claims for arrears of rent that had accrued by operation of an act of Congress. The court found the legislature did not have the power to do so, thus the provisions of § 13-a were wholly void. The landlord could claim the arrears.


OUTCOME: The court reversed, without costs, the judgment below, and remitted the action to the lower court.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - landlord and tenant - rent regulation - appeal - (1) State Emergency Housing Rent Control Law (L. 1950, ch. 250), terminating Federal residential rent control as of May 1, 1950, and imposing State rent control, is constitutional - (2) Federal act expressed willingness of Congress to withdraw from field of rent control; State acted in exercise of police power reserved to States by Tenth Amendment of Federal Constitution - (3) State act need not closely follow pattern of Federal act - (4) State freezing of Federally controlled rents in New York City as of March 1, 1949, and elsewhere as of March 1, 1950, is justifiable classification - (5) Legislature enacted three rent control bills and Governor had legislative power to veto two and approve one (N.Y. Const., art. IV, § 7) - (6) though emergency law may now and then compel owner to suffer loss, it is not arbitrary exercise of police power - (7) so much of New York City Local Law No. 73 of 1949 (as ratified by L. 1950, ch. 1) as forbade collection of rent increases granted by Federal Housing Expediter unless authorized by temporary city housing rent commission,  [***5] was void (U.S. Const., art. VI, § 2) - (8) section 13-a of State rent control law, purporting to suspend jurisdiction of courts as to claims based on increases granted by Federal Housing Expediter, is likewise void - (9) but section 13-a is separable from rest of statute; landlords may maintain summary proceedings for nonpayment of arrears of rent consisting of increases granted by Federal Housing Expediter for period up to April 30, 1950, and may recover such increases - (10) where complaint of landlord seeking to recover such increases plus entire rent of May, 1950, was dismissed and landlord did not seek partial judgment for rolled-back amount of May rent, direct appeal lay to Court of Appeals but sole question was constitutionality of statute; hence, although dismissal reversed, no recovery may be had for rent of May, 1950 - (11) since Federal rent control in this State has been terminated, those appeals which involve only questions of conflict between local law and Federal act as to landlords' right to possession, are academic and must be dismissed.

1. The State Emergency Housing Rent Control Law (L. 1950, ch. 250) (1) terminated as of May 1, 1950, Federal rent control in [***6] this State, (2) froze at the levels of March 1, 1949, residential rents in the city of New York that had theretofore been controlled either by the Federal acts or by New York City local laws, and (3) froze as of March 1, 1950, residential rents that elsewhere in the State had been controlled by the Federal acts. These provisions are constitutional and valid.

2. Congress had expressed its willingness to withdraw from the field of rent control in the States and to permit them to occupy that field. (Housing and Rent Act of 1947, as amd.; U.S. Code, tit. 50, Appendix, § 1894, subd. [j], par. [1]. ) On the strength of that declaration, the Legislature of this State passed the rent control statute in the exercise of the inherent police power reserved to the States by the Tenth Amendment of the Federal Constitution.

3. The State rent control statute (§ 1) indicates the dissatisfaction of the Legislature with some of the results of Federal rent control. The Legislature had reasons of its own for not following more closely than it did the pattern of the Federal system of rent control and, this being so, it is not for this court to say that the Legislature was bound to take [***7] a different course.

4. The freezing of rents in the city of New York as of one date (March 1, 1949) and elsewhere in the State as of another date (March 1, 1950) is not an arbitrary classification.

5. The Legislature did not delegate its powers when it enacted three different rent control bills, of which the Governor approved one and vetoed two. In exercising his power to approve or veto legislation the Governor performs a legislative function (N.Y. Const., art. IV, § 7).

6. It cannot be said that the State rent control statute will deprive landlords of a fair return on their investment. The State statute was enacted to meet a passing emergency. It does not contemplate a taking of the property of any landlord. Even though it may, now and then, compel an owner to operate his real property at a loss, the statute is not for that reason to be condemned as an arbitrary use of the police power.

7. So much of New York City Local Law No. 73 of 1949 (Administrative Code, § U41-7.0, purportedly validated by L. 1950, ch. 1) as undertook to forbid collection of rent increases granted by the Federal Housing Expediter was void. It was not consistent and concurrent with the [***8] Federal act, but was rather an attempt to override the Federal rent-fixing formula. It was in conflict with the supremacy clause of the Federal Constitution (art. VI, § 2) which states: "This Constitution, and the Laws of the United States which shall be made in Pursuance thereof * * * shall be the supreme Law of the Land; and the Judges in every State shall be bound thereby, any Thing in the Constitution or Laws of any State to the Contrary notwithstanding." In actions or summary proceedings based on nonpayment of such increases, it was, therefore, not necessary to allege compliance with the local law.

8. Section 13-a of the State rent control law (L. 1950, ch. 250), which attempts to abolish or at least to suspend the jurisdiction of the courts in respect of claims for arrears of rent consisting of rent increases in the city of New York granted by the Federal Housing Expediter after March 1, 1949, is void. Such arrears of rent have accrued by operation of an act of the Congress of the United States and the Federal law is supreme. The question is not one of degree or of reasonableness of the State statute. The power which the Legislature assumed to exercise in enacting section [***9] 13-a does not exist.

9. But the invalidity of section 13-a of the State rent control statute does not vitiate any other provision thereof. Section 13-a has been plainly treated by the Legislature as a distinct and separable part of its statutory plan. Landlords may therefore recover, and may maintain summary proceedings for nonpayment of arrears of rent consisting of increases granted by the Federal Housing Expediter for the period prior to the effective date of State rent control, May 1, 1950.

10. In those cases where landlords sought a judgment for both (a) the amounts of increases granted by the Federal Housing Expediter and unpaid by the tenants for the period up to April 30, 1950, and (b) the entire rent for May, 1950, dismissals by the Municipal Court should be reversed. However, as to the amount of unpaid rent for May, 1950 (but without the Federal increase), recovery could have been had in the Municipal Court.The landlords were nevertheless content to have such complaints dismissed unless the tenants were to be held liable for the full sum demanded. Thus, the landlords' appeals were rightly taken directly to the Court of Appeals, upon the ground that the only question [***10] involved was the constitutionality of a State or local law; and, although the dismissals should be reversed, such landlords appellants can have no recovery of rent for the month of May, 1950.

11. Since Federal rent control in this State has been terminated, questions now presented upon reargument of the appeals in another action and in a summary proceeding - whether the Federal act was unconstitutionally interfered with by the requirements of New York City Local Law No. 73 of 1949 as to the eviction of tenants (a) where the Federal Housing Expediter had decontrolled an apartment in order to permit the landlord to subdivide it into smaller units, and (b) where the Federal Housing Expediter had authorized the landlord to institute proceedings to regain possession of an apartment for the immediate purpose of permanently withdrawing it from the rental market - have become academic, and accordingly those two appeals must be dismissed.

 

642 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Szwarce v. Buenaventura


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 558; 93 N.E.2d 448; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 905


Argued February 20, 1950  
May 25, 1950, decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District (New York) affirmed a filiation order of a trial court to the extent that it determined that the father was the father of the mother's child, reversed the order to the extent that it ordered the father to pay the mother's counsel fees, and modified the order by reducing child support payments. Both parties appealed.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the mother claimed that the appellate division erred in reversing the award of counsel fees. The father claimed that the award of counsel fees was properly reversed because there was no specific provision in the New York City Criminal Courts Act for the awarding of counsel fees in a paternity proceeding. He also alleged that N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 120, which allowed for counsel fees, did not apply to a proceeding in New York City. The court noted that §61(4) of the New York City Criminal Courts Act and N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 120 were identical except the words "including counsel fees" was inserted in the Domestic Relations Law whereas the Criminal Courts Act referred to "expenses." The court held that the Domestic Relations Law was not by its provisions or otherwise, limited to any particular portion of the State. Further, the court held that it specifically vested jurisdiction over paternity proceedings pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §§ 122(3), § 135. Also, the court held that because a harmonious construction could be had of the Domestic Relations Law and the Criminal Courts Act, they were to be construed together.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the Appellate Division insofar as it modified the amount to be paid in child support. The court reversed the order to the extent that it reversed the trial court's order awarding counsel fees to the mother.


HEADNOTES

Children born out of wedlock - paternity proceeding - counsel fees - Appellate Division affirmed order of filiation made by Court of Special Sessions of City of New York, but denied application for counsel fees - contentions by defendant that finding that he was father of child not supported by evidence; that evidence as to reputation of mother of child in foreign State had been improperly excluded; that since New York City Criminal Courts Act contained no provision for awarding counsel fees, and domestic Relations Law (§ 120) permitting award of counsel fees was not applicable to paternity proceeding in New York City, application for such fees had been properly denied - order affirmed.

 

643 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Robinson v. County of Broome


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 524; 93 N.E.2d 77; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 877


Argued April 13, 1950  
May 18, 1950, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - special or "local" laws - town welfare districts - action for judgment declaring invalid section 75-a [***4] of Social Welfare Law which provides that town with population of 50,000, having powers of city in county public welfare district, may elect to constitute itself town public welfare district - contention that statute was special or "local" law relating specially to one county and was violative of article IX of State Constitution, insofar as it purported to allow town of Union to withdraw from Broome County welfare unit - judgment dismissing complaint properly affirmed.

 

644 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Murphy v. Jackson


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 540; 93 N.E.2d 346; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 886


Argued April 13, 1950  
May 18, 1950, decided


HEADNOTES

Habeas corpus - statutory presumption of illegal possession of machine gun by one on premises where gun found - relator, convicted of possessing machine gun in violation of subdivision 1-a of section 1897 of Penal Law, asserts unconstitutionality of statute insofar as it rendered presence of machine gun presumptive evidence of its illegal possession by him - order dismissing writ of habeas corpus affirmed on ground that there was sufficient evidence to support conviction apart from statutory presumption, and [**3] that it was unnecessary to pass upon constitutionality of statute.

 

645 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New Rochelle v. Stevens


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 754; 92 N.E.2d 460; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 1535


Submitted April 10, 1950  
April 13, 1950, decided


HEADNOTES

Appeal - Court of Appeals - constitutional questions - appeal, on constitutional grounds, from judgment of Appellate Division unanimously affirming judgment entered upon order of County Court which granted motion by plaintiff for order under rule 113 of Rules of Civil Practice striking out answer and for summary judgment in favor of plaintiff in action to foreclose tax liens pursuant to title 3 of article VII-A of Tax Law - defendant alleged that subdivision 4 of section 165-h of Tax Law, which provides that sale directed by court shall be at public auction, was unconstitutional - motion to dismiss appeal granted and appeal dismissed on ground no substantial constitutional question presented.

 

646 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Bakers Mut. Ins. Co.


Court of Appeals of New York


301 N.Y. 21; 92 N.E.2d 49; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 838


Argued January 5, 1950.  
April 13, 1950, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, DESMOND, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur with LOUGHRAN, Ch. J.; FROESSEL, J., dissents in opinion in which CONWAY, J., concurs.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, an employer's carrier, sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the first judicial department (New York), which affirmed an order of the trial court that denied an application by the employer's carrier to compel respondent, the Department of Health of the City of New York, to produce certain documents before a referee of the Workmen's Compensation Board. The employer's carrier appealed.


OVERVIEW: The court held that the Sanitary Code of the City of New York had within that city the force and effect of state law. The court determined that persons subpoenaed could assert against the compulsion of such process whatever privileges they had under the common law or statute. New York City, N.Y., Sanitary Code § 33 gave privacy to the confidential medical report at issue as a means of equipping public officials for the discharge of functions committed to them for the public good. Further, § 33 made a confidential medical report open to inspection only for scientific purposes approved by the New York City Board of Health. The court found that no provision of the state sanitary code related to the city of New York and every provision of the state sanitary code applied to and was effective in all portions of the state except the city of New York unless stated otherwise pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2-b.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Evidence - privileged communications - confidential medical report of cause of death - health - municipal corporations - statutory construction - (1) New York City Sanitary Code (§ 33), which provides for certificate of death from natural causes, validly further provides that separate confidential medical report is privileged communication [***2] not subject to subpoena - (2) application for warrant in aid of subpoena duces tecum to compel city health department to produce confidential medical report before workmen's compensation referee, properly denied - (3) whether reasons for enactment of section 33 of Sanitary Code outbalanced by reasons which might be urged against it is legislative question not to be reagitated in courts - (4) privileged communication under section 33 consistent with subpoena provisions of Workmen's Compensation Law ( § 119) - (5) city itself not given access to confidential medical reports, since they are open to inspection only "for scientific purposes approved by the Board of Health" - (6) policy of section 33, adopted in 1938, tacitly approved by amendments of section 2-b of Public Health Law in 1946 and 1947.

1. A certificate of death filed with the department of health of the city of New York by a physician set forth the name and residence of the decedent, the time and place of death, that the decedent was a white man sixty-two years old who had been under medical care since December, 1946, and further certified that the "death was not caused, directly or indirectly, by accident, homicide,  [***3] suicide, acute or chronic poisoning, or in any suspicious or unusual manner, and that it was due to NATURAL CAUSES more fully described in the confidential medical report filed with the [city] Department of Health." The Sanitary Code of the city (§ 33) provides, as to deaths from natural causes, that a certificate of death and a separate "confidential medical report" shall be filed. The section further provides that the latter report "shall be deemed not a part of such certificate" of death, but, on the contrary, "shall be regarded and treated as a confidential and privileged communication, and shall not be subject to subpoena or open to inspection for any reason whatsoever, other than for scientific purposes approved by the [city] Board of Health." This provision is valid.

2. The city department of health properly refused to produce the confidential medical report upon a subpoena duces tecum returnable before a workmen's compensation referee (Workmen's Compensation Law, § 119) upon a claim for death benefits. A warrant to compel its production was properly denied.

3. Whether the reasons in favor of such a privileged communication in the city of New York, as created [***4] by section 33, outbalance the reasons that may be urged against it was a legislative question which has been settled by the authorities having jurisdiction. The matter cannot be reagitated in the courts.

4. Section 33 of the Sanitary Code is consistent with the subpoena provisions of section 119 of the Workmen's Compensation Law and does not conflict with subdivision b of section 558 of the New York City Charter which authorizes the board of health to (1) add to, amend or repeal the Sanitary Code, (2) publish additional provisions for security of life and health in the city, and (3) confer additional powers on the city department of health not inconsistent with the Constitution or laws of the State. Persons subpoenaed may assert against the compulsion of such process whatever privileges they enjoy under the common law or by statute.

5. Since the confidential medical reports are open to inspection only "for scientific purposes approved by the Board of Health", it cannot be said that section 33 gives to the city, as an employer of labor, unequal and unrestricted access to such reports.

6. Under the Public Health Law ( §§ 2-b, 4, 38, 394) the New York City Sanitary Code has [***5] the effect of State law within the city. Since section 33 was adopted in 1938, the Legislature has twice declared that no provision of the State Sanitary Code shall relate to the city of New York (Public Health Law, § 2-b, as amd. by L. 1946, ch. 166, L. 1947, ch. 293). This tacit statutory sanction of the policy of section 33 leaves no room for judicial consideration of any contrary policy.

 

647 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Clay v. County of Monroe


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 724; 92 N.E.2d 61; 1950 N.Y. LEXIS 1504


Argued February 21, 1950  
April 6, 1950, decided


HEADNOTES

Appeal - Court of Appeals - constitutional questions - appeal, on asserted constitutional grounds, from judgment entered on order of Special Term which granted defendants' motion for judgment on pleadings dismissing complaint in action for judgment declaring unconstitutional resolution of Board of Supervisors imposing general business tax for privilege of carrying on profession of law, and statutory authority therefor (L. 1947, ch. 278; L. 1948, ch. 651) - appeal dismissed on ground questions other than constitutional validity of statutes were involved.

 

648 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wasservogel v. Meyerowitz


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 125; 89 N.E.2d 712; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 894


Argued October 4, 1949.  
December 29, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DYE and BROMLEY, JJ., concur; FULD, J., taking no part.

Ordered accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landlords and appellee tenants were involved in a dispute over whether the landlords were entitled to a retroactive rent increase granted by the Federal Office of Rent Control. The landlords appealed judgments of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), finding that the landlords were only entitled to the increases prospectively from the date the increase was granted.


OVERVIEW: The landlord filed summary proceedings against four tenants seeking to evict them for nonpayment. At the time of the landlords' applications to the Federal rent officials, all four tenants were occupying their respective apartments under unexpired written leases, but before the date of the orders increasing the maximum rents allowable, all four leases had expired by their terms, and none of them had been renewed, so that, when the federal orders came through, all four respondents were statutory tenants. The landlords demanded payment at the increased rents: prospectively, to which tenants agreed, and also retroactively back to the application dates, as the orders provided. Each tenant denied any obligation to make good the added amounts of rent for the period elapsed from the application date to the order date. On appeal, the court held that the rent increases became effective on the respective dates of expiration of the four leases and the landlords were entitled to the increased rent from that date.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the lower court was modified to provide that the landlords were entitled to rent increases from the date of expiration of each tenants' lease.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - landlord and tenant - Federal rent regulation - retroactive rent increases without notice to statutory tenants - (1) under Federal rent regulation, Federal Housing Expediter validly ordered [***2] rent increases retroactive to date of landlords' petitions, without notice to tenants whose leases had meantime expired; but, under provision in leases that if, during term of lease or any renewal or extension thereof, increase were Federally allowed tenant should pay increased rental on first day of following month, such increases are collectible only back to expiration dates of leases - (2) such provision in leases not carried over into statutory tenancies - (3) fixation of maximum emergency rents of statutory tenants is not judicial but legislative act, and was validly delegated by Congress to administrative agency without requirement of notice - (4) State courts may not overrule Federal Housing Expediter's determination - (5) omission from Federal Housing and Rent Acts of 1947 and 1948 of provision of Emergency Price Control Act of 1942 giving exclusive jurisdiction to Federal Emergency Court of Appeals to determine validity of Federal rent regulations, did not give State courts such power - (6) during pendency of petitions landlords had to accept rents theretofore fixed and are not thereby estopped from collecting retroactive increases.

1. Under the provisions of the Controlled [***3] Housing Rent Regulations, the Federal Housing Expediter, on petition of landlords for increases in the maximum allowable rents on the ground of hardship, may authorize rent increases retroactively to the date of the petitions. Notice of such application was not required by the regulations. In this case, the tenants had leases when the applications were filed in September, 1947, but by the time the retroactive orders were made in April, 1948, all the leases had expired. It was stated in the leases that: "The rent herein provided for is the maximum rent which the Landlord may collect under the O.P.A. [predecessor of the Expediter] rent regulations in force at the time of the execution of this lease. In the event that at any time during the term of this lease, or any renewal or extension thereof, such regulations * * * are cancelled or modified, or if the O.P.A. grants an increase * * * the tenant will pay a rental of [$] per month or as much thereof as is legally permissible or allowed, commencing the first day of the calendar month following the cancellation or modification of such regulation, or the allowance of an increase". The retroactive increases are valid and collectible,  [***4] but not further back than the expiration dates of the leases - November 1, 1947, December 1, 1947, and April 1, 1948, respectively - since such lease-fixed rentals controlled until expiration. Final orders of dispossess in summary proceedings should be modified accordingly.

2. After the leases expired, the above-quoted provision was not carried over into the ensuing statutory tenancy. Each tenant remained in the landlord's property, not by virtue of any agreement, but by virtue of the compulsion which the rent law and regulation exerted on the landlord to allow the tenant to remain. Some provisions of a lease are read into a statutory tenancy, so as to work out a complete relationship, but not a provision which the parties themselves specifically restricted to the term of the lease and any renewal or extension thereof. This provision, therefore, has no effect, except to prevent any increase from reaching back earlier than the expiration dates of the leases.

3. Their leases having expired, the tenants became statutory tenants; that is, tenants who hold over not because they have any property right or estate in the premises but because emergency laws forbid their eviction [***5] as long as they pay the rent. The orders for retroactive rent increases without notice to them did not unconstitutionally deprive them of property or due process. Fixation of the maximum rent to be paid by a statutory tenant during his emergency occupancy is not a judicial, but a legislative act, and the actual computation thereof was validly delegated by Congress to an administrative agency, the Housing Expediter. Congress itself could have fixed emergency rents without any hearing or notice to landlords or tenants, and Congress need not make that requirement when it delegates the task to an administrative agency.

4. Moreover, the State courts, when shown the Federal Housing Expediter's determination, may not overrule it for supposed invalidity. Indeed, under the supremacy clause of the United States Constitution (art. VI), the State courts, in appropriate proceedings, are under a positive duty to enforce an administrative order by which a Federal agency performs the functions assigned to it by Congress.

5. Congress omitted from the Housing and Rent Acts of 1947 and 1948 the provision of the Emergency Price Control Act of 1942 which had conferred exclusive jurisdiction [***6] on the Federal Emergency Court of Appeals and on the United States Supreme Court to determine the validity of Federal rent regulations. That deletion left the law where it had been before - that State courts have no jurisdiction to review Federal administrative orders. Perhaps suits may be brought in the Federal District Courts, but that point is not for the State courts to decide.

6. During the pendency of their petitions to the Federal Housing Expediter for rent increases, the landlords were forbidden to accept more than the rents theretofore fixed, and, therefore, there is no basis for charging them thereby with waiver or estoppel as to the collection of the retroactive rent increases.

 

649 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


F. T. B. Corp. v. Goodman


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 140; 89 N.E.2d 865; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 896


Argued November 14, 1949.  
December 29, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and BROMLEY, JJ., concur.

Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landlord sought review of a decision of the Municipal Court of the City of New York (New York), which dismissed the landlord's petition to recover possession of respondent tenant's apartment for nonpayment of rent.


OVERVIEW: The landlord brought a petition in summary proceedings to recover possession of the tenant's apartment for nonpayment of rent. The trial court denied the petition without prejudice because the landlord did not comply with Local Law No. 73, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § U41-7.0. The landlord appealed from that decision and claimed that the local law was not valid under the state constitution. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's decision, holding that the local law was not consistent with the Civil Practice Act, the state statute that regulated summary proceedings, because it imposed prerequisite "additional restrictions" upon the right of the landlord to evict the tenant from the apartment. The court ruled that the inconsistency violated the language of the Home Rule Amendment of the state constitution that limited the city's power to only adopt local laws that were not inconsistent with the laws of the state. The court remitted the matter to the trial court for further proceedings.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decision that denied the landlord's petition to recover possession of the tenant's apartment and remitted to the trial court for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - landlord and tenant - local law fixing rents and restricting evictions - separability - (1) direct appeal may be taken to Court of Appeals from final order of Municipal Court which dismissed summary proceedings for nonpayment of rent without prejudice to new proceedings after landlord shall have complied with local law; local law is "statutory provision of the state", constitutionality of which is only question to be considered on appeal (N.Y. Const., art. VI, § 7, subd. [2] ) - (2) Local Law No. 73 of 1949 of City of New York, which declares [***2] emergency, fixes maximum rents of apartments, and requires certificate from city commission before commencement of any summary proceedings, is invalid as "inconsistent with the * * * laws of the state" (N.Y. Const., art. IX, § 12; Civ. Prac. Act, art. 83); order of Municipal Court reversed - (3) in view of separability clause in local law, question whether rent-fixing portion is separable from invalid restrictions on summary proceedings does not turn on division into sections but on whether city council would have enacted one part if aware other was void; entire text shows that city council regarded both parts as essential to declared purpose; severance and remodeling beyond judicial power.

1. A local law of a city is a "statutory provision of the state" within the meaning of the State Constitution (art. VI, § 7, subd. [2] ) which allows an appeal to the Court of Appeals "as of right, from a judgment or order of a court of record of original jurisdiction which finally determines an action or special proceeding where the only question involved on the appeal is the validity of a statutory provision of the state or of the United States under the constitution of the state or of [***3] the United States". A direct appeal may thus be taken from a final order of the Municipal Court of the City of New York - a court of record (Judiciary Law, § 2) - which, in summary proceedings for nonpayment of rent, had dismissed a landlord's petition "without prejudice" to a new proceeding after compliance by the landlord with the requirements of Local Law No. 73 of 1949 of the City of New York (Administrative Code, § U41-7.0), since the only question to be considered on appeal is the validity of the local law under the Federal and State Constitutions.

2. Local Law No. 73 declares that an emergency exists within the city by reason of a shortage of apartments and demands for excessive rent increases, fixes maximum rents of apartments at the amounts payable on March 1, 1949, authorizes a commission to make reasonable rent adjustments consistent with the emergency, requires that a certificate be obtained from the commission before an action or proceeding is commenced for collection or nonpayment of a rent greater than that payable on March 1, 1949, and before a tenant is excluded from possession, and further requires that before commencement of any summary proceedings other than [***4] for nonpayment of a rent no greater than that of March 1, 1949, application for a certificate be made to the commission, setting forth in detail the facts upon which such action or proceeding is based. The prerequisite restrictions thus imposed on a landlord's right under State law to maintain summary proceedings and obtain judgment for rent in arrears (Civ. Prac. Act, art. 83, §§ 1410, 1425; § 1; N.Y. City Mun. Ct. Code, § 15; Judiciary Law, § 2) are "inconsistent with the * * * laws of the state" (N.Y. Const., art. IX, § 12; see, too, City Home Rule Law, §§ 11, 12) and render the local law unconstitutional and void. Final order of the Municipal Court should be reversed and the matter remitted to it for further proceedings.

3. The local law has a separability clause. The question whether the rentfixing provisions are separable from the restrictions on summary proceedings does not turn upon the law's division into sections or subdivisions, but upon whether the city council would have enacted the law if aware that the eviction provisions were invalid. An examination of the entire text shows that the city council regarded the rent and the eviction restrictions as equally [***5] essential to the declared purpose of the law. Hence, the one set of restrictions cannot be separated from the other except by a remodeling on a scale which would be beyond the judicial power.

 

650 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Loab Estates, Inc. v. Druhe


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 176; 90 N.E.2d 25; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 901


Argued November 29, 1949.  
December 29, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Orders affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landlord challenged an order of the Municipal Court of the City of New York, Borough of the Bronx (New York), which dismissed his petition to evict respondent tenants.


OVERVIEW: The landlord claimed that his petition to evict certain tenants had been improperly dismissed because New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § U41-7.0(g) violated U.S. Const. Amend. XIV. The provision in question restricted the landlord's right to evict tenants from apartments located within the city of New York. Essentially, the landlord claimed that the questioned provision deprived him of his property by preventing him from withdrawing from the business of renting. The court affirmed. The court found that under its police power New York had the authority to cut down the landlord's property rights without paying him just compensation. The court reasoned that the restriction imposed on the landlord was designed to meet a pressing and immediate exigency, namely, it prevented chaos and confusion. Under § U41-7.0(g) the landlord was restricted from evicting the tenants until he found them another suitable place to live. Finally, the landlord did not claim that he had been deprived a "reasonable return" on his property and he did not challenge the existence of the emergency that supported the imposition of § U41-7.0(g).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order that dismissed the landlord's petition to evict certain tenants.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - landlord and tenant - validity of local law restricting evictions - (1) direct appeal may be taken to Court of Appeals from final order of New York Municipal Court in dispossess proceedings, where only question on appeal is constitutionality of local law - (2) no conflict exists between Federal Housing and Rent Act of 1949 and requirement of local law (Administrative Code, § U41-7.0, subd. g) that landlord wishing to demolish housing accommodations must make provision to relocate tenants at rents no greater than they have paid; section 301 of Federal act declaring that it shall not "be construed to require any person to offer any housing accommodations for rent" does not impose national policy on States - (3) local law in temporarily denying right of landlord to withdraw property from rental market, does not deprive [***2] landlord of property without due process of law.

1. A direct appeal may be taken to the Court of Appeals from a final order of the Municipal Court of the City of New York in dispossess proceedings, in a case where the only question to be considered on the appeal is the constitutionality of a local law (Civ. Prac. Act, § 588, subd. 4).

2. A requirement of the local law (Administrative Code, § U41-7.0, subd. g, as validated by L. 1948, chs. 4, 699) that a landlord must make provision for relocating his apartment tenants in comparable quarters at rents no greater than they have paid, when he seeks to obtain a certificate from the temporary city housing rent commission for permission to evict such tenants in order to demolish the housing accommodations and adapt the property to commercial uses, and the omission from the local law of any provision permitting eviction for the purpose of withdrawing accommodations permanently from the rental market, are not in conflict with the letter or policy of the eviction provisions of the Federal Housing and Rent Act of 1949 (U.S. Code, tit. 50, Appendix, § 1899). Section 301 of the Federal act which states that the act shall not "be construed [***3] to require any person to offer any housing accommodations for rent" merely declares the effect of the act and cannot be read as imposing a national policy upon the States.

3. The local law, in temporarily denying the landlord's right to withdraw his property from the rental market, does not deprive him of property without due process of law.

 

651 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Consolidated Edison Co. v. Maltbie


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 196; 90 N.E.2d 35; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 904


Argued November 30, 1949.  
December 29, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, DESMOND and BROMLEY, JJ., concur with FULD, J.; CONWAY and DYE, JJ., dissent and vote to affirm on the opinion of Justice SANTRY at the Appellate Division.

Order reversed, etc. [See 300 N.Y. 645.] 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, commissioner and Public Service Commission of the State of New York, challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) that annulled a commission order fixing temporary rates to be charged by petitioner utility for electrical service. The utility asserted that the commission violated the mandate of N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 114 (1934).


OVERVIEW: The commission appealed, as of right, the order of the appellate court annulling the commission's order fixing temporary electric rates for the utility. In setting the rates, the commission acted under N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 114 (1934) and ordered a 10 percent reduction in the total charges made to every consumer for electric service until final rates were determined. Although the appellate court thereafter annulled the commission's order, the rates continued in effect through stays of the appellate decision pending the court's review. The utility asserted that the commission violated the mandate of § 114 that the temporary rates be fixed and determined so as to yield a return of not less than five percent upon the original cost, less accrued depreciation, of the physical property of the utility. It urged that the commission erred by estimating the accrued depreciation, rather than using the reserves accumulated for retirement or replacement, as shown in the utility's books. The court disagreed and held that the commission had authority to estimate the accrued depreciation. The recoupment provisions of § 114 applied to prevent injustice if a temporary rate order was set too low.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate order annulling the decision of the commission and confirmed the commission's order setting a temporary rate for the electric service provide by the utility.


HEADNOTES

Public utilities - temporary rates - statutory construction - (1) temporary rate order properly made by Public Service Commission after close of hearings on permanent rates - (2) temporary rates must yield not less than 5% return upon original cost of property "less accrued depreciation" ( Public Service Law, § 114); commission properly made its own estimate of accrued depreciation - (3) corporate books which, under first paragraph [***2] of section 114 must "show currently * * * reserves accumulated * * * for the retirement or replacement of * * * property", are merely presumptive evidence of actual "accrued depreciation" under second paragraph of section; commission lacks power to compel corporation to accumulate reserves in amounts other than corporation's own judgment dictates - (4) such construction gives full play to all requirements of statute and is consistent with all of its objectives as to promptness, accuracy and effect of temporary rates in determining permanent rates; if temporary rates too low, section provides for recoupment.

1. Section 114 of the Public Service Law authorizes the Public Service Commission to fix temporary rates to be charged by a public utility corporation "pending * * * final determination" of a permanent rate proceeding. It is no objection to the validity of such an order that it was made after the close of hearings and pending final determination of permanent rates.

2. Under the second paragraph of section 114, the temporary rates shall be sufficient to yield a return of not less than 5% "upon the original cost, less accrued depreciation, of the physical property of said [***3] public utility company". The utility corporation's books listed $160,000,000 as a reserve for depreciation, but a witness for the corporation indicated that the actual depreciation exceeded that figure by some $40,000,000. Other and variant figures are in the record. An engineer employed by the commission testified that $95,000,000 was the amount of the deficiency in the reserve for depreciation. On all the evidence the commission was authorized to make its own estimate, which is not a final determination, that the accrued depreciation was actually $255,000,000, or $95,000,000 more than the book reserve of $160,000,000.
