3. The provision as to "accrued depreciation" in the second paragraph of section 114 is not the same as the provision in the first paragraph of the section that the commission may require the corporation to keep records which "show currently * * * the reserves accumulated * * * for the retirement or replacement of * * * property." In fixing permanent rates, the amount of accrued depreciation would have to be ascertained and reserves shown on the books, no matter how denominated, would not be controlling. The commission may require that information as to the [***4] amount of accrued depreciation shall be preserved somewhere in the books and records of the corporation, but the commission lacks power to require the corporation to accumulate reserves in any amount other than the corporation's own judgment dictates. The relationship between the first and second paragraphs is given effect if it be presumed, as would ordinarily be the case, that, for purposes of a temporary rate order, the reserves under the first paragraph represent the accrued depreciation specified in the second paragraph - for such reserves unquestionably constitute some evidence of accrued depreciation. But this presumption is not made conclusive.

4. This construction gives full play to all of the statutory prescriptions and is consistent with all of its objectives. Promptness will be achieved for reliance will continue to be placed upon the amount actually accumulated by the corporation rather than upon an estimate by the commission, except where the former is known to be misleading. Substitution of a more accurate figure in the latter case would seem to be demanded if meaning is to be given to the direction of the third paragraph of the statute that "the effect" of temporary [***5] rates is an element to be weighed and considered in determining permanent rates. The value of experience under temporary rates is naturally increased in proportion to the correspondence between the base for such temporary rates and the base for permanent rates. If a temporary rate is later found to have been placed too low, the recoupment provisions of section 114 apply to prevent any injustice to the corporation.

 

652 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kunz


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 273; 90 N.E.2d 455; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 915


Argued October 5, 1949.  
December 29, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS and DYE, JJ., concur with DESMOND, J.; CONWAY, J., dissents in opinion; BROMLEY, J., dissents in separate opinion in which FULD, J., concurs.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York, Appellate Part (New York) which affirmed a magistrate court's judgment convicting defendant of unlawfully conducting a religious meeting without a permit in violation of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 435-7.0.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a clergyman who was arrested after he conducted a public meeting in which he disparaged two religions. Defendant was convicted by the magistrate court of violating § 435-7.0 because he conducted the meeting without a permit. The appellate court affirmed the trial court's conviction. The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment. Section 435-7.0, which made it unlawful for a clergyman to preach on a public street without first obtaining a permit from the police commissioner, was a valid, constitutional time, place, and manner restriction. First, the police commissioner gave a permit to almost every applicant and only allowed police control of such meetings to the extent of ensuring that traffic flow would not be impaired. Second, it was within the police commissioner's power under § 435-7.0 to revoke defendant's permit and to refuse to issue him a new one because defendant was engaging in behavior that incited riots. Such "fighting words" were not constitutionally protected speech. Thus, defendant was properly convicted of violating § 435-7.0 because he had no defense for conducting his religious meeting without a permit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court which affirmed the magistrate court's judgment convicting defendant of unlawfully conducting a religious meeting without a permit.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - municipal ordinances - meetings for religious purposes on city streets - police regulation - validity of requirement for permit - (1) clergyman convicted of violating ordinance forbidding preaching of religion on streets of New York City without permit; permit granted defendant had been revoked for denunciation of religions contrary to ordinance; conviction affirmed - (2) ordinance requires issuance of permit to clergyman and certain others and regulations give police control only [***2] by requiring advance notice of meeting and approval of location subject to traffic conditions; ordinance necessary street regulation; requirement of permit not unconstitutional here - (3) revocation of permit reviewable under article 78 of Civil Practice Act; impropriety of such revocation no defense here - (4) since defendant used permit to utter insults tending to incite disorder, public order and decency required that meetings be stopped.

1. A clergyman has been convicted of violating section 435-7.0 of the New York City Administrative Code which forbids any person to be instrumental in collecting an assemblage of persons for public worship or to ridicule religion or to preach atheism or agnosticism on the streets of the city, but authorizes preaching or expounding by one who has obtained a permit as an authorized representative of a religious, atheistic or agnostic group. When arrested, defendant was conducting a religious meeting but without the required permit. Upon this appeal he contends that the statute is unconstitutional on its face. The conviction should be affirmed.

2. As construed by the police department and as here applied, the ordinance is not unconstitutional [***3] either as allowing the police commissioner to determine as a censor who may address the public on the streets or as prohibiting ridicule of religion. Reading into the ordinance the governing police regulations, it is clear that, merely upon application therefor, such a permit is granted for one year to any of the persons listed in the ordinance. Police control of meetings is allowed only to the extent of requiring advance notice to a police captain who must approve of the location requested unless traffic conditions make it inexpedient to use that site for such purpose. So read, the law is no more than a necessary and reasonable regulation of the use for public meetings of the crowded streets of a great city.

3. After a hearing on charges, defendant's permit to speak was revoked because "contrary to the provisions of law under which the permit was issued" he had "ridiculed and denounced religion". Subsequent applications by defendant for permits were denied and at the time of his arrest for speaking without a permit, he was again delivering denunciations against the same religions. Power to revoke such a permit for cause, while not specifically mentioned, is implied and, in [***4] any case, alleged illegality of a revocation is reviewable by proceedings in the nature of certiorari (Civ. Prac. Act, art. 78). Moreover, impropriety of the revocation of a former license in this case was no defense.

4. While the prohibition against ridiculing or denouncing any religion - read by itself - might be thought unconstitutional, here, defendant got his permit with no questions asked as to what he would preach and he used the permit to utter insults and epithets tending to incite disorder. A police regulation, printed on the permit, stated that "all meetings must be conducted in an orderly manner". Public order and decency required that defendant be stopped.

 

653 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re TUTTLE


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 1; 87 N.E.2d 558; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 932; 10 A.L.R.2d 652; 49-2 U.S. Tax Cas. (CCH) P10,731; 38 A.F.T.R. (P-H) 734


Argued April 20, 1949.  
July 19, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) reversed a decree of the trial court insofar as it directed respondent insurance carrier to pay petitioner executors' proportionate share of federal and state taxes on certain life insurance policy proceeds allocated in accordance with N.Y. Decedent Estate Law § 124. The executors appealed.


OVERVIEW: The insured died, and his beneficiary collected $ 50,000 in life insurance proceeds. Three years later, the treasury department increased the gross estate by including the policy proceeds and assessed a deficiency. Because the beneficiary had spent all of the proceeds and then died, the executors brought an action against the insurance carrier to recover its alleged proportionate share of the taxes due on the policy proceeds under § 124. The trial court entered judgment in the executors' favor, but the appellate court reversed. On appeal, the court affirmed the reversal, finding that the insurance carrier was not liable for any portion of the taxes due on the policy proceeds because it was not "an interested person" under § 124 as it had no beneficial interest in the estate and did not expect to receive a share of the decedent's assets. The court found that the carrier was not "one in possession of estate property" under § 124 because it had long since distributed the entire amount of the policy's proceeds to the policy's beneficiary. The court also found that 26 U.S.C.S. §§ 826, 827 did not provide any basis on which to hold the insurance carrier liable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the reversal of the trial court's ruling that the insurance carrier was liable for some portion of the estate taxes and declared that the insurance carrier was not liable for any portion of the estate taxes associated with the disbursement of the life insurance policy proceeds.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - apportionment of estate taxes - (1) beneficiary of life insurance policy died destitute three years after receipt of proceeds of policy; executors of insured's estate which paid deficiency in Federal estate taxes seek reimbursement from insurer of portion of tax allocable to policy; petition [***2] properly dismissed - (2) executor's right to reimbursement dependent on section 124 of Decedent Estate Law authorizing recovery by executor of proportionate amount of tax from "whomever is in possession" of taxable property or from "persons interested" in estate; insurer in neither class - (3) "possession" to be determined as of time reimbursement sought; insurer not party "in possession" since entire proceeds already paid over - (4) insurer not person "interested in estate" since term means one who has beneficial interest therein - (5) insurer not liable under Internal Revenue Code which authorizes proportionate recovery of taxes from "beneficiary" of insurance and also from "transferee" or "trustee" of property not coming to executor.

1. Shortly after the death of one who was insured under a policy of life insurance issued by respondent the entire proceeds of the policy were paid to the beneficiary. Three years later a deficiency of Federal estate taxes based on such payment was assessed by the Treasury Department and the claim paid by the executors. Meantime the beneficiary had died destitute after dissipating the funds received. In this proceeding by the executors to have [***3] that portion of the Federal estate tax allocable to the policy of insurance charged against the insurance carrier, an order of the Appellate Division dismissing the petition should be affirmed.

2. The executor's right to seek reimbursement from the insurance carrier under section 124 of the Decedent Estate Law which provides for the apportionment of estate taxes depends upon whether the insurance carrier falls within one of the two classes of persons named in the statute. Section 124 states that where property to be taxed does not come into the possession of the executor, he shall recover the proportionate amount of the tax from "whomever is in possession" of the taxable property or from the "persons interested in the estate" as defined in section 249-m of the Tax Law. Under the facts of the instant case, the insurance carrier cannot be said to fall in either class.

3. Since the insurer paid out the entire proceeds of the policy to the beneficiary in 1937, it is not now in fact "in possession" of any of the proceeds of the policy. The period for determining "possession" is at the time when the executor seeks reimbursement. On the theory that the proceeds were segregated [***4] into two separate funds, one for taxes which should have been paid over, the insurance company would be made a withholding agent for the tax authority. Section 124 is an apportionment statute, not a tax statute. ( Matter of Scott, 249 App. Div. 524, affd. 274 N.Y. 538, distinguished.)

4. Liability may not be imposed on the insurer as a "person interested in the estate" on the ground that it "received" the property, and obtained a "benefit" on discharge of its obligation. A "person interested in the estate" can only mean a person who has a beneficial interest in the estate and who expects to share or has received a share of the assets left by the decedent.

5. Nor may sanction for the executor's action be found in the Internal Revenue Code (U.S. Code, tit. 26, § 826, subd. [c]; § 827, subd. [b] ) which makes no general provision for apportionment of taxes. The statute - which provides for recovery by the executor of taxes paid on proceeds of insurance receivable by a beneficiary - directs recovery from "such beneficiary" of the proper portion of the total tax but a beneficiary of the proceeds is the only one on whom liability is cast. Under another provision, personal [***5] liability for the proportionate share of unpaid taxes attributable to property not coming into the hands of the executor is imposed on the transferee, trustee or beneficiary. An insurance company is not a transferee or trustee and is, therefore, not covered by the statute.

 

654 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Beloff v. Consolidated Edison Co.


Court of Appeals of New York


300 N.Y. 11; 87 N.E.2d 561; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 933


Argued June 3, 1949.  
July 19, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DYE, FULD and BROMLEY, JJ., concur.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the stockholders of the merged company, appealed the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed summary judgment in favor of defendant surviving corporation dismissing the first cause of action in the complaint, and granted the motion dismissing for insufficiency, but with leave to amend, the second, third, and fourth causes of action alleged in the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The stockholders attacked the constitutionality of N.Y. Stock Corporation Law § 85(1), (5), (7), which authorized the merger of electric, gas, or steam corporations if approved by the public service commission. The merging or taking corporation had to own 95 percent or more of the stock of the merged, or taken, corporation. Following the procedures set out in N.Y. Stock Corporation Law § 85, the company was merged into the corporation. The stockholders refused the appraisal proceedings and never accepted the price offered by the corporation for their stock. The stockholders claimed that their constitutional rights under U.S. Const. amend. XIV, § 1, N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6, and U.S. Const. art. I, § 10 were violated. The court affirmed the judgment below, holding that all causes of action were properly dismissed for insufficiency of law. The court found that N.Y. Stock Corporation Law § 85 was not unconstitutional. The remedy available to the stockholders once the merger took place was an appraisal. As minority stockholders, they had no constitutional right to deliberate, consult or vote on the merger, to have prior notice thereof, or prior opportunity to object.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgement below, which affirmed the grant of summary judgement in favor of the surviving corporation dismissing on the merits, the first cause of action set forth in the complaint, and granted a motion by the surviving corporation dismissing for insufficiency, but with leave to amend, the second, third and fourth causes of action alleged in the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Corporations - merger of public utility corporations - rights of dissenting stockholder - (1) utility corporation, of which defendant utility held 99.6% of stock, was merged into defendant under section 85 of Stock Corporation Law; plaintiffs, holders of few shares in merged corporation, neither took price offered by defendant for shares nor sought judicial appraisal [***2] thereof; in action to have merger declared invalid, complaint properly dismissed - (2) first cause of action alleges unconstitutionality of merger statute for lack of due process, equal protection of laws and impairment of contract rights; further causes allege ownership by merged corporation of choses in action against defendant; latter causes not available to individual stockholders nor actionable here by merged corporation since it no longer exists - (3) by virtue of power to amend charters of corporations (N.Y. Const., art. X, § 1) Legislature may make nonconfiscatory provision for merger of corporations - (4) on merger dissenting shareholder's only remedy is appraisal of stock (Stock Corporation Law, § 21); disabilities involved in merger constitute no deprivation of due process or contract rights - (5) where appraisal provided dissenting stockholder may not reject merger on assertion of injustice involved in appraisal - (6) statute permitting merger by utility corporations in case of less than 100% ownership not improper since applicable to all public utilities as class; such class may be differentiated from other corporations.

1. In 1945, following the procedures set out [***3] in section 85 of the Stock Corporation Law, there was merged into defendant another utility corporation of which defendant had held 99.6% of the stock for more than ten years. The resolution of merger provided for payment by defendant of $135 per share for such shares of the merged corporation as were not already owned by defendant, the surviving corporation. Plaintiffs, who held 59 shares of stock in the merged corporation, neither accepted the price offered nor took appraisal proceedings in accordance with a letter from defendant pointing out that, under section 21 of the Stock Corporation Law, stockholders unwilling to accept the offered price might have appraisers appointed to value their stock. In this action plaintiffs attack the merger as illegal on the ground that the statute is unconstitutional. All the causes of action set forth in the complaint were properly dismissed for insufficiency in law.

2. The first cause of action alleges that section 85, permitting a merger without notice to or consent of the minority, deprives plaintiffs and the merged corporation of their property without due process of law, denies them the equal protection of the laws and impairs the [***4] contract rights of plaintiffs and of their corporation. The second, third and fourth causes of action, similarly brought by plaintiffs for themselves and for all other stockholders who would join, set out transactions between the two corporations before the merger in which it is said that the surviving defendant took advantage of its position to benefit itself to the detriment of the other corporation. Insofar as these three counts are pleaded by plaintiffs individually, they are not maintainable since no individual stockholder has any such right of action. Insofar as they are set forth on behalf of the merged corporation, the alleged wrongs are actionable only if the merged corporation still exists and, since section 85 and its application to this merger are not unconstitutional, the sufficiency of these causes need not be further examined.

3. Under the express reservation of power therefor in the State Constitution (art. X, § 1), the Legislature may alter, suspend and repeal the charters of corporations and this provision is part of the contract or charter of every domestic corporation. It authorizes the Legislature to make appropriate non-confiscatory provisions for mergers.

 [***5] 4.If a merger is duly consummated in accordance with the statutes, the remedy of appraisal and payment is the only one available to a dissenting shareholder entitled to receive full compensation for his rights. His disabilities with respect to voting on the merger and lack of prior notice or opportunity to object are the result of his status as a member of a minority and there is no deprivation therein of due process or of contract rights.

5. Every right of a dissenting shareholder is to be appraised and paid for but, where such an appraisal and judicial control and review thereof have been provided, plaintiffs may not refuse it and upset the merger merely on their assertion that the appraisal would not have done them justice.

6. Amendments to section 85 permitting merger of public utility corporations in case of less than 100% ownership - alleged by plaintiffs to be a special privilege to a special class - apply to all corporations of the particular class. Public utility corporations may be subjected to treatment differing from that applied to other kinds of corporations and in this instance the Legislature had and stated a reason for the differentiation.

 

655 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Feyler v. Mortimer


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 309; 87 N.E.2d 273; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 934


Argued May 27, 1949.  
July 19, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and BROMLEY, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant mother sought review of the decision from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the first judicial department (New York), which affirmed the trial courts grant of appellee putative father's motion to quash summons in the filiation action instituted by the mother.


OVERVIEW: The mother was a resident and national of Germany and instituted a filiation action against the father. The father filed motion to quash summons and asserted that the trial court lacked jurisdiction because the mother and child were not United States residents. The trial court granted the motion and the appellate court affirmed. The mother challenged the decision and the court affirmed. N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 135 (L. 1925, ch. 255) controlled all matters dealing with paternity actions and stated that it was not a bar to an action if the mother or child resided in another county or state. The language "or state" was limited to meaning other states of the United States and did not encompass other countries. Section 64 of the New York City Criminal Courts Act (L. 1910, ch. 659, as amd. by L. 1930, ch. 434, and as renumd. by L. 1933, ch. 746), was not controlling because as a local law it could not supercede jurisdiction as provided by state statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the grant of the motion to quash the summons issued to the father in the filiation action brought by the mother.


HEADNOTES

Children born out of wedlock - paternity proceedings - jurisdiction where mother and child reside in foreign country - (1) complaint in paternity proceeding brought in Court of Special Sessions of New York City by mother, resident of Germany, against putative father in New York City, properly dismissed - (2) appeal to Court of Appeals properly taken as from final order in criminal proceeding - (3) section 135 of Domestic Relations Law controls all paternity proceedings and defines jurisdiction of courts therein; residence of mother [***2] or child in "another * * * state" no bar to jurisdiction if defendant resides here but word "state" in statute does not include foreign country - (4) section 135 derived from Uniform Illegitimacy Act which relates only to States of Union; requirement that complaining mother be resident of United States jurisdictional limitation - (5) section 64 of New York City Criminal Courts Act which provides that birth of child outside State shall not bar proceeding against putative father resident in New York City not to be construed as exception to jurisdictional requirements of section 135.

1. A paternity proceeding instituted in the Court of Special Sessions of New York City by a mother who is a national of Germany and who resides in that country, charging a resident of New York County with having fathered her child while he served in the occupation forces, was properly dismissed on defendant's challenge to the court's jurisdiction. The courts of this State lack jurisdiction to entertain a filiation proceeding if the mother and child reside in a foreign country.

2. Following unanimous affirmance by the Appellate Division of the dismissal of the proceeding the matter is properly before [***3] the Court of Appeals (by permission of the Presiding Justice of the appellate court) as an appeal from a final order in a criminal proceeding.

3. Paternity proceedings are creations solely of the Legislature and section 135 of the Domestic Relations Law is controlling in all suits involving such proceedings and defines the jurisdiction of every court hearing such matters. Although the statute provides that it shall be no bar to the jurisdiction of any of the courts enumerated that the complaining mother or child "resides in another county or state" if the defendant be a resident of this State, it was not intended that a foreign country - in this case, Germany - should be included within the term "another * * * state". By coupling that phrase with the words "this state", it was demonstrated that the word "state" refers only to other States of the United States including, perhaps, its territories and possessions.

4. Section 135 was taken almost verbatim from the Uniform Illegitimacy Act, a statute concerned exclusively with the problem of filiation and support in the various States of the Union and referring only to subdivisions of this country. The requirement that the complaining [***4] mother be a resident of the United States is thus a jurisdictional limitation on any court petitioned to hear the paternity proceeding.

5. Section 64 of the New York City Criminal Courts Act, cited by complainant, provides, inter alia, that the birth of a child outside this State shall not bar proceedings against the putative father in the city of New York if he resides or is found therein. However, even if, insofar as the courts of New York City are concerned, section 64 were to be considered as creating an exception to the jurisdictional prerequisites demanded by section 135 of the Domestic Relations Law, the Constitution of this State would probably intervene to stamp such a construction as invalid because of the distinction granted in favor of the courts in New York City.

 

656 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Dorsey v. Stuyvesant Town Corp.


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 512; 87 N.E.2d 541; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 961; 14 A.L.R.2d 133


Argued April 11, 1949.  
July 19, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: In Polier v. O'Dwyer; LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Appeal dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, African-American tenants (tenants), sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Department, which affirmed a judgment of the supreme court, dismissing the tenants' complaint against respondents, town corporation (town), pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 106 and 112.


OVERVIEW: The tenants contended that the town was subject to the restraints of the equal protection clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions and that it could not lawfully discriminate against the tenants in renting apartments. The town was a private corporation organized as a redevelopment company under the Redevelopment Companies Law. The city granted it tax exemption for 25 years only to the extent of the enhanced value to be created by the project. The court noted that tax exemption was given to many organizations, which necessarily limit their benefits to a restricted group, and that it had not yet been held that the recipients were subject to the restraints of the U.S. Const. amend. IV. The court found that the legislature deliberately and intentionally refrained from imposing any restriction upon a redevelopment company in its choice of tenants. The court held that the town could not be held to answer for its policy under the equal protection clauses. The court dismissed the tenant's appeal, concluding that the aid, which the state had afforded to the town, was not sufficient to transmute its conduct into state action under the constitution.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - equal protection of laws - civil rights - Negroes seeking apartments in housing project owned by redevelopment company - (1) refusal of corporation organized under Redevelopment Companies Law to its housing to Negroes is not of State denying equal protection of laws (U.S. Const., 14th Amendt.; N.Y. Const., art. I, § 11); complaint seeking injunction dismissed - (2) State constitutional provision is no broader than Fourteenth Amendment - (3) civil rights which are protected against public and private action (by N.Y. Const., art. I, § 11, second sentence) do not include right to lease - (4) under housing article (art. XVIII) of State Constitution and Redevelopment Companies Law, low-rent housing for persons of low income is government function, but rehabilitation and redevelopment of substandard areas is function of private enterprise aided by government; entire cost of acquisition and construction here borne by redevelopment corporation and insurance corporation - (5) Public Housing Law ( § [***3] 223) prohibits discrimination, but Redevelopment Companies Law Does not - (6) city granted partial tax exemption though it knew corporation would not rent to Negroes; local law prohibiting tax exemption in future cases of discrimination expressly excludes projects already contracted for - (7) public purpose was fulfilled by rehabilitation and redevelopment of substandard area; corporate owners' private rental policy is not State action or governmental function - (8) city's contract of tax exemption and use of its power of eminent domain to assemble land for construction do not subject redevelopment corporation to Fourteenth Amendment, in absence of restraints derived from statute or common law - (9) appellant taxpayer does not have status to challenge as unconstitutional acts of corporation and of city in granting tax exemption; therefore his appeal, on consolidated record, from unanimous affirmance by Appellate Division of dismissal of his complaint presents no constitutional question to Court of Appeals and must be dismissed.

1. Under the circumstances of this case, the exclusion, by a corporation organized under the Redevelopment Companies Law, of Negroes from consideration [***4] as prospective tenants of apartment houses owned by it, is not State action or discrimination in civil rights and is not prohibited by the provision of the United States Constitution (14th Amendt.) that "No State shall * * * deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws" or by the section of the State Constitution (art. I, § 11, adopted in 1938) which reads that "No person shall be denied the equal protection of the laws of this state or any subdivision thereof. No person shall, because of race, color, creed or religion, be subjected to any discrimination in his civil rights by any other person or by any firm, corporation, or institution, or by the state or any agency or subdivision of the state." The complaint in an action against the corporation and an insurance corporation which owns its stock, seeking an injunction against such discrimination, was properly dismissed.

2. The first sentence of section 11 of article I of the State Constitution is no broader in coverage than the above-quoted language of the Fourteenth Amendment of the Federal Constitution.

3. The second sentence of section 11, although applicable to private persons and private [***5] corporations, protects only against "discrimination in * * * civil rights". It was stated in the proceedings of the 1938 Constitutional Convention that this provision was not self-executing and that the civil rights protected by it were those already denominated as such in the Constitution itself, in the Civil Rights Law or in other statutes. No statute in New York recognizes the opportunity to acquire interests in real property as a civil right.

4. The housing article of the State Constitution (art. XVIII, adopted in 1938) is instinct with the theory (a) that low-rent housing for persons of low income is to be a function of government, but (b) that the rehabilitation of substandard areas is to be a function of private enterprise aided by government. The latter is the situation in this case. The entire cost of acquisition of the land and of the demolition and construction has been advanced by defendant insurance corporation which owns all the stock and debentures of defendant redevelopment corporation. Under article XVIII, a redevelopment corporation is not a public corporation, but is a corporation regulated by law as to rents, profits, dividends and disposition of its property [***6] or franchises and engaged in providing housing facilities. There is nothing in the Constitution or Redevelopment Companies Law enacted pursuant thereto indicating that the State is to have any part in the operation of dwellings resulting from the rehabilitation of substandard areas. Section 10 of the constitutional article seems to provide expressly to the contrary. Section 21 of the statute provides for visitation and control of a redevelopment corporation by a "supervising agency" which means the Superintendent of Insurance as to this corporation all of whose stock and debentures are owned by an insurance corporation (§ 3); but where, as here, a contract is entered into by a municipality, a redevelopment corporation and an insurance corporation, the superintendent has no power of supervision since he has approved the contract (§ 15).

5. The Legislature intentionally refrained from imposing any restriction upon a redevelopment company in its choice of tenants. Repeated attempts in the Legislature to alter that policy of the statute have failed. On the other hand, the Public Housing Law ( § 223), which is applicable to State-constructed, lowcost housing projects, expressly [***7] prohibits discrimination.

6. The contract, under which the city granted tax exemption for twenty-five years only to the extent of the enhanced value to be created by the redevelopment, was approved by the board of estimate of the city of New York despite a minority of the board who were against approval on the ground that it was expected that the redevelopment company would not rent to Negroes. Thereafter the city council passed legislation withholding tax exemption from any subsequent redeveloment company unless it gave assurance that no discrimination would be practiced in its rental policies, but expressly excluding any project "hitherto agreed upon or contracted for" (Administrative Code of City of New York, § J41-1.2).

7. The discrimination practiced by the redevelopment corporation would violate the equal protection clauses of the Constitutions if it were done by or under the constraint of a governmental body, or if the corporation were performing functions of a governmental character in matters of great public interest, or if the State had lent its power in support of the corporation's private rental policy. But the twenty-five-year tax exemption which the city contracted [***8] to give the corporation, the aggregation of eighteen city blocks through use of the city's power of eminent domain and through exchange of bordering tracts for streets which the city closed, and the size of the building project which forms a community of 25,000 people within the city, are not sufficient to transmute the corporation's rental policy into State action or governmental function. The public purpose has been fulfilled by the rehabilitation of a substandard area.This conclusion is reinforced by the provision of the State Constitution which specifically negates any authorization to State or city to engage in any private business or enterprise in connection with the rehabilitation of substandard areas (art. XVIII, § 10).

8. The fundamental policy implicit in our Federal system indicates that political processes must furnish the means for extension of the rights defined in the Fourteenth Amendment to areas wherein they have not heretofore been asserted. Though tax exemption and power of eminent domain are freely given to many organizations which necessarily limit their benefits to a restricted group, it has not yet been held that the recipients are subject to the restraints [***9] of the Fourteenth Amendment. Such restraints as have been imposed upon their freedom of action are most appropriately derived from statute or common law.

9. In another action on appeal, presented upon a consolidated record, plaintiff-appellant is a taxpayer who seeks to enjoin not only the redevelopment corporation and the insurance corporation but also to enjoin the city from granting tax exemption to and further performing its contract with the corporations unless they cease discriminating against Negroes. Defendant's motions for judgment on the pleadings were granted at Special Term and judgment of dismissal was unanimously affirmed by the Appellate Division. Since the appellant's status as a taxpayer does not support an action to challenge as unconstitutional the acts of respondent companies and officials, his appeal does not present the constitutional question essential to the jurisdiction of the Court of Appeals (Civ. Prac. Act, § 588, subd. 1, cl. [a] ) and must be dismissed.

 

657 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Grandview Dairy, Inc. v. Du Mond


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 695; 87 N.E.2d 73; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 1142


Argued May 19, 1949  
June 2, 1949, decided


HEADNOTES

Agriculture - milk control - license - application for permission to erect milk receiving station denied upon findings that area already adequately served and that issuance of license would tend to destructive competition and would not be in public interest (Agriculture and Markets Law, § 258-c) - contentions that statute constituted unlawful delegation of legislative power and denial of due process, that it was not intended to apply to production of milk, and [**4] that determination of Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets not supported by proper findings and evidence - determination properly confirmed.

 

658 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Greenwald


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 271; 86 N.E.2d 745; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 964


Argued April 19, 1949.  
June 2, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE and BROMLEY, JJ., concur.

Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the first judicial department, which unanimously affirmed a judgment of the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York convicting them of violating N.Y. Penal Law § 965, entitled "Excessive charges in connection with rental agreements."


OVERVIEW: Defendants contended that the statute was unconstitutional. The court held that that § 965 was not a rent control statute and did not purport, singly or in conjunction with other statutes or regulations, to prescribe or limit the amount of rent that they could have charged. The court held that there was no incorporation of any other laws by reference as prohibited by N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16 or an unlawful delegation of legislative powers in N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1. The court held that no extra premiums were tolerated, and the fees collected had to have represented the charges for actual services. The court affirmed, holding that the N.Y. Real Property Law §§ 442-d, 440 et seq., in permitting a broker to collect commissions for legitimate services, gave defendants no general license to exact tribute from a prospective tenant, and the trial court's findings were supported by overwhelming proof.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed each judgment, holding that the evidence supported the convictions and the statute under which they were convicted in no way violated the constitution.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - excessive charges in connection with rental agreements - (1) defendants,  [***2] upon proof that goods or money were exacted by them in return for offering housing preferences, properly convicted of violation of section 965 of Penal Law prohibiting acceptance of excessive charges in connection with rental agreements - (2) statute not unconstitutional by reason of incorporation of other laws by reference (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 16) or unlawful delegation of legislative power (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 1) - (3) statute not vague and uncertain or lacking ascertainable standards - (4) whether defendants licensed real estate brokers or not, issue on trial is whether payment exacted was of type condemned or for legitimate service; evidence shows violation of statute.

1. Defendants, each of whom exacted from apartment seekers goods or money on the strength of representations that such contributions would facilitate and influence the securing of housing accommodations, were properly convicted of violating section 965 of the Penal Law which makes it a misdemeanor for anyone to request or accept from another "any donation, gratuity, bonus, emolument, gift, payment or thing of value, in addition to lawful charges" on the understanding that "compliance * * * will facilitate,  [***3] influence or procure an advantage over others" as to rental of real property.

2.Section 965 is not a rent control statute nor does it purport singly or in conjunction with other statutes to prescribe or limit the amount of rent that may be charged. Therefore, defendants' claim that there was either an unconstitutional incorporation of other laws by reference (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 16) or an unlawful delegation of legislative powers (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 1), cannot be sustained.

3. The statute is not vague and uncertain or lacking an ascertainable standard. It meets the constitutional tests by giving reasonable notice of what must be done and what must be avoided and as to how the charge may be defended. Acceptance of donations and gratuities in connection with arranging leases is prohibited by the statute. The phrase "in addition to lawful charges" defines no essential element of the crime, simply serving to limit the preceding words "payment or thing of value" and to assimilate their meaning to that of the operative and controlling words - donation, gratuity, bonus or gift.

4. In permitting a broker to collect commissions for legitimate services the Real Property [***4] Law ( § 440 et seq.) gives no general license to exact tribute on the strength of a representation of an advantage to be gained thereby in securing a lease. The question presented upon the trial of a defendant who is a licensed real estate broker is no different from that involved in the case of an unlicensed person. In each the issue is - was the payment in fact exacted as a special premium of the type condemned or was it received in payment of some legitimate service. In these prosecutions the People more than met the burden of establishing beyond a reasonable doubt that defendants, licensed or not, exacted large sums, not in return for legitimate services, but in manifest violation of the statute.

 

659 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Sedlak v. Foster


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 291; 86 N.E.2d 752; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 967


Argued April 20, 1949.  
June 2, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and BROMLEY, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator inmate pleaded guilty in a county court to first-degree robbery. Two years before his sentence was due to expire the inmate filed an application for a writ of habeas corpus in a supreme court. He appealed after the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Fourth Judicial Department (New York), reversed the supreme court's order, which had sustained the habeas application and had ordered respondent warden to release the inmate from prison.


OVERVIEW: Seventeen years after he was sentenced, the inmate filed a motion in the supreme court to vacate and set his conviction aside on the ground that, at the time he entered his guilty plea, he had been deprived of his constitutional right to counsel. After the motion was denied, the inmate filed the habeas application asserting the same grounds as the basis for relief. Although the application was initially granted, the appellate court reversed, holding that the inmate had failed to overcome the presumption of regularity surrounding his conviction and that a writ of habeas corpus was not a proper remedy. In affirming, the court agreed that habeas corpus was not a proper remedy under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1231. There were no exceptional circumstance that would justify the supreme court, as another and different court without appellate jurisdiction, in setting aside the inmate's judgment of conviction. The inmate should file a motion in the nature of a writ of error coram nobis in the county court to vacate and set aside the judgment of conviction. Coram nobis was the proper remedy for any prisoner who claimed to have been unconstitutionally deprived of his right to counsel.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's order.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - coram nobis and habeas corpus - (1) coram nobis motion in court in which conviction was obtained is exclusive remedy of prisoner who claims he was deprived of constitutional right to counsel; writ of habeas corpus properly dismissed - (2) prisoner, convicted in 1927, whose coram nobis motion was denied in 1945 when no appeal lay, may apply for leave to renew motion, and appeal will now lie if leave be refused or motion is again denied.

1. The exclusive remedy of a prisoner who claims that he was deprived of his constitutional right to counsel is a proceeding [***2] in the nature of a writ of error coram nobis to the court which convicted him to vacate its judgment of conviction. Under our statute (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1231) and cases, a writ of habeas corpus is not the proper remedy. In this instance such a writ was properly dismissed, because the court wherein the judgment of conviction was rendered is a competent tribunal which had jurisdiction of the person of the accused and general jurisdiction of criminal offenses. There is no exceptional circumstance in this case which would justify another and different court, without appellate jurisdiction, in setting aside such a judgment of conviction.

2. In 1945, by writ of error coram nobis, the prisoner moved in the County Court wherein he had been convicted in 1927 to vacate his sentence and that motion was denied. At that time the statute had not been enacted which now permits an appeal to be taken from such a determination (L. 1947, ch. 706). However, the prisoner is not now precluded from obtaining leave to move again by way of coram nobis in the County Court. If leave be refused or the motion again denied, the correctness of such determination may be reviewed on appeal.

 

660 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Guaranty Trust Co. v. State


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 295; 86 N.E.2d 754; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 968


Reargued April 4, 1949.  
June 2, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, DYE, FULD and BROMLEY, JJ., concur.

Judgment reversed,  [***2] etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State challenged an order in favor of appellee claimant by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which dismissed the State's appeal as untimely.


OVERVIEW: The State claimed that the dismissal of its claim was in error because the merits should have been determined by the appellate court. The claimant paid unemployment insurance contributions as it was compelled to do so; however the claim had long been barred as the court of claims held below. The court held that the payments were illegally compelled by the State, and additionally, they were barred by the time limitations prescribed by the Legislature. The court held that the court of claims was bound to accept the opinion of the appellate court as the law of the case. But it held that the final judgment for the claimant was occasioned by the parties themselves through their stipulation of agreed facts, and, therefore, § 590 of the Civil Practice Act had no application to this case.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment below.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - restitution of taxes - limitation of actions - appeal - (1) claim against State, for restitution of unemployment insurance contributions paid under statute subsequently declared unconstitutional, barred by six months' limitation in Court of Claims Act ( § 10, subd. 4) applicable to "claim for breach of contract, express or implied" - (2) unemployment insurance contributions are excise tax on employer, in which statutory trust has no settlor; Statute of Limitations commenced to run when employer paid tax - (3) remedy prescribed by Labor Law (art. 18, § 570, subd. 6) is no bar to right to restitution of taxes paid under compulsion of void statute - (4) Appellate Division reversed dismissal of claim by Court of Claims and remitted case for hearing on merits; such order decided only that claim was sufficient on its face; parties then stipulated facts and Court of Claims gave claimant judgment; no direct appeal lay therefrom to Court of Appeals - (5) when Appellate Division, by divided court, dismissed appeal of State, judgment for claimant was entered in Court of Claims; claimant thus had equivalent of final judgment of affirmance from which State properly appealed [***3] to Court of Appeals as of right.

1. Collection of unemployment insurance contributions from state banks for the period between August 10, 1939, and December 31, 1939, was declared unconstitutional in 1944 for the reason that national banks had not been subjected to such an exaction during the same period. A claim against the State filed in 1945 by a State bank for restitution of unemployment insurance contributions paid by it for the same period, is barred by a requirement of the Court of Claims Act ( § 10, subd. 4) that "A claim for breach of contract, express or implied * * * shall be filed within six months after the accrual of such claim". The claim accrued immediately on payment of the tax.

2. Unemployment insurance contributions are an excise tax on an employer and such contributions are trust funds under the jurisdiction of statutory trustees. Unlike trusts set up by wills or deeds, however, statutory trusts are enactments of the Legislature in which no "settlor" plays a part. It cannot be said that the illegally enforced payment of the tax resulted in a trust for the benefit of the payer as "settlor" and that the Statute of Limitations did not commence to run against [***4] such "settlor" until demand for a refund had been made upon the State as a statutory trustee.

3. The Labor Law (art. 18, § 570, subd. 6), does not establish an exclusive remedy for obtaining a refund of taxes paid under compulsion of a void statute, and claimant, therefore, had the right to seek restitution in this proceeding.

4. A dismissal of the claim by the Court of Claims as barred by the Court of Claims Act ( § 10, subd. 4) was reversed by the Appellate Division and the case remitted "for a hearing on the merits." Thereupon, in the Court of Claims, the parties entered into a stipulation of agreed facts and the court awarded judgment to claimant. An appeal therefrom by the State was dismissed by the Appellate Division, apparently on the erroneous theory that its earlier order had been a mandate for recovery by the claimant, and that therefore only a direct appeal lay to the Court of Appeals (under Civ. Prac. Act, § 590, subd. [1] ). The earlier order decided only that the claim on its face was sufficient and not barred by the Statute of Limitations, and it was the parties themselves who occasioned the final judgment of the Court of Claims through their stipulation [***5] of agreed facts. Consequently, subdivision (1) of section 590 of the Civil Practice Act did not apply to this case and the dismissal by the Appellate Division of the State's appeal to that court was unjustified.

5. Upon the order of the Appellate Division dismissing the appeal, judgment in claimant's favor was entered in the office of the clerk of the Court of Claims. At that stage, claimant had acquired the equivalent of a final judgment of affirmance by the Appellate Division. Hence the State properly appealed from that judgment to the Court of Appeals as of right, two Justices of the Appellate Division having dissented (Civ. Prac. Act, § 588, subd. 1, cl. [b] ).

 

661 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


National Cash Register Co. v. Joseph


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 200; 86 N.E.2d 561; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 977; 12 A.L.R.2d 812


Argued March 2, 1949.  
May 19, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: CONWAY, DESMOND, FULD and BROMLEY, JJ., concur with LOUGHRAN, Ch. J.; LEWIS, J., dissents in opinion in which DYE, J., concurs.

Orders reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant vendor sought review of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which found in favor of respondent city comptroller and affirmed the decision of the special term, which struck out appellant's second cause of action for insufficiency in law and ordered that appellant's petition should thereafter consist only of the first cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The proceeding in the nature of certiorari was brought by appellant vendor against respondent city comptroller. Two actions were set forth in the petition. The first cause requested a review of a determination of respondent which assessed against appellant a deficiency of city sales taxes for the period of September 1, 1935 to December 31, 1940. The second cause requested review of respondent's determination that denied a claim made by appellant for a refund of city sales taxes that it paid to respondent in the period of April 1, 1936 to September 30, 1940. The refund claim asserted by appellant was filed more than three years after the one-year statute of limitations had run against that claim. Because of that delay, the special term struck out the second cause of action for insufficiency in law and ordered that the petition should thereafter consist only of the first cause. The appellate division affirmed and the court reversed. Because respondent opened the question of appellant's sales tax liability, appellant should have been entitled to set off, against any deficiency finally determined, the amount of any overpayment of sales taxes made during the period under review.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the appellate court in favor of respondent city comptroller and against appellant vendor because appellant should have been given an equitable right to plead against respondent a recoupment claim for taxes of the same type that the vendor, as it alleged, had erroneously paid to respondent for the same period.


HEADNOTES

Setoff and counterclaim - taxation - New York City sales tax - recoupment arising out of same transaction - limitation of time to claim refund - appeal - finality of determination - (1) city having assessed deficiency of sales taxes, vendor has equitable right to seek recoupment of sales taxes erroneously paid in same period, even though claim for such refund was made after expiration of period [***2] fixed by local law; recoupment process permits whole transaction to be examined in all its aspects - (2) dismissal, in article 78 proceeding, of cause of action to review city comptroller's denial of refund, severed it from cause of action to review comptroller's assessment of deficiency; affirmance of such order by Appellate Division, by divided vote, appealable as of right to Court of Appeals.

1. A vendor paid sales taxes imposed by the City of New York and the city subsequently reopened the matter of the amount of the liability for a specified period and assessed a deficiency. The vendor was thereby given an equitable right to plead against the city a claim for recoupment of taxes of the same type - erroneously paid by the vendor within the same period. This is so even though the vendor's claim for a refund of such payments was made after the expiration of the period limited for sales tax refunds by the Administrative Code (§ N41-8.0, subd. a). By means of recoupment a deduction may be made from a money claim arising out of the same transaction and the balance only recovered. Such a process permits a transaction which is made the subject of suit to be examined in all its [***3] aspects and a judgment rendered that does justice in view of the one transaction as a whole.

2. In this proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act petitioner sought, by a first cause of action, to review the comptroller's determination assessing the deficiency and by a second cause of action to review the denial of a refund. Special Term struck out the second cause of action for insufficiency in law, thus severing the second cause of action from the first. A subsequent order of affirmance by the Appellate Division was a final determination of the insufficiency of the second cause of action and said order having been made by a divided court an appeal therefrom was properly taken to the Court of Appeals as of right. Upon such appeal the orders should be reversed and the matter remitted to Special Term for further proceedings.

 

662 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Monaco v. McNeill


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 605; 86 N.E.2d 176; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 1068


Argued April 4, 1949  
April 20, 1949, decided


HEADNOTES

Insane and other incompetent persons - habeas corpus - transfer of patient to State institution for criminal insane - relator, thrice convicted of crimes, committed to State mental hospital before expiration of last sentence, transferred to State hospital for criminal insane pursuant to section 412 of Correction Law - on habeas corpus Special Term held relator properly transferred under section 412 and ruled that claim of unconstitutionality of statute was without merit since provisions thereof applied only to transfer of patients already inmates of other State hospitals - order dismissing writ affirmed.

 

663 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dessaure


Court of Appeals of New York


299 N.Y. 126; 85 N.E.2d 900; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 991


Argued October 11, 1948.  
April 14, 1949, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY and DYE, JJ., concur with LOUGHRAN, Ch. J.; DESMOND and FULD, JJ., dissent in separate opinions.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed his conviction after trial by jury in the trial court for assault in the second degree. After affirming the conviction, the appellate division certified the matter to the court because defendant had raised a question of law in his appeal from the trial court's order denying his motion to vacate the indictment on grounds of discrimination.


OVERVIEW: Prior to trial, defendant, who was African American, filed a motion to vacate the indictment on the grounds that the grand jury was unconstitutionally formed based on the alleged systematic and intentional exclusion of African American persons from the grand jury. The trial court held a hearing on defendant's motion. The New York Commissioner of Jurors testified that when he filled the vacancies on the grand jury list, he did not know the race of the persons selected. The trial court found that no African American persons had been selected for grand jury service in the county for a period of 10 years "or so." The trial court credited the Commissioner's testimony and denied defendant's motion. On appeal, the court held that the trial court was in the best position to determine the credibility of the witnesses. The court noted that the trial court found that according to a census, there was one African American person to every 33 persons in the county. The court determined that under the circumstances, the trial court's conclusion that defendant had not established a prima facie case of discrimination was supported by the record.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - grand jury - asserted exclusion of Negroes - (1) no prima facie case of discrimination against Negroes in selection of grand jurors established on hearing on motion to vacate indictment; judgment affirmed - (2) appellate court has no power to deny right of trial court to believe testimony of creditable witness, commissioner of jurors, that his questionnaire of prospective grand jurors as to color,  [***2] sex, weight, etc., was to identify criminal records - (3) trial court found that for ten years no Negro had been selected for grand jury list but that Negroes were serving on petit juries, and credited testimony of commissioner that he did not know color of persons selected; selections certified by board of judges who are not charged with discrimination - (4) in year of indictment, 45 persons were added to grand jury list to replace those dead and disabled; on basis of census of county, naming of only 1 Negro would have afforded proportionate representation among persons added that year; but qualifying statutes do not require racial representation - (5) contentions involving sufficiency of proof, breadth of prosecutor's cross-examination, and regularity of verdict, without merit.

1. After a hearing on a motion to vacate an indictment, made on the alleged ground that Negroes in the county were unconstitutionally discriminated against in the selection of grand jurors, the County Judge denied the motion on the ground that no prima facie case of discrimination had been established and the defendant was thereafter found guilty of assault by a trial jury as charged in the indictment.  [***3] The Appellate Division unanimously affirmed. The Court of Appeals cannot announce a contrary decision as matter of law on this record and, accordingly, the judgment should be affirmed.

2. The County Judge credited testimony of the commissioner of jurors of the county that his reason for requiring prospective jurors to answer a questionnaire as to their color, sex, weight, height and color of eyes and hair, was to identify police department criminal records of persons of the same names as prospective jurors. An appellate court has no power to deny the right of the trier of the facts thus to believe a creditable witness.

3. The County Judge found that for "ten years or so" no Negro had been selected to serve on a grand jury, but that Negroes were constantly serving on petit juries, and he credited testimony of the commissioner of jurors that the latter did not know the color of the persons whose names he selected. Under the statute (McKinney's Unconsol. Laws, §§ 3802, 3813), there has long existed in the county a grand jury list of 600 names, selected by the commissioner from a petit jury list of approximately 18,000 names, and certified by a board of judges consisting of [***4] the County Judge and the Supreme Court Justices resident in the county. Additional names are selected by the commissioner every year to replace depletions by death, disability, or removal from the county; and over the years, the names of some trial jurors have been added to the grand jury list by the board of judges of their own motion. Certification of the list has been the responsibility of the judges alone and no charge of discrimination (N.Y. Const., art. I, § 11; U.S. Const., 14th Amendt.; cf. Civil Rights Law, § 13) has here been made against them.

4. In 1946, when defendant was indicted, 45 grand jurors were added to replace that number who had died, become disabled, or removed from the county. According to the 1940 census, there was 1 Negro to every 33 white persons in the county, so that the naming of only 1 Negro would have afforded proportionate representation to his race among those persons added to the grand jury list that year, assuming that all Negroes then resident in the county were duly qualified. The relevant statutes, however, required no fixed representation of racial or other groups but authorized the board of judges to certify as grand jurors persons [***5] found by them to be "Free from all legal exceptions; of fair character; of approved integrity; of sound judgment; and well informed." (Judiciary Law, § 502, subd. 5; Code Crim. Pro., §§ 223, 229-b; McKinney's Unconsol. Laws, § 3813.)

5.Other points on appeal, involving the sufficiency of proof of the assault, the breadth of the prosecutor's cross-examination, and the regularity of the verdict, have been examined and found to be without merit.

 

664 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Monaco v. McNeill


Court of Appeals of New York


298 N.Y. 854; 84 N.E.2d 153; 1949 N.Y. LEXIS 1711


Submitted January 3, 1949  
January 13, 1949, decided


HEADNOTES

Appeal - Court of Appeals - matters appealable [**2] - appeal on alleged constitutional grounds from order of Supreme Court at Special Term dismissing writ of habeas corpus - relator transferred to Matteawan State Hospital pursuant to section 412 of Correction Law - contention that statute unconstitutional - motion to dismiss appeal on ground no constitutional question presented denied - motion to dismiss appeal for failure to file return granted, unless relator files return within thirty days - motion by relator to dispense with undertaking on appeal granted.

 

665 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kaney v. New York State Civil Service Com.


Court of Appeals of New York


298 N.Y. 707; 83 N.E.2d 11; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 1270


Argued October 7, 1948  
November 24, 1948, decided


HEADNOTES

Civil service - veterans - rescission of municipal eligible list - proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act for order restraining State Civil Service Commission from maintaining proceeding to cancel eligible list and appointment of veterans as fire-fighters of fire department of city of Lackawanna - contentions that State commission had "prejudged" case, that statute (Civil Service Law, § 11, subd. 7, as amd. by L. 1944, ch. 435) under which proceeding had been instituted was unconstitutional, and that no notice of [***4] hearing had been given to petitioners - dismissal of petition affirmed.

 

666 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Beldegreen


Court of Appeals of New York


298 N.Y. 601; 81 N.E.2d 330; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 1173


Argued June 7, 1948  
July 16, 1948, decided


HEADNOTES

Crimes - attorneys - soliciting legal business - attorney convicted of violations of section 270-a of Penal Law which prohibits any person from soliciting legal business - contentions that section 270-a not applicable to attorney soliciting business for himself and that statute unconstitutional if held to apply to attorneys since its provisions were so comprehensive as to constitute denial of due process and hence an unreasonable restraint upon defendant attorney in practice of his profession - judgment of conviction properly affirmed.

 

667 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lapchak v. Baker


Court of Appeals of New York


298 N.Y. 89; 80 N.E.2d 751; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 805


Argued May 18, 1948.  
July 16, 1948, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, THACHER, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff stockholder sought direct appeal of a constitutional issue that arose from the decision of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which ordered that under N.Y. Gen. Corp. Law § 61-b the stockholder was required to provide security to defendant corporation in his derivative action against defendants, the officers and the directors.


OVERVIEW: The stockholder filed a derivative action against the corporation, officers, and directors and to recover for alleged waste and mismanagement. The corporation filed a motion under N.Y. Gen. Corp. Law § 61-b to require the stockholder to post collateral to secure the corporation's reasonable expenses, including attorneys' fees. The stockholder objected on the basis that he did not have sufficient security to post such collateral and the trial court dismissed the action. The stockholder challenged the constitutionality of § 61-b and prosecuted a direct appeal to the court. On appeal, the court affirmed the dismissal and found that § 61-b was not so palpably arbitrary or unduly discriminatory as to be obnoxious either to the due process clause or to the guaranty of the equal protection of the laws. Because it was a direct appeal the court could only rule on the constitutionality of the statute and not the reasonableness of the amount of security set by the trial court. The statute addressed certain evils inherent in stockholder derivative actions and the court was not in a position to question the remedy chosen by the legislature.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order that required the stockholder to post security for the corporation in his derivative action against the officers and directors.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - corporations - stockholder's derivative action - (1) section 61-b of General Corporation Law, requiring plaintiff in stockholder's derivative action to give security for defendants' reasonable litigation expenses, is constitutional - (2) amount of security, however, not reviewable on appeal taken directly to Court of Appeals on ground only question involved is validity of statutory provision of State under State or Federal Constitution (Civ. Prac. Act,  [***2] § 588, subd. 4).

1. Section 61-b of the General Corporation Law which provides that, in a stockholder's derivative action, the plaintiffs - unless they represent at least 5% of the corporation's shares or an aggregate of its shares having a value in excess of $50,000 - must give security for the reasonable litigation expenses, including attorneys" fees, of all parties joined as defendants in the action, is valid and constitutional. It must be assumed that the Legislature inquired and found (a) justification for making special provision as to derivative suits brought by holders of relatively small amounts of a corporation's stock and (b) occasion for requiring plaintiffs in such suits to give reasonable security for litigation expenses of defendants therein. The section is not so palpably arbitrary or unduly discriminatory as to be obnoxious either to the due process clause or to the guarantee of equal protection of the laws. (U.S. Const., 14th Amendt; N.Y. Const., art. I, §§ 1, 6, 11.)

2. On an appeal from a judgment of the Supreme Court dismissing a complaint for plaintiff's failure to furnish $25,000 security, bringing up for review an order of Special Term requiring plaintiff [***3] to furnish security in such amount pursuant to section 61-b of the General Corporation Law, where the appeal is taken directly to the Court of Appeals on the ground that "the only question involved * * * is the validity of a statutory provision of the state * * * under the constitution of the state or of the United States" (Civ. Prac. Act, § 588, subd. 4), the only issue open for review is whether section 61-b is unconstitutional because it requires security in any amount whatever. Special Term's determination of a question of fact, that is, the amount of security required, cannot be considered by the Court of Appeals on such direct appeal. (N.Y. Const., art. VI, § 7, subd. [2]. )

 

668 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Packer Collegiate Institute v. University of New York


Court of Appeals of New York


298 N.Y. 184; 81 N.E.2d 80; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 818


Argued June 4, 1948.  
July 16, 1948, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., and DYE, J., concur with DESMOND, J.; FULD, J., concurs in separate opinion; LEWIS, J., dissents in opinion in which THACHER, J., concurs; CONWAY, J., taking no part.

Judgment reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant private school sought review of a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which ruled in favor of a public university that a certain statute was not unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The private school, which was a private, nonsectarian school for girls, consisting of several departments: nursery or preschool, kindergarten, elementary or primary, high school or secondary, and two-year junior college. The private school sued for a declaration of unconstitutionality of a statute which required that no private school shall establish or maintain a nursery school and/or kindergarten and/or elementary school giving instruction in certain subjects unless the school was registered under regulations prescribed by the board of regents. Upon appeal, the court reversed, holding the statute patently unconstitutional as being an attempted delegation of legislative power, in violation of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1, in that it attempted to empower an administrative officer, a New York State Commissioner of Education, to register and license, or refuse to register and license, private schools, under regulations to be adopted by him, with no standards or limitations of any sort.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the prior ruling and held the statute regulating private schools unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Schools - regulation of private schools - (1) statute (Education Law, former § 625, subd. B, par. 5, now § 3210, subd. 2, par. e) requiring registration, under regulations of Board of Regents, of private nonsectarian schools, unconstitutional - (2) statute attempts to delegate legislative power in violation of section 1 of article III of State Constitution, which vests same in Senate and Assembly; power is given to Commissioner of Education to grant or refuse registration under regulations to be adopted by him but statute indicates no clearly delimited field of action or standards [***2] for action therein - (3) neither field nor limits of action indicated elsewhere in statute - (4) Legislature may regulate private schools but may not transfer to officials unlimited and undefined power to make regulations and to grant or refuse license depending upon compliance with such regulations.

1. For many years plaintiff has conducted a private nonsectarian school consisting of nursery or preschool, kindergarten, elementary or primary and high school or secondary departments, as well as a two year junior college. In this submission of a controversy, plaintiff seeks a declaration of unconstitutionality of a statute (Education Law, former § 625, subd. B, par. 5, now § 3210, subd. 2, par. e) which provides that no person other than the public school authorities or an established religious group shall establish or maintain a nursery school, kindergarten or elementary school giving certain instruction unless the school is registered under regulations prescribed by the Board of Regents. The statute is unconstitutional.

2. It is an attempted delegation of legislative power in violation of section 1 of article III of the State Constitution which states that the legislative [***3] power of the State shall be vested in the Senate and Assembly. The statute attempts to empower an administrative officer, the State Commissioner of Education, to register and license or to refuse to register and license private schools, under regulations to be adopted by him, with no standards or limitations of any sort. The Legislature has not only failed to set out standards or tests by which the qualifications of the schools might be measured but has not specified even in most general terms what the subject matter of the regulations is to be. There must be a clearly delimited field of action and also standards for action therein. Here there is neither.

3. Nor can the field and limits of action, while not immediately expressed, be found elsewhere in the law. The article of the Education Law (former art. 23, now art. 65) in which this law is found deals with "compulsory education", as its title showed, and the section of which this particular paragraph is a part (former § 625, now § 3210) has to do, as the heading shows, with "amount and character of required attendance" but it cannot be that the Legislature was instructing the commissioner to make regulations concerning [***4] attendance only, since the character and amount of compulsory attendance in both private and public schools was already minutely regulated in other parts of the section and elsewhere in said article.

4. Private schools have a constitutional right to exist and parents have a constitutional right to send their children to such schools. The Legislature, under the police power, has a limited right to regulate such schools in the public interest. Such being the fundamental law of the subject, it would be intolerable for the Legislature to hand over to any official or group of officials an unlimited and undefined power to make such regulations as he or they should desire and to grant or refuse licenses to such schools depending upon their compliance with such regulations.

 

669 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Molnar v. Curtin


Court of Appeals of New York


297 N.Y. 967; 80 N.E.2d 356; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 1051


Argued April 14, 1948  
May 20, 1948, decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - landlord and tenant - rent regulation - application by landlord who had obtained final order, to compel municipal court clerk to issue warrant of dispossess, denied on ground landlord had failed to obtain from city rent commission certificate required by Local Law No. 66 of 1947 of City of New York (Administrative Code, § U41-7.0) in "all pending and future eviction proceedings" - contention [***3] by landlord that local law unconstitutional - order of Appellate Division upholding constitutionality of local law validated by statute (L. 1948, ch. 4), affirmed.

 

670 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Tartaglia v. McLaughlin


Court of Appeals of New York


297 N.Y. 419; 79 N.E.2d 809; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 833


Argued March 16, 1948.  
May 20, 1948, decided



DISPOSITION: LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, THACHER, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Orders reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a municipal court justice and a court clerk, appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a trial court order in a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 granting petitioner landlords' motion for an order directing defendants to issue a warrant for the eviction of their tenants.


OVERVIEW: The landlords brought the N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 proceeding after the municipal court dismissed their action.
