The landlords refused to obtain an eviction certificate from the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission as required under a newly enacted local law, New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 66 (1947). The landlords had obtained an eviction certificate from the Rent Control Division of the Federal Office of Price Administration before instituting their summary proceeding in the municipal court. The law was nullified because a local law changing a legislative act was prohibited by N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 12; New York City, N.Y., Home Rule Law, § 11(2), but the legislation enacted 1948 N.Y. Laws ch. 4. Reversing, the court concluded that the curative law should be given effect on appeal. The landlords' summary proceeding was still pending when the statute was enacted. 1948 N.Y. Laws ch. 4 did not exceed the jurisdiction of the legislature and was valid. The local law was not preempted by federal law. Under New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 66, the landlords had to obtain an eviction certificate from the local agency before they could obtain a warrant for eviction.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate division and dismissed the landlords' petition.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - landlord and tenant - rent regulation - (1) Local Law No. 66 of 1947 of City of New York (Administrative Code, § U41-7.0), as validated by State (L. 1948, ch. 4), requires landlords to obtain certificate from city rent commission in "all pending and future eviction proceedings"; petition of landlords, who had obtained final order of dispossess, for order under article 78 of Civil Practice Act to compel Municipal Court to issue warrant should be dismissed [***2] - (2) validating act constitutional - (3) eviction certificate issued to landlords by former Federal Office of Price Administration merely license to resort to remedies in State courts - (4) Federal Housing and Rent Acts of 1947 and 1948 do not prohibit local complementary legislation; State-adopted local law's requirement of certificate does not conflict with, but aids, Federal act - (5) order of Special Term, affirmed by Appellate Division, directing issuance of warrant, reversed on basis of such subsequent enactment; since no warrant issued when validating act passed, summary proceedings still pending.

1. Local Law No. 66 of 1947 of the City of New York (Administrative Code of City of New York, § U41-7.0, eff. Sept. 17, 1947) bars removal, except for nonpayment of rent, of an apartment tenant in the city unless a certificate of the existence of one or more specified grounds for eviction is obtained from the temporary city housing rent commission. The local law has been validated by a State statute (L. 1948, ch. 4, eff. Feb. 3, 1948) and expressly applies "to all pending and future eviction proceedings". Landlords in summary proceedings have been granted a final order of dispossess [***3] with issuance of warrant stayed. In the present proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act, the landlords' petition for an order to compel the Municipal Court to issue a warrant of dispossess should be dismissed.

2. Even if the local law were not a legitimate exercise of city power, the curative statute (L. 1948, ch. 4) is constitutional. It validates what the Legislature might have authorized in the first place and it does not incorporate by mere reference one statutory provision into another (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 16) nor is it contrary to the principle of city home rule (art. IX, § 11).

3. An eviction certificate which the landlords had formerly obtained from the Federal Office of Price Administration, pursuant to the then existing requirement of Federal statute, merely authorized resort to any remedies open to them in the State courts.

4. The Federal Housing and Rent Act of 1947 (U.S. Code, tit. 50, Appendix, § 1881 et seq.) and that of 1948 (Public Law 464, 80th Cong.) contain no prohibition against local complementary legislation, though such a prohibition formerly appeared in the Price Control Extension Act of 1946 (60 U.S. Stat. 664, 671).  [***4] The requirement of the State-adopted local law, that a landlord submit to the local administrative body the question of his right to possession, does not conflict with the letter or the policy of the Federal act but rather aids in its enforcement.

5. Special Term granted the landlords' petition to compel issuance of a warrant, and the Appellate Division affirmed; but at that time the curative statute (L. 1948, ch. 4, eff. Feb. 3, 1948) had not yet been enacted. The statute may be given effect, at least as of its effective date, on this appeal and the orders below reversed. The summary proceeding was still pending on February 3, 1948, since no warrant was ever issued.

 

671 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Estreich


Court of Appeals of New York


297 N.Y. 910; 79 N.E.2d 742; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 1002


Argued March 11, 1948  
April 22, 1948, decided


HEADNOTES

Crimes - receiving stolen property - junk dealer convicted of criminally receiving quantity of drills and tools - statute (Penal Law, § 1308, subd. 1, par. b) under which conviction obtained, provides that junk dealer who, among other things, buys or receives "machinery equipment" is guilty of felony - Appellate Division properly reversed conviction and dismissed indictment on grounds statute unconstitutional, since it renders one guilty of buying and receiving stolen property regardless of his knowledge or intent, and that term "machinery equipment" too indefinite.

 

672 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Erie County v. Metz


Court of Appeals of New York


297 N.Y. 928; 79 N.E.2d 820; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 1013


Argued March 4, 1948  
April 22, 1948, decided


HEADNOTES

Taxation - counties - school and fire districts - action by county to recover, under section 40 of Erie County Special Tax Act (L. 1884, ch. 135, as amd. by L. 1910, ch. 672 and L. 1938, ch. 401), school and fire district taxes erroneously paid by it on county-owned property, acquired in foreclosure action, which had been exempted from taxation under section 32-e of act and which were charged back to defendant [**4] school and fire districts - trial court determined that action had been timely instituted, that defendants, sued in representative capacity and not as individual taxpayers, had suffered no injury which would permit them to raise constitutional question and that plaintiff's board of supervisors had unlimited power to cancel taxes - judgments properly affirmed.

 

673 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


H. P. Hood & Sons v. Du Mond


Court of Appeals of New York


297 N.Y. 209; 78 N.E.2d 476; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 862


Argued January 9, 1948.  
March 11, 1948, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, THACHER, DYE and FULD, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant milk dealer challenged the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), confirming the denial of its application for a license extension. The milk dealer sought to establish an additional site and claimed that the denial violated the Commerce Clause, U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 3. Respondent Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets of the State of New York issued the denial.


OVERVIEW: The dealer, whose products were sold in interstate commerce, owned three milk distribution plants within the State. Its application for a license to construct a fourth facility was denied under N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 257. The Commissioner concluded that the plant would have tended to destroy competition. The supreme court upheld the decision. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment, finding that the Commissioner's decision did not violate the Commerce Clause because it did not constitute a prohibited interference with interstate commerce. It did not prevent, obstruct, or burden interstate commerce. Rather, the license denial was an incidental burden on a local business and did not essay to regulate or restrain the shipment of the dealer's products into other states or the price at which it was sold. The Commissioner's decision was permissible regulation of local business within the residuum of power in the State to make laws governing matters of local concern which in some measure affected interstate commerce. The court also held that the decision did not conflict with regulations promulgated under the Agricultural Marketing Agreement Act of 1937, 7 U.S.C.S. § 671 et seq.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Agriculture - milk control - (1) petitioner milk dealer having two receiving plants in State for milk which it sold outside State, sought license for third plant in same vicinity; Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets concluded new plant might tend to deprive local market of milk, lead to destructive competition and would be contrary to public interest; denial of license proper - (2) commissioner in denying license dealt with situation essentially local and any burden therefrom on interstate commerce [***2] deemed only incidental - (3) no conflict between licensing of local dealers and Federal control under Federal milk order No. 4 governing petitioner in foreign State - (4) Agriculture and Markets Law (§ 258-c) forbids such license if it would tend to destructive competition and be contrary to public interest; sufficient basis for findings of commissioner to that effect.

1. Petitioner, operating milk receiving plants at two places near the eastern border of New York State, applied for an extension of its milk dealer's license so as to operate a third plant in the same vicinity. It was shown that petitioner receives milk from producers, tests, cools and ships it, without processing, to the Boston marketing area and the Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets has found that the new plant would serve the convenience of petitioner and its suppliers and would enable petitioner to divert from its other plants milk arriving there which has been found difficult to handle; that it would enable petitioner to take on new producers, but that other dealers nearby have facilities for handling more milk than they are getting. The commissioner concluded that the opening of another plant and taking [***3] of milk now delivered to other dealers would tend to reduce the volume of the other dealers, thus increasing milk handling costs there, that there would be a tendency to deprive local markets of their milk, that all producers had outlets for their milk, and that it would tend to destructive competition in a market adequately served and would not be in the public interest. A determination denying petitioner's application was proper.

2. Petitioner's whole business, present and proposed, is interstate in character and it insists that the commissioner's order constitutes a prohibited interference with interstate commerce since it obstructs or burdens the transmission of goods. The determination here does not, as petitioner contends, prohibit, but is merely a permissible regulation of local business with which the State is authorized to deal and any interference with the free flow of interstate commerce is only incidental.

3. There is no conflict between the order and the Federal control set up by Federal milk order No. 4, issued under the Agricultural Marketing Agreement Act of 1937, which regulates milk sold in interstate commerce in the Boston area and which is valid as to [***4] petitioner and its business.

4. An argument that the determination is unreasonable and unsupported by evidence is without merit. The statute (Agriculture and Markets Law, § 258-c) forbids the issuance of a license unless the commissioner is satisfied that it will not tend to destructive competition in a market adequately served and that the issuance of the license is in the public interest. There was a basis for the commissioner's findings.

 

674 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Fifth Madison Corp.


Court of Appeals of New York


297 N.Y. 155; 77 N.E.2d 134; 1948 N.Y. LEXIS 868


Argued November 18, 1947.  
January 15, 1948, decided



DISPOSITION: LOUGHRAN, Ch. J., LEWIS, CONWAY, DESMOND, THACHER and DYE, JJ., concur.

Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord, by permission, appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order of the supreme court at special term fixing the reasonable rental, under 1945 N.Y. Laws 314, of the space in the landlord's office building at an amount 17 1/2 percent above the June 1, 1944, rental value of such space.


OVERVIEW: The appeal involved the construction and application of the Business Rent Law, 1945 N.Y. Laws 314, which fixed rents within certain parameters as a response to a housing and office shortage because of the war. The landlord attempted to increase his rents by almost 50 percent and the supreme court at special term allowed a uniform rent increase of 17 1/2 percent, which was affirmed on appeal. The court agreed and stated that property owners might suffer unfairly if rents were frozen in a period when costs of goods and services were rising. Accordingly, provision was made for revising rents upward to meet those exigencies. But such increases were to be limited to compensating landlords for increased costs of operation resulting from war conditions. Here, the landlord charged an item of depreciation, but could not prove such depreciation. The court found that the conclusion was clear that depreciation could not be considered a cost within the meaning of the Business Rent Law. The phrase "cost of maintenance and operation" in that statute was confined to sums actually paid out or incurred.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant - rent regulation - reasonable rent - (1) depreciation properly excluded in determining "reasonable" rent of business property under Business Rent Law - (2) "cost of maintenance and operation" must be considered but specific items included and excluded by statute suggest restrictive content for phrase - (3) such phrase to be confined to sums actually paid out or incurred - (4) no actual depreciation shown here; allowance for theoretical depreciation unwarranted - (5) in absence of actual depreciation,  [***2] no constitutional question as to confiscatory nature of statute exists - (6) same is true as to claim of discrimination.

1. Pursuant to the Business Rent Law (L. 1945, ch. 314) petitioner landlord sought an order of the Supreme Court authorizing such further increase in rentals of its business property in the city of New York as is "reasonable" according to the formula provided by the statute (§ 4) which sanctions a net annual return equal to 6% of the "fair value" of the property. In the determination of such reasonable rental, annual depreciation of the property was properly excluded as an item of petitioner's costs of maintenance and operation.

2. The statute provides that in such determination "due consideration shall be given to the cost of maintenance and operation of the entire property * * * including amount paid for taxes * * * but excluding amortization or interest paid or accrued on any incumbrances". The explicit inclusion of taxes as an item of cost and the express exclusion of continuing fixed charges, such as interest and amortization, suggest a restrictive content for the phrase "cost of maintenance and operation". Depreciation not specifically included as [***3] such a cost should not be so treated unless, having in mind the basic anti-inflationary aim of the statute, a reasonable construction requires that result.

3. The increases authorized by the statute were intended to be limited to compensating landlords for increased costs of operation resulting from war conditions and however depreciation may be treated as an accounting item in other situations, it may not be considered a cost within the meaning of the statute. The phrase "cost of maintenance and operation" is to be confined to sums actually paid out or incurred.

4. Petitioner offered no evidence of actual depreciation, none being available, and an allowance for theoretical depreciation would not be warranted. One of petitioner's own witnesses testified that there had been no depreciation in value of petitioner's building since 1942.

5. The statute is not confiscatory and, therefore, unconstitutional, if it fails to give the landlord the benefit of theoretical depreciation even though actually there be none. A contention that in such case the return on the property is only 5.23% instead of the 6% allowed by statute is answered by the fact that, since depreciation is [***4] not to be treated as a cost, the determination actually allows petitioner a return of 6%. Moreover, until petitioner can show that 5.23% is so low a return as to be beyond the power of the Legislature to authorize, no constitutional problem arises.

6. Nor is there anything discriminatory in the fact that fully depreciated property derives a full return of 6% while property not fully depreciated receives less. It may not be held as a matter of constitutional law that a landlord is entitled to have an otherwise reasonable rent increased by an allowance for theoretical depreciation.

 

675 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Santiago


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


51 A.D.2d 1; 379 N.Y.S.2d 843; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11495



December 31, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

Sentence reversed, on the law, and case remanded to the Criminal Term for resentence.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a consolidated action, defendants sought review of judgments of the Supreme Court in Westchester County, the Suffolk County Court, and the Supreme Court in Kings County (New York), which failed to convict them under the youthful offender statute, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10, after they were convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance, manslaughter in the first degree, and criminal sale of a controlled substance, respectively.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance, manslaughter in the first degree, and criminal sale of a controlled substance, respectively. The trial courts refused to convict them under the youthful offender statute, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10. Defendants sought review and contended that the statute was unconstitutional. Under the statute, every youth was considered a youthful offender unless he was indicted for a class A felony or had previously been convicted of a felony. The court determined that the two defendants who pled guilty waived their right to claim that they were youthful offenders under the statute. The court held that the statute was constitutional because it classification was not suspect and because there was a rational, reasonable connection between the statute and the promotion of the safety and welfare of the community. The court affirmed the two judgments of the trial courts and reversed and remanded the judgment of the trial court convicting defendant of criminal sale of a controlled substance.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed judgments of the trial courts, which refused to convict defendants under the youthful offender statute after they were found guilty of criminal possession of a controlled substance and manslaughter in the first degree. The court reversed and remanded a judgment of the trial court, which also failed to convict defendant under the youthful offender statute for the criminal sale of a controlled substance.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- youthful offenders -- subdivision 2 of CPL 720.10 (prior to L 1975, ch 832, eff Aug. 9, 1975), which provides that person between  [***2] ages of 16 and 19 is eligible for youthful offender treatment "unless he (a) is indicted for a class A felony, or (b) has previously been convicted of a felony", is constitutional -- defendants who have been allowed to plead guilty to one of number of crimes charged in satisfaction of entire indictment or to lesser crime than charged have derived benefits which constitute grounds for waiver of subsequent claims by them that they could not constitutionally be rendered ineligible for youthful offender treatment on basis of charge or charges in indictment -- defendant who was indicted on, and convicted by jury of, count which precludes consideration for youthful offender treatment was improperly accorded such treatment.

1. Subdivision 2 of CPL 720.10 (prior to L 1975, ch 832, eff Aug. 9, 1975), which provides that a person between the ages of 16 and 19 is eligible for youthful offender treatment "unless he (a) is indicted for a class A felony, or (b) has previously been convicted of a felony", is constitutional. It does not violate the dictates either of due process or equal protection of the laws.

2. A youth within the eligible age group has no absolute right to adjudication as [***3] a youthful offender but has the right, if so it may be called, only to be considered for youthful offender treatment. Such an attenuated right should not survive a conscious and knowing plea of guilty. Defendants who have been allowed to plead guilty to one of a number of crimes charged in satisfaction of an entire indictment or to a lesser crime than charged have derived benefits which constitute grounds for waiver of subsequent claims by them that they could not constitutionally be rendered ineligible for youthful offender treatment on the basis of the charge or charges in the indictment. They entered into a bargain with full knowledge of the consequences and with the receipt of benefits under the bargain not otherwise available to them, and their acceptance of those benefits precludes the maintenance of such subsequent claims. Judgments convicting such defendants upon their pleas of guilty are affirmed.

3. A defendant who was indicted on, and convicted by a jury of, a count which precludes consideration for youthful offender treatment was improperly accorded such treatment. His sentence is reversed and his case is remanded for resentencing.

 

676 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Merrick v. Four Star Stage Lighting, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


50 A.D.2d 335; 378 N.Y.S.2d 65; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11476



December 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on July 15, 1975, unanimously affirmed. Respondent shall recover of appellants $ 40 costs and disbursements of this appeal.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a stage lighting company and the company's president, sought review of an order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which directed the sheriff to seize electrical lighting equipment in the action of respondent, an equipment owner, for replevin, wrongful use, and conversion.


OVERVIEW: The company and the owner entered into a storage agreement with regard to the lighting equipment, which was terminable at will. Prior to the time when the president became a principal of the company, the owner's equipment was intermingled with equipment used in other productions. At trial, there was a discrepancy as to whether the owner requested that his equipment be segregated at some point. Eventually, the owner demanded his equipment, which he was unable to take possession of because the company was using it in other productions. The owner filed a complaint seeking the return of his equipment and damages. A hearing was held pursuant to an order to show cause why an order of seizure should not have been entered. An order of seizure was entered. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's order. Procedural due process was followed in the case because the owner furnished adequate security and a showing of the validity of the claim was made. Therefore, a prompt subsequent adversary hearing after sequestration would have been sufficient. In addition, the places to be searched and the equipment to be seized was specified with reasonable particularity.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order that directed the sheriff to seize the electrical equipment from appellants.


HEADNOTES

Replevin -- seizure of property -- Sheriff properly directed to seize electrical lighting equipment useful for theatrical productions which plaintiff had stored with defendant -- no constitutional issues -- procedural due process followed -- bailment properly terminated.

The Sheriff was properly directed to seize personalty consisting of electrical lighting equipment useful for theatrical productions which plaintiff had stored with the defendant. There are no constitutional issues. Procedural due process has been followed. Under the circumstances here involved, CPLR 7102 (subd [c], par 5) does not require that the place to be searched and the chattel to be seized must be specified. The defendants were bailees whose bailment was properly terminated.

 

677 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kominski v. Levine


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


50 A.D.2d 346; 377 N.Y.S.2d 700; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11479



December 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed, without costs, and matter remitted for further proceedings not inconsistent herewith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant claimant sought review of a decision of the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board (New York), which adopted and affirmed a referee's decision sustaining an initial determination of respondent, the Industrial Commissioner, that the claimant had been overpaid unemployment benefits which were subject to recoupment.


OVERVIEW: The claimant filed an application for benefits and was ruled ineligible by the Commissioner. That decision was reversed by a referee and the claimant received benefits retroactive to the initial decision and continued to draw benefits thereafter. The Board reversed the referee's decision and sustained the ineligibility determination. The claimant did not appeal from the Board's decision. The Commissioner then issued a determination that the claimant had been overpaid all the benefits received and that he had to repay those benefits. The referee sustained this determination, and the Board adopted this decision. On appeal, the court reversed the Board's decision. The court held that pending an appeal to the Board, the Commissioner could not have withheld benefits from the claimant because there was no enforceable statutory provision allowing it. Also, there was no effective statutory provision which would directly permit recoupment of benefits paid pending an appeal to the Board. N.Y. Labor Law § 598(2) was inapplicable to the claimant's case. The court did not reach the claimant's argument that § 598(2) was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the Board's order that required the claimant to pay back the unemployment benefits he received.


HEADNOTES

Unemployment insurance -- recovery of erroneous award -- Industrial Commissioner has no right under Labor Law to recover benefits which had been paid to claimant prior to reversal by Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board of decision by referee awarding such benefits, since subdivision 1 of section 598 of Labor Law, which suspends benefit payment pending appeal from referee's decision, has been declared unconstitutional, and subdivision 2 of section 598 thereof, which provides for recovery of benefits which have been paid upon referee's decision notwithstanding subdivision 1, is inoperative absent determination of Secretary of Labor that subdivision 1 is unlawful -- return of benefits awarded by referee should not be required under common law, absent showing of bad faith, false representation or concealment of facts, since allowance of such recovery, while disallowing recovery of like benefits if awarded by Commissioner, would constitute class preference and, if ordered without fact-finding  [***2] hearing which is required with respect to commissioner's award, would constitute denial of equal protection -- decision of board is erroneously based upon section 598 of Labor Law and is, accordingly, arbitrary and capricious -- claimant may not now appeal from board decision that original payment of benefits was erroneous.

1. The Industrial Commissioner has no right under the Labor Law to recover unemployment benefits which were paid to claimant prior to reversal by the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board of a referee's decision awarding such benefits. A Federal court has declared unconstitutional subdivision 1 of section 598 of the Labor Law, which suspends payment of benefits awarded by a referee pending appeal to the board within 20 days and, upon reversal by the courts of a board decision, allows recovery of any benefits paid thereunder. Subdivision 2 of section 598 of the Labor Law becomes operative to allow recovery of benefits which have been paid upon a referee's decision notwithstanding subdivision 1, only where such payment has resulted from a determination by the Secretary of Labor that subdivision 1 is unlawful. Accordingly, the commissioner could neither suspend [***3] benefits pending appeal of the referee's decision nor recover payment of such benefits absent a determination by the Secretary of Labor, which determination has not been made.

2. Although a common-law right of action exists in favor of the State to recover erroneously paid benefits and although the claimant has not shown that such action would constitute a denial of equal protection or violate Federal statute, no return of benefits awarded by a referee should be required, as in the case of benefits awarded by the commissioner and recovered under section 597 of the Labor Law, where there is no bad faith, false representation or concealment of facts. To require recovery of nonfraudulently obtained benefits awarded by a referee, while disallowing recovery of such benefits if awarded by the commissioner, would constitute a class preference and, in any event, would constitute a denial of equal protection if ordered without a fact-finding hearing equivalent to that provided under section 597.

3. Accordingly, the decision of the board ordering recovery of benefits paid to the claimant is arbitrary and capricious, since it is erroneously based upon subdivision 2 of section 598 of the Labor [***4] Law.

4. The claimant may not now appeal from the decision of the board that the original payment of benefits was erroneous.

 

678 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Jeter v. Ellenville Cent. School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


50 A.D.2d 366; 377 N.Y.S.2d 685; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11481



December 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, on the law and the facts, by striking therefrom the fifth decretal paragraph thereof which imposes immediate liability upon the school district in which a child resided at the time of his transfer to the school district seeking tuition, and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, school districts and city boards of education, disputed decisions of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Ulster County (New York), which converted a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 into an action for a declaratory judgment and granted various relief declaratory of the rights and relationships among 17 school districts and social services agencies. The issue was who had to pay for education of children transferred to foster homes.


OVERVIEW: One school district refused to admit foster children into its schools until their tuition was paid either by the school district where each child resided before he was removed to the school district or by the welfare agency responsible for his support and maintenance. On appeal, the court held that under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3202(5), as amended by 1973 N.Y. Laws 867 and 1974 N.Y. Laws 919, liability for tuition costs was imposed upon welfare agencies only when they had been directly subjected to such costs prior to January 1, 1974. The intent was to provide relief to those districts receiving the foster children. The court construed the word "pupil" in § 3202(5) to mean "child" in fixing a school district's liability. A denial of summary judgment in one school district's case was proper, because the lower court's judgment did not fix the tuition liability of any party. Although boards of education had standing to challenge the enforceability of § 3202(5), the statute was not unconstitutional. However, because the lower court improperly read into § 3202(5) a rebuttable procedural presumption, the judgment had to be modified to eliminate that part of the judgement.


OUTCOME: The court modified the lower court's judgment in one respect, but otherwise affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- liability for cost of instruction -- pursuant to Education Law ( § 3202, subd 5, par a) Special Term properly determined that social services agencies are responsible for all tuition costs for children placed in family homes at board if they had assumed responsibility for such costs prior to January 1, 1974 and, otherwise, school district in which child resided at time he became public charge is liable for tuition costs -- not established  [***2] that there had been no assumption of tuition costs prior to 1974 -- declaratory judgment and class action proper -- Yonkers Board of Education and City of New York have standing to challenge validity of statute -- no denial of procedural due process or equal protection to school district -- error to presume that school district in which infant resided before transfer to receiving district is responsible for tuition payments.

1. Section 3202 (subd 5, par a) of the Education Law provides that "The cost of instruction of pupils placed in family homes at board by a social services district or a state department or agency shall be borne by the school district in which each such pupil resided at the time the social services district or state department or agency assumed responsibility for the support and maintenance of such pupil; provided, however, that such cost of instruction shall continue to be borne while such pupil remains under the age of twenty-one years, by any social services district or state department or agency which assumed responsibility for tuition costs for any such pupil prior to January one, nineteen hundred seventy-four." Special Term properly determined that, under [***3] this statute, social services agencies are responsible for all tuition costs if they had assumed responsibility for such costs prior to January 1, 1974; and where there has been no such assumption, the school district in which such pupil resided at the time he became a public charge is ultimately liable for the tuition costs.

2. A declaration that, as to any child who became a foster child prior to January 1, 1974, tuition costs are to be borne solely by the appropriate welfare agency responsible for the general support of the infant prior to that date would be an improper interpretation.

3. That there had been no assumption of tuition costs by welfare agencies prior to 1974 is not established in the record.

4. The statute does not impose liability for tuition upon the school district of residence at the time the child first became a pupil.

5. A declaratory judgment action is proper here.

6. A class action was also properly maintained.

7. The Yonkers Board of Education and New York City have standing to challenge the validity of the statute. Subordinate governmental entities may challenge the enforceability of State statutes that directly affect the private property or tax funds [***4] of the local government.

8. The statute does not result in an arbitrary allocation of the fiscal burdens of educating foster children with no rational relationship to a legitimate State interest. ( Vlandis v Kline, 412 U.S. 441, distinguished.)

9. The failure of the Legislature to provide a mechanism whereby school districts which must ultimately bear the educational costs would have an opportunity to be heard on the issue of where an infant will be placed in foster care does not violate concepts of procedural due process and there has been no denial of equal protection. Boards of education and school districts are agents of the State for the raising of funds to provide for education and those funds are public funds collected for the State-wide interest in education and become public property for that purpose and subject to the will of the Legislature.

10. Special Term erred in declaring that it would be presumed that the school district in which the infant resided immediately before his transfer to the receiving district is the entity responsible for tuition payments to such receiving district. The appropriate tuition is to be determined pursuant to a formula to be established [***5] by the Commissioner of Education. In establishing such formulas, the Commissioner of Education would also have the jurisdiction necessary to determine which governmental entities should bear the tuition costs. There is, therefore, no necessity to impose a procedural presumption.

 

679 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hall v. Ambach


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


50 A.D.2d 1015; 377 N.Y.S.2d 301; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12003



December 23, 1975 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment, Supreme Court, Albany County, entered October 7, 1974, affirmed, without costs, on the opinion of Williams, J.

 

680 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Sacolick v. Cagliostro


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


50 A.D.2d 875; 377 N.Y.S.2d 153; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11762



December 22, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants physicians sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York) in favor of respondents, state official and others, in an action to declare that the Medicaid reimbursement allowance paid to methadone maintenance clinics for methadone maintenance treatments of indigent patients was constitutionally confiscatory and discriminatory and to enjoin the enforcement of certain regulations.


OVERVIEW: Methadone administration by physicians for the treatment of heroin addiction was subject to Medicaid allowances in New York State and city. The maximum amount of such payments was determined by state and city health departments in collaboration with social service agencies of the city and state. The physicians alleged in the instant action that they were discriminated against because the Medicaid allowance of $ 4 per visit was less than the $ 6 per visit paid to privately owned clinics outside of New York City. The trial court held that the methadone maintenance rate paid by New York City violated the equal protection clauses of the state and federal constitutions, and enjoined the state official and others from enforcing certain regulations. On appeal, the court found that the lower payment did not constitute unconstitutional discrimination because the city's health agencies had the right to fix what they deemed to be a reasonable Medicaid allowance in the light of the services rendered by the physicians. The court also found that the appropriate remedy for review of Medicaid allowances claimed to be unreasonable or contrary to law was a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment in favor of the physicians.

 

681 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hodgkins v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


50 A.D.2d 73; 376 N.Y.S.2d 235; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11440



December 18, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Determination modified by annulling so much thereof as found petitioner guilty of charge I, specification No. 2 and charge II, specifications Nos. 2, 3 and 4, matter remitted to respondent with directions to reinstate petitioner in his position as a teacher with appropriate back salary to the date of reinstatement, subject to the loss of five days' pay as the penalty fixed upon the finding of guilt herein, and, as so modified, confirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner teacher sought review of a decision of respondent board of education (board), which dismissed the teacher for excessive use of force and insubordination in violating district policy regarding corporal punishment of students.


OVERVIEW: The teacher was charged with insubordination and conduct unbecoming a teacher based upon physical abuse of students. A hearing was held by a hearing panel pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 3020-a, which found the teacher innocent of all charges except the use of excessive force. The hearing panel recommended that the teacher be reinstated to his position immediately, subject to the loss of five days' pay. The board, upon its review of the hearing of the transcript, found the teacher guilty of excessive use of force and insubordination in violating district policy regarding corporal punishment of students. The board dismissed the teacher. On appeal, the court modified the board's determination by annulling so much of it as found the teacher guilty of offenses in addition to those recommended by the hearing panel, and remitted the matter with directions to reinstate the teacher with appropriate back salary, subject to the loss of five days' pay. The court held that the charge of excessive force could not be relied upon under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3012 as a cause for removal and that the record did not sufficiently establish a finding of guilt on the charge of insubordination.


OUTCOME: The court modified the determination of the board by annulling so much of it as found the teacher guilty of charges in addition to those recommended by the hearing panel, and remitted the matter to the board with directions to reinstate the teacher to his position as a teacher with the appropriate back salary, subject to the loss of five days' pay. As modified, the court affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- teachers -- insubordination -- use of excessive force -- decision of board of education did not properly set forth reasons and factual basis for its determination dismissing tenured teacher for insubordination -- in addition, decision was not supported by substantial evidence, but was silent as to proceedings before hearing panel despite requirement that it must be based solely on record of those proceedings  [***2] -- there was substantial evidence to support charge that teacher used excessive force on student; since petitioner might not be removed for use of such force, matter is remitted to board to reinstate teacher with back pay, subject to loss of five days' pay for use of excessive force.

1. The decision of respondent board of education did not properly set forth, as required by the regulations (8 NYCRR 82.11), the reasons and the factual basis for its determination dismissing petitioner, a tenured teacher, for insubordination. The board had stated its own conclusory observations in finding petitioner guilty of using excessive physical force on students on two occasions thereby violating the board's policy regarding corporal punishment of students although petitioner had been warned with respect thereto.

2. In addition, the board's decision of guilt of insubordination was not supported by substantial evidence. The decision is silent as to the proceedings before the hearing panel despite the requirement that it must be based solely on the record of those proceedings. While the findings of the panel are not conclusive on the board, its report is part of the record and is entitled [***3] to some weight on the question of substantial evidence in the light of the record as a whole.

3. There was substantial evidence to support the charge that petitioner had used excessive force when he pulled a strip of hair from the head of a student. Since petitioner might not be removed for the use of such force (Education Law, § 3012, subd 2), the matter is remitted to the board to reinstate petitioner with back pay, subject to a loss of five days' pay as a penalty on the finding of guilt on the charge of the use of excessive force.

 

682 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Pray


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


50 A.D.2d 987; 376 N.Y.S.2d 691; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11956



December 18, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order from the County Court of St. Lawrence County (New York), which accepted defendant's plea of guilty, found him guilty of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the sixth degree, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 220.06, and sentenced defendant as a second felony offender to an indeterminate term of imprisonment with a maximum of four years and a minimum of two years.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pled guilty to criminal possession of a controlled substance in the sixth degree, which was a Class D felony. The court sentenced defendant as a second felony offender. Defendant appealed, contending that N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06, as applied to him, was an ex post facto law and, therefore, unconstitutional, because he received a heavier sentence as a second felony offender and his predicate felony conviction was obtained prior to the enactment of § 70.06. The court disagreed, holding that: (1) these circumstances did not render the statute an ex post facto law as applied to defendant because the increased punishment was imposed for the present crime only and was not an additional penalty for the prior offense; (2) the legislature had the power to define criminal offenses and to prescribe the punishment therefor; and (3) the legislature was justified in not differentiating between more and less serious felonies in defining a "predicate felony." The fact that defendant may have been unaware of the provisions of § 70.06 did not excuse him from the sentence of imprisonment imposed pursuant thereto.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction and sentence for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the sixth degree.

 

683 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Pastore


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


50 A.D.2d 1088; 377 N.Y.S.2d 325; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12122



December 17, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a consolidated appeal, the People of the State of New York, challenged judgments from the Supreme Court, Onondaga County (New York), which dismissed indictments against defendants.


OVERVIEW: After indictments against defendants were returned by a grand jury, defendants moved, among other things, for a declaration that N.Y. Exec. Law § 70-a under which the indictments were found was unconstitutional and a determination that the subpoenas issued by the People were invalid for failure to comply with N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 73. Under stipulation between counsel and the court only the constitutionality of N.Y. Exec. Law § 70-a and the question of compliance with N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 73 were argued and decided, and the remaining aspects of the several motions were reserved for later consideration. On appeal, the court held that since the arguments on the motion regarding N.Y. Exec. Law § 70-a focused on the constitutionality of the statute and not on the facts, which could have supported its application, the matter was remitted to afford the parties an opportunity to develop jurisdictional facts. Likewise, the court reversed the order of the trial court regarding the fair procedure rights granted by N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 73 and remitted the matter for further proceedings after the People conceded that an Organized Crime Task Force did not comply with the statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment, which had dismissed the indictments. As a result, the court reinstated the indictments and remitted the cases to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

684 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Penn Cent. Transp. Co. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


50 A.D.2d 265; 377 N.Y.S.2d 20; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11493; 6 ELR 20251



December 16, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on January 21, 1975 and February 4, 1975, and all findings of fact and declarations of law inconsistent with the opinion of this court, reversed, on the law and the facts, said order, judgment and findings vacated, and judgment directed to be entered declaring that plaintiffs have failed to establish that the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law is unconstitutional as applied to them. Appellants shall recover of respondents $ 60 costs and disbursements of these appeals.

Settle order on notice providing, inter alia, for new findings of fact consistent with the opinion of this court.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant railroad appealed from the order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which enjoined a taking of the city's property without just compensation, based on a finding that the Landmark Preservation Law (LPL), N.Y. City Admin. Code ch. 8-A, was unconstitutionally applied.


OVERVIEW: The railroad sought to preserve a historic railroad terminal as a landmark. The city prevailed on objections that the application of the LPL was unconstitutionally applied. On appeal, the court found that the city failed to meet the burden of showing that the LPL was not valid or that there was a compensable taking. The city's exercise of the police power to regulate the private use of property was not unlimited. In the instant case, the disputed landmark property was not devoted to a charitable purpose, and the city did not claim it could not be used for its prime function as a railroad terminal. The validity of the LPL, as applied to the disputed terminal did not depend on a showing that the landmark parcel would be undiminished in any degree by the resulting restrictions. The test was whether it would deprive the individual property owner of all beneficial use of his property, which did not occur here.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and vacated the judgment below.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- preservation of landmarks  [***2] -- denial by Landmarks Preservation Commission of certificate of appropriateness for construction of tower over Grand Central Station is not unconstitutional application of New York City Landmarks Preservation Law, since regulation is important to public good, reasonably related thereto and plaintiffs have not shown such burden as would constitute compensable taking -- plaintiffs failed to meet burden of showing deprivation of all beneficial use of property, since no claim is made that property cannot be used for railroad purposes, financial statements showing deficit fail to segregate railroad expenses, no rental value is imputed to space used for railroad purposes and no satisfactory showing was made of inability to increase commercial income or that unused development rights could not have been profitably transferred -- plaintiffs are not unconstitutionally discriminated against by ineligibility for hardship relief by virtue of partial tax exemption, since statute authorizes relief in some cases without precluding judicial relief in others.

1. The denial by the Landmarks Preservation Commission of the City of New York of a certificate of appropriateness for construction of a [***3] tower over Grand Central Station is not an unconstitutional application of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, ch 8-A), since the regulation is important to the public good, reasonably related to such end and the plaintiffs have not shown that such a burden has been imposed as would constitute a compensable taking.

2. The plaintiffs failed to meet their burden of establishing, not hardship, but, that there will be a deprivation of all beneficial use of the property. There is no claim that the property cannot be used for its prime function as a railroad terminal. The financial statements submitted by the plaintiffs, which show an operating deficit, fail to segregate railroad operating expenses from real estate operating expenses and there is no imputation therein of rental value to the space used for railroad purposes. There is no satisfactory showing of an inability to increase commercial income by putting underutilized space to productive use or that unused development rights could not have been profitably transferred to nearby sites.

3. The Landmarks Preservation Law does not unconstitutionally discriminate against the plaintiffs [***4] by rendering them ineligible for hardship relief by virtue of their partial tax exemption, since the statute authorizes relief in some cases without precluding judicial relief in others.

 

685 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cooper v. Morin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


50 A.D.2d 32; 375 N.Y.S.2d 928; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11423



December 12, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed, with costs, and motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff inmates brought an action under the Civil Rights Act, 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983, that sought equitable remedies for the failure of defendants, county officers, sheriff and prison doctor, to provide adequate or any medical treatment to them during the period of their incarceration. The Supreme Court at Special Term in Monroe County (New York) granted the doctor's motion for summary judgment and the inmates appealed.


OVERVIEW: The inmates' complaint set forth several allegations of inadequate medical treatment of female inmates as a class and individual allegations as to the six named inmates. The trial court granted summary judgment to the doctor and held that the claim against the doctor failed to state a cause of action under § 1983 and that the inmates' failure to file a notice of claim under the N.Y. General Municipal Law was a fatal defect. On appeal, the court found the notice of claim was not necessary to bring the action because the complaint sought primarily equitable relief. The court found the allegations of inadequate medical treatment stated a cause of action pursuant to § 1983. The complaint alleged a clear pattern of delayed treatment, callous disregard of severe physical symptoms, failure to conduct physical examinations or other tests, and general indifference to requests of medical care sufficient to establish a claim for relief under § 1983. The inmates' allegations established a pattern of conduct that could demonstrate a willful refusal or failure to provide adequate medical care to the inmates incarcerated in the jail.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that granted the doctor's motion to dismiss and denied the motion.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- notice of claim -- class action -- treatment of prisoners -- inmates of Monroe County Jail commenced class action alleging lack of adequate medical treatment at jail and liability of defendant physician, employed by county as official physician of jail -- action brought under United States Code (tit 42, § 1983), not tort action -- notice of claim provisions of General Municipal Law ( § 50-e) not applicable -- cause of action stated under Federal Civil Rights Act (US Code, tit 42, § 1983) -- record insufficient to determine whether physician has right to indemnification and defense by county.

1. Six female inmates in the Monroe County Jail commenced a class action, alleging a lack of adequate medical treatment at the jail and the liability therefor of the defendant physician, employed by the County of Monroe as the official physician of the County Jail. The complaint sets forth numerous allegations [***2] of inadequate medical treatment or facilities which affect all members of plaintiffs' class similarly situated. Additionally, each of the plaintiffs has alleged individual facts to show the inadequacy of medical treatment. Plaintiffs seek equitable remedies of injunction and affirmative relief for the class as well as monetary damages for the named plaintiffs. The instant action was commenced pursuant to section 1983 of title 42 of the United States Code, which does not describe a tort action. Where the relief demanded is primarily equitable in nature and the monetary relief demanded is merely incidental to the equitable relief sought, the notice of claim provisions of the General Municipal Law ( § 50-e) do not apply. A notice of claim is not a necessary condition precedent to bringing this suit.

2. Applying the standards applicable in determining whether a cause of action under the Federal Civil Rights Act (US Code, tit 42, § 1983) is stated establishes that the allegations in the complaint are sufficient. Plaintiffs have alleged conduct on the part of defendant physician and other prison officials which raises questions as to the adequacy and willfulness of the treatment [***3] afforded the female prisoners at the County Jail. A pattern of delayed treatment, callous disregard of severe physical symptoms, failure to conduct physical examinations or other tests and general indifference to requests of medical care establish a claim for relief under the Federal statute. The complaint states a claim for relief under the above section 1983.

3. The record before the court is insufficient to rule on the question of whether the physician has a right under the General Municipal Law to indemnification and a defense by the County of Monroe against the claims arising out of the complaint.

 

686 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Brown


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


50 A.D.2d 1078; 376 N.Y.S.2d 335; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12106



December 12, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the judgment from the Supreme Court (New York), which found defendant guilty of murder reduced to manslaughter in the first degree because he was acting under extreme emotional disturbance, as provided for by N.Y. Penal Law §125.20(2).


OVERVIEW: Defendant went to a ball park to find his wife, and he urged her to come home with him. After the wife rejected defendant, defendant went home to obtain his shotgun and returned to the ball park where he shot his wife twice at close range. On appeal, defendant argued that N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25, which defined the affirmative defense of extreme emotional distress, was unconstitutional. The court concluded that defendant was not injured by the alleged unconstitutional provision of the statute because he was successful in his affirmative defense. The jury found defendant guilty of murder reduced to manslaughter in the first degree because defendant was acting under extreme emotional disturbance. Consequently, the court did not reach the constitutional question raised by defendant. There was no error in the trial court's refusal to charge the jury on manslaughter in the second degree because the evidence did not support the charge. There was substantial evidence to support the jury's findings that defendant's shots caused the wife's death and that defendant was sane when he shot her.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

687 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Ceracche Television Corp. v. Kelly


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


50 A.D.2d 134; 376 N.Y.S.2d 217; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11455



December 11, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant cable company sought review from judgments of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Albany County (New York), which dismissed an application by the cable company to annul a regulation promulgated by respondent, the New York State Commission on Cable Television, and granted a cross motion by the commission for summary judgment in a declaratory judgment action and declared N.Y. Exec. Law § 817(2) to be constitutional and valid.


OVERVIEW: The cable company brought this action for a declaratory judgment attacking the constitutionality of § 817 and to enjoin the commission from enforcing said statute, to declare the cable company entitled to a refund of moneys paid under General Orders Nos. 3 and 4 and to order the commission to refund such moneys. Special Term granted the commission's cross motion for summary judgment in the declaratory judgment action declaring that § 817 was constitutional and granted their motion to dismiss. The cable company's primary contention was that the assessment imposed by § 817 on the entire gross receipts derived from its operations within the State violated U.S. Const. art I, § 8, cl. 3, in that such assessment failed to allocate between the interstate and intrastate aspects of cable television operations. On appeal, the court affirmed holding that the cable company was in operation prior to the start of the applicable time and they could not challenge the validity of General Order No. 3 since the time to have done so had long since expired.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the cable company's application to annul a regulation of the commission and which held the statute constitutional and valid.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- assessments on cable television companies -- subdivision 2 of section 817 of Executive Law, providing that expenses of New York State Commission on Cable Television are to be reimbursed by assessing each cable television company in proportion to its gross annual receipts, is constitutional; it does not discriminate against interstate commerce -- Federal regulation is inapplicable -- General Order issued by commission fixing 1973 assessments not invalid for failure to estimate expenses earlier in year; petitioner not prejudiced -- proceedings cannot be maintained as class actions.

1. Subdivision 2 of section [***2] 817 of the Executive Law which provides that the expenses of the New York State Commission on Cable Television are to be reimbursed by assessing each cable television company operating in New York in proportion to its gross receipts, is constitutional. While the cable television industry is engaged in interstate communication, the statute does not discriminate against interstate commerce. Since gross annual receipts as defined by section 812 (subd 5) include only income derived from operations within New York State and petitioner's activities occur entirely within the State, no question of fair apportionment of the tax arises.

2. A Federal regulation, which provides that a franchise fee is to be computed on gross subscriber revenues, instead of gross annual receipts, has no application since petitioner is excluded from its effective dates.

3. General Order No. 4 issued by the commission, fixing assessments for 1973, is not invalid for failure of the commission to estimate its expenses until after December 1, 1973. Petitioner is not prejudiced by the late estimate.

4. A challenge to the validity of General Order No. 3, fixing assessments for 1972, is untimely.

5. The proceedings [***3] cannot be maintained as class actions. The questions are not of common interest affecting the rights of all television companies in the State. Furthermore, subsequent petitioners will be protected by stare decisis.

 

688 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


49 A.D.2d 437; 376 N.Y.S.2d 266; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11408



December 5, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed on the law and a new trial granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of conviction by the Monroe County Court (New York) that was rendered after a jury trial upon an indictment charging murder, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(1).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of murder. In its charge to the jury, the trial court instructed on murder, manslaughter, first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.20, and manslaughter second degree as defined by § 125.15. The trial court instructed that extreme emotional disturbance was an affirmative defense and that the burden of proving such a defense by a preponderance of the evidence rested upon defendant. On appeal, the court found that under the instructions, defendant was required to establish extreme emotional disturbance, and that defendant bore the risk of nonpersuasion. Based upon a United States Supreme Court holding that due process required the prosecution to prove beyond a reasonable doubt the absence of heat of passion when the issue was properly presented, the court reversed the conviction. The court held that the decision applied retroactively, and that the statute under which defendant was convicted was unconstitutional because defendant bore the burden to establish the existence of extreme emotional disturbance. Thus, defendant was entitled to a new trial. The court also found that the evidence did not fit into the elements of criminally negligent homicide.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment of conviction for murder and granted defendant a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- murder -- extreme emotional disturbance as affirmative defense -- in light of decision of United States Supreme Court in Mullaney v Wilbur (421 U.S. 684), provision of New York murder statute which makes claim that killing was committed under influence of extreme emotional disturbance affirmative defense, with burden of proof upon defendant to establish existence of extreme emotional disturbance by preponderance of evidence, is unconstitutional as violative of due process -- decision in Mullaney case must be given fully retroactive effect, and, therefore, applies to trial of defendant tried and convicted prior to date it was rendered -- in instant case, involving defendant convicted of murder, evidence relating to his mental state at time of killing required charge that, to establish his guilt of murder, People had burden of proving he was not acting under influence of extreme emotional disturbance -- court should also have charged manslaughter in first  [***2] degree under subdivision 2 of section 125.20 of Penal Law, but did not err in refusing to charge criminally negligent homicide -- testimony by defense character witness concerned defendant's reputation in his local community for peaceableness, relevant and proper query in homicide trial, and court erred in ruling that question concerning prior bad acts with respect to peaceableness was not permissible.

1. In the light of the decision of the United States Supreme Court in Mullaney v Wilbur (421 U.S. 684), holding that, where a defendant in a homicide prosecution asserted that the homicide was committed in the heat of passion, due process required that the prosecution prove beyond a reasonable doubt that it was not committed in the heat of passion, the provision of the New York murder statute (Penal Law, § 125.25, prior to L 1974, ch 367, eff Sept. 1, 1974) which makes the claim that a killing was committed under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance an affirmative defense, with the burden of proof upon the defendant to establish the existence of extreme emotional disturbance by a preponderance of the evidence, is unconstitutional as violative of due process.

2. The [***3] decision in the Mullaney case must be given fully retroactive effect, and, therefore, applies to the trial of a defendant who was tried and convicted prior to the date it was rendered.

3. In the instant case, involving a defendant convicted of murder under section 125.25 (subd 1) of the Penal Law, prior to its September 1, 1974 revision, the evidence relating to his mental state at the time of the killing required a charge by the court that, to establish his guilt of murder, the People had the burden of proving he was not acting under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance. Furthermore, the court, which had charged manslaughter in the first degree under subdivision 1 of section 125.20 of the Penal Law, should also have charged manslaughter in the first degree under subdivision 2 of that section. However, it is not conceivable that defendant, who plunged a 7-inch dagger into the deceased five times, at least twice in vital areas, failed to perceive the risk of death which might ensue from his conduct, and, therefore, there was no error in a refusal by the court to charge criminally negligent homicide under section 125.10 of the Penal Law.

4. Immediately following the [***4] prosecutor's cross-examination of a defense character witness, defense counsel asked her if she had ever heard anything bad about defendant, and the court refused to allow her to answer. Her testimony concerned defendant's reputation in his local community for peaceableness, a relevant and proper query in a homicide trial. The court was in error in ruling that a question concerning prior bad acts with respect to peaceableness was not permissible.

 

689 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wright


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FIRST DEPARTMENT


50 A.D.2d 729; 376 N.Y.S.2d 925; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11500



December 2, 1975 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Upon defendant's plea of guilty, the Supreme Court, New York County (New York) convicted defendant of possession of a weapon as a felony and sentenced defendant, as a second felony offender, to a term of imprisonment of not less than two nor more than four years. Defendant sought review.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted, on his plea of guilty, of possession of a weapon as a felony. The trial court sentenced defendant, as a second felony offender, to a term of imprisonment of not less than two nor more than four years. On review, the court affirmed the judgment of the trial court. In reaching its decision, the court held that the trial court's application of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06(1)(b)(i), in sentencing defendant as a second felony offender, resulted in no denial of equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

690 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Steinman v. Nadjari


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


49 A.D.2d 456; 375 N.Y.S.2d 622; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11412



December 1, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order modified, on the law, by striking therefrom the provisions granting dismissal of the complaint and by substituting therefor a provision declaring that section 27 of article VI of the New York State Constitution, section 149 of the Judiciary Law and section 63 of the Executive Law are constitutional. As so modified, order affirmed, with one bill of $ 50 costs and disbursements jointly to respondents.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff appealed an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Kings County (New York), which granted motions to dismiss by defendants, a Special Deputy Attorney-General and the Attorney General, and denied plaintiff's cross-motion for summary judgment in his suit attacking his indictments. Plaintiff challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Jud. Law § 149, N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(2), and N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 27.


OVERVIEW: The challenged provisions provided for the governor's power to terminate a justice named by him and to appoint a replacement and for appointment of a special prosecutor. The court rejected plaintiff's claims. The governor's power to terminate did not violate the separation of powers doctrine. The three branches of government did not operate in isolation; a certain interdependence was required for balance and stability. As to the appointment of the special prosecutor, whatever the governor's preference, it was the attorney-general who actually appointed the special prosecutor, and it was as a special deputy attorney-general that conducted the prosecution. A declaration in favor of defendants should have been made instead of dismissing the claim.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order by striking the provisions granting dismissal of the complaint and substituting a provision declaring the challenged statutory and constitutional provisions constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- termination of assignment of Justice of Supreme Court -- appointment of special prosecutor -- section 27 of article VI of State Constitution and section 149 of Judiciary Law, both providing that Governor may terminate assignment of Supreme Court Justice to extraordinary term, are constitutional; power to terminate does not violate independence of judiciary and separation of powers -- section 63 of Executive Law, providing that Attorney-General, whenever required by Governor, shall attend any term of  [***2] Supreme Court or appear before grand jury in person or by deputy, is constitutional; whatever preference of Governor, Attorney-General appoints special prosecutor and it is as Special Deputy that he conducts prosecution.

1. Section 27 of article VI of the State Constitution and section 149 of the Judiciary Law, both providing that the Governor may terminate the assignment of a Justice of the Supreme Court to an extraordinary term, are constitutional. The power to terminate the assignment of a Justice does not violate the independence of the judiciary and the theory of separation of powers. There is an interdependence of the three branches of government which was designed to give the government balance and stability.

2. Section 63 of the Executive Law, providing that the Attorney-General, whenever required by the Governor, shall attend any term of the Supreme Court or appear before a grand jury in person or by one of his deputies, is constitutional. Whatever the preference expressed by the Governor, the Attorney-General appoints a special prosecutor and it is as a Special Deputy Attorney-General that he conducts a prosecution.

3. Under the particular circumstances of an action [***3] by plaintiff who has been indicted by an Extraordinary and Special Grand Jury for conspiracy, attempted bribery and grand larceny, including the nature of the constitutional claims and the absence of disputed facts, a decision on the merits with respect to constitutionality is appropriate.

 

691 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Torsoe Bros. Constr. Corp. v. Board of Trustees


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


49 A.D.2d 461; 375 N.Y.S.2d 612; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11413



December 1, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order-judgment of the Supreme Court, Orange County, dated May 5, 1975, modified by deleting the first two decretal paragraphs thereof and substituting therefor (1) a provision declaring that (a) respondent has properly enacted an ordinance requiring the obtaining of a permit to tap into the village's water lines upon payment of a permit fee and (b) that the fee promulgated pursuant to section 44-9 of the Village Code of the Incorporated Village of Monroe is unconstitutional, as applied, to the extent that it is a revenue-raising [***2] device and (2) a provision directing that a hearing be held at Special Term limited to the issue whether the fee imposed pursuant to the ordinance is valid as a regulatory fee. As so modified, order-judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowner sought review of an order and judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which denied his application challenging the validity of a fee schedule adopted by respondent village board for water tap-in fees used to offset general municipal expenditures.


OVERVIEW: The village board adopted a fee rate schedule for water tap-in fees and used the funds to offset general municipal expenditures. The landowner commenced a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding challenging the validity of the fee schedule. The trial court determined that the proceeding could continue in the form of an action for a declaratory judgment, but denied the application. On appeal, the court modified the order, and, as so modified, affirmed it. The court held that the trial court properly determined that the action could continue as a declaratory judgment action. The court further held that the village board had the power to supervise and regulate connections into its water mains under N.Y. Village Law § 11-1112. It could require the obtaining of a permit and could impose a fee as a regulatory measure. However, to the extent that fees charged were exacted for revenue purposes or to offset the cost of general governmental functions, they were invalid as an unauthorized tax. Thus, the court directed that a hearing be held to determine whether the amount charged was greater than the sum reasonably necessary to cover the costs of issuance, inspection, and enforcement.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's order, in the landowner's action against the village board to challenge the validity of a water tap-in fee schedule. It held that the village board had the power to impose a fee, but it directed a hearing on the issue of whether the fee was valid as a regulatory fee or whether it exceeded the sum reasonably necessary to cover the costs of issuance, inspection, and enforcement.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- water supply -- fees for tapping into village water system -- fees established by village for tapping into village water system were improperly exacted to offset bond issue for financing improvement to such system; fees are invalid as unauthorized tax -- fee schedule violates section 2 (subd [c]) of article IX of State Constitution as local ordinance conflicting with State statute -- hearing must be held to determine whether schedule may be upheld as regulatory measure -- article 78 proceeding continued as action for declaratory judgment.

1. Pursuant to section 11-1112 of the Village Law, a village may require the obtaining of a permit to tap into the village water mains and may impose a fee for the issuance of such permit as a regulatory measure. However, the fees established in the Village of Monroe for tapping into the village water system were improperly exacted for revenue purposes to offset the cost of a bond [***3] issue authorized for the purpose of financing improvements to the village water system. While the village may charge an amount reasonably necessary to cover the cost of issuance of a permit, inspection and enforcement, the present fees are invalid as an unauthorized tax.

2. Moreover, the exclusive means to recoup the cost of improving the water system are general taxation, special benefit assessment and water rents (Village Law, §§ 11-1108, 11-1118) and the fees charged herein do not come within those charges. Accordingly, the fee schedule violates section 2 (subd [c]) of article IX of the State Constitution as a local ordinance which conflicts with a State statute.

3. A hearing must be held to determine, on all relevant evidence, whether the fee schedule may be upheld as a regulatory measure.

4. The fixing of fees for municipal services is a legislative act, particularly where no provision has been made for notice and a hearing, and, accordingly, an article 78 proceeding was an inappropriate vehicle to test the constitutionality of the enactment. However, the proceeding can continue as an action for a declaratory judgment.

 

692 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Black Brook v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


49 A.D.2d 417; 376 N.Y.S.2d 15; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10927



November 26, 1975
