DISPOSITION: Order and judgment reversed, on the law and the facts, without costs, complaint reinstated and matter remitted to Special Term for further proceedings not inconsistent herewith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff Town of Black Brook appealed an order and judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Essex County (New York), which granted a motion to dismiss by defendant State of New York in the town's suit challenging the constitutionality of the Adirondack Park Agency Act, N.Y. Exec. Law § 27.


OVERVIEW: The town claimed that the Act was void under the state constitution because it was passed by only one session of the legislature. The special term held that the town lacked standing to challenge the Act. On appeal, the court reversed because the challenge was to constitutional procedure, not substance. The town did not challenge the power to pass the Act, but sought to determine whether the legislature validly passed the Act. Because the town was challenging the method in which the law was passed, it fell within an exception to the general standing rule.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment dismissing the town's suit.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- suits against State -- standing -- plaintiff town has standing to bring action against State for declaration that Adirondack Park Agency Act (Executive Law, art 27) is unconstitutional for failure to be passed in two successive sessions of Legislature, although suit relates to governmental powers over which State has absolute discretion, since challenge is to constitutionality of enactment procedure and not to substantive validity of act -- accordingly, complaint should not have been dismissed for lack of standing, and motion to consolidate with companion action by private corporation should be entertained.

1. The plaintiff town has standing to bring an action against the State of New York for a judgment declaring the Adirondack Park Agency Act (Executive Law, art 27)  [***2] unconstitutional because such act was passed by only one, rather than two successive sessions of the Legislature (NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd b, par [1]). Although the suit relates to the plaintiff's governmental powers, which are within the absolute discretion of the State such that there would not be any standing to challenge the substantive validity of the act, the challenge is directed to the constitutionality of the procedure by which the law was enacted and presents an exception to the general standing rule.

2. Accordingly, the complaint should not have been dismissed for lack of standing, and a motion to consolidate the action with a companion action by a private corporation, challenging the act on the same grounds, should be entertained.

 

693 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hoffman v. Poston


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


49 A.D.2d 316; 374 N.Y.S.2d 774; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10903



November 13, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law and the facts, without costs, and judgment directed to be entered declaring that paragraph designated "2." of respondent Poston's memorandum dated April 5, 1974 is unconstitutional and that the remaining paragraphs of said memorandum are constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner civil service employees sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County (New York) denying a petition to review and declare improper and unconstitutional a trainee program established by respondents, a civil service employer and its president, for certain grade 18 administrative positions.


OVERVIEW: The employees held positions allocated to salary grade 14. Under part 1 of the trainee program in question, all positions set forth in the plan, and which were not occupied, were reclassified from grade 14 to grade 18. Thereafter, future appointees to those positions would have been required to satisfactorily complete two levels of training to establish eligibility for permanent appointment at grade 18. Part 2 of the plan pertained to incumbents with 1 year or more of permanent service in a grade 14 position. The plan provided that such an incumbent may have been advanced in a direct line in the discretion of the appointing officer, without examination. The employees' principal contention was that the latter part of the plan was constitutionally prohibited. The court held that part two of the plan was an impermissible method of promoting civil service employees without examination under the guise of reclassification. To have been considered a true reclassification, all incumbents occupying the positions upgraded should have been eligible to receive grade 18 status, without examination, and not only those advanced at the discretion of the appointing officer.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment from the trial court and directed a judgment to have been entered declaring that paragraph two of the civil service employer's memorandum was unconstitutional and that the remaining paragraphs of said memorandum were constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- establishment of two-year trainee program -- under first of two basic parts of trainee program established for certain administrative civil service positions, those not occupied are reclassified from Grade 14 to Grade 18, and future appointees thereto will be required to satisfactorily complete two levels of training to establish eligibility for permanent appointment -- under second part, incumbent with one year or more of service in Grade 14 position in direct line to such Grade 18 position  [***2] may be advanced thereto, without examination, at discretion of appointing officer -- there is no impropriety in first part, but second part is impermissible method of promoting civil service employees without examination under guise of reclassification, and is violative of constitutional requirement that appointments and promotions in civil service be made according to merit and fitness, to be ascertained, so far as practicable, by competitive examinations -- to be considered true reclassification, all incumbents occupying positions upgraded should be eligible to receive Grade 18 status without examination.

1. Under the first of two basic parts of a trainee program established for certain administrative civil service positions, all of those positions which are not occupied are reclassified from Grade 14 to Grade 18, and future appointees thereto will be required to satisfactorily complete two levels of training, each entailing one year's service, in order to establish eligibility for permanent appointment at Grade 18. Under the second part of the program, an incumbent with one year or more of permanent service in a Grade 14 position in a direct line to such a Grade 18 position [***3] may be advanced thereto, without examination, at the discretion of the appointing officer, and with the approval of the Division of Classification and Compensation and the Division of the Budget. There is no impropriety in the first part of this program. However, the second part is an impermissible method of promoting civil service employees without examination under the guise of a reclassification, and is violative of the constitutional requirement that appointments and promotions in the civil service shall be made according to merit and fitness, to be ascertained, so far as practicable, by competitive examinations. An article 78 proceeding challenging the constitutionality of the program is treated as an action for a declaratory judgment, the second part of the program is declared unconstitutional, and the remainder is declared constitutional.

2. While subdivision 4 of section 132 of the Civil Service Law permits an incumbent to continue to serve in a position reclassified to a higher salary grade without further examination when the reclassification represents no substantial change in duties or responsibilities, it does not authorize an appointing officer to decide, in his discretion,  [***4] who among such incumbents shall have their positions so reclassified. To be considered a true reclassification, all incumbents occupying the positions upgraded should be eligible to receive the Grade 18 status without examination, not only those advanced at the discretion of the appointing officer.

3. Petitioners, who are employed as Assistant Accountants, Grade 14 positions, have standing, as citizens, residents and taxpayers of the State, to maintain this proceeding. However, class action relief sought by them should not be granted.

 

694 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Clayton v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


49 A.D.2d 343; 375 N.Y.S.2d 169; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10910



November 13, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Determination annulled, with costs, and matter remitted to respondent with directions to reinstate petitioner in his position as a teacher with appropriate back salary to the date of reinstatement less a credit to respondent for all earnings which petitioner may have had from other employment during his period of suspension.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner teacher brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding to appeal his dismissal by respondent board of education for crimes and for conduct unbecoming a teacher under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3020-a.


OVERVIEW: A teacher was discharged allegedly for restraining a student, fighting with a student, writing a letter to a newspaper, failing to answer the board of education's questions about the letter, and failing to prepare permanent lesson plans. A hearing panel found no evidence of crimes or misconduct and recommended against discharge. The board discharged the teacher, relying on the five-year limitations period in § 3020-a to consider the fight with the student. The court found that the limitations period was discriminatory because a similar period found in § 2573(8) was only three years. The court thus applied only a three-year period to considering whether the earlier fight constituted conduct unbecoming a teacher and found it to be barred. The court further found (1) that writing a letter to the newspaper was protected by U.S. Const. amend. I, (2) that the teacher had not failed to respond to questions about his letter, (3) that the teacher had not failed to prepare lesson plans, (4) that the board's written policy allowed teachers to use corporal punishment on students, and (5) that the teacher did not strike the student that he was restraining.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the determination made by the board of education and ordered the teacher reinstated with back pay.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- teachers -- dismissal -- tenured teacher was charged with using excessive physical force on students, insubordination and conduct unbecoming teacher, based on incidents which occurred in 1969 and 1973, when he applied physical force to students, and with insubordination and conduct unbecoming teacher, based on his writing letter to newspaper and on his failure to prepare permanent lesson plans for substitute -- board of education found him guilty of all charges and dismissed him -- its determination  [***2] is annulled and matter is remitted, with directions to reinstate teacher with back salary less credit for any earnings from other employment during his suspension -- excessive force is not statutory cause for removal, and, assuming charge might be allegation of crime, record is devoid of substantial evidence he committed such crime -- there is no substantial evidence that either 1969 or 1973 incident involved conduct constituting insubordination, or that 1973 incident involved conduct unbecoming teacher -- 1969 incident occurred over four years before charges were instituted and, strictly construing statute to provide for three-year time limitation, it may not be considered substantial evidence of conduct unbecoming teacher -- record contains no substantial evidence to support finding of insubordination in regard to lesson plans, nor could this specification rationally support conclusion of conduct unbecoming teacher -- record does not contain substantial evidence to sustain finding that proof as to specification relating to letter constituted proof of insubordination or conduct unbecoming teacher -- this specification would constitute indirect attempt to abridge teacher's freedom  [***3] of speech.

1. In February, 1974 a tenured teacher was charged with using excessive physical force on students, insubordination and conduct unbecoming a teacher, based on incidents which occurred in October, 1969 and December, 1973, when he applied physical force to students, despite warnings from his building principal not to physically discipline students, and with insubordination and conduct unbecoming a teacher, based on his writing a letter to a newspaper and his alleged delay in answering a superior's questions in regard to the letter, and based on his failure to prepare permanent lesson plans for a substitute. The matter was submitted to a hearing panel pursuant to section 3020-a of the Education Law, and it found that all charges and specifications should be dismissed. In its decision, the board of education referred to the transcript of the record and the hearing panel's report, and found the teacher guilty of all charges, upon findings that all of the factual specifications were established. The board's determination is annulled and the matter is remitted to it, with directions to reinstate the teacher with appropriate back salary less a credit to the board for all [***4] earnings he may have had from other employment during his period of suspension.

2. Section 3012 (subd 2) of the Education Law controls as to causes for removal in this case, and excessive force is not listed therein. Assuming that the charge of excessive force might be an allegation of a crime, and thus a valid, independent charge, the record is devoid of substantial evidence that the teacher committed such a crime.

3. While the charges of insubordination and conduct unbecoming a teacher might be based on excessive use of force, there is no substantial evidence that either the October, 1969 incident or the December, 1973 incident involved conduct on the part of the teacher which constituted insubordination, nor any substantial evidence that the December, 1973 incident involved conduct on his part unbecoming a teacher.

4. The October, 1969 incident occurred over four years before the charges against the teacher were instituted. Under section 2573 (subd 8) of the Education Law, which is applicable to teachers in city school districts, no charges of misconduct may be brought pursuant to that section more than three years after the occurrence of the misconduct, except in the case [***5] of a crime, while section 3020-a (subd 1) of that law, which is not upon its face concerned with any particular section pursuant to which charges might be filed and is simply a time limitation, provides that, except as provided in section 2573 (subd 8), no charges shall be brought more than five years after the occurrence of the alleged misconduct, except when the charge is of misconduct constituting a crime when committed. There is no apparent reason for having a three-year limitation in regard to teachers in city school districts and not imposing the same limitation in regard to teachers of large central school districts. The limiting language of section 3020-a should be strictly construed and, given such a strict construction, a limitation of time as affected by the importation in section 3020-a (subd 1) of section 2573 (subd 8) is, in fact, three years from the date the alleged incident occurred, except when the charge constituted a crime when committed. Accordingly, the board erred, as a matter of law, when it rejected a claim by the teacher of laches or staleness, and the 1969 incident may not be considered substantial evidence of conduct unbecoming a teacher.

5. The record [***6] contains no substantial evidence which would support a finding of insubordination in regard to lesson plans, nor could this specification rationally support a conclusion of conduct unbecoming a teacher.

6. As to the specification relating to the letter which the teacher wrote to the newspaper, the record does not contain substantial evidence to sustain a finding that the proof as to that specification constituted proof of insubordination or conduct unbecoming a teacher. And, as a matter of law, that specification would constitute an indirect attempt by the board to abridge the teacher's freedom of speech.

 

695 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Currier v. Honig


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


50 A.D.2d 632; 374 N.Y.S.2d 758; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12444



November 6, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law, without costs, and the ex parte order of the Family Court of Rensselaer County dated May 16, 1975 is hereby vacated and set aside.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, the county auditor and the chairman of the county legislature, sought review of an order from the Family Court of Rensselaer County (New York) denying their motion for an order vacating and setting aside an ex parte order from the family court directing the employment of an attorney to act as an assistant county attorney to represent persons in the family court.


OVERVIEW: Upon application of respondent district attorney, the family court signed an ex parte order directing the district attorney to employ an assistant county attorney to provide representation to persons petitioning in the family court and which further ordered the county auditor and the chief fiscal auditor to pay compensation to such assistant out of county funds. The family court denied the motion filed by the county auditor and the chairman on the ground that they were not proper parties. On appeal, the court found that the family court did not have the authority to order the hiring of an assistant county attorney. In any event, the fact that the county auditor and the chairman were not parties to the original application was not controlling. The challenged order purported to bind the county auditor in his official role. It was of no consequence that he might not have been civilly liable for compliance with the family court order since he had been ordered to perform an act that he contended he did not have the authority to perform. Thus, he had the responsibility with respect to the disposition of county funds, and was sufficiently interested in the case to attain standing.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order from the trial court and vacated and set aside the ex parte order from the family court that had directed the employment of an assistant county attorney to represent persons in the family court, and that had directed the county auditor to pay compensation to such assistant out of county funds.

 

696 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fomenko v. Fomenko


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


50 A.D.2d 712; 374 N.Y.S.2d 882; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12585



November 6, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously modified in accordance with memorandum and as modified affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant ex-husband and plaintiff ex-wife sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court, Monroe County (New York), which granted a divorce in each person's favor on the ground of their cruel and inhuman treatment of each other, pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 170.


OVERVIEW: The trial court granted a divorce to the ex-husband and to the ex-wife on the ground of their cruel and inhuman treatment of each other. Both parties sought review. The court found that under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 170, the trial court had the authority to grant a dual divorce to the parties. Further, under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 236, the trial court was required to deny alimony to the ex-wife because sufficient evidence established that her conduct constituted grounds for the separation and divorce. The court held that the statute was not violative of the equal protection clause because it bore a rational relationship to a legitimate state objective. However, the court found that the trial court erred in holding that it was compelled to award counsel fees to the ex-wife without regard to the financial circumstances of the parties, as required under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 237(a). The court affirmed as modified the judgment of the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed as modified the judgment of the trial court, which granted a dual divorce to the parties and denied the wife alimony. The court further remanded the case to the trial court solely for a hearing with respect to the financial condition of the parties and for a new determination of the amount, if any, that should be awarded to the ex-wife for counsel fees.

 

697 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Wright v. Smith


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


50 A.D.2d 718; 375 N.Y.S.2d 73; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12597



November 6, 1975 

 

698 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rochester Poster Advertising Co. v. Brighton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


49 A.D.2d 273; 374 N.Y.S.2d 510; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10894



November 6, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed without costs and Town of Brighton Sign Ordinance and section 42-29 of the Zoning Ordinance of the Town of Brighton declared constitutional and valid in accordance with opinion by Del Vecchio, J.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant town sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court in Monroe County (New York) adjudging that the Town of Brighton, N.Y., Sign Ordinance and the Town of Brighton, N.Y., Zoning Ordinance § 42.29 were void and unconstitutional as applied to plaintiff advertising company's property.


OVERVIEW: The advertising company successfully challenged a sign and zoning ordinance, the application of which gave the advertising company a period of 34 months during which it was permitted to maintain a non-accessory outdoor advertising billboard after adoption of the ordinance which prohibited such billboard. The evidence established that the billboard that was the subject of the action was located 25 feet from the pavement of a heavily travelled four-lane highway that was the major route for traffic going south from the town. The billboard was 600 feet from one traffic control signal and 150 feet from another signal. There was testimony by an experienced police officer that the billboard created a traffic safety hazard by virtue of its location. Under those circumstances, the application of the ordinances represented a permissible exercise of the police power in the protection of the public safety. The court concluded that the 34-month period during which the billboard was permitted to have remained as a nonconforming use represented a reasonable reconciliation of the public and private interests and an adequate time for amortization of the advertising company's investment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment from the trial court and granted a judgment declaring that a sign ordinance and a zoning ordinance, as applied to the advertising company's property, were constitutional and valid as providing a reasonable period of amortization of the advertising company's investment.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- advertising signs -- town sign ordinance and town zoning ordinance, which excluded billboards and gave plaintiff 34 months to maintain existing outdoor advertising billboard, is proper exercise of police power in protection of public safety from traffic hazard -- enactment of section 88 of Highway Law does not create implied revocation of authority to adopt ordinances -- 34-month period is reasonable -- ordinances, as applied to plaintiff's property, are constitutional.

1. The application of the Sign Ordinance and the Zoning Ordinance [***2] ( § 42-29) of the Town of Brighton, which excluded billboards from a regulated area and gave plaintiff 34 months during which it was permitted to maintain an existing outdoor advertising billboard, is a legitimate exercise of the police power in the protection of the public safety. Plaintiff's billboard is located near two traffic control signals and there was testimony by a police officer that the billboard creates a traffic hazard. As a proper exercise of the police power, the ordinances are not violative of the due process or just compensation clauses of the Constitution.

2. The enactment of section 88 of the Highway Law, which provides for the control of outdoor advertising, does not create an implied revocation of the delegated authority under which the town adopted the ordinances.

3. The 34-month period during which the billboard was to remain as a nonconforming use represented a reasonable reconciliation of the public and private interests and an adequate time for amortization of plaintiff's investment.

 

699 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Raleigh


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


49 A.D.2d 306; 374 N.Y.S.2d 410; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10901



November 6, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant dog owners appealed an order of the Saratoga County Court (New York), which reversed an order of the Justice Court of the Town of Moreau holding that N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 109-b was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The dog owners paid the fee required by N.Y., Agric. & Mkts. Law § 109 to license their dogs, but did not pay the additional 10 cents required by N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 109-b. The Town Clerk imposed a civil penalty of $ 10 and the dog owners appealed. The town court held that § 109-b was unconstitutional and the State appealed. The trial court reversed the town court and remanded the matter. The dog owners appealed on the basis that the purpose of the statute, to provide funds for the research of dog diseases, violated the Equal Protection Clause. The court found that the law did not violate the Equal Protection Clause and was not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court.


HEADNOTES

Animals -- tax on dog owners for study of diseases -- section 109-b of Agriculture and Markets Law, adding 10 cents to dog license fees to be used for research into diseases of dogs, does not violate equal protection clause of Constitution; there is no unreasonableness in classification of dogs as appropriate base for such tax.

Section 109-b of the Agriculture and Markets Law which adds 10 cents to all fees for dog licenses to be used for research into diseases of dogs, does not violate the equal protection clause of the Constitution. Dogs are a specific species of animal which presumably have particular immunities and susceptibilities to various diseases. The Legislature [***2] has found that some diseases affect both men and dogs (§ 109-b, subd 1). Research into dog diseases will benefit dog owners although such research may incidentally benefit owners of other animals. Accordingly, it does not appear that there is any unreasonableness in the classification of dogs as an appropriate base for the tax and, where defendants had tendered the license fee without the additional 10-cent tax, the Town Clerk was empowered to collect a $ 10 civil penalty for harboring an unlicensed dog (§ 113).

 

700 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Yale


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


49 A.D.2d 167; 373 N.Y.S.2d 901; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10615



October 24, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of conviction rendered in Erie County Court (New York) following his plea to a reduced charge of attempted burglary in the third degree and attempted criminal possession of stolen property. Since defendant had a previous felony conviction, he was sentenced to concurrent terms of not less than one and one-half nor more than three years as a second felony offender, N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06(3)(d) and (4).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was sentenced as a second felony offender pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06. Defendant argued on appeal that the mandatory prison sentences of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 provided for second felony offenders constituted a denial of the equal protection of the laws when such was considered in relation to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10 which dealt with persistent felony offenders. Defendant claimed that it was theoretically possible for a second felony offender to receive a longer term of imprisonment than a third or fourth felony offender. The court stated, however, that the legislative scheme was clear. A reasonable construction of the statute did not permit the unconstitutional result defendant posited. Since the only available sentences for a persistent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10 were the same as or longer than those imposed upon a second felony offender N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06, there was no denial of equal protection of the law in the statutory sentencing scheme set forth in N.Y. Penal Law §§ 70.00, 70.06 and 70.10 or in its application to defendant's case. Consequently, the judgment of conviction was affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence -- second felony offender -- since only available sentences for persistent felony offender under section 70.10 of Penal Law are same as or longer than those imposed upon second felony offender under section 70.06, there is no denial of equal protection of law in statutory sentencing scheme set forth in sections 70.00, 70.06 and 70.10 of Penal Law or in its application to defendant sentenced as second felony offender.

Following his plea to class E felonies, defendant was sentenced to concurrent terms as a second felony offender (Penal Law, § 70.06), since he had a previous felony conviction. The mandatory prison sentences of section 70.06 provided for second felony offenders do not constitute a denial of equal protection of the laws when considered in relation to section 70.10 of the Penal Law which deals with persistent felony offenders, in that section 70.10 does not grant discretion [***2] to the sentencing court which is unavailable to it under section 70.06 when sentencing a second felony offender. A reasonable construction of the statute does not permit a second felony offender to receive a longer term of imprisonment than a persistent felony offender. Since the only available sentences for a persistent felony offender under 70.10 are the same as or longer than those imposed upon a second felony offender under 70.06, there is no denial of equal protection of the law in the statutory sentencing scheme set forth in sections 70.00, 70.06 and 70.10 of the Penal Law or in its application to this case.

 

701 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Downs


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


49 A.D.2d 964; 374 N.Y.S.2d 59; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11268



October 23, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law, to the extent of vacating the sentence imposed on January 13, 1975, and matter remitted to the County Court of St. Lawrence County for resentencing defendant as a first-felony offender.

 

702 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Colenzo v. Kernan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


49 A.D.2d 809; 373 N.Y.S.2d 426; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10876



September 24, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of the Oneida Special Term (New York), which--in an action to recover damages for personal injuries suffered by plaintiff in an automobile accident--denied defendant's motion for summary judgment of dismissal of the complaint. Defendant argued that New York's no-fault insurance law required plaintiff to bring a claim plaintiff's own insurance carrier.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff sued to recover damages for personal injuries he suffered in an automobile accident. Defendant moved for summary judgment of dismissal of the complaint upon the ground that under New York's no-fault insurance law, plaintiff had no cause of action against defendant but had to resort solely to a claim against his own insurance carrier. The motion was denied. The court affirmed the denial holding that, although plaintiff did not fall within the purview of N.Y. Ins. Law § 673 because his medical expenses did not meet the statutory minimum to maintain an action, plaintiff's allegation in his complaint, supplemented by his bill of particulars and the affidavit in opposition to the motion for summary judgment--that he suffered serious permanent injury to his knee--brought him expressly within N.Y. Ins. Law § 671 and qualified him prima facie to maintain the suit. The court found a question of fact was presented in this respect which required denial of the motion for summary judgment.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the denial of defendant's motion for summary judgment. Although plaintiff did not fall under statute in terms of medical expenses because physical therapy bills were excluded by the statute, plaintiff's allegation in his complaint, that he suffered serious permanent injury to his knee, brought him expressly within the statute and qualified him prima face to maintain the suit.

 

703 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Goodwin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


49 A.D.2d 53; 378 N.Y.S.2d 82; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10333



July 24, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of his conviction for criminally negligent homicide in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.10 from the County Court of Chemung County (New York). Defendant contended that N.Y. Crim. Pro. Law § 720.10(2) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was originally indicted for the crime of murder in violation of N.Y. Penal Law 125.25(2). Following his conviction for criminally negligent homicide, his motion to be considered for youthful offender status was denied by the trial court because of his indictment for murder. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding that the language of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10(2) plainly provided for the denial of youthful offender status based solely on the seriousness of the crime alleged in the indictment without regard to whatever conviction ultimately resulted therefrom and there was a rational relationship between limiting the availability of youthful offender status and the exclusion therefrom of those indicted for certain types of felonies. The court found that defendant's contention that the denial of constitutionally guaranteed equal protection and due process rights would result from the operation of this questioned statutory provision was without merit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for criminally negligent homicide.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- youthful offenders -- CPL 720.10 (subd 2), which prohibits granting of youthful offender status to youth indicted for class A felony, applies even though that youth is convicted of class E felony; statute provide for denial of such status based solely on seriousness of crime alleged in indictment -- statute is not unconstitutional as violative of equal protection and due process provisions of Constitutions; there is rational relationship between limiting availability of procedure and said exclusion.

1. Defendant, who had been indicted for murder, then a class A felony and now a class A-1 felony, and had been convicted of criminally negligent homicide, a class E felony, was properly denied youthful offender status following his conviction. CPL 720.10 (subd 2), which prohibits the granting of youthful offender status to a youth who is indicted for a class A felony, does not apply only where the youth is convicted of a class A felony. The language of the statute plainly [***2] provides for denial of youthful offender status based solely on the seriousness of the crime alleged in the indictment without regard to whatever conviction results.

2. CPL 720.10 (subd 2) is not unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection and due process provisions of the State and Federal Constitutions. There is a rational relationship between limiting the availability of the procedure and the exclusion therefrom of those indicted for class A felonies. Moreover, the public's interest in being informed as to the disposition of serious crimes against society is also served.

 

704 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Russell


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


49 A.D.2d 655; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10492



July 24, 1975, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the County Court of Albany County (New York), which convicted him of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree and sentenced him to an indeterminate term of imprisonment of seven years to life.


OVERVIEW: After the police arrested defendant, an undercover officer sealed the drugs and placed them in an evidence locker at state police headquarters. Later, the same undercover officer took the evidence to the state police laboratory and gave it to the evidence clerk. At trial, the chemist testified that he removed the evidence from the locker to perform the chemical analysis on the drugs. On appeal, defendant argued that the trial court committed reversible error when it allowed the undercover officer to testify on other drug related transactions for which he was not on trial. Defendant also claimed that the prosecution did not prove the chain of custody; that the district attorney's summation went beyond the normal scope of fair advocacy; and that the sentence was unconstitutional. The court held that: (1) the undercover agent could testify on the other transactions because defendant's identity was at issue, (2) the prosecution established the chain of custody, (3) the prosecutor's comments did not go beyond the scope of fair advocacy; but, even if they did, the error was harmless because the evidence against defendant was overwhelming, and (4) the sentence was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

705 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Parker


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


49 A.D.2d 657; 385 N.Y.S.2d 147; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10494



July 24, 1975, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a decision of the County Court of Ulster County (New York), which, upon her guilty plea, convicted defendant of manslaughter in the first degree and sentenced defendant as a second felony offender to a maximum term of 12 years and a minimum term of 6 years.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that she was improperly adjudged a second felony offender. In reversing the imposed sentence and remitting to the trial court for resentencing as a first felony offender, the court held that defendant was improperly sentenced as a second felony offender pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06. The court noted that § 70.06 was unconstitutional. The court determined that the trial court improperly based its determination as to defendant's status upon a suspended sentence that she had received for a prior conviction in North Carolina.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court to the extent of vacating the imposed sentence. The court remanded to the trial court for resentencing as a first felony offender.

 

706 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Ruiz v. Lavine


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


49 A.D.2d 1; 370 N.Y.S.2d 710; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10324



July 18, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Determination unanimously annulled without costs and matter remitted to respondents for a new hearing in accordance with opinion by Goldman, J.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, health care applicants, brought a proceeding under N.Y.C.P.L.R. art. 78, transferred by order of the Supreme Court, Monroe County (New York), to review an administrative determination that denied an application for medical assistance.


OVERVIEW: The petitioners, husband and wife, came to New York from Puerto Rico because the wife was suffering from an illness that could not be treated properly in Puerto Rico. The couple brought many of their personal belongings with them to their daughter's home in New York, but at the time of their original application for medical assistance and at the time of the hearing, they still owned a home in Puerto Rico. The wife's treatment was to be for a long and indefinite time. At the hearing, the husband stated that he would prefer to live in Puerto Rico if his wife were not ill. Assistance was denied pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 366(1)(b) on the ground that the couple had entered New York for the purpose of obtaining medical assistance. The court reversed and remanded, holding that residence depended upon the applicants' intent to make New York their place of residence, regardless of whether the move was motivated by health reasons. The court noted that the husband's preference as to where he would live under hypothetical circumstances was not determinative of whether he actually intended to remain in New York.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the denial of medical assistance and remanded for a new hearing.


HEADNOTES

Social services -- medical assistance -- application by petitioners for medical assistance was denied, after hearing, on ground that they were residents of Puerto Rico and had come to New York for purpose of receiving medical assistance -- determination is annulled and matter remanded for new hearing -- primary focus of inquiry at hearing should have been their intent to make New York their place of residence, rather than, as it was, motivation behind their intention -- in view of remand, it is unnecessary to reach question of constitutionality of provision of section 366 of Social Services Law, applicable to persons temporarily in State and not to residents, which prohibits medical assistance to persons who enter State to obtain medical care.

1. At a hearing held on an application for medical assistance, made by petitioners husband [***2] and wife within one month of their arrival in Rochester from Puerto Rico, testimony was elicited that they came to New York because petitioner wife was suffering from an illness which could not be properly treated in Puerto Rico; that they owned a home in Puerto Rico but had brought all the personal belongings they could with them, and moved in with a daughter and son-in-law; that, on the day after their arrival, petitioner wife entered a hospital, and that, although she had been discharged from it, they intended to remain and make their home in Rochester because she required continuing treatment for an indefinite time, although, if she was not ill, they would return to Puerto Rico. Their application was denied on the ground that they were residents of Puerto Rico and had come to New York for the purpose of receiving medical assistance. This determination was centered on their continued ownership of property in Puerto Rico and the admission that they were motivated to move to New York because of petitioner wife's poor health. However, in view of the short time sequence between their arrival in Rochester and the hearing, it is not surprising that they still owned a home in Puerto [***3] Rico, nor was any evidence adduced at the hearing on the issue of what was to become of the home. And, since the proviso in section 366 (subd 1, par [b]) of the Social Services Law which prohibits medical assistance to persons who enter the State to obtain medical care applies only to persons temporarily in the State and not to residents, the primary focus of inquiry at the hearing should have been petitioners' intent to make New York their place of residence, rather than, as it was, the motivation behind their intention. The determination is annulled and the matter remanded for a new hearing as to their intent to make Rochester their home.

2. Since the matter is being remanded for a new hearing, it is unnecessary to reach the question of the constitutionality of section 366 (subd 1, par [b]) of the Social Services Law.

 

707 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Antinore v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


49 A.D.2d 6; 371 N.Y.S.2d 213; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10325; 90 L.R.R.M. 2127



July 18, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed on the law without costs and judgment granted in favor of defendants in accordance with opinion by Del Vecchio, J.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff public employee brought a cause of action against defendant state alleging that a provision of a collective bargaining agreement was unconstitutional. The agreement provided for binding arbitration as the method of disposing of challenges to disciplinary action. The Supreme Court of Monroe County (New York) entered a judgment in favor of the employee. The state sought review of the judgment.


OVERVIEW: The collective bargaining agreement in question was entered into between the state and the representative of the negotiating unit to which the employee belonged. A provision of the agreement provided that arbitration would be the binding method of disposing of challenges to disciplinary action addressed to an employee. The provision removed the employee's option of resorting to the Civil Service Commission or filing a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding in a court. The public employee was a childcare worker at a state training school. The employee filed the action after he was notified of charges and prospective termination of employment. On appeal, the court reversed the judgment of the trial court and entered a judgment in favor of the state. The court found that the agreement was voluntarily entered into by the employee's representative and the fact that the employee disagreed with the agreement made it no less binding upon him. If the employee was unsatisfied with his representation, he could have changed his representation or certification. The court found that the employee's waiver of his individual constitutional rights did not violate public policy.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was reversed, and the court entered a judgment in favor of the state.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- disciplinary proceedings -- binding arbitration of disciplinary disputes -- public employee who is in negotiating unit for which Civil Service Employees' Association (CSEA) is designated bargaining agent may not challenge, as violative of his rights to due process and equal protection of laws, collective bargaining agreement executed by State and CSEA, providing for binding arbitration as method of disposing of challenges to disciplinary action and removing, even as option, resort to Civil Service Commission or to court through article 78 proceeding -- CSEA was acting as agent for him, its assent to agreement, voluntarily entered into, was his assent, and, accordingly, he has waived his rights -- such waiver of individual constitutional  [***2] rights incidental to procedure for removal from employment does not contravene any public policy such that waiver should not be given effect.

1. Following the passage of an amendment to section 76 of the Civil Service Law which permitted sections 75 and 76 of that law, prescribing the procedures and remedies available to covered public employees to challenge disciplinary action taken against them, to be replaced by agreements negotiated between the State and employee organizations, the State and the Civil Service Employees' Association (CSEA) executed a collective bargaining agreement which provided for binding arbitration as the method of disposing of challenges to disciplinary action, removing, even as an option, resort to the Civil Service Commission or to the court through an article 78 proceeding. A public employee who is in a negotiating unit for which CSEA is the designated bargaining agent may not challenge these arbitration provisions on the ground that they violate his rights to due process and equal protection of the laws. CSEA, as designated bargaining agent for the group of employees in which he was included, was acting as agent for him, its assent to the agreement,  [***3] which was voluntarily entered into, was his assent, and, accordingly, he has waived his statutory and constitutional rights.

2. Such a waiver of individual constitutional rights incidental to a procedure for removal from employment does not contravene any public policy such that the waiver should not be given effect. On the contrary, the binding arbitration procedures provided for in the agreement advance the public good by providing for resolution of disciplinary disputes in a simpler, more prompt manner than would attend their disposition by one of the methods provided by sections 75 and 76 of the Civil Service Law.

 

708 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Simone


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


48 A.D.2d 497; 370 N.Y.S.2d 583; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9927



July 10, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment, Supreme Court, New York County, rendered on December 21, 1973, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), convicting him, after he entered a plea of guilty, of possession of a weapon as a felony subsequent to the trial court's denial of his motion to suppress.


OVERVIEW: When defendant's automobile was pulled over by a police officer for a "routine" license and registration check, defendant handed over to the officer a forged driver's license and was unable to produce a registration for the vehicle. He was subsequently arrested. A loaded revolver was found on his person and drugs were discovered in the vehicle. He filed a motion to suppress the forged license, drugs, and revolver, but the motion was denied. The Court of Appeals subsequently delivered an interpretation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 390 that mandated that the citizenry had the right to not be subject to stops merely at the whims of the police authorities. Defendant contended that this interpretation of the law should be applied retroactively, while the prosecution argued it should have only prospective effect. The court agreed with the prosecution and determined that the new standard should not be applied retroactively because it had no relation to whether or not defendant was in fact guilty of a criminal offense. Therefore, reversal and dismissal of defendant's indictment for failure to suppress the seized evidence was not warranted.


OUTCOME: The trial court's judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- unlawful search and seizure -- routine check of motor vehicle -- decision of Court of Appeals in People v Ingle (36 NY2d 413), holding that section 390 of Vehicle and Traffic Law may not be read to authorize stopping of vehicle for routine traffic check if stop is arbitrary and without justification, will not be applied retroactively -- assuming, however, retroactive application of People v Ingle, at most circumstances of instant case would mandate remand for further hearing; in fact, rule in Ingle may have been complied with -- accordingly, judgment of conviction affirmed.

1. The 1975 decision of the Court of Appeals in People v Ingle (36 NY2d 413), holding that section 390 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law may not be read to authorize the stopping of a vehicle for a routine traffic check if such stop is gratuitous, arbitrary and without justification or excuse, will not be [***2] applied retroactively. The new standard announced in People v Ingle has no relation to the truth-determining process and in no way involves the question of whether a defendant is guilty of a criminal offense, but is designed to safeguard the right of the citizenry not to be subjected to stops at the whims of the police.

2. Assuming, however, the retroactive application of the Ingle rule, the circumstances of the instant case would mandate at most a remand for a further hearing. Upon a routine stop of defendant's car for license and registration check on August 21, 1972 defendant handed the police officer a forged license and could not produce a registration. He was arrested and a loaded revolver was found in his coat pocket and illegal drugs were found in the car. The officer may have stopped the car due to some irregularity or suspicious circumstance or because of some uniform procedure adopted with respect to halting motor vehicles and, in fact, the rule in Ingle may have been complied with.

3. Accordingly, the judgment convicting defendant, upon his plea of guilty, of possession of a weapon as a felony should be affirmed.

 

709 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Todd Mart, Inc. v. Town Bd. of Webster


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


49 A.D.2d 12; 370 N.Y.S.2d 683; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10326



July 10, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed without costs and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, town and town board, sought review of the judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which reversed the town board's decision denying petitioner developer's application to rezone land and remitted the developer's application to the town board for further factual development.


OVERVIEW: The developer brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding to (1) annul the town board's decision denying the developer's application to rezone land for a shopping center and (2) secure an order requiring the rezoning of the land. The lower court determined that the town board's factual findings were conclusory statements that were arbitrary and unreasonable. It reversed the decision and remitted the developer's application to the town board for further factual development. The town and the town board appealed. The court reversed the judgment and dismissed the developer's petition because there was no evidence to support the lower court's determination that the town board's action was arbitrary or discriminatory.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and dismissed the developer's petition.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- in article 78 proceeding brought to annul decision of Town Board which refused to rezone petitioner's property to that of shopping center district, petition is dismissed; determination to approve or reject planned unit development (PUD) is legislative, rather than administrative determination -- although board restricted its discretion to approve shopping centers only within previously set up districts, decision to rezone or not to rezone was not, therefore, administrative -- town's PUD procedures not analogous to application for special use permit -- board's determination did not deprive petitioner of due process of law.

1. Pursuant to the Town of Webster Zoning Ordinance and Official Map, land owned by petitioner, a developer of retail [***2] shopping centers, was placed in a district limited to single family dwellings and various public, religious and agricultural uses. The Town Board was given authority to establish a planned shopping center district within that district, and petitioner went through the procedure outlined in the ordinance to have the property rezoned. Ultimately, the Town Board denied the request for intent to rezone. In an article 78 proceeding brought to annul this decision, the petition is dismissed. The determination to approve or reject a planned unit development (PUD) is a legislative, rather than an administrative determination, and judicial review may only ascertain whether the local legislative body had authority to act as it did under its zoning enabling statute or whether the action is an unconstitutional taking or deprivation of due process or equal protection. Inasmuch as the Town of Webster ordinance states that the Town Board shall enact the legislation to create the appropriate PUD district, the intent to rezone is a legislative act and must be performed by the board.

2. Although the board restricted its discretion to approve planned shopping centers only within districts set up [***3] in 1969, it does not follow that the board's secondary decision to rezone or not to rezone was administrative. The Zoning Ordinance and Master Plan did not limit the district use to shopping centers only since other residential and commercial uses were permitted, as well as public uses.

3. The town's PUD procedures are not analogous to an application for a special use permit, which involves only administrative action. Special use permits usually seek approval for a specified single use on a small parcel, whereas PUD is a multi-use proposal for large scale developments. The proposed shopping center has a greater impact on the body politic and the community, and a broad determination by the town's legislative body is more appropriate for this task.

4. The board's determination did not deprive petitioner of due process of law by virtue of being an unreasonable exercise of zoning powers. The burden of proving the legislative zoning decision unreasonable is upon petitioner, and no evidence was produced to support a judicial determination that the board's action was arbitrary or discriminatory.

 

710 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Scannelli


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


49 A.D.2d 648; 370 N.Y.S.2d 254; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10481



July 10, 1975, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the County Court of Clinton County (New York) that convicted him of absconding from temporary release in the first degree, a violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 205.17.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of absconding from temporary release in the first degree. He argued that the trial court did not have jurisdiction to convict him because, if his act of absconding took place, it was outside the geographic boundary of the court. In affirming the conviction, the court noted that defendant was released from a facility located in the county in order to participate in the temporary release program. He intentionally failed to return to the facility by the proscribed time. The duty to return imposed by N.Y. Penal Law § 205.17 was required to be performed in the county or satisfied in that county.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the conviction, holding the state criminal procedure law governed the situation and provided ample authority for the county court to entertain jurisdiction over the offense and defendant upon the indictment presented to it.

 

711 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Galpin


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


49 A.D.2d 654; 370 N.Y.S.2d 249; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10489



July 10, 1975, Decided

 

712 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Anthony "CC"


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


48 A.D.2d 415; 370 N.Y.S.2d 219; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9908



July 2, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant mother challenged an order of the Family Court, Schenectady County (New York), which determined that her minor child was permanently neglected and permanently terminated the mother's custody of the child pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act §§ 611, 614.


OVERVIEW: A child was placed in the care of the county social services department at age two when his mother became a heroin addict. Afterwards the mother was incarcerated most of the time and had no regular contact with the child. She contended that the evidence before the trial court was insufficient to prove permanent neglect under § 611 of the Act or sustain the findings required under § 614 of the Act to justify termination of parental custody. She also claimed that article 6 of the Act was unconstitutional because it did not define the parental conduct that justified termination of custody. In affirming, the court held that the record established that the department had tried to strengthen and encourage the parental relationship but that the mother had not maintained contact with the child or formulated or seriously contemplated any plans for the child's future. Although there was some evidence that the mother had rehabilitated herself and wanted the child, she was arrested between the date of the decision finding the child permanently neglected and the date of the disposition hearing. The statutory requirements for termination did not violate due process.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the finding that the child was permanently neglected and the order terminating permanently the mother's custody of the child.


HEADNOTES

Parent and child -- custody of children -- permanently neglected child -- appellant's conduct toward her child has met definition of "permanently neglected child" and Agency carried out its responsibility (Family Ct Act, § 611); accordingly, appellant's custody of child was properly terminated permanently -- failure of appellant to provide for child physically and financially was result of her own transgressions and purpose of section 611 should not be defeated by negative action -- sections 611, 614 and 622 of Family Court Act are not unconstitutional.

1. The conduct of appellant toward her child has met the definition of a "permanently neglected child" and the Agency, in whose care the child has been, has carried out its responsibility as required by section 611 of the Family Court Act. Appellant, a heroin addict, has been incarcerated for most [***2] of the time since the child came into the care of the Agency. Although she overcame her addiction, her incarceration has continued. While she has been on furlough, parole or not yet convicted, she only had three visits with the child and the record establishes that she has not kept regular contact with the child or the Agency. The Agency gave her as much encouragement to enter into a continuing parental relationship as her way of life permitted. Accordingly, appellant's custody of the child was properly terminated permanently.

2. The record does not establish affirmatively that appellant was physically or financially able to provide for the child. Such failure was the direct result of her own transgressions. Therefore, the purpose of section 611 of the Family Court Act, which speaks affirmatively with respect to the mother's physical and financial ability to provide, should not be defeated by negative action. The intent of the statute was satisfied.

3. Sections 611, 614 and 622 of the Family Court Act are not unconstitutional because of a failure to define the conduct of a parent and because section 622 does not require adequate weight of the evidence. The proof required [***3] by the statute is for the court to decide. Due process infirmities are not established.

 

713 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Leo v. Barnett


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


48 A.D.2d 463; 369 N.Y.S.2d 789; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9918



June 30, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order of the Supreme Court, Suffolk County, dated November 15, 1974, reversed, on the law, without costs; plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment denied, and defendants' cross application for summary judgment granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, town and members of the town board, challenged the judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which granted summary judgment in favor of respondent attorneys in the attorneys' action to recover the value of legal services rendered to town public officials wrongfully ousted from office.


OVERVIEW: The attorneys successfully represented the public officials in an action filed by them against the town for reinstatement after they were wrongfully ousted. The attorneys filed an action to recover the value of their services after the town failed to provide payment. The trial court granted the attorneys' motion for summary judgment. On appeal, the court reversed, finding that in the absence of express statutory authority, the town was not liable for the payment of the value of the legal services rendered to the public officers who successfully sued to be reinstated after wrongful removal from office. The court held that at common law the public officers contested their ouster at their own expense regardless of the baseless character of the attack. The court noted that neither party had cited it to a statute that allowed counsel fees to a town officer who defeated an attempt to remove him from office.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the grant of summary judgment in favor of the attorneys in their action against the town and the members of the town board to recover the value of legal services rendered to public officials. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the town and dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and client -- action against town -- attorneys at law may not recover from town and members of town board value of legal services rendered to assessor of town and members of Board of Assessment Review in securing annulment of resolution of town board removing them from office and in securing their reinstatement.

Attorneys at law may not recover from the Town of Babylon and the members of its town board the value of legal services rendered to the assessor of the town, and to the members of the Board of Assessment Review of the town in securing an annulment of the resolution of the town board by which they were removed from office and having them reinstated. At common law a [***2] public officer contested his ouster at his own expense. In the absence of statutory authority expressly permitting the payment of counsel fees, a public officer or his attorneys may not recover for such counsel fees in successfully opposing his removal from office.

 

714 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mariculture, Ltd. v. Biggane


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


48 A.D.2d 295; 369 N.Y.S.2d 219; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9883



June 12, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order modified, on the law and the facts, by vacating the preliminary injunction, with costs to defendants, and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation (commissioner) appealed from an order of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which granted plaintiff turtle raiser's motion for a preliminary injunction in his action seeking a declaration that N.Y. Agric. & Mkt. Law § 358-a did not apply to him.


OVERVIEW: The turtle raiser had a farm out of the country where he raised a particular type of turtle and offered their shells and other parts for sale within the State of New York. The raiser brought an action seeking a declaration that § 358-a did not apply to him because he did not sell "wild animal" parts. The trial court granted a preliminary injunction against the commissioner's enforcement of § 358-a against him pending the outcome of the action. The commissioner sought review of that order and the court modified the order by vacating the preliminary injunction. The court held that it was error to have granted the injunction upon a finding that the turtle raiser's interpretation of § 358-a was "not unreasonable" and that therefore he had a fair possibility of success. The court held that the turtle raiser had failed to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits, which was essential to the granting of a preliminary injunction. The court noted that the raiser's threat of financial injury was not sufficient to warrant preliminary injunctive relief where the injury was measured against the threat of injury to a public interest.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's order by vacating the preliminary injunction granted to the turtle raiser pending the outcome of his declaratory judgment action against the commissioner, wherein he sought a determination that a statute prohibiting the sale of certain turtles was not applicable to him.


HEADNOTES

Injunctions -- preliminary injunctions -- in granting preliminary injunction to plaintiff against enforcement of section 358-a of Agriculture and Markets Law, which prohibits sale of parts of skin or body in New York of marine turtles of family Cheloniidae, trial court failed to adopt correct standard, which is that before injunction will issue there must be shown clear legal and equitable right to relief demanded -- threat of financial injury to plaintiff is not alone sufficient to warrant preliminary injunction where injury is measured against threat of injury to public interest -- defendants not entitled to preliminary injunction against plaintiff since they have adequate remedy at law pursuant to sections 358-a and 41 of Agriculture and Markets Law.

1. Plaintiff, a foreign corporation that raises marine turtles of the family Cheloniidae, was [***2] granted a preliminary injunction against enforcement of section 358-a of the Agriculture and Markets Law, which states that no part of the skin or body of such wild animals may be sold within New York. Taking into account plaintiff's interpretation of the statute, that since it expressly prohibits the sale of "wild animal" parts, the sale of turtles raised from eggs is not prohibited, the injunction was granted upon the trial court's finding that plaintiff's interpretation was "not unreasonable" and therefore plaintiff had a "fair probability of success" in the main action. The court failed to adopt the correct standard, which is that before an injunction will issue there must be shown a clear legal and equitable right to the relief demanded, especially where the enforcement of law is involved. Since defendants' interpretation of the statute, that "wild animals" was not meant to exclude the sale of animals which are by their nature wild merely because they are raised in a man-controlled environment, appears to be more reasonable, plaintiff has failed to demonstrate a likelihood of success.

2. The threat of financial injury to plaintiff is not alone sufficient to warrant preliminary [***3] injunctive relief where the injury is measured against the threat of injury to a public interest which the Legislature has determined to outweigh commercial interests.

3. Although it is unlikely that plaintiff will be able to show that its activities are not in violation of the statute, defendants are not entitled to a preliminary injunction against plaintiff since they have an adequate remedy at law pursuant to the enforcement provisions of section 358-a and the penal sanctions of section 41 of the Agriculture and Markets Law.

 

715 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hodgkins v. Central School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


48 A.D.2d 302; 368 N.Y.S.2d 891; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9885



June 12, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff tenured teachers challenged the decision of the Supreme Court, Broome County (New York), which granted summary judgment to defendant school district, in the teachers' action challenging the right of the school district to suspend the teachers and to remove them from their teaching duties pending a hearing on charges pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 3020-a.


OVERVIEW: The teachers were advised that pursuant to § 3020-a that the school district was suspending them on charges of unwarranted and excessive physical force against students. A federal district court subsequently ruled that § 3020-a was unconstitutional absent administrative regulations requiring a decision to be based upon evidence elicited before a hearing panel with resulting factual determinations. The Board of Regents of the State of New York (board) approved an amendment to the commissioner of education's regulations in conformance with the decision. The teachers challenged the updated regulations and the disciplinary proceeding as applied to them. The trial court found in favor of the school district and the teachers sought review. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that the board was authorized to pass the regulations it did, and the commissioner was duly authorized to carry them out. In addition, the suspension of the teachers without pay pending the final determination of disciplinary proceedings under § 3020-a, provided such determination was not unreasonably delayed, involved no infringement of the teachers' constitutional rights.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the summary judgment in favor of the school district in the teachers' action challenging the right of the school district to suspend the teachers and to remove them from their teaching duties pending a hearing on charges pursuant to an education law provision.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- teachers -- disciplinary proceedings -- defendant Commissioner of Education had power to promulgate new regulations ( 8 NYCRR 82.10 [h]) for conducting disciplinary hearings ( Education Law, § 3020-a) -- plaintiffs, tenured teachers, were properly suspended pending final determination of disciplinary proceeding charging them with excessive use of force against students; suspension prior to hearing did not violate plaintiffs' due process rights since hearings were not unreasonably delayed.

1. Plaintiffs, tenured teachers of defendant school district, were properly suspended pending the final determination of disciplinary proceedings ( Education Law, § 3020-a) charging them with unwarranted and excessive use of physical force against students. To remedy certain unconstitutional procedures [***2] under section 3020-a (see Kinsella v Board of Educ. of Cent. School Dist. No. 7 of Towns of Amherst and Tonawanda, 378 F Supp 54), defendant Commissioner of Education, pursuant to the power granted him under section 3020-a (subd 3, par c) to establish necessary rules and procedures for the conduct of hearings, properly promulgated regulations requiring a board of education to base its decision solely on the record before the hearing panel, to set forth the results and factual basis for the determination and requiring the commissioner to forward the hearing transcript to the board of education ( 8 NYCRR 82.10 [h], 82.11). The regulations adopted are within the scope of the broad policy, rule making and administrative powers granted to the commissioner and the Board of Regents under the Education Law.

2. Since the disciplinary proceedings were not unreasonably delayed, plaintiffs' due process rights as tenured teachers were not violated by their suspension prior to a hearing. A balancing of the governmental interest against the rights of a tenured teacher accused of using excessive physical force on students weighs in favor of suspension prior to a hearing.

 

716 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


AMF, Inc. v. Algo Distributors, Ltd.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


48 A.D.2d 352; 369 N.Y.S.2d 460; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9880



June 9, 1975 



DISPOSITION: On this appeal from an order of the Supreme Court, Westchester County, dated March 15, 1974, this court rendered a decision and order, both dated May 7, 1975. Now, on this court's own motion said decision and order are recalled and vacated and the following decision is rendered.

Order of March 15, 1974 modified so as to provide that the defendants' motion to vacate the order of attachment is granted as to defendants Mildred Swartz and Marion Swartz and, except as so granted, is otherwise denied. As so modified, order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant corporation, defendant officers, and defendant individuals filed a motion to vacate an order of attachment obtained by plaintiff creditor. The supreme court (New York) denied the motion. The corporation, officers, and individuals appealed.


OVERVIEW: The creditor and the corporation entered into an agreement whereby the creditor acquired a security interest, later perfected, in all inventory sold to the corporation, including the proceeds realized from any resale. Subsequently, the creditor obtained an ex parte order of attachment. The summons, verified complaint, and order of attachment, together with the affidavits submitted in support of that application, were then served upon the corporation, the officers, and the individuals. In response, they argued the papers upon which the order of attachment was granted were insufficient in that they failed to show that a cause of action for conversion existed in favor of the creditor and that any ex parte attachment based upon N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6201 was unconstitutional. On appeal, the court found the creditor's complaint and affidavits established a prima facie cause of action against the corporation and the officers only. Moreover, the corporation and the officers, on their motion to vacate, did not establish that the creditor would ultimately fail.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed as modified to provide that the motion to vacate the order of attachment was granted as to the individuals.


HEADNOTES

Attachment -- constitutional law -- conversion -- where security agreement imposed upon debtor obligation to hold specific moneys for creditor and barred debtor from disbursing those moneys for general corporate purposes, and diversion of proceeds occurred, debtor and individual corporate officers who participated in misconduct are liable -- ex parte order of attachment based upon CPLR 6201 (subd 8) is not unconstitutional for failure  [***2] to afford defendants notice and opportunity for hearing prior to seizure of their property.

1. Plaintiff obtained an ex parte order of attachment against the property of the corporate defendant and all the individual defendants. The complaint contained a cause of action for damages from all of the defendants for the alleged conversion by them of the proceeds of the sale of inventory acquired by the corporate defendant pursuant to a security agreement. Plaintiff's papers sufficiently established the existence of a security interest in the collateral and in the proceeds of any sale thereof, the sale of the collateral, the failure by two of the defendants to pay over the proceeds on behalf of the corporate defendant upon proper demand therefor and the diversion of the proceeds for general corporate purposes. Additionally, the express terms of the security agreement created an immediate right to possession of specific moneys, since under its terms the debtor covenanted to account to the plaintiff for the proceeds of any goods upon request. A prima facie cause of action for conversion was spelled out against two of the defendants, but not against two others. The security agreement [***3] imposed upon the debtor the obligation to hold specific moneys for the creditor and barred the debtor from disbursing those moneys for general corporate purposes.
