In this context, where a diversion of the proceeds occurs, the debtor and the individual corporate officers who participated in the misconduct are personally liable. There was ample proof in the pleadings that two of the defendants were corporate officers and knowingly participated in the prohibited conduct. However, the pleadings are insufficient to establish that either of the other two was an officer of the corporate defendant or anticipated in the conversion of the proceeds.

2. An ex parte order of attachment based upon CPLR 6201 (subd 8) is not unconstitutional for failure to afford the defendants notice and an opportunity for a hearing prior to the seizure of their property. The CPLR provisions regarding attachment are closely analogous to the Louisiana statute which was held constitutional in Mitchell v W.T. Grant Co. (416 U.S. 600), since: there is judicial scrutiny over the application; the creditor must show that there is a cause of action, that grounds exist and the amount demanded; the creditor is required [***4] to post a bond to protect the debtor from damages; the debtor may regain possession and discharge the attachment by posting a bond; and any person claiming an interest in the debt or property may move for an order to vacate or modify the attachment. Nor is CPLR article 62 defective for failure to provide an immediate postseizure hearing at which the creditor has the burden of proving the grounds upon which the writ issued. The fact that the burden of proof is placed upon the debtor to establish the order's invalidity is not a ground upon which the entire statutory scheme must fall.

 

717 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Peterkin


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


48 A.D.2d 843; 368 N.Y.S.2d 290; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10060



June 2, 1975, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of his conviction following a jury trial in the Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York) for robbery in the third degree and grand larceny in the third degree and of the denial of his motion to suppress.


OVERVIEW: A police officer arrested defendant in a hospital for loitering. After the arrest, the officer noticed a bulge in defendant's pocket which, upon examination, proved to be money. When a gas station attendant identified the money as having been stolen in a robbery by a man wearing clothing similar to defendant's and of similar build who ran in the direction of the hospital, the loitering charge was dismissed and defendant was indicted for robbery. Reversing defendant's conviction, the court determined that the trial court erred in denying defendant's motion to suppress because the warrantless search made as an incident to the arrest under the loitering statute, which had been declared unconstitutional prior to defendant's trial, was illegal since the statute plainly undercut the requirement of the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution that arrests were lawful only on a showing of probable cause. The court further determined that without the evidence seized in the unlawful search there was no probable cause to support defendant's arrest for robbery.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction, granted defendant's motion to suppress, and dismissed the indictment.

 

718 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Goldswer


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


48 A.D.2d 748; 368 N.Y.S.2d 323; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9828



May 29, 1975, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court, Warren County (New York), which, following a jury verdict, convicted him of 11 misdemeanor counts of official misconduct in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 195.00(1).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was found guilty of misconduct or violations of regulations that provided minimum standards for jails. Defendant appealed. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment. The court found that N.Y. Penal Law § 195.00(1), pursuant to which defendant was convicted, was not too vague because the language clearly apprised a reasonable person of the nature of the acts prohibited and of what conduct was required. The court ruled that defendant failed to overcome the strong presumption of constitutionality. The court found no merit to defendant's contention that he was deprived of a speedy trial because defendant's pretrial motions consumed considerable time through no fault on the part of the prosecution. Further, the court held that the record in its entirety revealed there was ample proof to justify the jury's verdict of guilty of the 11 counts of official misconduct.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that convicted defendant of 11 misdemeanor counts of official misconduct.

 

719 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority v. Public Employment Relations Board


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


48 A.D.2d 206; 368 N.Y.S.2d 66; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9576; 77 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P53,711



May 22, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed, and petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner bus authority sought review of a judgment by respondent New York Public Employment Relations Board (board), which held that dispatchers and foremen employed by the bus authority did not meet the criteria for management status within the meaning of the Taylor Law, N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law, § 201(5).


OVERVIEW: The board found that the dispatchers and foremen employed by the bus authority did not come within the definition of managerial employees under the Taylor Law, N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law, § 201(7)(a), and, accordingly, were not exempt from coverage under the Taylor Law. The bus authority appealed. The court held that the determination of the employees' status under the Taylor Law required a consideration of whether the activities of the dispatchers and foremen had a major role in the administration of agreements or in personnel administration, provided that such roles were not of a routine or clerical nature and required the exercise of independent judgment. The court held that the employees clearly had no power to resolve actual grievances beyond initial claims. The court concluded that the employees did not warrant a designation as managerial because the employees had no role in establishing the standards for terminating employees and could only discharge subordinate employees for conduct which would immediately affect their capacity to perform their duties without danger to the public.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the decision of the board and dismissed the bus authority's petition challenging the board's ruling that the authority's dispatchers and foremen did not meet the definition of managerial employees.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- Public Employees' Fair Employment Act -- determination of Public Employment Relations Board that dispatchers and foremen employed by bus authority are not managerial employees, and, therefore, are not excluded from Taylor Law coverage, is confirmed -- they act in supervisory capacity but do not have major nonroutine role in administration of collective bargaining agreements or in personnel administration.

A determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) that dispatchers and foremen employed by the Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority are not managerial employees, and, therefore, are not excluded [***2] from Taylor Law coverage, is confirmed. While these employees act in a supervisory capacity, that fact alone is not sufficient to exclude them from being organized into a bargaining unit, but they must also "have a major role in the administration of [collective bargaining] agreements or in personnel administration provided that such role is not of a routine or clerical nature and requires the exercise of independent judgment" ( Civil Service Law, § 201, subd 7, par [a]). The record here establishes that, while these employees are involved in the administration of collective bargaining agreements to the extent that they are the ones to whom subordinates would first make their complaints known, they would merely be ascertaining factual matters at that stage, not making any major interpretation of the agreements, and, although they might later be involved as witnesses to factual matters, they clearly have no power to resolve actual grievances once the grievance procedure goes beyond the first step. The record also establishes that, while they have been given powers which directly affect personnel administration, those powers are exercisable only in accordance with standards which [***3] they have no part in formulating, and, in substance, they are merely a basic level of management, exercising routine roles and having no apparent major role in personnel administration. Accordingly, the record contains substantial evidence to support the finding of PERB that they do not warrant a designation as managerial employees.

 

720 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York State School Bus Operators Asso. v. County of Nassau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


48 A.D.2d 671; 367 N.Y.S.2d 825; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9692



May 12, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order-judgment modified, on the law, by adding thereto a provision declaring the operation of charter bus and school bus transportation by defendants to be constitutional and legal. As so modified, order-judgment affirmed, without costs.

 

721 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Morton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


48 A.D.2d 58; 367 N.Y.S.2d 595; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9542



May 8, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law, to the extent of vacating the sentence imposed on February 13, 1974, and matter remitted to the County Court of Albany County for resentencing defendant as a first felony offender.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Albany County Court (New York), which found defendant guilty of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the fifth degree and sentenced him as a second felony offender pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06.


OVERVIEW: Defendant entered a guilty plea to the charge of criminal possession of marijuana in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 220.09(10), which was a felony. At sentencing, it was established that defendant had been convicted of possession of marijuana in Texas for which he had been sentenced to five years in prison, with confinement suspended and probation imposed for five years. Under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06, the trial court sentence defendant as a second felony offender. On appeal, defendant contended § 70.06 was unconstitutional. The court agreed, holding that: (1) imposing sentence for a second felony based on another state's felony conviction denied defendant equal protection of the laws guaranteed by U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11; (2) such sentencing also resulted in the delegation of legislative authority by the New York Senate and Assembly to legislatures of other jurisdictions in violation of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1; (3) the legislative power for prescribing the proper punishment for criminal offenses could not be delegated to any other legislative body; therefore, (4) N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 was declared unconstitutional and null and void.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the sentenced imposed by the trial court based on its finding that defendant was a second felony offender, vacated the sentence, and remitted the matter to the trial court for resentencing of defendant as a first felony offender.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence -- second felony offender status -- section 70.06 of Penal Law, which mandates second felony offender status for persons previously convicted in other States for offenses for which term exceeding one year was authorized, deprives defendant of equal protection of law, since conviction for certain acts committed out of State would require second offender status, while same acts committed in New York State would result in first offender status -- term of imprisonment authorized in another jurisdiction cannot be basis of punishment in New York State, since delegation of responsibility to prescribe punishment would violate constitutional provision vesting legislative power of State in Senate and Assembly -- defendant  [***2] did not waive right to challenge sentence by failing to proceed for determination of status, since prior convictions are not disputed and do not bear upon constitutional issue -- accordingly, judgment of conviction is reversed and matter remitted for resentencing of defendant as first offender.

1. The operation of section 70.06 of the Penal Law, which mandates second felony offender status for persons previously convicted in other States for offenses for which a term of imprisonment exceeding one year was authorized, deprives the defendant of the equal protection of the law. A conviction under various out-of-State statutes would require imposition of second felony offender status, while a conviction in New York State for the same underlying acts would entitle the defendant to first offender status.

2. The term of imprisonment authorized in another jurisdiction cannot serve as the basis for determining the extent of punishment upon a felony conviction in New York State, since a delegation of the responsibility to prescribe punishment would violate the constitutional provision (NY Const, art III, § 1) vesting the legislative power of the State in the Senate and Assembly.

3. The [***3] defendant did not waive his right to challenge his sentence by failing to proceed under CPL 400.21 for a determination of his second offender status, since the defendant's prior convictions are not in dispute and have no bearing upon the constitutionality of section 70.06 of the Penal Law.

4. Accordingly, section 70.06 of the Penal Law is declared unconstitutional insofar as it provides that the extent of punishment for a New York State felon depends upon the authorized sentence for a conviction in another State, the judgment of conviction should be reversed and the matter remitted for resentencing defendant as a first felony offender.

 

722 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fishman


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


48 A.D.2d 726; 367 N.Y.S.2d 608; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9794



May 8, 1975, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the County Court, Albany County (New York), which convicted him of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree because the search warrant issued in Albany was jurisdictionally invalid in the town of Colonie.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree pursuant to a search warrant issued to the Albany police. Defendant appealed his conviction on the grounds that the issuing magistrate did not have jurisdiction to issue a warrant to the Albany police or to search defendant's premises in the town of Colonie. The court affirmed defendant's conviction. The court found that, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 690.20(2), a search warrant issued by a city court could be executed in the county of issuance or an adjoining county.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

723 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rizzo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


47 A.D.2d 468; 367 N.Y.S.2d 523; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9519



May 5, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of the Supreme Court, Suffolk County, rendered July 17, 1972, reversed, on the law, motion to suppress evidence granted and case remitted to said court for further proceedings.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the decision of the Supreme Court (New York), which convicted him of possession for sale of untaxed cigarettes in violation of N.Y. Tax Law § 20, contending that the evidence obtained during a warrantless search of his residence should have been suppressed.


OVERVIEW: Based on suspicion and a complaint, a warrantless administrative search was conducted of defendant's residence without his permission, and untaxed cigarettes were seized. The court reversed defendant's conviction, and suppressed the cigarette evidence because the warrantless administrative search provision of N.Y. Tax Law § 474 did not include the right to search a residence without consent.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction for possession for sale of untaxed cigarettes, granted defendant's motion to suppress the evidence, and remanded the matter for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- unlawful search and seizure -- administrative search -- section 474 of Tax Law, which provides for examination of cigarettes in any premises where they are sold or stored, does not justify warrantless search of residence of defendant, whose only connection to statute was investigator's observation of 30 cartons of cigarettes and hearsay information that person possibly connected to premises had prior arrest for possession of untaxed cigarettes; quantity of cigarettes and possibility of storage were insufficient and privacy interest too great and statute does not contemplate nonconsensual search of residence; accordingly, evidence should be suppressed on ground that seizure was result of unreasonable search.

 Section 474 of the Tax Law, which [***2] provides that the State Tax Commission is authorized to examine the stock of cigarettes in any premises or vehicle of any person in possession of premises where cigarettes are placed, stored, sold or offered for sale, does not justify a warrantless search of the garage of the defendant's residence. The only connection of the defendant to the statute was the suspicion of a tax investigator based upon observation of 30 cartons of cigarettes and upon hearsay information that a person possibly connected with the premises had previously been arrested for possession of untaxed cigarettes. The quantity of cigarettes observed was too small, the possibility of storage and sale too weak and the privacy interest too great to invoke the inspection powers of the statute, and although it is unclear that the authority to inspect includes the right to enter and search without consent, the statute does not contemplate nonconsensual entry and search of a residence. The essentially judicial determination of whether the statute applies to the residence of the defendant, who had no obvious connection with the cigarette industry, should not be left to a field investigator. Accordingly, the motion by [***3] defendant to suppress the cigarettes which were seized should be granted on the ground that the seizure was a result of an unreasonable search.

 

724 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Koutrakos v. Long Island College Hospital


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


47 A.D.2d 500; 368 N.Y.S.2d 528; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9525



May 5, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order modified, on the law, without costs, by striking the figure $ 13,424.91 from the third decretal paragraph thereof and substituting therefor the figure $ 20,870. As so modified, order affirmed insofar as appealed from, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York), directing that payment be made to it from the settlement of an action in satisfaction of its lien for workers' compensation benefits less deductions for respondent's attorney fees and expenses of the action.


OVERVIEW: Respondent's husband was killed in an accidental injury that occurred in the course of his employment. His employer carried workers' compensation insurance through appellant. Respondent claimed and received death benefits. She later filed a wrongful death action to recover damages for the alleged failure of defendant hospitals to properly treat and diagnose her husband's condition. She settled the suit with court approval. Appellant's lien was ordered to be paid; however, a deduction was made for respondent's attorney's fees and court costs. On appeal, the court modified the amount payable to appellant, finding appellant to be eligible for full reimbursement of the benefits that it paid. Respondent's attorney's fees and court costs were not to be taxed to appellant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment but modified the amount awarded to appellant, because appellant was not responsible for respondent's attorney fees or costs.


HEADNOTES

Workmen's compensation -- attorney's fees -- carrier's lien -- subdivision 1 of section 29 of Workmen's Compensation Law, which requires that compensation carrier's lien be satisfied in full without carrier proportionately sharing cost of plaintiff's attorney's fees in effectuating recovery in third-party action, does not  [***2] violate either Federal or State Constitution -- rectification of statute's possible inequity is by repeal or modification by Legislature.

1. Subdivision 1 of section 29 of the Workmen's Compensation Law, which requires that a compensation carrier's lien be satisfied in full without the carrier proportionately sharing the cost of plaintiff's attorney's fees in effectuating recovery in her third-party action, does not violate either the Federal or State Constitution. After receiving a workmen's compensation award, plaintiff's compromise of a wrongful death action against a third party resulted in a settlement for her in the amount of $ 150,000. Holding subdivision 1 of section 29 unconstitutional, the Trial Judge asserted that defendant carrier's lien for the total amount of compensation paid by it was subject to a proportionate share of plaintiff's attorney's fee for prosecuting the third-party action, as computed in relation to the total over-all recovery. Since subdivision 1 of section 29 does not violate either the State or Federal Constitution, the carrier is reimbursed in full for its lien. The statute presently gives greater benefits to an injured employee or his dependents [***3] than it did when it was held by both the United States Supreme Court and the New York Court of Appeals as not violative of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Federal Constitution, and the Supreme Court's decision has been consistently cited with approval in subsequent decisions of that court. The explicit language of section 18 of article I of the New York Constitution (which states that "nothing contained in this constitution" shall be construed to limit the plenary power of the Legislature to enact workmen's compensation laws) puts to rest all attacks on the Workmen's Compensation Law predicated on the State Constitution.

2. Although a strict application of subdivision 1 of section 29 has been termed unfair and unconscionable, rectification is by its repeal or modification by the Legislature, and while the Legislature has been put on notice of the possible inequity, it has seen fit to do nothing about it.

 

725 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Drayton


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


47 A.D.2d 952; 367 N.Y.S.2d 506; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9430



April 28, 1975, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a 16-year old young man, was indicted by a grand jury in Kings County, New York, charging him with the felonies of attempted robbery in the second degree and assault in the second degree. He was sentenced to one year in jail, and he appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, a young man 16 years of age, was charged with commission of the felonies of robbery in the second degree and assault in the second degree. The trial judge indicated that he would charge defendant as a youthful offender if his probation report would support such a charge. The probation report indicated that defendant had a very serious history. Therefore, the trial judge instead imposed a one year sentence. Defendant appealed the judgment. The judge had absolute discretion in determining whether to charge defendant, a 16-year old boy, as a youthful offender. The purpose of charging defendant was the hope of rehabilitating him. Based on his record, the chance of rehabilitation was not high. Defendant was charged with a felony, not a misdemeanor. Defendant had already received the benefit of being charged as a youthful offender. Based on the defendant's record and the trial judge's discretion, it was appropriate to sentence defendant to one year.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was affirmed. It was appropriate to sentence defendant to one year in jail. The trial judge had absolute discretion when determining whether to charge defendant as a youthful offender.

 

726 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cathedral Academy v. State


Claim No. 56557


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


47 A.D.2d 390; 366 N.Y.S.2d 900; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9507



April 24, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parochial school brought an action under 1972 N.Y. Laws 996 against respondent State of New York for reimbursement of funds it had expended in the performance of services under the Mandated Services Act, 1970 N.Y. Laws 138, before the Act was declared unconstitutional. The New York Court of Claims dismissed on the ground that 1972 N.Y. Laws 996 violated the First Amendment's Establishment Clause. The school appealed.


OVERVIEW: The Act provided that qualifying non-public schools were to be reimbursed for expenses incurred in providing various testing, record-keeping, and related services required by separate statutory authority. The payments were not conditioned upon performance, and the amounts of reimbursement were based on the judgment of the New York State Education Department. The Act was declared an unconstitutional aid to religion, as the aid devoted to secular functions was not identifiable and separate from aid to sectarian activities. The State was permanently enjoined from reimbursing non-public schools under the Act. Prior to the Act being declared unconstitutional, the school incurred expenses for which it would have been entitled to reimbursement. 1972 N.Y. Laws 996 conferred jurisdiction to hear, audit, and determine claims of eligible non-public schools for reimbursement of funds expended in reliance of the Act. The court held that 1972 N.Y. Laws 996 violated the Establishment Clause, as payments thereunder were to be determined by the same formula as had been in effect under the Act. The constitutional interests were recurring, as the State needed to provide oversight.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that declared that a remedial state statute violated the First Amendment's Establishment Clause.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- aid to nonpublic schools -- identifiable secular purposes -- chapter 996 of Laws of 1972, which authorizes determination of claims of nonpublic schools for expenses incurred in providing statutorily required services no longer reimbursable under invalidated Mandated Services Act (L. 1970, ch. 138), is unconstitutional, since payments would be under either previously invalidated formula or based upon actual costs, requiring audit which would excessively entangle the State with church schools.

Chapter 996 of the Laws of 1972, which confers on the Court of Claims jurisdiction to determine claims by nonpublic secondary and elementary schools for reimbursement for expenses incurred in providing statutorily required services no longer reimbursable under the invalidated Mandated Services Act (L. 1970, ch. 138), is unconstitutional. The Mandated Services Act was held to violate the religion clause of First Amendment because no relationship [***2] was shown between the payment formula and the secular purposes to which the payments would be applied. If payments are to be made under chapter 996 of the Laws of 1972 according to that same formula, such payments would be unconstitutional because not limited to an identifiable secular purpose. If only actual costs are reimbursed, some process of audit, inspection and supervision would be required which would foster an excessive entanglement between church schools and State. Although payments have been upheld where the constitutional interests involved were "implicated only once under special circumstances that will not recur", that situation occurred when the "entangling" process was already completed with no invalidity of the payments per se, whereas in this case the payments themselves have been invalidated and State supervision would be required.

 

727 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Prim


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


47 A.D.2d 409; 366 N.Y.S.2d 726; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9509



April 23, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and a new trial granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of her conviction and sentence by the Erie County Court (New York) for grand larceny in the second degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 155.35 and a misdemeanor violation of N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 145. Defendant claimed that the trial court erred because it had not held a hearing on her challenge to the venire as required by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.10, and had not permitted her discovery of particular documents.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, who received public assistance through the Department of Social Services (DSS), also received other income, which she claimed had been condoned by the DSS. Prior to trial, defendant sought discovery of DSS inter-office memoranda, which she claimed would have shown that DSS was aware of and condoned her receipt of other income. Defendant also challenged the entire jury panel under the Sixth Amendment, claiming that students, blacks, women, the poor and young people had been intentionally excluded, depriving her of the right to a fair and impartial jury. On appeal, the court reversed the conviction and remanded the case for a new trial, finding first that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.10 had required the trial court to have conducted a hearing on defendant's challenge to the venire because she had demonstrated facts that supported her challenge. The court also held that the trial court had abused its discretion in denying defendant's pre-trial motion that sought discovery of the DSS memoranda. Since defendant had waived the confidentiality of the memoranda, the court held that she had been denied her rights of due process, confrontation, and equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction and remanded the case for a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- wrongful appropriation of public welfare funds -- defendant was improperly convicted of both grand larceny in second degree and violation of section 145 of Social Services Law, both based on same conduct on her part, involving wrongful appropriation of public welfare funds, since latter statute provides that person violating it is guilty of misdemeanor unless act constitutes violation of Penal Law, in which case he is to be punished in accordance with penalties fixed by Penal Law -- trial court erred in failing to conduct hearing on oral defense challenge to jury panel -- it abused its discretion in denying defense request for pretrial discovery of inter-office memoranda of Department of Social Services -- circumstantial evidence adduced by People is sufficient to establish beyond reasonable doubt that defendant acted with requisite felonious intent, and charge was fair and correct  [***2] on law -- errors in failing to conduct hearing on challenge and in not permitting requested discovery make new trial necessary.

1. Defendant was improperly convicted of both grand larceny in the second degree (Penal Law, § 155.35) and a violation of section 145 of the Social Services Law. The evidence unquestionably demonstrated that she committed a series of acts with the culpable intent or design of appropriating public welfare funds to herself or to third parties, and the same conduct on her part constituted violations of both section 155.35 of the Penal Law and section 145 of the Social Services Law. The latter section provides that a person who violates that statute is guilty of a misdemeanor unless his act constitutes a violation of the Penal Law, in which case he is to be punished in accordance with the penalties fixed by the Penal Law. Therefore, and in view of the fact that the record supports the larceny conviction, no misdemeanor offense survived of which defendant could be convicted.

2. The trial court erred in failing to conduct a hearing on a challenge made by defendant to the jury panel. Although it was not made in writing, as provided in CPL 270.10, it was [***3] made in open court and before the selection of the jury, and the record contains fully and with specificity the grounds therefor and the arguments made in respect of it. Absent a showing of prejudice to the People, the lack of a writing in and of itself should not preclude review of the issue on the merits. Nor was the failure of defendant to specifically request a factual hearing fatal, since CPL 270.10 provides for a trial of the issues of fact and law arising out of a challenge to the jury panel.

3. The trial court abused its discretion when it denied a request by defendant for a pretrial discovery of inter-office memoranda of the Department of Social Services. If a welfare recipient who is a defendant in a criminal case desires to waive the protection of confidentiality, she is entitled to discovery of such inter-office memoranda as are relevant to an issue in the case.

4. Circumstantial evidence adduced by the People was sufficient to establish beyond a reasonable doubt that defendant acted with the requisite felonious intent, and the trial court's charge was eminently fair and correctly stated the law. Its errors in failing to conduct the hearing on the challenge to the [***4] jury panel and in not permitting the requested discovery make a new trial necessary, at which trial the court should note the merger of the charged violation of section 145 of the Social Services Law into the larceny charge.

 

728 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Charles v. Diamond


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


47 A.D.2d 426; 366 N.Y.S.2d 921; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9511



April 23, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously modified on the law in accordance with opinion by Cardamone, J. and as modified affirmed with costs to petitioner.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner owner appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which directed respondent village to correct deficiencies in its sewage system and directed respondent State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation (commissioner) to issue a permit to the owner allowing him to connect to the sewage system upon proof of the village's corrections. The trial court dismissed the owner's cause of action for money damages.


OVERVIEW: The owner planned to construct apartment buildings on his real property. The owner alleged that his property was taken without just compensation by reason of denial of his request to develop it. On remand from a previous appeal, the trial court ordered the village to correct sewage system deficiencies. The owner was not allowed to tie into the system until the village corrected the deficiencies. The village had submitted to a consent decree of a state agency concerning the system; the village later submitted to a modified decree, which extended the village's time to make corrections. On appeal, the court affirmed as modified the judgment of the trial court, which directed the village to make corrections and directed the commissioner to issue a permit to the owner allowing him to connect to the system upon proof of the corrections. The court reinstated the owner's cause of action for money damages and an immediate trial was allowed. N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 relief was, to all intents and purposes, ineffectual and unavailing to the owner because, although the village had been under a consent order for nearly nine years, it had no definite timetable for making the corrections.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed as modified the judgment of the trial court, which directed the village to correct deficiencies in its sewage system and directed the commissioner to issue a permit to the owner allowing him to connect to the sewage system upon proof of the corrections. The judgment was modified by reinstating the owner's cause of action for money damages for the alleged taking and an immediate trial was allowed on that claim.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- confiscatory governmental regulation -- petitioner should be permitted to adjudicate immediately claim for damages for taking of property without just compensation, resulting from nonapproval of sewer connections to his apartment buildings, since prior article 78 relief, directing corrections by village in its sewage system, has proved ineffectual for nine years in spite of consent order -- Supreme Court is appropriate forum for resolution of claim against various governmental agencies, including State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, where municipal corporation is "final actor" in multi-governmental regulation which amounts to unconstitutional appropriation of private property.

1. Petitioner should be permitted to adjudicate immediately his claim for money damages for a taking of his property without just compensation resulting from nonapproval [***2] of sewer connections to his apartment buildings. Prior article 78 relief, directing the respondent village to correct deficiencies in its sewage system and directing the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation to issue a permit upon proof of such corrections, has been ineffectual. Although the village has been under a consent order for nearly nine years to modify its sewage system, it has not done so and its timetable is indefinite. A property owner who has been denied an existing governmental service proves a constitutional taking when he proves that the denial is confiscatory in effect, unreasonable in terms of necessity and indefinite in duration.

2. The Court of Claims does not have exclusive jurisdiction over petitioner's claim against the commissioner, and the claim may be adjudicated in Supreme Court, which has jurisdiction over Fifth Amendment claims against municipal corporations and other public entities. Where a municipal corporation is the "final actor" in a multi-governmental regulation which amounts to an unconstitutional appropriation of private property, the Supreme Court is the appropriate forum for resolution of the claim against the various governmental entities.

 

729 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wein v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


47 A.D.2d 367; 366 N.Y.S.2d 885; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9248



April 17, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on March 17, 1975, affirmed, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer filed an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against defendant City of New York in the Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County (New York), pursuant to N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51. The taxpayer challenged the constitutionality of the Stabilization Reserve Corporation Act. The trial court granted the city's motion for accelerated judgment dismissing the complaint. The parties filed cross appeals.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer filed suit against the city to challenge the constitutionality of New York City Stabilization Reserve Corporation Act, N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 2530 et seq. The act established an independent public benefit corporation to assist the city in providing services during a fiscal crisis. The trial court dismissed the taxpayer's complaint after finding that the taxpayer had standing to sue but that the legislation was constitutional. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's judgment. The court found that the taxpayer was not required to show that he would suffer peculiar injury but that it was enough for him to show that he had the status as a taxpayer, which the statute prescribed, and that the city's act was one that the law forbade. However, the court found that the act in question did not violate N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1 because the obligations delineated under the act were not legal obligations of the city and were not chargeable against the constitutional debt limits. The court also held that N.Y. Const. art. X, § 5, was not violated because the state and the city were not liable on the bonds and notes of the corporation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court granting the city's motion for accelerated judgment in the taxpayer's suit for declaratory and injunctive relief.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- New York City debt limitations -- New York City Stabilization Reserve Corporation -- New York City taxpayer, whose real property tax assessment is in excess of $ 1,000, has standing to bring action for judgment declaring New York City Stabilization Reserve Corporation Act unconstitutional as violative of article VIII of New York State Constitution, but has failed to state cause of action -- obligations delineated under legislation are not legal obligations of city, and, therefore, are not chargeable against its constitutional debt limit -- nor is State liable for payment thereof.

A New York City taxpayer, whose real property tax assessment is in excess of $ 1,000, seeks a judgment declaring unconstitutional, as violative of article VIII of the New York State Constitution,  [***2] the New York City Stabilization Reserve Corporation Act (Public Authorities Law, § 2530 et seq.), which establishes an independent public benefit corporation to assist the City of New York, in a time of unprecedented fiscal crisis, to enable it to provide essential services during the 1973-1975 fiscal years on a sound financial basis; authorizes that corporation, upon certification by the Mayor of the need for funds to provide such services, to issue and sell bonds and notes in an aggregate amount not exceeding $ 520,000,000; provides for the proceeds of the sale to be paid to the Comptroller, with repayment generated from the corporation's revenues; provides for the establishment by the corporation of a capital reserve fund, towards the maintenance of which the city is to make certain payments, but only if the amount thereof shall have been first appropriated by or on behalf of the city for such purpose or shall have been otherwise made available, and also provides that the "notes, bonds or other obligations of the corporation shall not be a debt of either the state or the city, and neither the state nor the city shall be liable thereon, nor shall they be payable out of any funds [***3] other than those of the corporation" (§ 2542). A motion by defendants, the city and its Mayor and Comptroller, for accelerated judgment declaring the legislation constitutional and the proposed bond issue valid was properly granted. Plaintiff has standing to bring the action, but he has failed to state a cause of action. The obligations delineated under the legislation are not legal obligations of the city and, therefore, are not chargeable against its constitutional debt limit, nor is the State liable for the payment thereof.

 

730 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Sutton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


47 A.D.2d 455; 366 N.Y.S.2d 500; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9516



April 17, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court in Erie County (New York), which convicted him of robbery in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: Two men held up a bar. Three patrons at the bar gave the police descriptions of defendant. The police showed them photographs of men matching their descriptions. Each patron picked defendant as one of the perpetrators of the robbery. At a pretrial hearing to determine whether the photographic procedures utilized were suggestive, the people offered into evidence the photographs that were shown to the victims. Defendant's request that the people be required to produce the patrons themselves was denied. He was convicted of robbery. The court affirmed and held that there was no error committed when the trial court refused to require the people to produce the patrons at the pretrial hearing. The people properly met their initial burden of going forward with evidence by showing the reasonableness of the police conduct in the first instance. The patrons who failed to testify at the hearing testified at the trial, and no testimony was elicited from them that showed that any improper identification procedure in violation of due process was used.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment convicting defendant of robbery in the first degree.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- identification of defendant -- burden of proof -- burden of proof is upon defendant to show that pretrial identification procedure violated due process -- since burden of proof is upon defendant to show improper identification, People met burden of going forward with evidence by showing reasonableness of police conduct in first instance, and there was no need to produce identifying eyewitnesses at suppression hearing -- upon testimony that defendant had pierced ear and upon showing at trial that his ear was not pierced, People could rebut such evidence with police testimony that defendant's ear had string in it two days after crime -- sentence to concurrent 15-year terms is not unduly harsh upon conviction of three counts of robbery committed with gun and involving assault.

1. The burden of proof is upon the defendant to show that a pretrial identification procedure violated his right to due process. The burden of establishing a waiver [***2] of a constitutional right is upon the prosecution, but the burden of showing that an illegal procedure violated the right to due process is upon the defendant. The statutory language ( CPL 710.20) with respect to identification testimony provides that suppression may be ordered upon a "claim" of impropriety by the defendant, and such terminology indicates that the burden of proving such a claim should be upon the defendant.

2. Since the burden of showing an improper identification is upon the defendant, the People met their initial burden of going forward with evidence by showing the reasonableness of police conduct in the first instance, and there was no need to produce the identifying eyewitnesses at the pretrial hearing. To require such production would be impractical and unfair and would further inconvenience the witnesses.

3. Upon eyewitness testimony that the defendant had had a pierced ear and upon a showing at the trial that the defendant's ear was not pierced, the People had the right to rebut such evidence by eliciting testimony from a police officer that the defendant's ear had a string in it two days after the crime. Even if that rebuttal were in error, it would be [***3] nonconstitutional error which would not be reversible without a showing that there was a significant probability of acquittal absent the error.

4. The sentence to concurrent terms of 15 years upon conviction of three counts of robbery in the first degree is not unduly harsh, since a gun was used in the commission of the crime and one of the victims was assaulted.

 

731 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bonomo


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


47 A.D.2d 862; 366 N.Y.S.2d 42; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9214



March 31, 1975, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, who were mother and a daughter, sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York), which convicted them of assault in the first degree and imposed a sentence.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of assault in the first degree. The court affirmed the convictions, but reduced their sentences. The court found that although the notice-of-alibi statute, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.20, was probably unconstitutional prior to its modification in 1974 because of its failure to provide reciprocal rights to the accused, the cases holding the statute unconstitutional were not entitled to retroactive application. Thus, because the trial started before 1974 and defendants both testified that at the time of the commission of the crime the daughter was visiting a friend, the trial court's refusal to permit testimony by the alibi witness because of defendants' failure to give the required notice, did not infect the verdict. Further, the court found that the complainant and two witnesses who had observed the incident from a short distance testified to the daughter's presence at and participation in the assault.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendants' convictions, but reduced the sentences imposed.

 

732 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Alessi v. Nadjari


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


47 A.D.2d 189; 365 N.Y.S.2d 859; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9137



March 27, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Motion to quash certain subpoenas denied, and the stay dated March 3, 1975, affixed to the notice of motion, is vacated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, persons subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury, filed a motion to quash the subpoenas issued by respondent State for their appearance on the grand jury.


OVERVIEW: Those persons subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury filed motions to quash the subpoenas pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 149(2). The persons subpoenaed contended that the grand jury was unconstitutionally empaneled because women were exempted from service. The State contended that N.Y. Jud. Law § 599(7) did not exclude women from the pool of jurors but merely allowed for a blanket exemption. The court held that the persons subpoenaed had standing to challenge the selection of jurors. The court denied the motion to quash the subpoenas and vacated the interim stay that was imposed. The court held that it was not entitled to retroactively apply a case law decision to the empanelling of the jury based on a determination by the United States Supreme Court in a separate decision. The court held that it was unnecessary to declare § 599(7) unconstitutional because the automatic exemption of women from appearing for jury was repealed by 1975 N.Y. Laws 4.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion of those persons subpoenaed that sought to quash the subpoenas that were issued to them. The court vacated the stay that was affixed to the notice of motion.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- exemption of women from jury duty -- while United States Supreme Court in Taylor v Louisiana (419 U.S. 522) has held that systematic exclusion of women from juries violates right to jury drawn from cross section of community (US Const., 6th and 14th Amdts.), that court in Daniel v Louisiana (420 U.S. 31) has denied retroactive application of Taylor decision to cases involving juries impaneled prior to date of Taylor decision; accordingly, motion to quash subpoenas to appear before Grand Jury, on ground exemption of women from jury duty (Judiciary Law, § 599, subd 7) results in unconstitutionally impaneled Grand Jury, is denied -- it would be of little moment to declare section 599 (subd 7) prospectively unconstitutional since automatic exemption of women has been repealed (L. 1975, ch 4).

1. A motion by petitioners, who had been subpoenaed to appear before a [***2] Special and Extraordinary Grand Jury of New York County, to quash the subpoenas, on the ground that the Grand Jury was unconstitutionally impaneled in that women are granted a blanket exemption from jury duty (Judiciary Law, § 599, subd. 7), is denied. The United States Supreme Court in Taylor v Louisiana (419 U.S. 522) has held that the systematic exclusion of women violates the right to a jury drawn from a pool representing a fair cross section of the community (U.S. Const., 6th and 14th Amdts.) and has narrowed its prior decision in Hoyt v Florida (368 U.S. 57) which held the blanket exemption of women constitutional. However, in Daniel v Louisiana (420 U.S. 31) that court denied retroactive application of the Taylor decision to cases involving juries impaneled prior to the date of the Taylor decision and that rationale is applicable to grand juries as well as petit juries. Finally, it would be of little moment to declare section 599 (subd. 7) of the Judiciary Law prospectively unconstitutional since the automatic exemption of women has been repealed (L. 1975, ch. 4).

2. Petitioners have standing to challenge the selection of jurors.

3. The fact that the [***3] Taylor decision involved a petit jury while the present challenge is to a Grand Jury is a distinction without practical difference.

 

733 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


U. S. Pioneer Electronics Corp. v. District Sound, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


47 A.D.2d 142; 364 N.Y.S.2d 919; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8730; 1975-1 Trade Cas. (CCH) P60,209



March 11, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on November 21, 1974, unanimously modified, on the law, to grant the cross motion of defendant-respondent-appellant for summary judgment dismissing the complaint, and to sever the action as to it, and as so modified the order is otherwise affirmed. Defendant-respondent-appellant shall recover of plaintiff-appellant-respondent $ 60 costs and disbursements of these appeals.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff distributor and defendant dealer cross-appealed from an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York), which denied a motion by the distributor to enjoin the dealer pendente lite from offering for sale or selling fair traded products below their fair trade prices, and denied a cross motion by the dealer for summary judgment dismissing the distributor's complaint.


OVERVIEW: The distributor was the exclusive distributor of a line of products and entered into a fair trade agreement with the dealer. The distributor had previously won a permanent injunction against the dealer for certain sales. Several years later the dealer ran an ad in two newspapers whereby it offered the products at discounted prices. The court affirmed the refusal to enter an injunction against the dealer and granted the dealer's motion for summary judgment because the state's Fair Trade Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law art. 24-A, § 369-a et seq., did not prohibit the activities complained of. The court found that the McGuire Act, 15 U.S.C.S. § 45, left the acceptance or rejection of fair trade legislation to the individual states, but where adopted it did not have such extraterritorial effect as to prohibit sales in states which had no such legislation. The court held that to apply the prohibition to newspaper advertising and a sale resulting therefrom would not only have unduly hampered and restricted the right of free publication, but would have permitted one state to dominate or interfere improperly in the economic activities of another.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order to grant the dealer's motion for summary judgment and as modified, affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Trade-marks, trade names and unfair competition -- price fixing of trademarked commodities -- in action to enjoin defendant, District of Columbia corporation, from offering for sale plaintiff's fair trade products below fair trade prices through newspaper advertisements in New York stating that sale was made and title was to pass in Washington, D.  [***2] C., a non-fair trade jurisdiction, complaint dismissed -- while Federal act left acceptance or rejection of fair trade legislation to States, such legislation does not have extraterritorial effect of prohibiting sales in States having no such legislation; to apply prohibition to newspaper advertising and sales resulting therefrom would permit one State to interfere in economic activities of another.

Defendant, a District of Columbia corporation and a wholly owned subsidiary of a New Jersey corporation, was a franchised dealer of high fidelity equipment distributed by plaintiff and had entered into a fair trade agreement with plaintiff. In newspaper advertisements in New York and Philadelphia, defendant offered for sale plaintiff's products at discount prices, the advertisements suggesting ordering by mail and stating that the sale was made and title was to pass in Washington, D. C., a non-fair trade jurisdiction. In an action to enjoin defendant from advertising, offering for sale or selling plaintiff's products below the fair trade prices (see General Business Law, § 369-a et seq.), the cross motion by defendant for summary judgment dismissing the complaint is granted.  [***3] While the United States Congress in adopting the McGuire Act (U. S. Code, tit. 15, § 45) left the acceptance or rejection of fair trade legislation to the individual States, such legislation does not have the extraterritorial effect of prohibiting sales in States having no such legislation. To apply the prohibition to newspaper advertising and sales resulting therefrom would not only unduly hamper and restrict the right of free publication, but would permit one State to interfere in the economic activities of another. The State statute derives its authority from the Federal statute and in any conflict the Federal statute prevails.

 

734 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bryant


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


47 A.D.2d 51; 365 N.Y.S.2d 223; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8712



March 3, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Sentences affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged the decision of the Nassau County Court (New York), which sentenced them as second felony offenders, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06, after they had pled guilty to various felonies.


OVERVIEW: On review, the issues were whether N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 violated the federal constitutional ban on "cruel and unusual" punishment, and whether N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.21(3) violated defendants' privilege against self-incrimination. The court affirmed the sentences. The court found that § 400.21(3) was constitutional, and there was no authority for defendants' contentions that they had a constitutional right to stand silent on the issues of the truth or constitutional validity of a record of previous convictions. The court also found that N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 was constitutional because the legislature's exercise of discretion in determining punishment was not unusually severe, a legislative enactment carried a strong presumption of constitutionality, and the fact that the sentencing statute was mandatory eliminated the possibility that it was inflicted arbitrarily. As to an alleged noncompliance with N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.21, the court determined that defendants were informed in either the plea hearing or the sentencing hearing, or both, that they were second felony offenders and as such would be subject to the minimum sentences prescribed by N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06.


OUTCOME: The sentencing of defendants as second felony offenders following guilty pleas to various felonies was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence -- second felony offenders -- in adopting CPL 400.21 (subd. 3), Legislature clearly intended to eliminate right, previously accorded to defendant convicted of felony and charged with being second felony offender, to stand silent on issue of prior convictions and not have his silence construed as admission -- nor is right to remain silent on issue of truth or constitutional validity of prior convictions right which is protected by constitutional guarantee of due process -- provisions of section 70.06 of Penal Law for mandatory minimum terms for second felony offenders do not violate constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment -- defendants who were not served with statements setting forth alleged predicate felonies, as required by CPL 400.21,  [***2] or were not advised of their rights under that section, but who voluntarily admitted that they were persons named in prior felony conviction records, in face of advice by court as to mandatory minimum terms, waived their privileges against self incrimination and their rights under statute and also estopped themselves from attacking validity of sentences imposed -- furthermore, there was substantial compliance with statute -- but attention should be given to every detail of it before defendant is sentenced as second felony offender.

1. CPL 400.21, which governs the procedure for determining whether a defendant is a second felony offender, provides, inter alia, that a defendant who stands convicted of a felony, and who might be a second felony offender, must be given a copy of a statement setting forth the alleged predicate felony, and must be asked by the court whether he wishes to controvert any allegation made therein; that, if he does, he must specify the particular allegation or allegations which he wishes to controvert, and that he shall be deemed to have admitted uncontroverted allegations in the statement. In adopting this statute, the Legislature clearly intended to [***3] eliminate the right, accorded to such a defendant under predecessor statutes, to stand silent on the issue of prior convictions and not have his silence construed as an admission. Nor is the right to stand silent on the issue of the truth or constitutional validity of prior convictions a right which is protected by the constitutional guarantee of due process.

2. The provisions of section 70.06 of the Penal Law which prescribed mandatory minimum terms for second felony offenders do not violate the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.

3. Defendants who were not served with copies of the statement required by CPL 400.21, or were not advised of their rights under that section to controvert specific allegations and to a hearing in the event of such controversion, or of the fact that uncontroverted allegations would be taken as true, but who, in open court and with counsel present, elected to admit voluntarily that they were the persons named in prior felony conviction records called to their attention by the court, and did so in the face of advice by the court that it would be mandated to impose specified minimum terms upon them as second felony offenders,  [***4] thereby waived their privileges against self incrimination and their rights under CPL 400.21, and also estopped themselves from attacking the validity of the sentences imposed upon them in accordance with the mandate of section 70.06 of the Penal Law. Furthermore, there was substantial compliance with CPL 400.21.

4. Since CPL 400.21 is mandatory on its face and is easily complied with, attention should be given to its every detail before a defendant is sentenced as a second felony offender.

 

735 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cook v. Griffin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


47 A.D.2d 23; 364 N.Y.S.2d 632; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8708



February 28, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed on the law without costs and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent school board appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Erie County (New York), which granted a motion by petitioner resident for an order pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to compel the school board to provide transportation on field trips for nonpublic school students. The school board appealed.


OVERVIEW: School board officials refused a parochial school's request to furnish transportation for field trips to be conducted by the school. A resident filed a petition under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to compel the officials to provide transportation to and from school related activities for pupils enrolled at the parochial school. The petition alleged that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3635 required a school district to furnish transportation to all students residing within its boundaries and that to deny equal transportation to nonpublic school children unconstitutionally denied them equal protection of the law. The school board filed a motion to dismiss on the ground that the resident had failed to obtain administrative review before seeking judicial intervention. The trial court granted the petition and directed the school board to provide filed trip transportation to nonpublic students. The school board appealed. On appeal, the court reversed, dismissed the resident's petition, and held that no statutory authority existed to permit the school board to transport nonpublic school students on field trips and that there was right to equal aid in the absence of specific legislative authorization.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment, which granted a motion by a resident for an order to compel the school officials to provide transportation for nonpublic school students. The court dismissed the resident's petition.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- transportation of students on field trips -- public school district is not required to provide transportation to nonpublic school students for field trips, since there is no authority for such transportation corresponding to implicit authority to provide such for public school students -- requirement that transportation is to be provided for all students in district is worded entirely in terms of transportation "to and from" schools -- provisions empowering school districts to purchase or contract for vehicles for transportation of children contain no specific authority for assistance to nonpublic schools -- failure to provide field trip transportation for nonpublic school students does not violate right of equal protection of law, since all students have equal right to attend public schools.

 [***2] 1. The respondent public school district is not required to provide bus transportation to nonpublic schools for use in connection with field trips conducted by the nonpublic schools as part of their educational curriculum. A public school district has only the statutory powers delegated to it by the Legislature. Under the wide range of powers implicit in subdivisions 3, 5 and 33 of section 1709 of the Education Law, pursuant to which a school district has all powers reasonably necessary to prescribe a course of study and make provision for the instruction of pupils, a school district may conduct educational field trips as an alternative to classroom instruction. No corresponding authority is conferred to provide such trips for nonpublic schools.

2. Subdivision 1 of section 3635 of the Education Law, which requires school districts to provide transportation for all children within the school district, is worded entirely in terms of providing transportation "to and from" schools and makes no reference to field trips.

3. In those instances in which assistance is extended to nonpublic schools there has always been specific statutory authority, and no such express provision is found [***3] in subdivisions 25 and 27 of section 1709 of the Education Law, which empowers a school district to purchase or contract for vehicles for transportation of children of the district.

4. The failure of the school district to make field trips available to nonpublic school students does not violate their right to equal protection of the law under the United States and New York State Constitutions, since all children have an equal opportunity to attend public schools. The fact that such opportunity is foregone deprives the child of nothing by State action, and while there is a right to attend a nonpublic school, there is no corresponding right to receive aid.

5. Accordingly, the judgment of Special Term should be reversed and the petition dismissed.

 

736 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Great Lakes Dredge & Dock Co. v. State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


46 A.D.2d 533; 363 N.Y.S.2d 674; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8533



February 6, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Determination annulled, and petition granted, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner New Jersey corporation challenged a judgment from the State Tax Commission (New York), which sustained a sales and use tax assessment imposed against the corporation. The proceeding was transferred to the court, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78.


OVERVIEW: The corporation argued that it was exempt from the assessment of sales and use tax by reason of N.Y. Tax Law § 1115(8)(a), which provided relief from the sales and use tax when the tax arose, in part, from commercial vessels primarily engaged in interstate or foreign commerce. On appeal, the court held that the Commission's determination assessing the tax against the corporation should have been annulled because the corporation was entitled to the exemption. Specifically, the court noted that the corporation was a marine contractor primarily engaged in dredging operations. Thus, the court held that the corporation's business was the improving of the arteries of interstate travel, and that the activities had to be construed as "interstate commerce" within the contemplation of § 1115(8)(a). In addition, the court noted that there was abundant proof that the corporation's vessels were continually moved, both before and during the tax period in question, from state to state and did not come to rest for use or consumption in the local business of New York. Accordingly, the court granted the corporation's petition.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the Commission's determination, which had sustained the assessment of the sales and use tax against the corporation. As a result, the court granted the corporation's petition and exempted the corporation from the taxes.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- sales tax -- use tax -- interstate commerce -- State Tax Commission should not have imposed sales and use tax on equipment and supplies of petitioner, marine contractor engaged in dredging operations -- petitioner engaged in interstate commerce -- petitioner exempt under statute (Tax Law, § 1115, subd. [a], par. [8]).

Petitioner, a marine contractor primarily engaged in dredging operations, performed work in Albany County, Erie County and the City of New York which involved the dredging, widening and excavation of navigable waterways. Petitioner employed several floating dredges, cranes, drillboats, tugs, scows, barges and launches, purchasing the ordinary supplies for their use as needed. Respondent Tax Commission imposed a sales and use tax on certain of the [***2] equipment and on all the supplies engaged or consumed in furtherance of the New York projects. The Tax Law ( § 1115, subd. [a], par. [8]) provides exemption from a sales and use tax when arising from "commercial vessels primarily engaged in interstate or foreign commerce and property used by or purchased for the use of such vessels for fuel, provisions, supplies, maintenance and repairs (other than articles purchased for the original equipping of a new ship)." Respondent's determination is without substantial evidentiary support and is erroneous. The taxed supplies were used on taxed equipment constituting "commercial vessels." Petitioner's business is the improving of arteries of interstate travel and such activities must be construed as "interstate commerce" within the contemplation of the statute. In addition, there was abundant proof that petitioner's vessels were continually moved, both before and during the tax period, from State to State and did not come to rest for use or consumption in the local business of this State. The determination should be annulled.

 

737 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Herrick v. Ingraham


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


46 A.D.2d 546; 363 N.Y.S.2d 665; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8537



February 6, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, on the law and the facts, by reversing so much thereof as declared section 1116 and related sections of the Public Health Law unconstitutional, and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant health department sought review of a decision from the Supreme Court, Delaware County (New York), which held N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1116 and related sections to be unconstitutional, which enjoined the department from imposing penalties on respondent property seller for the sale of certain property, and which vacated a "Notice of Hearing and Complaint" served on the property seller.


OVERVIEW: When the department of health sought to impose penalties upon him for selling certain land pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1116 by sending him a "Notice of Complaint," a property seller filed an action in the trial court for a declaratory judgment. The trial court found § 1116 to be unconstitutional and enjoined the department from imposing penalties on the property seller. The department appealed. The court determined that the property seller did not violate § 1116 because the manner in which he sold his property did not constitute the development of land for the purpose of creating residential dwellings. The court did not reach the constitutional issues presented.


OUTCOME: The court reformed the judgment of the trial court, finding that the statute at issue had not been violated and affirmed the modified order of the trial court in favor of the property seller.


HEADNOTES

Health -- subdivision development -- random sales by plaintiff of 263 parcels of land which consisted of mountainous farmlands of no uniform size or shape to purchasers who used land for seasonal recreational purposes, do not constitute subdivision development and therefore do not come within purview of sections 1115 and 1116 of Public Health Law; to require plaintiff to submit detailed plans for water  [***2] and sewage facilities would be contrary to intent of statute; there is no need to reach constitutional issues.

Plaintiff purchased 13 farms located in mountainous regions mainly in Delaware County. During an eight-year period, he sold off portions of the farms by making random sales of 263 parcels of land to purchasers who were seasonal residents who used the land mainly for recreational purposes. The structures that were erected by the purchasers were only put to seasonal recreational use. The State Department of Health commenced proceedings against plaintiff for alleged violations of section 1116 of the Public Health Law, which provides that no subdivision or portion thereof shall be sold until a map or plan of such subdivision is filed and approved by the appropriate department of health. The intent of the statute is to assure proper water and sewage facilities in subdivision developments. Such sales from mountainous farmlands of no uniform size or shape do not constitute subdivision development and, since the land was not divided for sale as residential lots or residential building plots, the sales do not come within the purview of sections 1115 and 1116. To require plaintiff [***3] to submit detailed plans for water and sewage facilities for the vast amount of land involved where he was selling off acreage at random for recreational purposes would be contrary to the intent of the statute. Since there is no need to reach the constitutional issues, the judgment in favor of plaintiff should be modified, on the law and the facts, by reversing so much thereof as declared section 1116 and related sections of the Public Health Law unconstitutional and, as so modified, affirmed.

 

738 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Dutchess County Pharmaceutical Soc. v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


47 A.D.2d 627; 363 N.Y.S.2d 644; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8790



February 3, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Order modified, on the law, by striking therefrom all its decretal provisions except that which denied plaintiffs' motion and by adding thereto a provision granting defendants' cross application and declaring chapter 751 of the Laws of 1973 constitutional. As so modified, order affirmed, without costs.

 

739 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Greenwald v. Frank


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


47 A.D.2d 628; 363 N.Y.S.2d 955; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8794; 10 Empl. Prac. Dec. (CCH) P10,584



February 3, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed and petition dismissed on the merits, with costs.

 

740 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nowak


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


46 A.D.2d 469; 363 N.Y.S.2d 142; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8521



January 16, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment insofar as it convicts defendant of criminal possession of a dangerous drug, 3rd degree, unanimously reversed on the law and a new trial granted; and judgment insofar as it convicts defendant of loitering, 1st degree, unanimously reversed on the law and that count of indictment dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Erie County Court (New York), convicting defendant of criminal possession of a dangerous drug in the third degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 220.10, and loitering in the first degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 240.36.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a dangerous drug in the third degree and loitering in the first degree. Defendant claimed that evidence was improperly received against him and that the loitering statute was unconstitutional. The court reversed, holding that the prosecution improperly admitted evidence which tended to show a predisposition to crime and also tended to prove unlawful selling, a crime with which defendant was not charged. Receipt of the evidence under the circumstances constituted reversible error and required a new trial. The court dismissed the indictment for loitering, holding that the loitering statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 240.36, had no application to the facts of the case. The court held that the statute, clearly valid under most circumstances, could not reasonably be construed to be applicable insofar as it attempted to make loitering in a private apartment an offense.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction, holding that the prosecution improperly admitted evidence which tended to show a predisposition to crime and also tended to prove unlawful selling, a crime with which defendant was not charged. The court held further that the loitering statute could not be construed to be applicable insofar as it attempted to make loitering in a private apartment an offense.


HEADNOTES
