Crimes -- dangerous drugs -- evidence -- loitering -- in prosecution for possession of dangerous drug, testimony of arresting officers as to large amount of cash found on defendant when arrested in apartment and as to street value of marijuana, 19.4 pounds of marijuana having been found in apartment, improperly tended to show predisposition to crime and to prove unlawful selling, crime with which defendant was not charged; accordingly, receipt of such evidence was reversible error and requires new trial -- count in indictment charging defendant with loitering in first degree dismissed; Penal Law ( § 240.36) cannot be construed to make loitering  [***2] in private apartment offense.

1. In a prosecution of defendant for possession of a dangerous drug, the arresting officers testified that, when defendant was searched at an apartment in which he was arrested while in the company of four others, he had on his person $ 1,700 in bills and that the street value of 10 pounds of marijuana was about $ 300 per pound. A total of 19.4 pounds of marijuana was found in the apartment. The evidence improperly tended to show a predisposition to crime and to prove unlawful selling, a crime with which defendant was not charged. Accordingly, receipt of such evidence constituted reversible error and requires a new trial.

2. A count in the indictment charging defendant with loitering in the first degree is dismissed. Then section 240.36 of the Penal Law prohibiting loitering in any place by two or more persons for the purpose of using or possessing a dangerous drug cannot be construed so as to make loitering in a private apartment an offense. The rationale of loitering statutes is the prevention of minor offenses or incipient crimes in places frequented by the public for the protection of the public. When applied to an apartment, the statute [***3] does not insulate the public from injury or assist the police in maintaining the peace. The application of the statute to the present facts only invites questionable intrusions into personal privacy and makes the law an instrument of harassment.

 

741 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. McNair


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


46 A.D.2d 476; 363 N.Y.S.2d 151; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8523



January 16, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment in People v. McNair unanimously affirmed.

Judgment in People v. Mosely insofar as it imposes sentence unanimously reversed on the law and matter remitted to Monroe County Court for resentencing in accordance with opinion by Cardamone, J.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appeals in proceedings of the Monroe County Court (New York), were consolidated. Defendants argued that sentencing provisions of the N.Y. Penal Law mandating life sentences for drug-related convictions were unconstitutional, Eighth Amendment and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 5, as cruel and unusual punishment. The People appealed, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 450.20(4), in the first case after the law was found unconstitutional and defendant, in the second.


OVERVIEW: The first defendant was convicted of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 220.39(1), and sentenced to a term of from three to six years of imprisonment. The second defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance, second degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 220.18; criminal use of drug paraphernalia; and criminal possession of a hypodermic instrument. The court explained that the public interest usually required that legislative enactments were given recognition and enforced by the courts as embodying the people's will. Although the punishment was not so severe as to be degrading, nor arbitrarily inflicted, unacceptable to contemporary society, disproportionate to the crime, or failing to serve a penal purpose more effectively than a less severe punishment, the court found some aspects troubling. The court noted that addicts and non-addicts were treated the same even though the purposes for their crimes differed. The court concluded that the punishment could have been justified by the heinous nature of the crime. The court also noted that lifetime parole subjected defendants to perpetual limitation of liberty.


OUTCOME: Holding that the statute was constitutional, the court reversed, on the law, the judgment with regard to the first defendant insofar as it imposed sentence and remitted the matter to the lower court for resentencing. The court affirmed judgment with regard to the second defendant.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- drug law -- mandatory sentencing provisions for drug related convictions are not unconstitutional, and similar treatment for addict and nonaddict and lifetime supervision for offenders have reasonable justification.

The mandatory sentencing provisions of the Penal [***2] Law ( §§ 220.18, 220.39; § 70.00, subd. 2, par. a; § 70.00, subd. 3, par. a, subpar. ii) in drug related convictions are not unconstitutional as violating the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution and section 5 of article I of the New York State Constitution. The punishment is not so severe as to be degrading, nor arbitrarily inflicted, unacceptable to contemporary society, disproportionate to the crime or failing to serve a penal purpose more effectively than a less severe punishment. The fact that sale of heroin is a heinous, essentially violent crime justifies similar treatment for addict and nonaddict alike, and because of the high recidivist rate among felons convicted of narcotics crimes, the Legislature did not act without reasonable justification in providing for lifetime supervision for released offenders as a protection for the public.

 

742 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Seligman v. Tucker


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


46 A.D.2d 402; 362 N.Y.S.2d 881; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8504



January 9, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Orders unanimously affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Two cases were combined to determine the same issue. In both cases, defendants, the nonresident automobile owners and operators, appealed from an order of the Supreme Court, Erie County (New York), denying defendants' motions to vacate an order of attachment of an insurance policy for the benefit of plaintiff residents, who had incurred injury and loss as a result of automobile accidents involving defendants.


OVERVIEW: Two cases were combined to determine whether courts in the State of New York were required to give full effect to a provision in a casualty insurance policy issued in another state. The provision stated that the insurer had no obligation under the policies in a state where the presence of an insurer-obligor provided the sole basis of jurisdiction over the insured. In both cases, the parties were from multiple states and were involved in car accidents. Companies located outside of New York, but authorized to do business in the state, provided the policies. Plaintiffs obtained orders to attach defendants' insurance policies. The lower court denied defendants' motions to vacate the orders. The appeals court affirmed the denials in each case. A New York resident was able to acquire in rem jurisdiction of an insured defendant by attaching an insurance policy protecting the defendant. In view of New York's strong public policy for the protection of its residents, the doctrine of forum non conveniens was only to be applied upon a formidable showing by defendant of inconvenience and hardship in the trial of the case in New York.


OUTCOME: The lower court's judgments were affirmed. Defendants in both cases bore the burden of establishing that it would be an inconvenience and a hardship to attend the trial of the case in New York. Defendants were unable to meet this burden in either case.


HEADNOTES

Attachment -- attachment of insurance policy of nonresident -- disclaimer provision -- doctrine of Seider v. Roth (17 N Y 2d 111) is applicable to obtain quasi-in-rem jurisdiction over nonresident defendants by attachment of defendants' automobile liability insurance policies which were issued in another State, despite provision in policies that insurer shall have no obligation thereunder in State where presence of insurer-obligor provides sole basis of jurisdiction over insured, since such provision contravenes public policy of New York -- forum non conveniens not applicable; defendants have not made formidable showing of inconvenience and hardship in  [***2] trial of case in New York -- orders denying motions to vacate attachments and dismiss complaints affirmed.

1. Plaintiffs are New York residents who were injured by nonresident defendants in automobile accidents occurring outside the State. Defendants' automobile liability insurance policies, while not issued in this State, were issued by an insurer doing business in New York. Plaintiffs thereupon instituted an action by service on the insurer in New York of an order for the attachment of the insurance policies for purposes of acquiring quasi-in-rem jurisdiction over defendants pursuant to the doctrine of Seider v. Roth (17 N Y 2d 111). Although a disclaimer provision contained in each policy which provided that the insurer "shall have no obligation to indemnify, pay to or on behalf of, or defend any person entitled to protection under this policy where such obligations or this policy provide the sole basis of jurisdiction of the court over said persons", is valid where made, it is not recognized as valid in New York since it contravenes the public policy of this State. Such provision does not defeat the acquiring of in rem jurisdiction over the insured defendants by [***3] way of a valid attachment of their insurance policies in New York.

2. The fact that the form of the policies including the disclaimer provision was approved by the Superintendent of Insurance does not mean that the provision should be honored by New York courts since the Superintendent cannot vitiate or remake the public policies of this State.

3. In actions founded upon the application of the Seider principle, the doctrine of forum non conveniens should only be applied upon a formidable showing by defendant of inconvenience and hardship in the trial of the case in New York, which was not shown here.

4. Accordingly, the orders denying the motions to vacate attachments and dismiss the complaints are affirmed.

 

743 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Butler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


46 A.D.2d 422; 362 N.Y.S.2d 658; 1975 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8507



January 9, 1975 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Oneida County Court (New York), which convicted him, upon his guilty plea, of burglary in the third degree. Defendant was sentenced pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 as a second felony offender to an indeterminate term with a minimum of two and a maximum of four years. Defendant attacked the constitutionality of the second felony offender statute.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution by treating felons with prior felony convictions as a class different from first-time felons. Where the challenge was to a legislative classification the question became whether there was a rational relationship between the classification employed in the statute and some legitimate state purpose, and where fundamental liberties were affected by the legislation, a "compelling" state interest had to be demonstrated. The question to be determined, insofar as the second felony offender statute was concerned, was whether the increased punishment of second felony offenders bore a reasonable relationship to some compelling state interest. The court concluded that it did. The court held that it was a reasonable exercise of legislative prerogative in providing for the public safety to limit judicial discretion upon defendant's conviction as a second felony offender and that such limitation did not deprive defendant of his right to substantive due process.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that convicted defendant for burglary and sentenced him as a second felony offender.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence -- second felony offenders -- section 70.06 of Penal Law, providing for mandatory imprisonment of defendant convicted of second felony within 10 years of prior felony conviction, is constitutional; compelling State interest in public safety is promoted -- statute is not denial of equal protection of law since all second felony offenders are treated same -- although statute limits plea bargaining, such bargaining is not constitutional right -- limitation on judicial discretion in sentencing does not deprive second felony offender of due process.

1. Section 70.06 of the Penal Law, providing for mandatory imprisonment of a defendant convicted of a second felony within a 10-year period following a prior felony conviction with sentence imposed to be an intermediate one varying according to the seriousness of the second felony, is constitutional. Even if it is assumed that mandatory and increased incarceration does not further the policy expressed [***2] in the Penal Law of rehabilitation, a compelling State interest in public safety is promoted because of the deterrent effect of incarceration and because it removes from society an individual who has previously been guilty of a felony.

2. The statute is not a denial of equal protection of the law since all second felony offenders are treated the same.

3. The fact that a defendant's fate, as to the pleading process, is fixed at the time of indictment does not render the statute unconstitutional although a defendant is not permitted to plead to a misdemeanor in satisfaction of the indictment thereby limiting plea bargaining. In any event, plea bargaining is not a constitutional right.

4. It is a reasonable exercise of the legislative prerogative in providing for the public safety to limit judicial discretion with respect to fashioning sentences for second felony offenders. Such limitation does not deprive those offenders of the right to substantive due process.

 

744 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lane v. Mt. Vernon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


46 A.D.2d 900; 362 N.Y.S.2d 30; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3341



December 16, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order modified by deleting the second ordering paragraph thereof and substituting therefor a provision denying defendant's cross motion; and order further modified and judgment modified, on the law, by adding to each of them a provision declaring that the ordinance in question is constitutional and valid. As so modified, order and judgment affirmed, without costs.

 

745 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Finkel, Nadler & Goldstein v. Levine


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


46 A.D.2d 196; 361 N.Y.S.2d 941; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3358



December 12, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer sought review of the decision of respondent Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board (New York), which affirmed a referee's decision upholding experience rating charges against the account of the employer pursuant to N.Y. Lab. Law § 581(1)(e).


OVERVIEW: An employee voluntarily left her job with the employer after four weeks and accepted employment elsewhere, where she worked for 11 weeks. Her second employment was terminated and she commenced receiving unemployment insurance benefits. Pursuant to § 581(1)(e), the first 11 weeks of her unemployment were charged to her second job and the next four weeks were charged to the employer. The employer unsuccessfully challenged the charges as assessed against its experience rating account, and sought review. The court affirmed the judgment, noting that the constitutionality of legislation assessing the cost of unemployment benefits to employers without regard to the employers' fault regarding the particular instance of employment had been repeatedly sustained. The court reasoned that while there were inequities in the scheme, it bore a rational relationship to the elimination of the problem of unemployment, and the court could not properly second-guess the wisdom of the legislature in distributing the cost of unemployment insurance benefits unless the means chosen were arbitrary.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the board, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Unemployment insurance -- contributions -- assessment of experience rating charges -- section 581 (subd. 1, par. [e]) of Labor Law, providing that benefits payable to claimant shall be charged to account of each base period employer in inverse chronological order of claimant's most recent date of base period employment by each, is not so unfair as to be denial of due process to first employer -- statute provides for notice to employer who was not denied hearing before proper forum and, consequently, employer was afforded procedural due process.

1. Section 581 (subd. 1, par. [e]) of the Labor Law, permitting the assessment of experience rating charges and providing that unemployment insurance benefits payable to a claimant shall be charged to the account of each base period employer in inverse chronological order of the claimant's most recent date of base period employment by each, is not so unfair as to be a denial of due process. Appellant had employed claimant for 4 weeks and thereafter she was employed elsewhere for 11 weeks. The [***2] first 11 weeks of her benefits were charged to the last employer and appellant was then properly charged with the next 4 weeks. The means selected by the Legislature bear a rational relationship to the amelioration of the problem of unemployment insurance compensation and it cannot be said that the measures are so extreme as to be arbitrary.

2. The statute provides for notice and notice was mailed to appellant. Appellant was afforded a hearing although the relief sought, a declaration of the unconstitutionality of the statute, was denied since neither the referee nor the Appeal Board had the power to grant it. However, the appellant was not denied a forum since the Appellate Division could pass on the question. Consequently, appellant was afforded procedural due process.

 

746 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Stetter v. Town Board of Amherst


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


46 A.D.2d 1006; 362 N.Y.S.2d 97; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3391



December 12, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, without costs, and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Town Board of the Town of Amherst sought review of a judgment of Erie Court at Special Term (New York), which annulled a decision of the Board abolishing the position of Deputy Supervisor to which respondent appointee was selected to fill.


OVERVIEW: The Board created the position of Deputy Supervisor pursuant to N.Y. Town Law § 42. The appointee was selected to fill the post. A newly elected board then abolished the position. A lawsuit was brought on behalf of the appointee. The trial court annulled the legislative act of abolishing the position, and the Board appealed. On appeal, the court ruled that the trial court committed error. The court considered misplaced the reliance on N.Y. Const. art. XIII, § 2, N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 36, and N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 23(2)(f) to support the argument that the Board was without power to abolish the position. The court noted that N.Y. Town Law § 42, under which authority the position was established, contained no provision its termination. The court ruled that there was no positive law qualifying the general rule that the power creating an office can abolish it. The court held that it did not have the authority to inquire into the motives behind legislative action. The court concluded that considering that the Board acted within its power and without any evidence of illegality or fraud, there was no basis upon which the trial court could properly annul the legislative resolution.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court annulling the Board's abolishment of the position of Deputy Supervisor. The court dismissed the petition.

 

747 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Young


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


46 A.D.2d 202; 361 N.Y.S.2d 762; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3448



December 5, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment insofar as it imposes sentence unanimously modified, as a matter of discretion in the interest of justice, by changing the sentence to a five-year period of probation and by certification of defendant to the care and custody of the Drug Abuse Control Commission of the State of New York. Defendant is remanded to Supreme Court of Monroe County, Kennedy, J., for the fixing of conditions of probation, as specified in subdivision 3 of section 65.10 of the Penal Law and any other conditions reasonably related to his rehabilitation, whereupon defendant is to be committed to the Sheriff of Monroe County for delivery to the Drug Abuse Control Commission.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court in Monroe County (New York) convicting him of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the sixth degree upon his plea of guilty and sentencing him to a term of imprisonment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted, upon his plea of guilty, of a class D felony of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the sixth degree, for which he could have been sentenced to a maximum term of seven years. He was sentenced to an indeterminate term with a maximum of four years. On appeal, the court modified the trial court judgment by changing the sentence to a five-year period of probation and by certification of defendant to the care and custody of the Drug Abuse Control Commission of the State of New York. The court chose to give defendant an opportunity to be treated at a drug center, rather than continue to be incarcerated in a maximum security prison. The court noted that, although one of the penalties for criminal action was punishment of the individual, the principal aim of the law was to rehabilitate offenders and to return them to society as useful law-abiding members. The court further noted that drug dependent persons could be rehabilitated and returned to useful lives only through periods of treatment in a controlled environment followed by supervision in an aftercare program.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court judgment by changing defendant's sentence to a five-year period of probation and by certification of defendant to the care and custody of the Drug Abuse Control Commission of the State of New York.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- drug law -- classification of possession of marijuana as felony is not cruel and unusual punishment, since crime gradation is legislative function with wide scope of discretion, and statute will not be struck down unless arbitrary and without reasonable basis -- since defendant  [***2] may reach potential of his above-average intelligence by treatment, rather than continuation of four years' incarceration, and since he has experienced consequences of failure to free himself of drugs, sentence is modified to five years' probation with one year of residential drug treatment.

1. The classification of possession of a sufficient quantity of marijuana as a Class D felony, carrying a maximum penalty of seven years, does not constitute cruel and unusual punishment. Gradation of crimes is a legislative function, within which there is a wide scope of discretion, and a statute will not be struck down unless it is purely arbitrary and without any reasonable basis. The defendant's conviction is, accordingly, affirmed.

2. The defendant's prior indictment for possession of a dangerous drug was dismissed after six months' adjournment, although he later admitted that he had continued to use marijuana during the period of adjournment. After release on bail upon a plea of not guilty to the instant charges, defendant was again arrested for possession of marijuana and changed his plea to one of guilty of possession of a controlled substance in the sixth degree. The defendant [***3] is presently sentenced to four years' maximum imprisonment and has experienced the consequences of failure to free himself of drugs. By treatment, rather than incarceration, the defendant may reach the potential of his above-average intelligence, and his sentence is, accordingly, modified to five years' probation and a maximum of one year of residential drug treatment.

 

748 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Scornavacca v. Leary


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


46 A.D.2d 114; 361 N.Y.S.2d 654; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3489



December 3, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Determination of the respondent Police Commissioner, dated October 6, 1969, unanimously modified, on the law, without costs and without disbursements, to the extent of remanding to Special Term the factual issues as to what extent petitioner was responsible for the delay beyond 30 days in reaching a determination on the departmental charge against him and to what extent the delay is reasonable, and as so modified, the determination is confirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner patrolman, in a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding, challenged the determination of respondent Commissioner of the Police Department of the City of New York (New York) (commissioner), which found the patrolman guilty of violating the police department's rules and procedures in that the patrolman wrongfully assaulted a prisoner. The patrolman was directed to lose 14 days' vacation and be on probation for one year.


OVERVIEW: While escorting a prisoner, the patrolman wrongfully assaulted the prisoner. The patrolman was immediately suspended and then arrested in connection with the criminal charges that arose from the incident. The patrolman was acquitted of the criminal charges. However, after a departmental hearing, the commissioner found the patrolman guilty of violating the police department's rules and procedures. The patrolman challenged the commissioner's determination, and also contended that he was entitled to full pay for the period of his suspension pending that determination. The court modified the commissioner's determination only as to the patrolman's pay for the period of his suspension. The court held that the patrolman's acquittal of the criminal charges did not mandate the dismissal of the department's charge. The court determined that the patrolman was entitled to pay for the period of his suspension that was an unreasonable time for the filing of the departmental charges and the determination of the same. The first 30 days of the suspension were reasonable as a matter of law.


OUTCOME: The court modified the commissioner's determination to the extent of remanding the matter for the resolution of factual issues as to what extent the patrolman was responsible for the delay beyond 30 days in reaching the determination on the department charge against the patrolman, and to what extent the delay was reasonable. As modified, the court confirmed the commissioner's determination.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- police -- payment to police officer during period of suspension -- determination of respondent police commissioner after departmental hearing, finding petitioner police officer guilty of assaulting prisoner in violation of rules and procedures  [***2] of New York City Police Department, should be modified to extent of remanding to Special Term factual issues as to what extent delay beyond 30 days in reaching determination on departmental charge was reasonable, thereby determining whether petitioner is entitled to payment for period of his suspension -- petitioner's acquittal on criminal charges arising from assault does not mandate dismissal of departmental charges -- section 434a-20.0 of Administrative Code of City of New York does not bar payment to suspended police force member for period of suspension because of fact of conviction on departmental charges.

1. On August 30, 1968, petitioner, a police officer, was arrested for assaulting a prisoner he was escorting on that date. On the same date, petitioner was suspended from the department and arrested on criminal charges arising from the assault. The departmental charge and specification was filed September 6, 1968. On January 22, 1969 petitioner was acquitted of the criminal charges after trial in the Criminal Court. On October 6, 1969, after a departmental hearing, respondent police commissioner, in his determination found petitioner guilty of assaulting a prisoner [***3] in violation of certain rules and procedures of the New York City Police Department and directed that petitioner lose 14 days' vacation and be on probation for one year. Since the determination under review is supported by substantial evidence, petitioner's assertion that dismissal of the departmental charge is mandated by his acquittal of criminal charges, and that the rules and procedures which he violated are unconstitutional, is without merit.

2. Section 434a-20.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York does not bar payment to a suspended police force member for the period of his suspension simply because of the fact of conviction on the departmental charge. Charges must be filed within a reasonable time after suspension and trial must thereafter be held. While the first 30 days of a suspension of a member of the police force is, as a matter of law, a reasonable time in which to file departmental charges and determine the charges after a hearing ( Matter of Stein v. Murphy, 44 A D 2d 796), this does not prohibit a factual finding that a period in excess of 30 days may also be reasonable with regard to the totality of circumstances. Accordingly, the determination [***4] of respondent police commissioner is modified, on the law, to the extent of remanding to Special Term the factual issues as to what extent the delay beyond 30 days in reaching a determination on the departmental charge was reasonable. As so modified, the determination should be confirmed.

 

749 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Venable


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


46 A.D.2d 73; 361 N.Y.S.2d 398; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3530



November 27, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Albany County Court (New York), entered upon a verdict convicting him of the criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree. He was sentenced to an indeterminate term of imprisonment with a minimum of seven years and a maximum of life.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of the criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, and he was sentenced him to an indeterminate term of imprisonment with a minimum of seven years and a maximum of life. The court affirmed this decision. The court held that no reversible error occurred when the trial judge instructed the jury to go to dinner after the judge received a note stating that the jury was unable to agree following approximately two hours of deliberations. The court also rejected defendant's argument that the sentence imposed was unconstitutional as being cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Federal and New York State Constitutions. In so holding, the court considered (1) the nature and gravity of the offense, (2) the legislative purpose behind the punishment, (3) how other jurisdictions would have punished defendant for the same offense, and (4) how the punishment compared to other punishments in the same jurisdiction for other types of crimes. After considering these factors, the court concluded that defendant failed to establish that the mandatory imposition of lifetime surveillance was without a reasonable basis.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction and his sentence.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- drug law -- mandatory maximum sentence of life imprisonment for criminal sale of narcotic substance in third degree is not cruel and unusual punishment, since it is not disproportionate to crime -- there is no prejudice to defendant in undisclosed note from jury to Judge, and any error was waived by failure to object.

1. The mandatory maximum sentence of life imprisonment under subdivision 2 of section 70.00 of the Penal Law for criminal sale of a narcotic substance in the third degree is not at the present time cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Federal and State Constitutions. Under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution, punishment should not be disproportionate to the offense, as determined by the nature and gravity of the offense, the legislative purpose for punishment, a comparison [***2] with other jurisdictions, and a comparison with punishment for other crimes. The criminal activity resulting from the drug market requires a strong deterrent, and severe punishment of importers alone would not be a practical deterrent. Some other States have similar or more severe sentences, and the insidious effect of the transfer of hard drugs is a sound basis for punishment equal to or, by the partial elimination of plea bargaining, exceeding that for "assassins, homicidal incendiaries and kidnappers", since hard drugs are a prior contributing factor of their crimes.

2. There was no prejudice to the defendant with respect to an undisclosed note from the jury to the Judge, informing him that it was unable to agree upon a verdict. Any error was waived by failure to object and would not, in any event, justify reversal.

 

750 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Broadie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


45 A.D.2d 649; 360 N.Y.S.2d 906; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3610



November 18, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Sentence affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court, Queens County (New York), which imposed a sentence of one year to life following a guilty plea for the criminal sale of a controlled substance under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.00(2)(a).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of the criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, and sentenced to a term of imprisonment with a minimum of one year and a maximum of life, as mandated by N.Y. Penal Law § 70.00(2)(a). Defendant challenged the sentencing statute and argued that its mandatory nature constituted an improper legislative infringement upon the exercise of judicial discretion and that it was violative of the Eighth Amendment which prohibited the imposition of cruel and unusual punishment. The court affirmed defendant's sentence because it found that the sentencing provisions of the new drug laws represented a permissible exercise of legislative power and that they were constitutional. The court concluded that the legislature could determine that the prescribed punishment was not unusually severe considering the effect of narcotic addition on society.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the mandatory sentence imposed for defendant's controlled substance conviction.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- drug law -- section 70.00 of Penal Law, mandating imposition of maximum sentence of life imprisonment upon person convicted of drug offense classified as A felony, does not constitute impermissible legislative infringement upon exercise of judicial discretion, nor does it violate constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment -- sentence to prison term of one year to life, imposed upon defendant who has pleaded guilty to class A-III drug felony, is affirmed.

1. Section 70.00 of the Penal Law, enacted in 1973 as a part of the State's new drug law, which, inter alia, mandates the imposition of a maximum sentence of life imprisonment upon a person convicted of a drug offense classified as an A felony, does not constitute an impermissible legislative infringement upon the exercise of judicial discretion, nor [***2] does it violate the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.

2. A sentence to a prison term of one year to life, imposed upon a defendant who has pleaded guilty to criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, a class A-III felony, is affirmed.

 

751 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Michaelis v. Long Beach


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


46 A.D.2d 772; 360 N.Y.S.2d 473; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3712



November 4, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, without costs, and motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city sought review of the order of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which granted plaintiff zoning board members' motion for a preliminary injunction and enjoined the city from interfering with the rights of the members to hold office as members of the zoning board, pending a trial of the action.


OVERVIEW: The city enacted an ordinance, which changed the pattern of selecting members of the zoning board from that set forth in Long Beach, N.Y., Gen. City Law § 81-a to that set forth in § 81, and terminated the tenure of the members. The members filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, enjoining the city from interfering with the members' right to hold office, pending trial of the matter. The trial court granted the motion. On appeal, the court reversed. The court held that the city had the authority to enact the ordinance pursuant to § 81-a and later revert back to § 81. According to the court, absent any express constitutional limitation, a legislative body had full and unquestionable power to abolish an office of its creation or to modify the terms of the office, in the public interest, even though the effect may have curtailed an incumbent's unexpired term.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order that granted the members' motion for a preliminary injunction.

 

752 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Paciona v. Marshall


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


45 A.D.2d 462; 359 N.Y.S.2d 360; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4119



September 19, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Application unanimously denied and petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a petition, under article 78, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7801, seeking an order of prohibition to prevent the trial judge and the state from proceeding against him on a homicide indictment. There had been a judicial finding in a different case that the county selection of a grand jury pool violated constitutional due process requirements because it routinely excluded students and deliberately discriminated against women.


OVERVIEW: On appeal of the denial of his application, defendant claimed that he was entitled to a dismissal of the indictment returned by the illegally constituted grand jury because it was constitutionally infirm and that his allegations of constitutional deprivations precluded the dismissal of his application for failing to comply with the requirement under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.35 that he file a motion to dismiss the indictment within 30 days of a plea of not guilty. Finding that, notwithstanding the civil nature of a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, defendant properly invoked relief thereunder to enjoin the trial court's actions that were allegedly in excess of its jurisdiction due to the illegal indictment, the court nevertheless denied defendant's application. In so doing, the court held that defendant's unwarranted failure to comply with § 210.35 and his failure to demonstrate any prejudice that required relief in the interests of justice, rendered his application meritless and constituted a waiver of his right to object to the grand jury's composition. The court took judicial notice of facts that the jury commissioner systematically excluded women and disqualified students.


OUTCOME: The court unanimously denied defendant's application and dismissed his petition, without costs.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- indictment -- illegally constituted Grand Jury -- article 78 proceeding for order of prohibition against Trial Justice and District Attorney, on ground Grand Jury pool from which indictment against petitioner was drawn had been drawn in violation of constitutional due process by exclusion of students and women, dismissed; motion to dismiss indictment under CPL 210.20 was not sought within time prescribed and no prejudice requiring relief in interest of justice is suggested; failure of petitioner to avail himself of relief by motion constituted waiver of right to object to composition of Grand Jury -- article 78 proceeding proper remedy.

1. An article 78 proceeding for an order of prohibition against the Trial Justice and the District Attorney, on the ground that the Grand Jury pool from which the indictment returned against petitioner was drawn had been drawn in violation of [***2] constitutional due process by the exclusion of students and women, should be dismissed. A motion to dismiss an indictment under CPL 210.20 by reason of the Grand Jury having been illegally constituted must be made within 30 days of a plea of not guilty or later in the discretion of the Trial Judge if the interest of justice requires. Such relief was not sought within the time prescribed and no prejudice requiring relief in the interest of justice is suggested. The application for a writ is without merit since petitioner failed to avail himself of the relief by motion and that failure constituted a waiver of his right to object to the composition of the Grand Jury.

2. Since petitioner seeks to enjoin the trial court from acting in excess of its jurisdiction by proceeding to trial on an illegal indictment, an article 78 proceeding is his proper remedy.

 

753 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Enders v. Rossi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


45 A.D.2d 447; 358 N.Y.S.2d 782; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4191



August 23, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed without costs and petition granted in accordance with opinion by Witmer, J.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, elected officials, and intervenor, a candidate, sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court of Oneida County (New York), which dismissed their petition requesting a declaration that provisions of the county charter, fixing the terms of petitioners' offices at four years, were invalid, and requesting that respondent Commissioners of Elections place the elected positions on the ballot for the November general elections.


OVERVIEW: The court examined Oneida County Charter (Local Laws, 1961, No. 3 of County of Oneida), art. XVI, XVII, and XVIII. The charter provided that the positions of sheriff, county clerk, and district attorney would be for four-year terms. N.Y. Const. art. XIII, § 13(a) and N.Y. County Law 400(1) provided that the terms for such offices in counties outside of the City of New York would be for three years each. The elected officials claimed that the charter was unconstitutional and the court agreed. The court concluded that there was no indication of any intent in the Constitution or in the legislation to permit local county governments to establish disparate, unbridled terms in the offices of sheriff, county clerk, or district attorney. Therefore, the court held that the Oneida County Charter provisions fixing the terms of office of the sheriff, county clerk, and district attorney, at four years were unconstitutional and invalid. The court held that the elected officials were entitled to a judgment declaring such invalidity.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that dismissed the elected officials' petition. The court issued a declaration that the county charter provisions fixing the terms of public office at four years were unconstitutional and invalid. The court declared that the terms of such offices were for three years.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- public officers -- in Oneida County, terms of office of Sheriff, County Clerk, and District Attorney are three years, not four years (N. Y. Const., art. XIII, § 13, subd. [a]).

In Oneida County, the Sheriff, the County Clerk, and the District Attorney are each elected for terms of three years, not four years. The corresponding four-year-term provisions of the Oneida County Charter (Local Laws, 1961, No. 3 of County of Oneida, arts. XVI, XVII, XVIII) are unconstitutional and invalid (N. Y. Const., art. XIII, § 13, subd. [a]; cf. art. IX, § 1, subd. [h], par. [1]; cf. former art. IX, § 2, subds. [a], [d], and § 5; County Law, § 400, subd. 1; cf. § 400, subds. 1-a, 1-b; cf. § 2, subd. [b]).

 

754 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Amerman v. Lizza & Sons, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


45 A.D.2d 996; 358 N.Y.S.2d 220; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4234



July 29, 1974 *


* Not published with other decisions of July 29, 1974, 45 A D 2d 891. [Rep.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff parents sought review of an order from the Supreme Court of Suffolk County (New York), which granted defendant contractor's motion to set aside the jury verdict of damages in favor of plaintiff for the wrongful death of one of the infants, and personal injury of the other infants.


OVERVIEW: The parents filed two actions that were consolidated for the trial against the contractor. One was for the wrongful death of one of the infants and the other was for the personal injuries sustained by the other two infants. A jury returned a verdict in favor of the parents and awarded them damages. The trial court granted the contractor's motion to set aside the jury's award of damages as excessive. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that N.Y. Const. art. I, § 16 did not make the provisions of N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-4.2, which limited damages to pecuniary injuries resulting from the decedent's death to the persons for whose benefits the action was brought, unconstitutional. The court found no ground to overturn the trial court's action in finding the verdict was excessive. Further, there was no statutory limitation of damages in a case for pecuniary loss.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order that granted the contractor's motion to set aside the jury verdict of damages in favor of the parents for the wrongful death of one of the infants, and personal injuries for the other infants.

 

755 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cummings v. Regan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


45 A.D.2d 415; 358 N.Y.S.2d 556; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4335



July 25, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law, and petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, state parole board and administrators, sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Albany County (New York), which denied the parole board's motion to dismiss the petition for a writ of mandamus filed by petitioner inmates.


OVERVIEW: Each of the inmates had been denied parole release without a statement of reasons by appellants. The inmates filed a petition seeking a writ of mandamus to compel appellants to provide such statements. The trial court ordered that the proceeding be treated as a class action and ruled that appellants had to provide each member of the class with a written statement setting forth the ground for the parole denial. Appellants sought review, contending that the trial court erred in certifying the class and in compelling appellants to furnish a written statement. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's judgment. The court held that the inmates possessed no presently existing interest in liberty or property that was threatened by further governmental deprivation that would justifiably support a claim for due process. The court further held that a written statement of reasons was unnecessary because judicial review in parole denial cases was severely limited in scope. The court concluded that the trial court also erred in designating the proceeding as a class action.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and dismissed the inmates' petition for a writ of mandamus to compel appellants to provide statements of reasons for denying parole release.


HEADNOTES

Parole -- denial of parole -- statement of reasons -- State Board of Parole is under no statutory duty to provide inmate with statement of its reasons for denying him release on parole, nor is it under constitutional duty to do so as matter of due process -- in view of this conclusion, it is not necessary to determine whether proceeding, brought by inmates seeking to have board required to state reasons, was properly treated as class action.

1. The State Board of Parole is under no statutory duty to provide an inmate [***2] with a statement of its reasons for denying him release on parole, nor is it under a constitutional duty to do so as a matter of due process. The article 78 machinery now available for review of the board's determination adequately provides the process due to such an inmate.

2. In view of this conclusion, it is not necessary to determine whether the present proceeding, brought by inmates who seek to have the board required to state its reasons for denying them release on parole, was properly treated as a class action.

 

756 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Broad Properties, Inc. v. O'Hara


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


45 A.D.2d 868; 358 N.Y.S.2d 3; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4349



July 22, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, New York City Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) and New York State Commissioner of the Office of General Services, appealed an order of the Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York), which denied their motion to dismiss the complaint, and defendant property purchaser (purchaser) appealed a separate order denying its summary judgment motion, in plaintiff corporation's action challenging 1973 N.Y. Laws 688 (Act) as invalid.


OVERVIEW: The Act authorized the Commissioner to sell a certain state-owned parcel of land to the purchaser upon such terms and conditions as the Commissioner determined. The purchaser acquired the land from the Commissioner pursuant to the Act and used it as a recharge basin for water drainage. The MTA later acquired a nearby parcel for use as a transportation center, and surface water from its parcel drained into the basin. The corporation brought an action against defendants for a declaration that the Act was unconstitutional. The trial court denied the motions to dismiss brought by the MTA and the Commissioner, as well as the summary judgment motion brought by the purchaser, and defendants appealed. The court, which treated all the motions as being for summary judgment, held that defendants were entitled to summary judgment because the corporation failed to show beyond a reasonable doubt that the Act violated any statutory or constitutional provisions. The purchaser had agreed to pay consideration, to continue using the property as a basin, to grant the MTA an easement for its drainage, and to maintain the property at no cost to the state.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's order and, in treating all motions as being for summary judgment, granted summary judgment to defendants. The court further declared the Act to be valid and constitutional.

 

757 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Goldin v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


45 A.D.2d 870; 357 N.Y.S.2d 867; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4352



July 22, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant school board sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court of Suffolk County (New York), which enjoined it from disciplining respondent counselor for sleeping with a student. The counselor cross-appealed from the portions of the order that allowed the school board to proceed on charges that he lied about his conduct and to continue his suspension without pay.


OVERVIEW: The counselor was accused of sleeping with a student and he was suspended without pay under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3020-a. The counselor brought an action against the school board and alleged that the suspension without pay pending the outcome of his disciplinary hearing was unconstitutional. The court held that there was no basis for the lower court's decision to bar disciplinary proceedings on the charge that the counselor slept with a student because the issue went to the heart of his ability to perform his duty without destroying the public trust. The court held that § 3020-a was not unconstitutional. Although the statute was deficient because it did not limit the length of the suspension, the court saved the statute when it imposed a 30-day limit, as provided in the statutes for the suspension for civil servants. The court held that the counselor was entitled to pay after the 30 days expired even though the disciplinary process was not completed.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the lower court was modified and affirmed.

 

758 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Boston Stock Exchange v. State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


45 A.D.2d 365; 357 N.Y.S.2d 116; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4416



July 9, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County entered on December 20, 1973, unanimously modified, on the law, and defendants' motion to dismiss the complaint granted to the extent of directing that a judgment be entered declaring that the provisions added to the Tax Law by chapter 827 of the Laws of 1968 are valid and constitutional. Appellants shall recover of respondents $ 60 costs and disbursements of this appeal.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state tax commission appealed an order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which denied its motion to dismiss plaintiff stock exchanges' complaint for a declaration that N.Y. Tax Law § 270-a was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The stock exchanges, located in outside New York, sought a declaration that § 270-a amending the existing stock transfer tax law was constitutionally invalid. The tax commission sought to dismiss the complaint on the grounds that the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction; that the stock exchanges had no legal capacity to sue because they were not subject to the transfer tax and were not legally aggrieved thereby; and that the complaint failed to state a cause of action. The trial court denied the motion and the tax commission appealed. The court modified the judgment to the extent of declaring that the provisions of 1968 N.Y. Laws 827 were constitutional, holding that New York courts had jurisdiction to decide the case and that the stock exchanges had standing to maintain the action because the purpose of the amendment was to discourage diversion of stock transactions from New York exchanges. Therefore, the stock exchanges could have been potentially injured by the amendment. However, there was no constitutional infirmity in N.Y. Tax Law § 270-a because the State's taxing power could be used to promote the economy of the taxing unit by favoring nonresidents over residents.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's judgment and granted the tax commission's motion to dismiss the complaint to the extent of directing that a judgment be entered declaring that the provisions added to the Tax Law were valid and constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- stock transfer tax -- section 270-a of Tax Law, providing that, in case of sales of securities within New York by nonresident, rate of tax was to be reduced by graduated annual steps to 50% and further providing for maximum tax, is constitutional; taxing power may be used to promote economy by favoring nonresidents over residents -- section 270-a does not impose unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce -- New York courts have jurisdiction of action by out-of-State stock exchanges to declare section 270-a unconstitutional -- plaintiffs have standing to maintain action.

1. Section [***2] 270-a of the Tax Law, providing that, in the case of sales of securities within New York State by a nonresident, the rate of tax was reduced by graduated annual steps to 50% and further providing for a maximum tax on sales within the State relating to shares of the same class and issued by the same issuer, is constitutional. The underlying motivation of the Legislature was not to favor New York stock exchanges over out-of-State exchanges, but to enact legislation providing taxation sufficient to permit the State and its subdivisions to raise funds to meet the increasing needs of governmental services. The taxing power may be used to promote the economy of the taxing unit by favoring nonresidents over residents. Further, the ease of collection warrants the distinction for transactions in New York are less susceptible to tax evasion than those made outside the State.

2. The statute does not impose an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce.

3. The courts of New York have jurisdiction of an action by out-of-State stock exchanges to declare section 270-a of the Tax Law unconstitutional since those courts have jurisdiction to decide cases involving rights of litigants under [***3] the Federal Constitution unless deprived of that power by that Constitution or statute.

4. Plaintiffs have standing to maintain the action since the purpose of section 270-a was to discourage diversion of stock transactions from New York exchanges and plaintiffs may, therefore, claim to be potentially injured by the statute.

 

759 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bowne v. County of Nassau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


45 A.D.2d 304; 358 N.Y.S.2d 144; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4430



July 8, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of the Supreme Court, Nassau County, entered October 12, 1973, reversed, on the law, with $ 20 costs and disbursements to appellants against the respondent county, county agency and county official, the termination of petitioners' employment is annulled, effective as of May 17, 1973, and said respondents are enjoined from interfering with petitioners' employment.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, terminated employees of a county probation department, appealed from the judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Nassau County (New York), which held that the employees fell under the administrative supervision of respondents, a county, a county civil service commission, and a county director of probation, and which upheld respondents' termination of the employees.


OVERVIEW: 1971 N.Y. Laws 387 transferred supervision over the employees from the administrative board of the judicial conference to the county supervisors. The trial court held that the county thus had the right to require a competitive examination and to terminate employees who did not make the eligible list. On appeal, the court reversed because N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 28 vested the judicial conference with the administrative supervision of the unified court system, and the various departments subject to the direction and control of the courts were part of that system. The inclusion of the probation department in the court system accorded with reason, common sense, and the integrity of the judiciary because probation departments were limited in their function to providing of ancillary services to the courts, and the confidential relationship between the courts and the department required close control by the courts. While the board could be made subject to reasonable limitations in the exercise of its supervisory power, 1971 N.Y. Laws 387 divested the board of such power, which violated N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 28 and which the legislature thus was powerless to do.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court, which upheld the termination of the employees, and enjoined respondents from interfering with the employees' employment.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- unified court system -- probation department -- Nassau County Probation Department is part of unified court system -- insofar as chapter 387 of Laws of 1971 places supervision and control of said department in county rather than in judiciary, it violates State Constitution (art. VI, § 28).

Chapter 387 of the Laws of 1971, effective September 1, 1971, in effect transferred supervision over various county probation departments from the Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference to the boards of supervisors or county legislatures of the counties. The unified court system was created [***2] by the adoption of article VI of the State Constitution, effective on September 1, 1962. Administrative authority over ancillary services was placed in the courts by virtue of the extensive court reorganization in 1962 and, accordingly, on September 1, 1962 the Nassau County Probation Department became a part of the unified court system as an auxiliary service. Insofar as chapter 387 of the Laws of 1971 places supervision and control of the Nassau County Probation Department in the county rather than in the judiciary, it is violative of section 28 of article VI of the State Constitution.

 

760 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Susan B.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


45 A.D.2d 920; 357 N.Y.S.2d 313; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4487



July 5, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the law guardian for a 16-year-old girl, challenged the order of the Jefferson County Family Court (New York) to keep the girl in a school for troubled youth past her 16th birthday.


OVERVIEW: The girl was in trouble with the law and had been sent to several public and private treatment facilities. She refused to attend school, physically struck a teacher, and when released on probation stayed away from home and lived with persons under conditions that had a deleterious effect on her morals. The family court found that one school seemed to have a program that was committed to helping the girl, who had recently turned 16, and issued an order to keep the girl in the school past her 16th birthday. The court affirmed the family court's decision. The court held that the legislature intended that a 16-year-old could be subject to continued placement in a treatment facility under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 756(b), (c).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the family court's order.

 

761 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Soucy v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


45 A.D.2d 808; 357 N.Y.S.2d 59; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4585



June 27, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a tenured kindergarten teacher, appealed a judgment from the Supreme Court of New York, Albany County, which dismissed her application for a judgment of restraint prohibiting respondent school board from taking any further proceedings for the teacher's dismissal on charges of incompetency.


OVERVIEW: In a prior proceeding, the teacher was dismissed by the school board for incompetency. The teacher filed an action for a judgment of restraint, and the school board's determination was annulled because the teacher was dismissed for acts of incompetence not charged, depriving her of her rights to a fair hearing and due process. After the teacher was restored to her position as a tenured teacher, the school board proceeded de novo against the teacher. The teacher was then served with a notice of the school board's proceedings and a copy of the statement of charges against her. The notice properly informed the teacher that she had 10 days within which to request a formal hearing on the charges. Instead, the teacher again filed an action for a judgment of restraint, which the trial court denied. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding that the school board adequately complied with the requirements of a fair hearing and due process. In reinstituting the proceedings against the teacher, all the school board did was to add more details and specifications to the charge of incompetence so as to allow the teacher to adequately prepare for a fair hearing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the teacher's application.

 

762 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rosenbloom


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


45 A.D.2d 794; 357 N.Y.S.2d 157; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4632



June 25, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the judgment of the County Court of Broome County (New York) that convicted him of criminally negligent homicide upon his plea of guilty.


OVERVIEW: The victim, who was a passenger in defendant's car, was killed as a result of an automobile accident. Defendant was indicted on charges of criminally negligent homicide, driving while intoxicated, and operating a motor vehicle while he had .10 of one percent or more of alcohol, by weight, in his blood. His motion to dismiss the indictment was denied, and defendant entered a guilty plea to criminally negligent homicide in full satisfaction of the indictment. In affirming the conviction, the court held that N.Y. Penal Law § 125.10 was not unconstitutionally vague. It also ruled that where the indictment alleged that defendant's speeding while intoxicated resulted in the accident that claimed the life of his passenger, defendant was fully apprised of the conduct that was the subject of the accusation and every element of the crime of criminally negligent homicide was alleged.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

763 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Slavin v. Ingraham


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


44 A.D.2d 874; 355 N.Y.S.2d 658; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4935



May 23, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Determination annulled, without costs, and petition granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowners sought review of the decision from respondent Commissioner of Health of the State of New York, which imposed fines and penalties upon the landowners for violations of N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1116.


OVERVIEW: The landowners inherited three tracts of land consisting of 328 acres, which they conveyed in 26 parcels. The New York State Department of Health brought an administrative proceeding against the landowners, alleging that the conveyances violated N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1116, in that the parcels had been sold without the landowners having filed a subdivision map approved by the Department. The hearing officer determined that the landowners had divided a tract of land with five or more parcels along an existing road for sale as residential lots. The landowners claimed that the determination was not supported by substantial evidence. The court agreed, holding that: (1) the Department of Health proceeded on the basis that the landowners' land consisted of a single tract, although their deed contained three descriptions; (2) by ordinary definition, custom, and usage, the three descriptions would be considered three separate tracts and there was no evidence that the 26 conveyances were out of one of the tracts or out of all the tracts; and (3) where the sales were of recreation lands, there was nothing in the record that indicated that the land was conveyed for residential purposes.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the Department of Health's determination and order, which imposed fines and penalties upon the landowners. The court granted the landowners' petition.

 

764 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Klein v. Murtagh


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


44 A.D.2d 465; 355 N.Y.S.2d 622; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4966



May 20, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Petitions dismissed on the merits, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner defendants applied for writs of prohibition, on double jeopardy grounds, to bar respondent state prosecutors and judges from prosecuting them under an indictment which charged them with violations of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 105.05 and 200.00 et seq. after their federal convictions for violations of 18 U.S.C.S. § 1952, based upon the same facts, were dismissed for insufficient evidence.


OVERVIEW: After charges against them for allegedly violating 18 U.S.C.S. § 1952 were dismissed in federal court for insufficient evidence, petitioner defendants and intervenor defendant were charged in a state indictment with violating N.Y. Penal Law §§ 105.05, 200.00, 200.10, 200.20, and 200.25. The state indictment was based upon the same overt acts for which they were prosecuted in federal court. Claiming the state prosecutions violated their rights against double jeopardy, U.S. Const. amend. V and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6, petitioners applied for writs of prohibition, with intervenor being allowed to intervene, to restrain respondent prosecutors and judges from pursuing the state prosecution. In denying the petitions, the court ruled that, while the same facts were involved in each, double jeopardy provisions did not bar the state proceedings because the two prosecutions did not involve the "same offense." The prosecutions were based on separate and distinct federal and state statutes. Moreover, § 1952 contained an element, use of interstate facilities, that was not an essential element of the state charges, so prosecution was also allowed under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 40.20(2)(f).


OUTCOME: The petitions were denied because the state prosecutions would not violate petitioners' or intervenor's double jeopardy rights since they were not being prosecuted for the "same offense" as under the federal prosecution; while the overt acts were the same, the prosecutions were based upon separate and distinct statutes of two different sovereigns and the federal statute included an essential element not present in the state statutes.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- former jeopardy -- prosecution of defendants under Queens County indictment charging conspiracy and bribery is not barred by their prosecution in Federal court in which their conviction for alleged violation of United States Code (tit. 18, § 1952) was reversed; defendants are being prosecuted for two different offenses based on same act or criminal transaction -- doctrine of separate and dual sovereignty still viable -- present situation falls within exception in paragraph (f) of subdivision 2 of CPL 40.20 which provides that person may be prosecuted for two offenses based on same act if prosecution, in another jurisdiction, as here, was terminated for insufficiency of evidence as to some element of offense -- paragraph (f) not unconstitutional.

1. The prosecution of petitioners and the intervenor (defendants) under an indictment returned in Queens County charging conspiracy and bribery and related crimes is not barred by reason of double [***2] jeopardy by their prosecution in Federal court in which their conviction for an alleged violation of section 1952 of title 18 of the United States Code was reversed. That reversal was based on the prosecution's failure to provide the "Federal" element, i.e., to establish that defendants used a facility in interstate or foreign commerce for purposes listed in section 1952 in a sufficiently meaningful way to subject them to liability under the statute. While the overt acts or transactions are substantially the same in both prosecutions, the prosecutions are not the same in law because they are based on separate and distinct statutes. Defendants are being prosecuted for two different offenses based on the same act or criminal transaction.

2. The doctrine underlying decisions of the Supreme Court in Bartkus v. Illinois (359 U.S. 121) and Abbate v. United States (359 U.S. 187) known as separate or dual sovereignty has not been discarded but is still a viable doctrine.

3. The present situation falls within the exception in paragraph (f) of subdivision 2 of CPL 40.20 which provides that a person may be separately prosecuted for two offenses based on the same act or criminal [***3] transaction if a prosecution in another jurisdiction has been terminated by an order founded on the insufficiency of the evidence to establish some element of the offense. The Federal offense was terminated on the ground of insufficient evidence to show use of interstate facilities, which is not an essential element of the crimes in the State prosecution.

4. Paragraph (f) is not unconstitutional as a denial of equal protection. That defendants are treated differently than a defendant who is acquitted by a jury does not make such treatment unconstitutional. New York has expanded the protection against double jeopardy by statute and the fact that some persons benefit thereby while defendants do not is no basis for a claim that they are being denied constitutional rights.

 

765 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Claire


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


44 A.D.2d 407; 355 N.Y.S.2d 399; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5021



May 14, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order, Family Court of the State of New York, entered on September 13, 1973, unanimously modified, on the law and the facts, to the extent of granting tuition costs for the months of July and August, 1973, thereby increasing the amount allowed for transportation and tuition costs to $ 2,339.60, and reversing so much of said order as denied maintenance costs and remanding the matter for determination of the amount to be charged for maintenance costs and the amount of contribution, if any, to be made by the petitioner to these costs, and as so modified, affirmed, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner father brought a proceeding, pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 232, against respondent city, seeking to secure an order for payment of tuition, transportation, and maintenance costs with respect to his physically handicapped child. The Family Court, Bronx County (New York) entered judgment allowing only tuition expenses during the school year. The father appealed.


OVERVIEW: The father brought the proceeding after his child was placed in a special school. At a hearing before the family court, the father asserted any requirement for contribution on his part was a violation of equal protection. He also challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act §§ 232, 234, asserting a denial of equal protection because parents of other handicapped children were not required to contribute support. In its decision the family court stated maintenance expenses were the responsibility of the child's family. No reason was given for disallowance of tuition expenses for the summer months. On appeal, the city conceded the family court should not have denied tuition costs for the summer months and should have allowed the application for maintenance. Also on appeal, the court modified the family court's judgment because an award of summertime tuition was appropriate and a determination as to the allocation of maintenance was necessary. The court, however, affirmed the judgment in part because there was rational basis for differentiating between blind and deaf children and children with other handicaps.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment to provide for the payment of tuition costs for the summer months, increased the amount allowed for transportation and tuition costs, reversed the denial of maintenance costs, and remanded for determination of the amount charged for maintenance costs and the amount of contribution. As so modified, the court affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- education of handicapped children -- in proceeding to secure order for payment of tuition, transportation and maintenance costs with respect to physically handicapped child who had been  [***2] placed in special school, Family Court erred in failing to allow maintenance costs -- tuition costs for months of July and August should not have been denied -- requirement that petitioner parent contribute to support not unconstitutional where parents of other handicapped children are not required to contribute to support.

1. In a proceeding brought pursuant to Family Court Act ( §§ 232, 234) to secure an order for payment for the months of March through August of 1973 of tuition, transportation and maintenance costs with respect to a physically handicapped child who had been placed in a special school, the Family Court erred in failing to allow maintenance costs. Such costs are properly includible as an item of educational service, together with tuition and transportation costs.

2. Respondent City of New York properly concedes that the Family Court should not have denied tuition costs for the months of July and August, 1973. The authority of the Family Court to make a "suitable order" whenever a physically handicapped child appears to be in need of educational service is not limited by the boundaries of the conventional school year of September through June.

3. The petitioner [***3] parent challenges the constitutionality of the statute ( Family Ct. Act, §§ 232, 234) on the ground that it denied him equal protection of the law because parents of other handicapped youngsters, such as blind and deaf children, are not required to contribute to their support. There is a rational basis for differentiating between blind and deaf children and children with other type handicaps and no invidious discrimination results.

4. Petitioner asserts that it is the duty of the State to provide a free education. The nature of the special educational training suitable for the needs of a physically handicapped child may well serve as a rational basis for distinguishing it from the common or public school training. There is no constitutional infirmity prohibiting the Family Court from directing the petitioner, as one chargeable for the support of the child, to contribute to maintenance costs, if he is financially able to do so.

 

766 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Battle v. Lavine


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


44 A.D.2d 307; 354 N.Y.S.2d 680; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5186



April 22, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law, without costs but with disbursements, respondents' determinations annulled, subdivision (c) of section 352.3 of the Regulations of the Department of Social Services of the State of New York declared unconstitutional and respondents directed to reinstate petitioner's shelter allowance as of May 1, 1973.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, an aid recipient, appealed a judgment from the Supreme Court at Special Term in Nassau County (New York), which denied her application under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78.
