The recipient sought to: (1) annul a determination of respondent Department of Social Services of the State of New York, which affirmed the reduction of her public assistance grant; and (2) to declare unconstitutional N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 352.3(c).


OVERVIEW: The recipient's shelter allowance was reduced because her landlord refused to provide verification of his mortgage. The recipient rented one room in a family dwelling. Also residing in the residence were the landlord, his children, and two other tenants. Section 352.3 provided that for children or adults in receipt of public assistance residing in the home of a self-maintaining non-legally responsible relative or friend, the allowance for rent and/or other shelter costs was computed on a prorated basis. The trial court held that § 352.3(c) was not violative of the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution, U.S. Const. art. VI, cl. 2, because it did not contravene 45 C.F.R. § 233.90(a). On review, the court disagreed. Section 233.90(a) provided that the inclusion in the family, or the presence in the home, of a substitute parent or any individual was not an acceptable basis for a finding of ineligibility or for assuming the availability of income by the State. The court held that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 352.3(c) violated the Supremacy Clause and was, therefore, unconstitutional. Accordingly, the judgment was reversed.


OUTCOME: The trial court's judgment, which denied the recipient's petition, was reversed with disbursements. The Department's determination to reduce the recipient's public assistance grant was annulled and the Regulations of the Department of Social Services of the State of New York at issue were declared unconstitutional. The court directed that the recipient's shelter allowance be reinstituted.


HEADNOTES

Social services -- shelter allowance -- subdivision (c) of section 352.3 of Regulations of State Department of Social Services providing that, for persons in receipt of public assistance residing in home of self-sustaining, nonlegally responsible relative or friend,  [***2] shelter allowance shall be computed on prorated basis, violates supremacy clause of United States Constitution in that it sanctions that which section 233.90 (subd. [a]) of title 45 of Code of Federal Regulations prohibits -- accordingly, petitioner whose shelter allowance was reduced following birth of child to her, father being landlord's son, is entitled to have allowance reinstated, statutory authority for reduction having been said subdivision (c) of section 352.3

1. Subdivision (c) of section 352.3 of the Regulations of the State Department of Social Services, which provides that, for persons in receipt of public assistance residing in the home of a self-maintaining, nonlegally responsible relative or friend, shelter allowance costs shall be computed on a prorated basis, is violative of the supremacy clause of the United States Constitution (art. VI, cl. 2). That subdivision sanctions that which section 233.90 (subd. [a]) of title 45 of the Code of Federal Regulations prohibits, i.e., the "inclusion in the family, or the presence in the home, of * * * any individual * * * is not an acceptable basis for a finding of ineligibility or for assuming the availability of income [***3] by the state."

2. Although the purpose of the State regulation may be to forbid a non-eligible individual from indirectly receiving State assistance from a qualified recipient by living with that person, the result is to reduce the rental stipend for those who are eligible.

3. The argument that the purpose of the State regulation, to assure that the qualified recipient is not receiving additional support from the person with whom she is living, does not contravene the Federal regulation is without merit.

4. Accordingly, petitioner whose shelter allowance was reduced by 100% following the birth of a child to her, the father being her landlord's son, is entitled to have her shelter allowance reinstated. She had received notice of the reduction with the reason given that her landlord refused to provide verification of his mortgage so that a proportionate share of the shelter could be allowed petitioner since she was living with "friends" and the statutory authority for the reduction was subdivision (c) of section 352.3, hereby declared to be unconstitutional.

5. The Department of Health, Education and Welfare of the United States is not a necessary party to the proceeding since it [***4] was not sought to cut off all Federal funds.

 

767 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Leroy Fantasies, Inc. v. Swidler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


44 A.D.2d 266; 354 N.Y.S.2d 182; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5214; 4 P.U.R.4th 334



April 18, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant restaurant owners sought review from a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which dismissed their application pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to vacate a determination of appellees, the public service commission (PSC) and others, ordering that gas service to the restaurant be discontinued unless the restaurant stopped using unmantled gas lamps in violation of N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 66.


OVERVIEW: The restaurant owners challenged the order requiring discontinuance of service based on arguments contesting the authority of the PSC and the appropriateness of the order and proceedings resulting in the order. The court found that: (1) under N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 66, the authority of the PSC over wasteful devices and practices with respect to the consumption of natural gas extended beyond uses by industrial and manufacturing concerns; (2) the statute created an adequate standard of review because the standard of wastefulness was neither vague nor indefinite; (3) there had been no evidence offered to contest the finding that the unmantled gas lamps used more gas than mantled gas lamps; and (4) the denial of an evidentiary hearing had been proper where the act of banning unmantled lamps had been legislative in nature and did not deprive the restaurant owners of their property, but rather merely imposed reasonable restrictions on future uses of gas.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's judgment dismissing the application to vacate the determination ordering the discontinuance of gas service absent compliance with restrictions on the use of gas lamps.


HEADNOTES

Public utilities -- discontinuance of gas service -- Public Service Commission properly directed utility company to discontinue gas service to petitioners' restaurant unless natural gas lamps used therein were extinguished or converted by installation of mantles (Public Service Law, § 66, subd. 2) -- statute is proper delegation of legislative authority -- lamps used in petitioners' restaurant are "decorative lamps" within definition in PSC order -- examination by Appellate Division satisfied requirement of review of prohibition of wasteful devices.

1. The Public Service Commission (PSC) properly directed Consolidated Edison Company of New York to discontinue gas service to petitioners' restaurant unless natural gas lamps used in the restaurant were extinguished or converted so that mantles [***2] were installed. Section 66 (subd. 2) of the Public Service Law provides that the PSC may order the curtailment or discontinuance of the use of natural gas for manufacturing or industrial purposes for up to four months if it is established that "the supply of natural gas is not adequate to meet the reasonable demands of domestic consumption and may prohibit the use of natural gas in wasteful devices and practices." The power given to the PSC in section 66 to prohibit wasteful devices and practices extends beyond uses by industrial and manufacturing concerns and is separate and distinct from the power to order the curtailment or discontinuance of gas usage for industrial purposes.

2. The statute creates an adequate standard against which to review the actions of the PSC and is, therefore, a proper delegation of legislative authority. The word "wasteful" is neither vague nor indefinite.

3. The gas lamps used in petitioners' restaurant fall within the definition of "decorative torches" as found in a PSC order of January, 1973, notwithstanding their illuminating function and petitioners have failed to produce any evidence to overcome the determination of the PSC that unmantled gas lamps [***3] use more gas than mantled lamps.

4. The examination by the Appellate Division has satisfied the requirement of a review of the prohibition of wasteful devices to determine if it was within the power of the PSC.

5. The effect of the order of the PSC is not to deprive petitioners of property since it imposes reasonable restrictions on future uses of gas to be acquired in connection with the lamps. Furthermore, there was no deprivation of any of petitioners' constitutional rights where all facts asserted by petitioners were presented to the PSC before it determined to disallow petitioners' request for an exemption.

 

768 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Canastota v. Queensboro Farm Products, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


44 A.D.2d 276; 354 N.Y.S.2d 451; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5217



April 18, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law and the facts, and motion for a stay of arbitration granted, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner village sought review after the Supreme Court at Special Term in Madison County (New York) denied its motion for a stay of arbitration in an action on a contract with respondent citizen.


OVERVIEW: The village enacted an ordinance that set forth rules and procedures for the determination of sewer service charges to be levied against property owners within the corporate limits of the village whose property was connected to the system. The citizen informed the village that the charges proposed to be imposed would require it to move or to construct its own sewage disposal system. The parties entered into negotiations, which resulted in a contract. Any controversy or claim arising out of or relating to the contract was to be submitted to arbitration. The Board of Trustees adopted a resolution declaring the contract void and unenforceable. The citizen served a notice of intention to arbitrate. The village filed a motion for an order staying arbitration, which the trial court denied. The court reversed. In light of the specific restrictions contained in N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 452(2), the village lacked authority to establish sewer rates by contract, and therefore the contract was of no force and effect. Estoppel did not apply because one who made a contract with a municipal corporation was bound to take notice of limitations on its power to contract.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order that denied the village's motion for a stay of arbitration in a contract dispute.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- sewer rents -- contract between village and respondent establishing special sewage charges pursuant to provisions of village ordinance was of no force and effect; section 452 (subd. 2) of General Municipal Law provides that sewer rents may be established only by local law or ordinance and, therefore, village lacked authority to establish charges by contract -- village cannot be estopped to deny validity of ultra vires contract -- ratification of contract by resolution of Board of Trustees did not satisfy provisions of section 452 -- furthermore, 1972 resolution could be viewed as having repealed 1966 resolution, thus repealing contract and, therefore there would not be contract pursuant to which respondent would have been entitled to arbitration -- motion for stay of arbitration granted.

1. A contract entered into in 1966 between the Village of Canastota and respondent [***2] establishing a special sewage charge was authorized by a resolution of the Board of Trustees and was made pursuant to a section of a village ordinance giving the board power to waive the general requirements of the ordinance and to assign a special charge by agreement to an industrial user. In December, 1972 the Board of Trustees adopted a resolution declaring the contract void and unenforceable and in March, 1973 respondent served a notice of intention to arbitrate under the terms of the contract. A motion by the village to stay arbitration should have been granted. Section 452 (subd. 2) of the General Municipal Law provides that sewer rents may be established and imposed only by local law or ordinance and, therefore, the village lacked authority to establish sewer charges by contract. Consequently, the 1966 contract was of no force and effect.

2. The village cannot be estopped to deny the validity of the ultra vires contract. Respondent must be charged to have notice that the village ordinance could not authorize a contract not authorized by section 452. In entering into the contract, respondent did so at its own risk.

3. While the Board of Trustees did adopt a resolution [***3] in 1966 adopting the contract, the failure to include resolutions in section 452 (subd. 2), as well as the fact that "resolution" is not included in the definition of village ordinances ( Village Law, § 92), requires the conclusion that ratification of the contract by resolution did not satisfy the provisions of section 452.

4. Furthermore, the 1972 resolution could only be viewed as a repealer of the 1966 resolution (§ 452, subd. 2, fifth sentence), thus repealing the contract as well. Therefore, there would not have been in existence in 1973 a contract pursuant to which respondent would have been entitled to arbitration.

 

769 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Albert Simon, Inc. v. Myerson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


44 A.D.2d 245; 354 N.Y.S.2d 419; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5242



April 16, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on January 17, 1974, reversed, on the law, without costs and without disbursements, and vacated, and the relief demanded in the petition granted.

Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant manufacturers sought review of decision by respondent Commissioner of Consumer Affairs of the City of New York, which withdrew approval of their gaming devices.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturers, who produced games like pinball machines, were granted approval of four samples of such machines by the Commissioner, then manufactured, sold, and installed them around the city. Over a year later, the Commissioner withdrew her approval on advice from a police expert that the machines were prohibited gambling devices, and the manufacturers brought a N.Y. R. Civ. Prac., art. 78 proceeding based on several grounds. On review, the court found that there could be no estoppel against a public body or officer under the facts, that hardship resulting from the Commissioner's corrective action did not change that rule, and that the State of New York had not pre-empted the field. However, it found that the statutory prohibition of the games was unconstitutional because the purpose was interdiction of gambling, but the statutory test distinguishing gambling from amusement, which was based on whether the game's outcome was affected by chance, had no reasonable relationship and application to the evil it was designed to avoid because the court found it difficult to conceive of any device in which the outcome would not be affected in some degree by chance.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and granted the relief demanded in the manufacturers' petition, on the law, without costs, and without disbursements.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- gambling devices -- section B32-40.0 of Administrative Code of City of New York, designed to prevent use of gambling devices while allowing amusement machines, is unconstitutional where there is no fair or reasonable connection between test, whether there is element of chance in playing game, and promotion of welfare and safety of society -- accordingly, following withdrawal of approval of pinball machines after one year on ground machines were gambling devices, relief demanded in article 78 petition granted.

1. Section B32-40.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York which was designed to prevent the use of gambling devices while allowing machines providing amusement is unconstitutional. The statutory test of whether there is any [***2] element of chance in the playing of the game has no relationship to the object to be attained, the interdiction of gambling. The player on the machines manufactured by petitioner can neither gain nor lose as a result of the game. Therefore, there is no fair, just or reasonable connection between said test and the promotion of the welfare and safety of society, the necessary element to validate an exercise of the police power.

2. Accordingly, where approval of certain devices in the nature of pinball machines, samples of which were submitted by petitioner, was withdrawn after a year upon advice from a police expert to respondent, the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, that the machines were gambling devices and prohibited by the statute, the relief demanded in the petition in a CPLR article 78 proceeding should be granted.

3. There can be no estoppel against a public body or officer in this situation.

4. The State has not pre-empted the field.

 

770 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bevan v. New York State Teachers' Retirement System


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


44 A.D.2d 163; 355 N.Y.S.2d 185; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5259; 8 Fair Empl. Prac. Cas. (BNA) 283; 8 Empl. Prac. Dec. (CCH) P9590



April 11, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment and order modified, on the law and the facts, by reversing so much thereof as declared a portion of subdivision 1 of section 511 of the Education Law unconstitutional, and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant school district appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which declared a portion of N.Y. Educ. Law § 511(1) unconstitutional and ordered the reinstatement of plaintiff teacher.


OVERVIEW: After receiving conflicting recommendations from physicians regarding the teacher's ability to return to work, the school board terminated the tenured teacher's sick leave, and submitted an application for disability retirement to the New York State Teachers' Retirement System. Contending that N.Y. Educ. Law § 511(1) was unconstitutional insofar as it would permit the teachers' retirement system to terminate a tenured teacher's continued employment without giving the teacher an opportunity for a hearing, the teacher commenced an action seeking to restrain the teachers' retirement system from processing the retirement application. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment ordering that the teacher be reinstated because the failure to grant the teacher a hearing before the termination of his employment was improper. The court reversed the part of the judgment declaring that § 511(1) was unconstitutional because the teachers' retirement system had not yet acted upon the application that was submitted by the school board and the court would not presume that the teachers' retirement system was going to deny the teacher due process.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the part of the judgment that declared that a statutory provision relating to the involuntary retirement of a tenured teacher was unconstitutional. The court affirmed the part of the judgment that directed the teacher's reinstatement.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- teachers -- tenured teacher who has become blind may not be placed on disability retirement without hearing -- action as to whether State Teachers' Retirement System has power (Education Law, § 511, subd. 1) to enforce member's retirement without consent for physical disability should have been dismissed as premature in that respect.

1. Plaintiff, a tenured elementary school teacher, had become blind while on extended sick leave to [***2] obtain medical treatment and, upon making known his desire to return to his teaching post, he was advised that the school board had changed his status to "medical disability retirement". Subsequently, upon resolution of the school board, plaintiff's sick leave was terminated and an application for disability retirement was authorized and submitted to the State Teachers' Retirement System. While no opinion is expressed on plaintiff's blindness as it might affect his teaching competency, the failure to grant him a hearing on that issue before termination of his unemployment was improper and his reinstatement was properly directed.

2. It is not necessary to resolve the question of whether the Retirement System has the power under section 511 (subd. 1) of the Education Law to enforce a member's retirement without his consent for physical disability since it will not be presumed that the Retirement System would exercise such authority, in an unconstitutional manner, without affording plaintiff an adversary hearing. It is enough to state that the action should have been dismissed as premature in that respect.

 

771 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Jerry v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


44 A.D.2d 198; 354 N.Y.S.2d 745; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5263



April 11, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgments unanimously modified in accordance with opinion by Goldman, J., and as modified affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner teachers challenged judgments of the New York Supreme Court in Onondaga County, which dismissed their petitions brought under N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 78 and directed hearings in accordance with § 3020-a of the New York Education Law.


OVERVIEW: In separate proceedings, petitioner teachers were each suspended from their teaching positions by respondent school districts without pay, pending the disposition of the charges against them. Petitioners brought proceedings pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 78, alleging that they were denied their procedural and substantive due process rights with respect to the suspension of their pay. The trial court held that article 78 relief was not available and that suspension of pay was appropriate because petitioners could be reimbursed if they were found innocent of the charges against them. The court reversed, holding that upon a balancing of interests, the harm due to suspension of pay outweighed the governmental interest in denying pay. The court held that article 78 was an inappropriate vehicle, but that 3020-1(2) of the Education Law provided procedural due process to petitioners.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment on the basis that suspension of pay of petitioner teachers was an inappropriate hardship and that respondent school districts could more easily bear the burden of continuing pay. A new trial was granted.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- teachers -- tenured teachers who are suspended pending hearing (Education Law, § 3020-a) must meantime be paid their regular pay and their back pay.

Charges against tenured teachers -- that one teacher is punishing pupils physically and that the other teacher is mentally disabled -- justify suspending them pending a hearing (Education Law, § 3020-a), but not without pay. The Appellate Division directs that each of these suspended teachers shall immediately be paid his or her back pay and his or her regular present pay and future pay; that the hearings shall begin at the earliest opportunity; that the hearings shall proceed in conformity with the Regulations [***2] of the State Commissioner of Education, as amended (8 NYCRR 82.10 [h] and 82.11); and that if, after such hearings and reports, the Board of Education decides that a teacher shall be dismissed or suspended, such board may also direct that the teacher's salary shall cease on the date of such decision by the board; and that, only after such final decision, may the entire proceeding be judicially reviewed and any errors corrected by means of a proceeding under article 78 of the CPLR.

 

772 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Duryea


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


44 A.D.2d 663; 354 N.Y.S.2d 129; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5273



April 11, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Orders affirmed, etc.

 

773 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Long Island Trust Co. v. Porta Aluminum Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


44 A.D.2d 118; 354 N.Y.S.2d 134; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5342; 14 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. (Callaghan) 833



April 1, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order modified (1) by striking therefrom the first two decretal paragraphs and substituting therefor a provision denying the motion, (2) by adding thereto a provision directing that trial of the action proceed immediately and (3) by inserting in the third decretal paragraph, which restrains defendants "from transferring * * * or otherwise disposing of said chattels," immediately after the words "said chattels", the following: "but only the chattels set forth in Schedule A of the financing statement in question, that is, excluding the Dorsey semi-trailer." As so modified, order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff creditor filed a motion, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7102, to direct seizure by a sheriff of certain chattels in the possession of defendant buyers. The supreme court (New York) entered an order that granted the creditor's motion. The buyers appealed.


OVERVIEW: The buyers purchased tractor-trailers from a debtor. Unknown to the buyers, all but one of the tractor-trailers were listed in a security agreement between the debtor and the creditor. On appeal of the order granting the creditor's request for seizure, the buyers contended the seizure statute, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7102, was unconstitutional; the creditor agreed to look solely to the proceeds if the chattels were sold, thereby waiving its lien on the chattel; and the after-acquired goods and chattels clause in the security agreement did not cover tractors and trailers other than those listed in the security agreement. The court found the buyers had been afforded due process because they had the kind of notice and hearing which was aimed at establishing the validity, or at least the probable validity, of the underlying claim against the alleged debtor before they were deprived of their property. However, the court concluded the order of seizure was improvidently made because there was a serious factual question as to whether the creditor authorized the debtor to sell the chattels free of any liens when the creditor asserted its right to receive the proceeds if the chattels were sold.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed, with modifications directing immediate trial of the action and limiting the chattels at issue to those listed in a schedule attached to the financing statement.


HEADNOTES

Secured transactions -- "proceeds" -- after-acquired property -- order of seizure -- notation on filed financing statement, "(X) Proceeds", might mean that creditor authorized debtor to sell chattels (Uniform Commercial Code, § 9-306, subd. [2]); meaning depends on course of dealing, usage of trade, and  [***2] nature of chattels -- in security agreement and in financing statement, after-acquired property clause meant only property acquired as replacement or substitute -- replevin action against debtor's purchasers shall be tried immediately, and meantime they are restrained from transferring or disposing of chattels listed in security agreement -- order of seizure, made on opposing affidavits and oral arguments in which hearing was not requested, accords with constitutional due process (cf. CPLR 7102, subd. [d]).

1. Pursuant to a security agreement pledging the debtor's three tractors and six trailers to secure payment of a loan of $ 23,952.24 in 36 monthly installments, and pursuant to the Uniform Commercial Code ( §§ 9-401, 9-402), the creditor signed and filed a financing statement with the Secretary of State and with the County Clerk covering "all motor vehicles", and stating, in the space provided on the official form, "(X) Proceeds". Thereafter the debtor sold the tractors and trailers to the defendants. Then the debtor failed to pay an installment due on the security agreement; and so the creditor called the whole balance due and commenced this replevin action against said [***3] purchasers, and obtained, after a contested motion, an order directing the Sheriff to seize the chattels from the purchasers, upon the creditor's filing a specified undertaking ( CPLR 7102). But, under the Uniform Commercial Code ( § 9-306, subd. [2]), the creditor's notation on the filed financing statement -- "(X) Proceeds" -- might mean that the creditor authorized the debtor to sell the chattels free of the creditor's lien. The meaning of the notation depends, at least in New York State, on the course of dealing between the parties, the usage of the trade, the nature of the chattels, etc. Since, moreover, the defendants' business might well be crippled by such a seizure prior to any judgment in the action, the order of seizure was improvidently granted and cannot stand.

2. The security agreement listed the three tractors and the six trailers and stated: "Together with all fixtures, additions, replacements * * * and substitutions * * * and * * * all goods and chattels now in, on or upon the within described premises * * * and * * * which the debtor may hereafter acquire * * * and debtor agrees to execute * * * such instruments * * * as may be required by the holder of this [***4] mortgage to create a valid lien thereon"; and the financing statement, as permitted by the security agreement, stated that it covered "all motor vehicles & attachments now owned or hereafter acquired". These words do not include an additional trailer which the debtor subsequently acquired and which was not a replacement of any of the six specified trailers. The order should not have directed the Sheriff to seize this additional trailer, too, from the debtor's purchasers.

3. Only the portion of the order which restrains the defendants from meantime transferring or disposing of the specified three tractors and six trailers shall stand; and, since such vehicles constantly depreciate and are in daily danger of damage, the replevin action shall be tried immediately.

4. The order of seizure was made in accord with constitutional due process (cf. CPLR 7102, subd. [d]), since it was made upon due service and undertaking by plaintiff and upon opposing affidavits and oral arguments of defendants' counsel, who did not ask to examine or cross-examine plaintiff's affiants.

 

774 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


R. v. Cory


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


44 A.D.2d 599; 353 N.Y.S.2d 783; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5390



March 25, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed insofar as appealed from, on the law, without costs, and petition dismissed.

 

775 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rochester Carting Co. v. Levitt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


44 A.D.2d 71; 353 N.Y.S.2d 551; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5413



March 21, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law and the facts, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Comptroller of the State of New York challenged the judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County (New York), which granted petitioner property owner's application, in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, for a judgment directing the Comptroller to pay an additional sum of post-judgment interest, on a judgment by the Court of Claims awarding damages for the State's appropriation of the owner's real property.


OVERVIEW: The Court of Claims allowed the owner, in accordance with N.Y. Court of Claims Act § 20(7), for 20 days after the time to appeal the judgment expired. The owner, however, demanded further interest from the day following entry of judgment to payment of the award. The Special Term held that § 20(7) of the Act was unconstitutional in that it denied the owner just compensation for its property by limiting the interest, and ruled that the owner was entitled to the further interest. The court noted that a person with a legal claim against the state was required seek out the appropriate state official and properly present his claim and vouchers, to be entitled to his money, therefore, interest was allowed for a 20-day period after entry of judgment to enable a claimant to obtain the necessary papers. The questioned statute, therefore, served a legitimate purpose. The court also noted that the owner neglected to file a certified copy of its judgment with the Comptroller as required by § 20(6) of the Act. The court held that any delay in payment and resultant loss to the owner could be attributed its own laxity, and not to the unconstitutional denial of just compensation.


OUTCOME: The judgment awarding additional post-judgment interest was reversed.


HEADNOTES

Judgments -- interest on judgment -- limitation on post-judgment interest on judgment of Court of Claims from date of judgment until "twentieth day after the comptroller is authorized to issue his warrant for the payment thereof" (Court of Claims Act, § 20, subd. 7) is not unconstitutional as depriving petitioner of just compensation for appropriation of its real property -- initiative for payment of claim must be that of claimant.

1. The limitation upon post-judgment interest on a judgment of the Court of Claims found in subdivision 7 of section 20 of the Court of Claims Act, which provides for such interest from the date of the judgment "until the twentieth day after the comptroller is authorized to issue his warrant for the payment thereof or until payment, if payment is made [***2] sooner", is not unconstitutional as depriving petitioner of just compensation for the appropriation of its real property. Petitioner neglected to file a certified copy of its judgment with the Comptroller, a prerequisite to its receiving payment. Therefore, any delay in payment and resulting loss to petitioner can be traced to its own laxity and not to an unconstitutional denial of just compensation.

2. A person with a claim against the State must seek out the appropriate State official and present his claim and vouchers to be entitled to his money. Interest is therefore allowed for a 20-day period after entry of judgment to enable a claimant to obtain the necessary papers, after which it is denied, to prevent the drawing of interest indefinitely upon a claim not presented within a reasonable time. Consequently, absent the requisite initiative by a claimant, the State cannot be in default on its payment.

 

776 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


King v. Power Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


44 A.D.2d 74; 353 N.Y.S.2d 547; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5414



March 21, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, on the law, to the extent of striking therefrom that part of the judgment which dismissed the complaint, and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff real property owners sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court, Greene County (New York), which dismissed their complaint in an action for a declaratory judgment that defendant state power authority's activities on the property owners' land was an illegal trespass and for a permanent injunction and set forth a declaration of rights in favor of the state power authority.


OVERVIEW: The state power authority entered the land of the real property owners for the purpose of making seismological and subsurface examinations of the property. The real property owners brought an action seeking a declaratory judgment that the authority's activities constituted an illegal trespass and that N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1007(8) was unconstitutional in that it provided for a taking of private property for public use without compensation. The lower court granted the authority's motion to dismiss. Upon appeal, the court affirmed the judgment with modifications. The court found that the entry on the land was not a taking in the constitutional sense. The court held that § 1007(8) was not unconstitutional because the authority assured the property owners that it would compensate them for any damage. However, the court found that the action for a declaratory judgment should not be dismissed merely because, on the face of the allegations, it would appear that the property owners were not entitled to a declaration of rights. The court should retain jurisdiction and declare the rights whatever they may be.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the authority that the entry on to the property owner's land was not unconstitutional. The court modified the judgment dismissing the property owners' action.


HEADNOTES

Public authorities -- entry onto private property -- section 1007 (subd. 8) of Public Authorities Law, providing that Power Authority may enter on private property to make surveys, is constitutional -- landowner subject to such entry is guaranteed just compensation by sections 1007 and 1002 of statute, which sections must be read together.

1. Subdivision 8 of section 1007 of the Public Authorities Law, which provides that the Power Authority of the State of New York and its agents and employees may enter upon private property for the purpose of making surveys to determine whether such property would be a proper site for an electric generating facility, is constitutional.  [***2] Such surveys are not the takings of property in the constitutional sense. Such a statute is constitutional to the extent that the entry is temporary, or the infliction of damage is incidental.

2. Section 1007 and section 1002, providing that the Power Authority may sue or be sued, must be read together to provide for the liability of the Authority for damages caused by the entry authorized by subdivision 8 of section 1007 and a remedy to compensate the landowner. Since a landowner subject to such entry is guaranteed just compensation by the statutes, subdivision 8 is not unconstitutional. In addition, the Power Authority has assured plaintiffs that it will compensate them for any such damage.

3. That part of the judgment granting the motion to dismiss the complaint should be eliminated and that part of the judgment declaring the rights of the parties should be affirmed.

 

777 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Sleepy Hollow Lake, Inc. v. Public Service Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


43 A.D.2d 439; 352 N.Y.S.2d 274; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5669



February 21, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed, with costs, and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, builders and developers, sought review, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 78, of the determination of respondent public service commission that any extensions of electric and telephone distribution wires to new residential subdivisions of five dwelling units or more had to be placed underground.


OVERVIEW: Respondent instituted hearings to consider the issue of the undergrounding of electric and telephone facilities. After the hearings, a hearing examiner issued a recommendation proposing mandatory undergrounding rules, which respondent adopted. After the rules were adopted a number of requests for exemptions were received. Petitioners' application for extension was denied. On appeal, the court confirmed the determination of respondent, holding that respondent was authorized to prescribe the terms and conditions under which utility companies could extend their lines, who bore the costs of those terms and conditions, and the appropriate charge for those services. It held that because respondent's determination was designed to improve the quality of service to the consuming public it was in the furtherance of the public interest, and thus, it fulfilled the legislative directive of N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 5(2). The court ruled that respondent's determination was supported by substantial evidence. The court found that although the regulations treated petitioners differently, the regulations were not arbitrarily discriminatory and a rational basis existed for the distinction.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the determination of respondent requiring electric and phone extensions to new residential subdivisions to be underground and dismissed the appeal of the petitioners.


HEADNOTES

Public utilities -- undergrounding of electric and telephone lines -- Public Service Commission has authority to mandate that extensions of electric and telephone lines to new residential subdivisions be placed underground -- Legislature provided adequate standards to guide commission in exercise of that power and delegation of such power is not unconstitutional -- determination, rules and regulations of commission are supported by substantial evidence and are neither arbitrary nor without rational basis -- there is rational basis as to payment of costs and refund thereof for distinction between home builders and developers.

1. The Public Service Commission is authorized generally to prescribe [***2] the terms and conditions under which utilities shall extend their lines, the manner in which costs shall be borne and the appropriate charges for such service (Public Service Law, § 65, subd. 1, § 66, subd. 2; § 5, subd. 2). Consequently, the commission has the authority to mandate that the extensions of electric and telephone distribution lines to most new residential subdivisions be placed underground for aesthetic reasons alone.

2. The commission's undergrounding determination was designed to effect an improvement in the quality of service rendered to the public and, thus, was in furtherance of the "public interest" as required by the Public Service Law. The determination, therefore, effectuates the legislative direction which provides adequate standards to guide the commission in the exercise of its powers. The delegation of those powers by the Legislature is not unconstitutional.

3. The determination, rules and regulations of the commission are supported by substantial evidence, that the undergrounding was aesthetically preferable and that the costs were not unduly burdensome and met the test of reasonableness, and are neither arbitrary nor without rational basis.

4.  [***3] The regulations are not arbitrarily discriminatory as between home builders and developers with respect to the payment of costs and the refund thereof. There is a rational basis for the distinction because in the case of home builders houses may be sold and connected up in a relatively short time whereas the lines may be nonrevenue producing to the utility in the case of developers for some period of time.

 

778 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Morales


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


43 A.D.2d 917; 352 N.Y.S.2d 938; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5737



February 14, 1974 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), convicting defendant of criminally selling a dangerous drug in the third degree on the grounds that identification testimony based upon a jailhouse viewing was improper and because defendant was improperly prevented from presenting an alibi witness.


OVERVIEW: A detective allegedly purchased a quantity of heroin from defendant, and, later, his backup team arrested defendant. The detective identified defendant at the jailhouse even though no lineup was assembled, and defendant was not informed of his right to have counsel present at the viewing. At trial, the detective was permitted to testify to the jailhouse identification over objection, and the two backup officers identified defendant as the person who was with the detective at the time of the sale. Defendant was also prevented from presenting an alibi witness because her name was not set forth in notice of alibi defendant was required to provide to prosecution. Defendant was convicted, and he appealed. The appeals court reversed the conviction because the viewing at the jailhouse was clearly improper, and this improper identification testimony bolstered the testimony of the two backup officers. Moreover, defendant was improperly prevented from presenting his alibi witness under a "notice of alibi" law because a decision finding such laws to be unconstitutional applied retroactively where the law was used to sanction defendant for failing to comply with the law.


OUTCOME: The conviction was reversed. The court improperly allowed the identification testimony even though no lineup was assembled, and defendant was not informed of his right to have counsel present. The court erred in refusing to allow an alibi witness to testify.

 

779 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mullins v. State Board of Parole


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


43 A.D.2d 382; 351 N.Y.S.2d 757; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5789



February 7, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law and the facts, and petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State Board of Prisons sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Albany County (New York), which granted defendant's application and directed the Board to hold a hearing within 30 days to determine whether he had violated the conditions of his parole.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of grand larceny, first degree. He was subsequently released from prison and placed on parole. Defendant was later convicted of bank robbery and declared delinquent as to his parole. Defendant filed an application seeking a hearing to determine whether he had violated the conditions of his parole. The trial court granted defendant's petition and ordered the Board to conduct the hearing within 30 days. The Board sought review. Pursuant to former N.Y. Correct. Law § 218, now N.Y. Correct. Laws § 212(7), parole revocation hearings must be conducted "as soon as practicable." However, the court determined that there were distinctions between technical violations of parole and more substantial deviations, such as a conviction for a new offense. The court held that there was no requirement that a new revocation hearing be held in each and every case. The court determined that defendant was not entitled to a hearing in this instance. The court reversed the judgment of the trial court and dismissed defendant's petition.


OUTCOME: The court reversed a judgment of the trial court, which ordered the Board to conduct a hearing to determine whether defendant had violated the conditions of his parole and dismissed defendant's petition requesting such hearing.


HEADNOTES

Parole -- parole revocation hearing -- parole revocation hearing is not required for parolee who commits another crime and is convicted of such crime and is now serving sentence for such other crime.

A convict, while on parole from a sentence of 2 1/2 to 10 years, committed a bank robbery in Ohio and was convicted thereof by a United States District Court and was sentenced to Federal prison for 20 years. He is now serving that sentence in a Federal correctional facility in Indiana; and the New York State Parole Board has there lodged a detention warrant declaring him delinquent as of the date of his robbery of the bank. In these circumstances, neither the Correction Law (former § 218; see, now, § 212, subd. 7) nor constitutional due process entitles him to a parole revocation hearing now.

 

780 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lake Illyria Corp. v. Gardiner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


43 A.D.2d 386; 352 N.Y.S.2d 54; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5790



February 7, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law and the facts, with costs, and summary judgment granted in favor of plaintiff declaring the Zoning Ordinance of the Town of Gardiner effective January 5, 1972 ultra vires and void. (See Matter of Golden v. Planning Bd. of Town of Ramapo, supra, p. 370.)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation challenged the decision oft the Supreme Court at Special Term, Ulster County (New York), which denied its motion for summary judgment in an action against respondent town contesting zoning regulations.


OVERVIEW: The corporation owned real property within the town. For four consecutive years, the town enacted local laws prohibiting any use of property for anything except residential purposes unless a variance was approved. The subject ordinances were denominated as interim or stop-gap legislation to maintain the status quo pending a comprehensive zoning ordinance. The corporation had attempted to obtain permission for a commercial use of its property and, after refusal, brought an action for a declaratory judgment that the local law restricting uses was unconstitutional. The trial court denied the corporation's request for summary judgment. The court reversed the judgment, holding that the purpose of stop-gap zoning was to allow a local legislative body, pending decision upon the adoption of a comprehensive zoning ordinance, to take reasonable measures temporarily to protect the public interest until an ordinance was adopted. The town's course of conduct was contrary to the purpose of interim or stop-gap zoning. The absence of justification for such an exercise of power rendered the four-year delay unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the denial of the corporation's request for summary judgment in an action against the town contesting zoning regulations.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- comprehensive plan -- town ordinance prohibiting use of certain property for anything but residential purposes, unless variance granted, pending enactment of comprehensive zoning ordinance is ultra vires and void; four-year delay in preparation of such comprehensive ordinance was unreasonable.

1. A 1972 ordinance of the Town of Gardiner prohibiting the use of certain property for anything except residential purposes unless a variance was approved by the Town Board is ultra vires and void. Starting in 1968 the town had annually enacted similar ordinances denominated as interim legislation to maintain the status quo pending the preparation and enactment of a [***2] comprehensive ordinance. However, the town has not been actively engaged in the enactment of such an ordinance, the only meaningful progress towards the preparation thereof having taken place recently. Consequently, the four-year delay was unreasonable.

2. A comprehensive plan is essential to proper permanent zoning. The purpose of stop-gap zoning is to allow the local legislative body, pending decision upon the adoption of a comprehensive ordinance, to take reasonable measures temporarily to protect the public interest and welfare until an ordinance is finally adopted. Otherwise, the eventual comprehensive zoning ordinance might be of little avail.

 

781 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Chiesa v. State


Claim No. 52427


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


43 A.D.2d 359; 351 N.Y.S.2d 735; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5837



January 31, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State sought review of a judgment from the trial court (New York), which awarded appellee claimant damages in an eminent domain action.


OVERVIEW: The state appropriated 22 acres of the claimant's 193-acre tract of land for the purpose of constructing a thruway interchange. The experts agreed that some of the remaining land was enhanced in value by the taking. The trial court awarded the claimant damages for the land taken. The state argued on appeal that the claimant did not sustain a loss because the over-all value of the land after the taking exceeded its value before. Upon review, the court affirmed. The court held that under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 7, the claimant was entitled to fair and adequate compensation for the land actually taken, regardless of any benefits which were conferred upon the remainder due to the direct taking. The court found that the value of the land taken was to be determined as of the date of the taking. The court concluded that any benefit to the claimant's remaining lands from the state's appropriation could not be used as an offset against the award for direct damages for the property taken.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed a judgment that awarded the claimant damages in an eminent domain action.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- compensation -- benefit to claimant's remaining lands from State's appropriation of portion of claimant's tract may not be used as offset against award for direct damages for property taken.

Any benefit to claimant's remaining lands from the State's appropriation of a portion of claimant's tract may not be used as an offset against the award for direct damages for the property taken. Compensation must be made regardless of any benefits conferred on the remainder due to the direct taking. The State must compensate for land actually taken. Permitting a setoff against direct damages for enhancement to the remainder would be an unconstitutionally discriminate exercise of the taxing power in favor of a neighboring owner who suffers no loss of land but benefits by the public improvement which led to the taking.

 

782 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Peoples Sav. Bank v. County Dollar Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


43 A.D.2d 327; 351 N.Y.S.2d 157; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5963



January 14, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order of the Supreme Court, Westchester County, dated September 4, 1973, modified, on the law, by adding thereto a provision granting summary judgment to plaintiff enjoining defendants, during the term of plaintiff's lease in premises in the Cross County Shopping Center in the City of Yonkers, from conducting business as a savings bank in said shopping center and, as so modified, order affirmed, with $ 20 costs and disbursements to plaintiff against defendant the Seamen's Bank for Savings.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant bank appealed from the judgment of the Westchester County Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) that granted plaintiff bank's motion for an injunction pendente lite restraining said defendant from maintaining, operating, and conducting the business of a savings bank within a certain shopping center in the New York, and that denied said defendant's cross-motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: Defendant bank appealed from the judgment of the lower court that granted plaintiff bank's motion for an injunction pendente lite restraining said defendant from maintaining the business of a savings bank within a certain shopping mall in New York. That judgment also denied defendant's cross-motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action. The court modified and affirmed the lower court's judgment through a grant of summary judgment to plaintiff. Defendant argued that the new banking law was to operate retroactively and that it made null and void such restrictive covenants. The covenant was a reasonable restriction because defendant could open up a short distance from the mall. Defendant's contention, that the restrictive covenant impaired the regulatory powers of the State Banking Department, was without merit. Plaintiff argued that the new banking law was unconstitutional. The statute was unconstitutional when applied retroactively under the circumstances because no emergency had been shown warranting such application. To give it that effect would have permanently, and without compensation, destroyed a valuable property right possessed by plaintiff.


OUTCOME: Lower court's judgment was affirmed as modified, on the law, by the grant of summary judgment to plaintiff because the retroactive application of the banking law was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Banks and banking -- covenant in lease -- in lease to bank of space in shopping center, landlord's covenant not to lease space there to any other  [***2] bank during term of lease is reasonable, and is enforceable by first bank by injunction against such other bank -- such covenant cannot constitutionally be annulled retroactively (by Banking Law, § 674-a, subd. 1) -- Appellate Division may award plaintiff summary judgment of injunction, even though plaintiff did not so move, where defendant's motion for dismissal for insufficiency showed there were no factual issues.

1. A long-term lease to a savings bank of space in a shopping center contained a reasonable and valid covenant by the landlord "during the term of this lease not to rent any part of" the shopping center "to a tenant for use as a savings bank or a savings and loan association." Since plenty of suitable banking space is available for rent in other nearby locations, this covenant does not restrain trade unreasonably. Absent any public emergency, this valid and enforceable covenant cannot constitutionally be annulled retroactively (by Banking Law, § 674-a, subd. 1; cf. §§ 10, 29). The Appellate Division grants summary judgment to the bank, permanently enjoining and restraining another savings bank from opening a branch in this shopping center during the term of the [***3] lease to the first bank.

2. On a motion for dismissal of a complaint for failure to state a cause of action, where the affidavits showed that there were no factual issues but only issues of law, the court -- that is, Special Term or Trial Term or, as in this case, the Appellate Division -- may award summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff, even though the plaintiff did not move for summary judgment ( CPLR 3211, subd. [c]; 3212, subd. [b]).

 

783 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Montez v. Metropolitan Transp. Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


43 A.D.2d 224; 350 N.Y.S.2d 665; 1974 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6027



January 3, 1974 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on May 21, 1973, reversed, on the law, plaintiff's motion to dismiss the affirmative defenses denied, and the defendants' cross motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint granted, and the complaint dismissed, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Metropolitan Transportation Authority sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York), which granted respondent arrested individual's motion to dismiss the Authority's affirmative defenses, and denied the Authority's motion for summary judgment in an action for false arrest and imprisonment initiated by respondent.


OVERVIEW: The individual initiated an action for false arrest and imprisonment against the Authority. The Authority submitted affirmative defenses and filed a motion for summary judgment. The trial court granted the individual's motion to dismiss the Authority's affirmative defenses and denied the Authority's summary judgment motion. The Authority sought review. The court held that, although service of a notice of claim was deemed effective on the date of mailing, the rule was only applicable where service was made in the manner prescribed by statute. Under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e(3), the notice must have been sent by registered mail. The court found that where service of the notice was made within the time limitation but "in a manner not in compliance" with the statute, it was not deemed valid. The court additionally held that, under N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1266(5), the Authority was not liable for torts committed by the railroad unless the employee of the railroad had become the Authority's agent. The court denied the individual's motion to dismiss the affirmative defenses and granted the Authority's motion for summary judgment. The court reversed the order of the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court reversed an order of the trial court, denied respondent's motion to dismiss the Authority's affirmative defenses, and granted the Authority's motion for summary judgment in an action for false arrest and imprisonment initiated by respondent.


HEADNOTES

Public authorities -- notice of claim -- notice of claim sent by certified rather than registered mail before expiration of 90-day period but received thereafter is not timely -- record does not permit exercise of discretion -- moreover, notice was directed to wrong party.

1. A notice of claim for false arrest and imprisonment predicated on the acts of an employee of defendant Long Island Railroad Company was due no later than May 3, 1972. It was sent by letter dated May 1 and addressed to defendant Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It was not received until May 8 and was not forwarded [***2] to the railroad company until May 12. The claim was properly disallowed for lateness of the service of the notice.

2. The notice having been sent by certified rather than registered mail as required by statute, service was not effected until actual receipt which occurred after expiration of the 90-day period.

3. Pursuant to General Municipal Law ( § 50-e, subd. 3) where service is made within the time limited but "in a manner not in compliance" with the statute, it is not valid unless the notice is actually received and claimant is examined in regard to the claim and there was no such compliance here.

4. The record does not permit the exercise of discretion, the statutory conditions for extension of time not being present.

5. Moreover, the notice of claim was directed to the wrong party, since the employee of the railroad company is not to be deemed an employee of the Authority (Public Authorities Law, § 1266, subd. 5).

 

784 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Graham


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


43 A.D.2d 182; 350 N.Y.S.2d 458; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2854



December 20, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, on the law, in the exercise of discretion, and in the interests of justice, to convict defendant of manslaughter in the first degree and, as so modified, affirmed, and matter remanded for resentencing pursuant to subdivision 4 of section 470.20 of the Criminal Procedure Law.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendant challenged the judgment of the Supreme Court, Chemung County (New York), which was entered upon a verdict convicting him of murder in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of second degree murder. The intermediary appellate court modified the judgment pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 543 so as to convict him of manslaughter in the first degree. Thereafter, defendant brought a coram nobis proceeding, which was unsuccessful. Defendant then brought a federal habeas corpus proceeding. The federal district court's denial of defendant's application was reversed on appeal. The district court was directed to issue the writ unless defendant was retried because the intermediary appellate court's modification of defendant's conviction had deprived him of his right to a jury trial. Defendant was retried and convicted of second degree murder. Defendant challenged that conviction. On appeal, the intermediary appellate court held that defendant's retrial on the second degree murder charge constituted double jeopardy as the original modification effectively acquitted him of the second degree murder charge. In the exercise of discretion and in the interests of justice, the intermediary appellate court modified the judgment on the law to convict defendant of manslaughter in the first degree and remanded for resentencing.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment, entered on retrial, convicting defendant of second degree murder to convict defendant of first degree manslaughter and remanded the case for resentencing. The court held that its original modification of defendant's second degree murder conviction to a first degree manslaughter conviction acquitted him of second degree murder and that retrial on the second degree murder charge constituted double jeopardy.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- former jeopardy -- retrial of defendant on charge of murder in second degree after appellate court modified prior judgment of conviction of murder in second degree to manslaughter in first degree was violation of double jeopardy; judgment of conviction of murder in second degree modified to manslaughter in first degree -- sufficient evidence before Grand Jury to support indictment for murder -- defendant was not denied speedy trial -- introduction of prior testimony of two witnesses did not deprive defendant of right of confrontation -- prior statement voluntarily made is admissible for impeachment purposes despite inadmissibility in People's direct  [***2] case -- removal of defendant's son by District Attorney after his appearance in court was not improper suppression of evidence.

1. Defendant, whose conviction for murder in the second degree was modified by an intermediate appellate court pursuant to section 543 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to manslaughter in the first degree and this modification was overturned by the Federal District Court because it deprived the defendant of his right to a jury trial, was subsequently retried and was convicted for murder in the second degree. The Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution was clearly violated by defendant's retrial on the charge of murder in the second degree as the earlier modification of the judgment of conviction to manslaughter in the first degree had the same finality as that of a verdict of acquittal of the greater charge. Therefore, the judgment of conviction of murder in the second degree is modified on the law and in the exercise of discretion in the interests of justice to convict defendant of manslaughter in the first degree ( CPL 470.15, subds. 2, 3).

2. There was sufficient evidence before the Grand Jury to support an [***3] indictment for murder. The receipt of some inadmissible evidence by the Grand Jury does not invalidate the indictment nor does it preclude a retrial upon the indictment following a reversal of the conviction due to the receipt at trial of such evidence.

3. Defendant was not denied a speedy trial, for both trials which defendant received were provided within constitutional periods measured from the moment they became necessary.

4. Introduction of prior testimony of two witnesses pursuant to CPL 670.10 did not deprive the defendant of his constitutional right of confrontation. One of the witnesses was dead, and the other, who was thoroughly cross-examined at the prior trial by capable counsel, was residing in Georgia and refused to honor a New York subpoena.

5. A prior statement voluntarily made by the defendant is admissible for impeachment purposes despite its inadmissibility in the People's direct case.

6. The removal by the District Attorney of defendant's son after his appearance in court was not an improper suppression of evidence. He was available for cross-examination and the District Attorney offered to produce him as a witness if the defense so desired.

 

785 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cullum v. O'Mara


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


43 A.D.2d 140; 350 N.Y.S.2d 162; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2950



December 7, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Motions to dismiss the petitions granted and petitions dismissed, on the law, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, criminal defendants with cases pending in a supreme court, filed prohibition proceedings under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, which challenged the constitutionality of provisions of 1973 N.Y. Laws 603. They questioned the validity of the authorization for the governor, with the advice and consent of the Senate, to appoint up to 68 additional judges to the Court of Claims, and the delegation of certain judicial administration.


OVERVIEW: Legislation to deal with a drug emergency through increased penalties and restrictions on plea bargaining were enacted. Chapter 603 allowed the governor to appoint up to 100 court of claims judges, who were to be assigned to the supreme court to handle the increased burden. The initial 16 judges appointed were all assigned to criminal parts of the supreme court. Defendants, in their petition, claimed that the process unconstitutionally allowed the appointment of supreme court judges, who were subject to election, and that delegation of court administration violated constitutional principles of separation of powers. In each proceeding, respondents, appointed court of claims judges, prosecutor, and commissioner of the division of criminal justice services, filed motions to dismiss the petitions. The court granted the motions to dismiss. Defendants had standing to dispute the appointment and assignment of the judges. N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 26b provided for temporary assignment to the supreme court of judges of other courts, and the nine-year court of claims term was considered "temporary." Defendants did not have standing to challenge the duties of the commissioner.


OUTCOME: The court granted the court of claims judges' motions to dismiss the petitions of the two groups of defendants, on the law, without costs.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- courts and judges -- Governor validly appoints additional Court of Claims Judges, and Appellate Division in Second Department validly assigns them temporarily to Supreme Court, Criminal Term, Kings County -- persons on trial before such Judges do not have standing to attack joint administration of State's judicial resources by Judicial Conference and by Commissioner of Criminal Justice Services appointed by Governor.

1. As part of an emergency program for the control of dangerous drugs, the Legislature (L. 1973, chs. 276, 277, 278) has imposed severe penalties on violators of the narcotic drug laws and has severely restricted plea bargaining; and, as part of a concomitant program to provide the necessary additional judges and moneys and criminal justice services, the Legislature (L. 1973, ch. 603) has authorized the Governor to appoint up to 68 additional Judges of the Court of Claims for the usual nine-year terms (see N. Y. Const., art. VI, § 9), which appointments [***2] however shall be made before July 1, 1974 and shall not be renewed and shall not be filled if vacancies occur; and further, the Legislature has provided that the efficient application of the State's judicial resources shall be administered jointly by the State Administrator of the Courts, who is an appointee of the Judicial Conference, and by the Commissioner of the Division of Criminal Justice Services, who is an appointee of the Governor. These additional 68 Judges of the Court of Claims (16 have been appointed so far) are available for temporary assignments by the Appellate Division to sit, as needed, in the Supreme Court (N. Y. Const., art. VI, § 26, subd. b) in order to handle an anticipated increase of criminal drug trials and proceedings. Such assignments by the Appellate Division are truly temporary and are constitutional, even though the Constitution also provides in article VI (§ 6, subd. c; § 7, subd. a; § 9) that Justices of the Supreme Court shall be elected, and that in New York City the Supreme Court has exclusive jurisdiction of felony prosecutions, and that the Court of Claims has jurisdiction of claims by or against the State.

2. These proceedings were instituted [***3] under CPLR article 78 in the Appellate Division, Second Department, by persons against whom criminal cases are pending in the Supreme Court, Kings County, before some of the assigned Judges of the Court of Claims. Although such petitioners have standing to test the right of such appointed Judges to hear their cases, these petitioners lack a direct interest or standing to complain that the statutory provision for a joint administration of the State's criminal justice resources by an appointee of the judiciary and by an appointee of the Governer represents an unconstitutional intrusion by the executive branch of government into the affairs of the judicial branch of government (cf. N. Y. Const., art. VI, § 28).

3. Accordingly, these petitions are dismissed, on the law.

 

786 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Redlich v. Capri Cinema, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


43 A.D.2d 27; 349 N.Y.S.2d 697; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3052



November 27, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Four orders, Supreme Court, New York County, each entered on or about August 14, 1973, unanimously reversed, on the law and on the facts, the cross motions denied, the complaints reinstated, and the motions for preliminary injunctions granted, and, in each action, appellants shall recover of respondents $ 60 costs and disbursements of the appeal.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, city and county, filed actions against defendants, theatre owners and distributors, to enjoin distribution of certain motion pictures asserted to be obscene. The Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) denied plaintiffs' motions for an injunction and granted defendants' cross motions to dismiss the complaints. Plaintiffs appealed.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.F. § 6330, which conferred jurisdiction upon the state supreme court to enjoin distribution of a motion picture of an indecent character, which was obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, indecent, or disgusting as defined in N.Y. Penal Law § 235.00. The trial court dismissed plaintiffs' complaints and denied the application for a preliminary injunction holding that N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 6330 was overbroad and unconstitutional, and the court had no evidence to gauge the contemporary standards of the community. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's judgment and remanded the matter for reinstatement of the complaints and granting of the injunction. The court held that the statute in question had previously been held to be constitutional and that there was case law providing guidance for determination of whether material was obscene. The court indicated that the material in question was obviously simply pornography, unrelieved by any merit and obscene.


OUTCOME: The trial court's judgment dismissing plaintiffs' complaint and denying the injunction sought was reversed and remanded for reinstatement of the complaint and granting of the injunction.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- obscenity -- motion pictures depicting acts of sexual perversion are obscene -- Judges who viewed films had probable cause for issuance of search warrant and seizure -- New York courts must read into CPLR 6330, which confers jurisdiction on Supreme Court to enjoin distribution of obscene motion pictures, guidelines for constitutionality enunciated in Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15 -- interpretations to save statute's constitutionality are stated; preliminary injunction should have been granted.

1. Four [***2] motion pictures depicting various acts of sexual perversion including sodomy and sadism are obscene, and constitute hard core pornography.

2. Criminal Court Judges who viewed the films had probable cause for the issuance of search warrants for their seizure.

3. New York courts should synthesize into CPLR 6330 which confers upon the Supreme Court jurisdiction to enjoin the distribution of a motion picture "of an indecent character, which is obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, indecent or disgusting * * * or in any other respect defined in section 235.00 of the penal law", the three guidelines for constitutionality enunciated in Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15: (a) whether the average person, applying community standards, would find the work appeals to prurient interest; (b) whether the work depicts, in a patently offensive way, sexual conduct specifically defined by the applicable State law; and (c) whether the work lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. In holding CPLR 6330 unconstitutional, Special Term overlooked the invitation in Miller v. California (supra) extended to the State courts, that they fill in any statutory interstices [***3] or rectify any deficiencies, by their own authoritative judicial constructions.

4. In saving the statute's constitutionality, the courts may interpret statutory language so as to preserve the validity of a statute; CPLR 6330 is a remedial statute, civil in nature which should be liberally construed and since the films are pornographic, the likelihood of success is great. A preliminary injunction should have been granted.

 

787 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Sherman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


43 A.D.2d 575; 349 N.Y.S.2d 124; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3118



November 19, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Sentence modified, etc.

 

788 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rosenthal v. Harwood


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


43 A.D.2d 558; 349 N.Y.S.2d 4; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3233



November 1, 1973, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant judge filed a petition, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, seeking to annul respondent members' censure, enjoin the members from taking any action in furtherance of the censure, and declare a political committee by-law inapplicable. The members filed a cross-motion to dismiss. The Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), entered judgment, dismissing the petition. The judge sought review.


OVERVIEW: The judge was nominated by the members' political party for the office of judge of the county court. He was also nominated for the same office by another political party. Based upon a by-law of the members' party, he was then censured by the members for accepting the nomination of second party. The trial court, treating the proceeding as an action for a declaratory judgment, dismissed the judge's petition, holding there was no justiciable controversy and the courts were barred from interfering with the internal operations of a political party. On appeal, the court reversed, even though it agreed it was unable to eradicate the censure of the judge and to restrain the members from taking action with respect to the judge's candidacy, because the by-law sought to be enforced by the members was invalid and unenforceable against the judge as a candidate for judicial office.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment dismissing the judge's petition, without costs, granted the petition to the extent of declaring the by-law invalid and unenforceable as to candidates for judicial office, and dismissed the petition in all other respects.

 

789 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Pesner v. County Court of County of Rockland


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


42 A.D.2d 275; 346 N.Y.S.2d 820; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3725



July 23, 1973
