DISPOSITION: Application, in Matter of Seidenberg, denied and motions to dismiss the petition granted, without costs.

Application, in Matter of Stewart, denied and motions to dismiss the petition granted, without costs.

Application, in Matter of Gess, denied and motions to dismiss the petition granted, without costs.

Application, in Matter of Pesner, denied and motions to dismiss the petition granted, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a consolidation proceeding, four defendants filed petitions to prohibit their trials on certain indictments and to dismiss the indictments. Plaintiff county filed a motion to dismiss the petitions.


OVERVIEW: Defendants argued that the grand jury was improperly impaneled and that the indictments returned against them were nullities. The court denied the petitions to prohibit trial and granted the county's motion to dismiss with respect to all four defendants. The court found that the trial court, in providing for the additional grand jury to sit from February 1 through May 31, enlarged the February Term of court so that it would terminate on May 31 instead of at the time that the next regular grand jury was to be convened. The court noted that the grand jury was in continuous session throughout the period for which it had been impaneled and the indictments at issue were returned during that period. The court reasoned that because each grand jury term could continue as long as the county judge deemed necessary, N.Y. Jud. Law § 190-c(3), and because it was undisputed that the additional grand jury in this case began to function immediately after it was charged by the county judge and actively continued to do so without recess or adjournment until the handing up of the indictments in this case, the position of defendants lacked merit.


OUTCOME: By separate orders for each, the court denied all four defendants' petitions to prohibit their trials. The court also granted, by separate order, the county's motions to dismiss defendants' petitions.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- creation of additional Grand Jury -- while order of Administrative Judge which provided for impaneling of additional Grand Jury for Rockland County improperly provided that it be "for the February, March, April and May, 1973 Terms" of County Court, County Judge properly impaneled additional Grand Jury for "February Term"; therefore, such Grand Jury had jurisdiction to indict petitioners and they are not entitled to order prohibiting their trials on such indictments.

The Administrative Judge for the Ninth Judicial District entered an order on January 18, 1973 which provided that an additional Grand Jury be impaneled "for the February, March, April and May, 1973 Terms of [***2] the County Court of the County of Rockland". Subdivision (b) of section 693.3 of the Rules of Practice of the Appellate Division, Second Department (22 NYCRR 693.3 [b]) stated that one Grand Jury shall be drawn for each term of the County Court and that "Additional grand juries may be drawn and impaneled upon the order of the administrative judge having jurisdiction over the courts in such county". The senior County Judge impaneled the "February Term" of the additional Grand Jury. CPL 190.15 provides that "A term * * * for which a grand jury has been impaneled remains in existence at least until and including the opening date of the next term of such court for which a grand jury has been designated. Upon such date, or within five days preceding it, the court may, upon declaration of both the grand jury and the district attorney that such grand jury has not yet completed * * * business before it, extend the term of court and the existence of such grand jury to a specified future date, and may subsequently order further extensions for such purpose." Petitioners, who were indicted by such Grand Jury, are not entitled to an order prohibiting their trials on the theory that such Grand [***3] Jury was improperly impaneled and did not have jurisdiction. While the Administrative Judge erred in designating the additional Grand Jury as one to sit for the February, March, April and May Terms of the court, the order made clear that the additional Grand Jury have a life existence for the period from February 1 to May 31, and the intent of the order was carried out by the County Judge when he impaneled the "February Term" of the additional Grand Jury. Moreover, the additional Grand Jury was a de facto Grand Jury, possessed of all of the powers which it would have if it were a de jure Grand Jury.

 

790 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wurlitzer Co. v. State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


42 A.D.2d 247; 346 N.Y.S.2d 471; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3730



July 19, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed, and petition dismissed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayers sought review of a decision of respondent state tax commission (commission), which sustained additional corporate franchise tax assessments against the taxpayers. The Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) transferred the case to the court. The proceeding was pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers were a foreign corporation doing business in the state and a subsidiary. The subsidiary was a foreign corporation having neither an office nor real or tangible property within New York. The subsidiary's purpose was to provide financing to the parent corporation by purchasing its accounts receivable, and employees or officers of the parent corporation performed all of the subsidiary's activities. The commission issued notices of franchise tax deficiencies to the taxpayers for four fiscal years. The deficiencies were based upon the failure of the parent corporation to report the net income of both it and its subsidiary in combined reports to accurately reflect the parent corporation's income subject to the New York franchise tax. On appeal, the court confirmed the determination of the commission, which sustained additional corporate franchise tax assessments against the taxpayers. The subsidiary had no separate corporate autonomy and was, in reality, merely the finance department of the parent corporation. Thus, the subsidiary's income had to be included with the parent corporation's income for an accurate report of the parent corporation's entire net income.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the determination of the commission, which sustained additional corporate franchise tax assessments against the taxpayers. The court dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- franchise tax -- net income of petitioner foreign corporation, doing business in New York, and of its wholly owned foreign subsidiary providing financing services was properly required to be included in combined tax report without showing that intercompany transactions were unfair; subsidiary had no separate existence -- issue of constitutionality based on subsidiary's not doing business in New York or being engaged exclusively in interstate commerce is academic.

1. A foreign corporation doing business in New York which organized a wholly owned foreign subsidiary to provide financing, the subsidiary's activities being performed by employees or officers of the parent corporation, was properly required to file a combined report of the income of the two corporations [***2] derived in New York and to pay a tax thereon under subdivisions 4 and 5 of section 211 of the Tax Law. The purpose of these subdivisions is to prevent the distortion of the net income of a taxpayer. Such distortion can occur either through intercompany transactions or an unfair agreement. There is nothing in the statute or its legislative history which mandates a showing that intercompany transactions be unfair as a prerequisite to requiring a combined report. The State Tax Commission found that the subsidiary had no separate corporate autonomy and was the finance department of petitioner's business, having no separate directors, officers or employees, and owning no separate real or tangible personal property. The subsidiary's income is derived solely from intercompany transactions with petitioner and such income must be included with petitioner's in order to properly reflect the entire net income of petitioner as a New York taxpayer. Since petitioner is doing business in New York and the tax is properly apportioned, it is constitutional.

2. The issue of constitutionality premised upon the contention that the subsidiary was not doing business in New York or was engaged exclusively [***3] in interstate commerce becomes academic upon the findings that the subsidiary is not an independent entity from the parent and the franchise tax is being levied upon the entire net income of the corporation doing business in New York as appropriately apportioned.

 

791 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bilello v. A. J. Eckert Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


42 A.D.2d 243; 346 N.Y.S.2d 2; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3775



July 12, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Motion insofar as it seeks permission to prosecute the appeal upon the original file of the Workmen's Compensation Board together with seven copies of brief and appendix granted and in all other respects denied, without costs. In lieu of furnishing the original file, the board may submit one copy of it to the Clerk of the court.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant workmen's compensation claimant filed a motion to prosecute his appeal of a determination from respondent workmen's compensation board (New York) denying his application to reopen a case following the termination of his disability benefits upon his arrest for murder.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was collecting disability benefits until he was arrested and charged with murder, at which time his benefits were terminated. When the board denied appellant's application to reopen the case, appellant filed a motion to prosecute an appeal of the board's determination alleging that the denial of the benefits following his arrest was based on the bar imposed by the Civil Death Statute, N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 79-a and that such statute, insofar as it barred him from presenting his appeal, violated his constitutional right to access to the courts and to due process and equal protection. The court granted appellant's motion relating to the prosecution of the appeal holding that to the extent the provision prohibited appellant from prosecuting his appeal, the statute was unconstitutionally violative of U.S. Const. amends. V and XIV. The court found that prisoners sentenced to imprisonment for life were prohibited from prosecuting appeals, whereas prisoners sentenced to a reformatory or county penitentiary did not lose their right to sue. The court concluded that similarly situated prisoners were treated differently and that the different classifications were unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court granted appellant's motion to prosecute an appeal of the board's denial to reopen a case concerning the termination of appellant's disability benefits following his arrest for murder.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- civil death -- statute ( Civil Rights Law, § 79-a, subd. 1), which provides that person sentenced to imprisonment for life is civilly dead, deprives said person of equal protection of law and violates Fourteenth Amendment of United States Constitution -- statute also violates due process requirement -- motion, insofar as it seeks permission to prosecute appeal from decision of Workmen's Compensation Board on original file together with seven copies of brief and appendix granted.

1. A person sentenced to imprisonment for life is deprived of equal protection of the law by the statutory declaration of civil death ( Civil Rights Law,  [***2] § 79-a, subd. 1) and the statute violates the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

2. The prohibition of access to the courts resulting from the effect of the provisions of section 79-a of the Civil Rights Law is also violative of the due process requirement of the Federal Constitution.

3. To the extent that section 79-a of the Civil Rights Law prohibits appellant from prosecuting his appeal, the statute is unconstitutional as violative of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.

4. The motion insofar as it seeks permission to prosecute the appeal from a decision of the Workmen's Compensation Board upon the original file of the Workmen's Compensation Board together with seven copies of brief and appendix should be granted and in all other respects denied.

 

792 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Tobin Packing Co. v. People


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


42 A.D.2d 82; 345 N.Y.S.2d 717; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3972



June 29, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed on the law and facts without costs and complaint dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant State appealed the order of the Supreme Court in Monroe County (New York), which invalidated the State's appropriation of a strip of land on plaintiff's owner's property in the owners action to bar the States claim to the strip of land brought pursuant to N.Y. Real Prop. Act. art. 15.


OVERVIEW: The State appropriated land along the north edge of the properties owned by the owner and his neighbor. As a result, both properties were deprived of access to an abutting street the lands. Thereafter, the State appropriated an additional strip across the edge of the owner's remaining property in order to provide highway access the neighbor's property and to replace the access destroyed by the first appropriation. The owner filed suit to bar the State from any claim to the strip taken in the remedial appropriation. The trial court invalidated the remedial appropriation because it occurred almost two years after the original taking. In reversing the trial court, the court held that N.Y. High. Law § 10(24)(d) did not require the remedial taking to occur simultaneously with or in close temporal proximity to the first taking. There was ample justification for the time lapse between the two takings, and the neighbor's access left after the first appropriation was clearly unsuitable. Thus, the State was justified in effecting the remedial appropriation under § 10(24)(d) to re-establish access to the neighbor's property by the taking of an inconsequential portion of the owner's land.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's invalidation of the State's appropriate and dismissed the owner's complaint.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- purpose -- suitable access -- appropriation of frontage having left condemnee with unsuitable access to rear street only, State properly appropriated, two years later, strip of adjoining owner's land so as to give said other condemnee suitable access to side street (Highway Law, § 10, subd. 24-d) -- on appeal from nonjury judgment, Appellate Division may make whatever determination trial court should have made ( CPLR 5522).

1. In 1967 for the purpose of constructing a highway, the State appropriated the frontage of premises owned by a meat packing company and the frontage of the adjoining premises owned by a truck repair business. The appropriation left the latter premises with access only to a rear street which, because of the width of a garage building, was unsuitable. Therefore, two years later, in [***2] 1969, the State properly and constitutionally appropriated an additional frontage strip of the meat packing company's premises and properly offered to convey this strip to the truck repair owner, as a suitable substitute means of access to a side street (Highway Law, § 10, subd. 24-d). This action against the State by the meat packing company for a judgment invalidating the 1969 appropriation is dismissed.

2. On appeal from a judgment which was rendered without a jury, the Appellate Division may make whatever determination the trial court should have made ( CPLR 5522).

 

793 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


McArdle v. Curran


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


42 A.D.2d 85; 345 N.Y.S.2d 690; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3994



June 28, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law, and petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, Temporary Commission of Investigation of the State of New York, sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which granted appellee's writ of prohibition restraining the commission from holding further hearings or proceedings.


OVERVIEW: The commission was created for special purposes within the requirement of the Constitution. On appeal, the court had to determine whether or not the commission was a temporary body. The commission was in existence for 15 years and authorized to continue for a few more years. Every amendment to the statute extending the life of the commission had contained a specific termination date and there had been no showing of any intent by the legislature to make the commission a permanent department. That the commission was of a temporary nature was best demonstrated by the fact of its limited duration in time. Furthermore, a legislative enactment carried with it an exceedingly strong presumption of constitutionality, and, while this presumption was rebuttable, petitioner's heavy burden had to be fulfilled by demonstrating unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt and it was only as a last resort that a reviewing court would strike down a legislative enactment on this ground. The court held that the presumption of constitutionality was not overcome and that unconstitutionality was not demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- Temporary Commission of Investigation -- State Investigation Commission erroneously declared unconstitutional -- its existence is always extended to specific date -- Legislature never intended it be permanent -- petitioners failed to carry burden of rebutting presumption of constitutionality.

1. The Temporary Commission of Investigation of the State of New York was erroneously declared unconstitutional and restrained from holding further proceedings. In being for 15 years, the commission is a constitutional temporary body. Every statutory amendment continuing its existence has had a specific termination date and the Legislature has never shown any intention to make it a permanent department.

2. The petitioners have failed to rebut [***2] the presumption of constitutionality or demonstrate the unconstitutionality of the statute creating the commission.

 

794 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Baker v. Cole-Layer-Trumble Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


42 A.D.2d 581; 344 N.Y.S.2d 695; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4200



June 11, 1973 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers sought review from the judgment of the Supreme Court of Orange County (New York), which denied the taxpayers' motion for preliminary and temporary injunctions and to declare a contract between defendants a town and a corporation illegal and void and granted the town's and the corporation's cross motions to dismiss the complaints.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers sought to challenge the assessments made by an expert and relied on by the town in order to determine valuations for tax. The lower court granted the town's and the corporation's motions to dismiss and the taxpayers sought review. The court noted that under applicable state statute the sole remedy to challenge tax assessments on the ground of illegality or irregularity was to seek judicial review of the assessments. The court found that the thrust of the taxpayers' complaints were directed to the great percentage increases in their properties' assessments which were adopted by the town assessor in reliance on the recommendations of the expert. The court held that under these circumstances, there was no basis for a judicial declaration that the contract providing for arbitration of disputes relating to taxpayers' realty taxes was illegal or unconstitutional. Further, where the court determined in an action for a declaratory judgment that the plaintiffs were not entitled to the declaration sought by them, the court nevertheless should not have dismissed the complaint but should have made the declaration required in the case.


OUTCOME: The court modified but affirmed the judgment of the lower court.

 

795 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Garlin v. Murphy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


42 A.D.2d 30; 344 N.Y.S.2d 402; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4226



June 7, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County (New York), which, in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. L. & R. art. 78, dismissed the taxpayer's application to annul respondent state's determination assessing additional income tax.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer filed an action against the State of New York after the State assessed an additional tax against his gross income for amounts that were not distributed to shareholders of a New York corporation that elected to be treated under subchapter S. The court affirmed. The court noted that N.Y. Tax Law § 612(a) defined the New York adjusted gross income of a resident individual as his federal adjusted gross income as defined in the laws of the United States for the taxable year modified by certain specified items. The court held that the taxpayer's assertion that he stood in danger of being taxed a second time when such income was actually distributed in the form of dividends was groundless because such a distribution was not included in federal adjusted gross income, 26 U.S.C.S. § 1375(d), and therefore would not have been included in his New York adjusted gross income.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the supreme court in favor of the State.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- personal income tax -- shareholder of electing subchapter S corporation which paid no Federal income tax improperly deducted from his adjusted gross income for State tax purposes undistributed gross income of corporation in amount of $ 8,279.97 on which he paid Federal tax; State Tax Commission properly assessed him for deficiency -- portion of State Constitution providing that "undistributed profits shall not be taxed" does not prohibit tax on income not received -- no unreasonable discrimination against shareholders of subchapter S corporations exists -- petitioner will not be taxed twice -- Legislature did not intend to exclude subchapter S concept from operation of New York statute.

1. Petitioner owned stock in a subchapter S small business corporation (U. S.  [***2] Code, tit. 26, § 1371 et seq.) which had elected to pay no Federal income tax, but its shareholders were required to report as gross income their pro rata shares of the taxable income upon which the corporation would have been taxed but for the election, regardless of whether or not such income had actually been distributed to the shareholders. Petitioner included $ 8,279.97 as gross income on his 1962 Federal return, which amount was not distributed to him. Because of subdivision 9 of section 208 of the Tax Law which provides that corporations which have elected to be taxed under subchapter S shall not be treated as having made such an election for New York tax purposes, the corporation was taxed. Under subdivision (a) of section 612 of the Tax Law, the New York adjusted gross income of a resident individual is "his federal adjusted gross income". Petitioner deducted the $ 8,279.97 of corporate income which had not been distributed to him from his adjusted gross income for State tax purposes. Respondent Tax Commission's disallowance of the deduction and the assessment of a deficiency against him was properly confirmed.

2. The purpose of the last sentence of section 3 of [***3] article XVI of the State Constitution which reads "Undistributed profits shall not be taxed" is not to prohibit the imposition of a tax on income not received but to prohibit the imposition of penalties on corporations for excessive accumulations of earnings.

3. The imposition of a tax on undistributed income does not unjustly discriminate against shareholders of subchapter S corporations. Shareholders in electing subchapter S corporations have a more direct beneficial interest in their pro rata share of corporate earnings than shareholders in other corporations. The discrimination therefore has a rational basis.

4. Petitioner will not be taxed a second time when such income is actually distributed as dividends for such a distribution is not included in Federal adjusted gross income (U. S. Code, tit. 26, § 1375, subd. [d]).

5. The Legislature did not intend, in imposing a tax on subchapter S corporations at the corporate level, to exclude the subchapter S concept entirely from the operation of the New York statute because section 632 of the Tax Law, in defining the adjusted gross income of nonresident individuals further provides in paragraph (4) of subdivision (b) thereof [***4] that "[for] a nonresident individual who is a shareholder of [an electing subchapter S corporation] * * * (A) undistributed taxable income shall not constitute income or gain derived from New York sources". No such exception appears in the modifications to adjusted gross income codified in section 612.

 

796 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Saratoga Harness Racing, Inc. v. New York State Quarter Horse Racing Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


42 A.D.2d 3; 344 N.Y.S.2d 95; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4294



May 31, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff horse racing corporation sought review of an order of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which declared N.Y. Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law § 67(4), added by 1970 N.Y. Laws ch. 1023, § 1, constitutional and dismissed the corporation's complaint against defendant New York State Quarter Horse Racing Commission.


OVERVIEW: The corporation claimed that the statute violated the equal protection guarantees of the state and federal constitutions. The challenged statute, N.Y. Pari-Mutuel Revenue Laws § 67(4), added by 1970 N.Y. Laws ch. 1023, § 1, provided that no license was to be granted to any quarter horse racetrack located within 50 miles of an existing harness, thoroughbred, or quarter horse track, except with the consent of the existing track, provided, however, in Albany and Suffolk Counties, a license could be granted if the track was more than 35 miles from an existing track. Two of the defendant racetracks were issued temporary licenses for tracks more than 35 but less than 50 miles from the tracks owned by the corporation. On review the court held that the legislature had a rational basis for setting a 35-mile buffer zone for the excepted counties. The court noted that an act of the legislature was presumptively constitutional and only as a last resort would the courts have declared a legislative act unconstitutional. The court noted that there were several reasonable explanations for the legislature's action.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the supreme court's judgment with costs.


HEADNOTES

Horse racing -- quarter horse racetrack -- license -- section 67 (subd. 4) of Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law (as added by L. 1970, ch. 1023, § 1), which forbids granting of licenses for quarter horse racetrack within 35 miles of existing track in two counties, as compared with 50-mile limit in all other counties, is not unconstitutional -- rational basis for classification.

Section 67 (subd. 4) of the Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law (as added by L. 1970, ch. 1023, § 1), which forbids the granting of a license for a quarter horse racetrack in Albany and Suffolk Counties within 35 miles of an existing track, as compared with a 50-mile limit in all other counties, is constitutional. Since a 50-mile limit could possibly exclude all suitable sites within these counties, denying the State a growing source of revenue, the Legislature, in its broad [***2] discretion, had a rational basis for the 35-mile classification.

 

797 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Weber v. Levitt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


41 A.D.2d 452; 344 N.Y.S.2d 381; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4299



May 31, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Judgment in the Weber [***2] case affirmed, without costs.

Judgment in the Lecci case affirmed, without costs.

Order in the Greenwald case, modified, on the law, so as to declare so much of section 431 of the Retirement and Social Security Law as prohibits the inclusion of termination pay in final average salary unconstitutional, and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, former and current police department employees, sought review of decisions by the Supreme Court at Special Term, Albany County (New York) in a consolidated appeal. The first and second employees challenged decisions regarding the computation of their retirement allowances by respondent comptroller. The third set of employees challenged a decision regarding the constitutionality of N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 431.


OVERVIEW: The first employee had his "final average salary" computed by including all compensation received during his final three years of employment. The comptroller recomputed it, using only three days per year. The second employee had his "final average salary" computed with no inclusion of accumulated sick pay or a lump sum cash payment for termination pay. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding that § 302(9)(b) required that termination pay be limited to that earned during the three-year period. The court also found that the first employee did not have a contractual right to payments as previously computed and that §§ 333 and 341(j) prohibited the inclusion of the second employee's sick pay. The third set of current employees entered into a collective bargaining agreement prior to the enactment of § 431. The court held that sick pay could not be included as noted above and vacation pay only included at the rate previously determined by the comptroller. However, the court modified the decision and held that § 431 unconstitutionally deprived them of their contractual right to have termination pay included but noted termination pay should be included at the rate previously discussed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's decision regarding the computation of the first and second employee's retirement benefits. The court modified the decision regarding the third set of employees and held that the statutory provision was unconstitutional insofar as it prohibited the inclusion of termination pay in the "final average salary" but affirmed the balance of the decision with respect to sick pay and vacation pay.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- retirement -- inclusion of termination pay, provided by contract between County Police Department and union computed on basis of three days' pay for each year of service, in "final average salary" on which retirement allowance is computed cannot exceed nine days or three days for each of three years used to compute final average salary rather than total of three days times number of years of service -- by including three times 20 years of service in final average salary for first two years of retirement benefits, no contract was established -- entitlement to nine days of termination pay is benefit which could not be impaired by section 431 of Retirement and Social Security Law -- sick leave pay cannot be included in final average salary whether resulting from collective bargaining agreement or resolution  [***3] adopted by county (Retirement and Social Security Law, § 333) because of subdivision j of section 341 of Retirement and Social Security Law -- even though collective bargaining agreement calls for pay for up to 60 days of unused vacation, inclusion of only 30 is benefit which cannot be impaired.

1. The Retirement and Social Security Law ( § 302, subd. 9, par. b) defines "Final average salary" as the "highest average annual compensation earned during any three consecutive years of member service". "Annual compensation" is defined (Retirement and Social Security Law, § 302, subd. 2, par. a) as the "wages annually earnable by a member". A patrolman employed by a county police department for over 20 years retired on February 23, 1970. His union had entered into a contract with the county whereby, upon retirement after 20 years of service, a patrolman was entitled to a lump sum payment for termination pay computed on the basis of three days' pay for each year of completed service. In computing the patrolman's "final average salary", respondent included the lump sum payment for all his years of service but two years later recomputed the final average salary by including only nine [***4] days' termination pay, three days for each of the last three years. Termination pay could be treated as having been earned in the 20th year of service only if such pay was a component of compensation for the 20th year alone. Since termination pay must be treated as earned over the 20-year period rather than in the 20th year, respondent correctly determined that the amount "earned during [the last] three consecutive years" (§ 302, subd. 9, par. b) is that amount representing three years' worth of termination credits.

2. By computation of the retirement benefit so as to include for two years the full amount of the termination pay in final average salary, no contract has been established requiring the inclusion of full termination pay in the computation of final average salary. Respondent's inclusion of the full payment was lacking in legal authority and cannot rise to the status of a contract. ( Kranker v. Levitt, 30 N Y 2d 574, distinguished.)

3. As to employees who were members of the retirement system prior to the effective date of section 431 of the Retirement and Social Security Law, which forbids the inclusion of any form of termination pay in the salary base for [***5] computing retirement benefits, and who receive, upon retirement, termination pay pursuant to contracts effective prior to that date, the inclusion of termination pay on an entitlement basis of three years in the computation of "final average salary" under paragraph b of subdivision 9 of section 302 constitutes a contract the benefits of which cannot be diminished or impaired by virtue of section 7 of article V of the Constitution.

4. Since a resolution had not been adopted by the County Police Department pursuant to section 333 of the Retirement and Social Security Law granting its employees the right to include sick leave pay in final average salary, sick leave credits in any form could not be taken into consideration. Moreover, by the inclusion in subdivision j of section 341 of the provision that sick leave shall not "be considered in computing final average salary", the Legislature intended to prohibit the inclusion of sick leave payments in final average salary regardless of whether the source of the payments was a collective bargaining agreement or a resolution adopted pursuant to section 333 of the Retirement and Social Security Law.

5. The collective bargaining agreement [***6] between the union and the Police Department allowed the employees to accrue unused vacation pay to a maximum of 60 days. The limitation to 60 of the number of unused vacation days for which a lump sum payment will be made does not bear any reasonable relation to the actual number of unused vacation days which are "earned" in any given year of service. Therefore that limitation should similarly bear no relation to the maximum number of days of vacation credit which can be included in the determination of final average salary. The contract benefits which are constitutionally protected from impairment by section 431 are similarly limited to those which were so protected under Kranker v. Levitt (30 N Y 2d 574).

 

798 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Stievater


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


41 A.D.2d 435; 344 N.Y.S.2d 656; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4357



May 24, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously modified on the law in accordance with opinion by Henry, J., and as so modified affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State sought review of an order from the Erie County Court (New York), which dismissed an indictment charging conspiracy to bribe and bribery as to all appellee architects.


OVERVIEW: The five architects were members of architectural firms employed by a county in connection with its proposed domed stadium. Simultaneous and independent investigations were made by federal and state grand juries and each architect indicated his intention to refuse to testify on U.S. Const. amend. V grounds. While the State excused them as witnesses, the federal authorities compelled two of the architects' testimony by offering immunity under 18 U.S.C.S. § 2514. After testifying, the State filed an indictment against the architects, charging them with conspiracy to bribe and bribery, and the trial court dismissed the indictment. On appeal, the court held that because there was there was a showing that the grant of immunity under §2514 was necessary and proper, it did not unconstitutionally infringe upon the police powers granted to the states in U.S. Const. amend. X. The court found that the order dismissing the indictment against the two architects that testified was affirmed, but determined that because the other architects did not testify at the trial, the indictment as to them was reinstated.


OUTCOME: The court modified and affirmed the order from the trial court, finding that the architects that did not testify at the trial were not given immunity and reinstated the indictments against them.


HEADNOTES

Witnesses -- immunity from prosecution -- County Court dismissed indictment against defendants, granted transactional immunity under Federal statutes -- immunity so granted was necessary and proper, thereby constitutional -- such immunity for Federal trial testimony granted others who did not so testify does not cover their testimony before Federal Grand Jury.

1. The County Court properly dismissed an indictment, because of a granting of immunity pursuant to section 2514 of title 18 of the United States Code based upon testimony given before a Federal Grand Jury, against two members of an architectural firm working on a proposed domed stadium who were accused of conspiracy to bribe and bribery of members of the Erie County Legislature. Assuming that they could have been granted the more limited use and derivative use immunity under sections 6002 and 6003 [***2] of said title, there was a showing that immunity under section 2514 was necessary and proper, and so did not unconstitutionally infringe upon State police powers under the Tenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

2. The County Court improperly dismissed the indictment against three other defendants, ordered to testify at a trial in Federal Court and immunized from prosecution based upon their trial testimony, who gave no such testimony but did subsequently testify before the Federal Grand Jury, because the immunity order granted for trial testimony cannot be extended to cover the Grand Jury testimony; the immunity is not conferred by court order alone but by testifying at the time and place directed by the order.

 

799 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Richman v. Richman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


41 A.D.2d 993; 344 N.Y.S.2d 52; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4368



May 24, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff husband sought review of an order from the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which vacated and set aside an order of attachment previously issued in an action that had been discontinued as the result of a stipulation entered into by the husband and defendant wife.


OVERVIEW: The husband and the wife were engaged in a domestic dispute. They entered into a stipulation whereby the wife was given certain assets and the husband was given the parties' investments. As a result of the stipulation, the action was discontinued and an order of attachment was vacated. The husband filed an action for specific performance of the prior stipulation and a warrant of attachment was secured in the trial court, without notice, attaching certain personal property of the wife, based upon the husband's claim of conversion pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6201(8). The trial court later vacated and set aside the warrant of attachment that it had issued. The court affirmed the trial court's order. The husband's affidavit was insufficient to sustain the issuance of the writ and it was error for the trial court to have granted the order of attachment because the stipulation could only be enforced by the bringing of the second action. Finally, it was not necessary to reach the constitutional issue raised by the wife as to notice and the opportunity because the wife's life and liberty were not involved nor was the invalidity of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6201, 6211 apparent on their face.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order, which vacated and set aside an order of attachment that it had previously issued in the husband's action for specific performance of the stipulation entered into by him and the wife.

 

800 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Knight v. Bodkin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


41 A.D.2d 413; 344 N.Y.S.2d 170; 1973 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4411



May 21, 1973 



DISPOSITION: Judgment of the Supreme Court, Rockland County, dated April 13, 1972, reversed insofar as appealed from, without costs, and respondents' determination annulled, on the law.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, property owners and a park commission, sought review of the judgment of the Supreme Court, Rockland County (New York), which confirmed a determination of respondent Zoning Board of Appeals of the Town of Orangetown, New York granting an application by respondent-intervenor manufacturer for a special permit.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer sought a special permit to build a plant for the manufacturing of metal chains for chandeliers and lamps. The manufacturer's property was zoned "LO" to permit light manufacturing upon the issuance of a special permit. "LO" zoning allowed such uses as office buildings, laboratories, schools, municipal parking lots, public parks, and a few other specified uses. A county planning board recommended that the manufacturer's application for a special permit be denied, but the zoning board approved the special permit. The petitioners sought judicial review, and the trial court confirmed the zoning board's determination. On appeal, the court reversed and annulled the zoning board's determination. The court noted that while its review was limited to whether the zoning board's determination was supported by substantial evidence, the manufacturer had not shown that its proposed factory would not adversely affect the character of the area, which included historic mansions and parks and was rural, residential, and recreational, or that it would be for light manufacturing in harmony with the zoning scheme; rather, a chain factory would sharply alter the character of the area.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and annulled the zoning board's determination.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- in zone for laboratories and offices where light manufacturing is allowable use by special permit, grant of special permit authorizing construction of building for manufacturing metal chains for chandeliers and lamps is annulled -- such manufacture is not "light" manufacturing -- factory would change character of area and is inharmonious with uses for which land is zoned.

1. In an LO zone for laboratories and offices, etc., light manufacturing is an allowable use by special permit. The subject premises are within 500 feet of a State park. The owner applied for a special permit for the construction of a building covering 2 of [***2] its 22.6 acres for the manufacture of metal chains for chandeliers and lamps. The grant of the special permit is annulled.

2. The manufacture of heavy steel chains to support overhead light fixtures in a structure covering two acres requiring the use of heavy trucks at the rate of one per hour, and causing air pollution is not light manufacturing within the zoning ordinance.

3. The character of the area is rural, residential and recreational. A chain factory is incongruous, would sharply alter the character of the area; and would be intrinsically inharmonious with the uses for which the land is zoned. Respondent-intervenor is not per se a valid applicant for a special permit.
